HEADLINE: As the Wolf Turns: A Saga of Yellowstone

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.

 BODY:
EARLY on a crystalline June morning, as sunlight began to brighten the peaks, forests and green meadows of the Northern Rockies, the wolves known as Yellowstone's pack from hell were already at work.
Confidently, almost nonchalantly, five of the six adult members of what is formally called the Druid Peak pack patrolled their territory, sniffing the ground and depositing urine scent marks along an open hillside studded with patches of Douglas fir, spruce and aspen. Only 300 yards from a well-traveled road, a big gray female headed the single file, with the dominant pack member strolling along third in line -- a 122-pound gray wolf, his outstretched, rigid tail advertising his status as alpha male.
He is no ordinary animal. Barrel-chested, powerful and aggressive even for a wolf (one scientist likened him to a linebacker), he ripped the bars out of an aluminum cage in which Federal scientists transported him from Canada last year. "Right away we knew he was different," said Dr. Douglas W. Smith, a wolf biologist for the National Park Service who directs the re-introduction project. 
 Thirty-eight, as this formidable creature is named, is part of what is widely hailed as a spectacularly successful effort to re-establish wolves in Yellowstone National Park. He solidified his reputation soon after arriving here by leading the Druids in a territorial raid on a longer-established wolf family, the Crystal Creek pack. The Druids killed the opposing alpha male and all his young offspring, banished the bleeding adult survivors to another part of the park and took over their den. They sealed the takeover with a group howl. Since then the pack has killed two more adult wolves, earning it nicknames like the Pack from Hell and the Dreadful Druids. "They are a bunch of hoodlums," Dr. Smith said.
But that is only one part of the continuing story of the Yellowstone wolves, a tale of family loyalty, clan warfare and over-all population expansion whose twists and turns will largely determine the future of this most charismatic of all endangered species in America.
In an enterprise that has restored the only missing piece to Yellowstone's renowned array of big mammal species, 41 wolves have been transplanted to the park from western Canada and northern Montana since January 1995, and they and their offspring have produced an estimated 60 to 70 pups. (The exact number will not be known until early winter, when this year's pups are nearly grown and a better count can be made.)
Since the program started, 10 pups and 10 adults have died from various causes.
Here, on an open and easily accessible stage, the day-to-day struggles that determine long-term evolutionary dominance are on unusually clear display. And in this arena it turns out that for all their aggression, the Druids have so far been eclipsed by another group, the Rose Creek pack, and especially by its central figure. She is an aging, long-suffering, charcoal-colored alpha female,called Rosie by some, Mom or Big Mama by others, but simply Nine (the number assigned to her when she was transported from Canada in 1995) by most.
Nine is the undisputed matriarch of Yellowstone wolfdom. With seven adult members, her pack is the largest of nine in and around the park. Only 30 months after the first wolves were transplanted here, there may be as many as 100 ranging freely hereabouts. If things keep going this way, Federal officials say, it may be possible to take the wolves off the Federal endangered list by 2001, ahead of the projected schedule. More than any other Yellowstone wolf, Nine is responsible for this success: Almost half the wolves here are her children or grandchildren.
This year alone, in a highly unusual feat of reproduction, her pack produced three litters of pups. An older daughter has formed a pack of her own, the first naturally formed such family grouping here since wolves were exterminated from Yellowstone by the Government in 1926. And as Nine's other descendants mature and form still more packs, her genetic legacy will spread further.
Nine attracted widespread attention two years ago when her original Yellowstone mate, Ten, was shot and killed, leaving her to fend for herself and eight pups, the first born of the restoration experiment. Now she not only has the upper hand in terms of reproductive and genetic dominance; she and her group have also shown their strength in battle, aggressively driving off the invading Druids. But there was a price. One of her yearling sons -- "feeling his oats," Dr. Smith said -- apparently pursued the fleeing Druids alone. They turned and killed him. And just a few weeks ago, the Druids caught one of Nine's daughters alone and killed her, too. The daughter's pups, one of this year's three Rose Creek litters, died.
Now there seems to be a standoff in this evolutionary numbers game, albeit a tenuous one since the Rose Creek and Druid Peak territories abut each other. Nine has surmounted all this and more to emerge grayer, distinguished looking and a near-legend. If anyone ever erects a statue of a wolf in Yellowstone, says Dr. Smith, "it should be her."
In all, an estimated 85 to 95 wolves now live here, and Dr. Smith says that given normal reproduction rates there could well turn out to be 100 when the count is complete. Officials of the Northern Rockies wolf recovery program say that no more introductions are necessary to meet the goal of removing the wolf from the endangered list. Natural reproduction, they say, should do the rest.
"We could de-list by Dec. 31, 2000," said Ed Bangs, a biologist with the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, based in Helena, Mont., who heads the Northern Rockies recovery program. For that to happen, there must be at least 100 wolves and 10 breeding packs three years running in each of three areas: Yellowstone, central Idaho (where another population has been successfully introduced) and northwestern Montana (which has been naturally recolonized from neighboring Canada). There is a "50-50 chance" that the three-year countdown to de-listing will begin next year, Mr. Bangs said.
The eventual hope is that as the three wolf populations expand, they will begin interbreeding with each other, creating a single, large Northern Rockies population with a large, healthy gene pool. Other imperiled American gray wolf populations, chiefly in the Great Lakes region and the Southwest, are being treated separately for de-listing purposes. Wolves are plentiful and in no danger in Canada and Alaska.
The big surprise in Yellowstone this year has been the birth of multiple litters of pups to three packs: the three litters of Nine's group and two each in the Druid Peak pack and a group called the Chief Joseph pack. Partly, some experts say, this may be an artifact of wolf re-introduction. Usually, members of a pack would all be part of the same biological family, with only the alpha pair breeding, and inbreeding would not be a regular occurrence. But here, most packs have been constituted by throwing together unrelated wolves. The upshot is that since the alpha male is not related to the pack's females, he can mate with them all without causing social disruption.
But the primary factor in producing multiple litters, many biologists believe, is simply that Yellowstone abounds with prey, especially elk. The wolves are "living on a high plane of nutrition," said Mike Phillips, a wolf biologist who recently left the re-introduction project after directing it from the start. Dr. L. David Mech, another Federal biologist and wolf expert, said that "you don't have to be a rocket scientist or even a wolf biologist to predict that with that amount of prey, once they get settled into the area, it's a matter of converting all that prey to new wolves, which they do well."
So rich are the pickings that the Druid Peak pack, for instance, last fall killed 21 elk in a month, 18 of them calves. Nor do the wolves have to search very far to find a meal. Most of the packs' territories are consequently small. The first naturally formed pack in the park, called the Leopold pack after the great conservationist Aldo Leopold, has what scientists believe may be the smallest and best wolf territory in North America: a relatively tiny turf about six miles by eight, just a short distance from park headquarters at Mammoth Hot Springs.
The easy availability of natural prey is also cited as a possible reason why there have been so few cases of Yellowstone wolves' killing livestock. In 30 months, only four instances of livestock depredation by the wolves have been reported, all involving sheep. The owners were compensated for their losses, a total of $2,186, from a special fund maintained by the Defenders of Wildlife.
But one group of wolves, the Soda Butte pack, was recaptured and transferred out of its territory on private land just north of the park where, Dr. Smith said, "they lived among cows and sheep and didn't touch a one." They were moved farther south into the park nevertheless, after threats were made on their lives. Tourists have also sometimes interfered with the wolves. In at least two cases, Dr. Smith said, overenthusiastic visitors have in effect chased wolves away from a kill by getting too close, an illegal act in Yellowstone. Wolves are afraid of humans and flee them.
For the most part, however, the wolves seem to be securely established and thriving, and Dr. Dr. Smith said that a second, more scientific phase of the project was now beginning in which their behavior was to be studied over the long term. A platoon of volunteers is staking out the packs in relays, tracking their movements with radio direction finders every half-hour for 48 hours at a stretch (several wolves in each pack wear radio collars) and trying to monitor their behavior through binoculars and telescopes.
It is in the area of wolf-to-wolf relationships, both within packs and between them, that some of the most revealing observations have been made.
The life of Nine, for example, reads like a soap opera. When she arrived here with a daughter from Canada in January 1995, she had been separated from her mate by trappers who captured her for a reward. A previous mate may have been killed. Here, she immediately mated with a big gray male, designated Ten. He was about as strapping as Thirty-Eight, and together he and Nine produced eight pups. The Canadian daughter went off on her own and began foraging as a lone wolf. About the time Nine's first Yellowstone pups were born on bare ground near Red Lodge, Mont., outside the park, Ten was shot by an unemployed carpenter. The shooter was later convicted of killing a member of an endangered species, assessed a $10,000 fine and sentenced to six months in jail.
Biologists rescued Nine and her pups and nurtured them in a pen until the pups were old enough to leave. Some of the pups escaped from the pen but stayed close, and a yearling male from the Crystal Creek pack, Eight by name, began hanging around and brought food to them. On her release from the pen, Nine immediately took up with Eight, making him alpha male.
"Yearlings don't get promoted to alpha male all that often," Mr. Phillips said. "If she hadn't found his presence acceptable, she'd have run him out of there; but "here's a young guy who knows the area, and she's got eight mouths to feed, and he seemed to like the pups."
Nine's daughter from Canada also mated with a Crystal Creek yearling to form the Leopold pack, making her mother her sister-in-law as well. "This is truly a family affair," Mr. Phillips said.
Within the Rose Creek pack, a characteristic picture of autocracy moderated by cooperation has emerged. Observers say that one of Nine's pups from 1995 appears to have emerged as the beneficent uncle; this year's pups overwhelm him with affection. He and Eight, the alpha male, tirelessly carried food to the mothers and pups of the pack's multiple litters this spring.
Once, in a common display of the brutal nature of life in the wolf world, Eight sniffed out and killed an elk calf. One of last year's litter of pups distracted the mother elk while Eight began to feed. But a wolf pack is not a democracy: Eight bared his fangs at the yearling and would not allow him at the table. In a wolf pack, subordinates must mind their manners and bide their time until they can go off and form their own packs.
The next chapter of the story depends not least on how the simmering confrontation between the Rose Creekers and the Druids turns out. Wolf warfare is simple, Dr. Smith said: "Whoever's got more wolves wins." When the Druids savaged the Crystal Creek pack, they had a 5-to-3 advantage in fighting adults. The Rose Creekers had an 8-to-5 edge when they repulsed the Druids.
When the Druids "add their bevy of pups to their war machine," Dr. Smith said, "they're going to be a pack to contend with."

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Plays the Role of a Drama-Filled City;
Wayne Wang Films a Tale of Love and Loss Set Amid Real-Life Uncertainties

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 30

 BODY:
Filming a street scene in this hustling and bustling city has never been easy, what with all the local gangs of organized criminals who demand protection money virtually every time a camera sets up.
On top of these obstacles, Wayne Wang is directing sections of his new movie, "Chinese Box," smack in the middle of the chaos and hoopla surrounding Hong Kong's return to Chinese rule. 
 This week, he and his crew are filming several critical scenes in public places while historic events like the handover ceremony and the sailing away of the last British Governor unfold in the background.
In "Chinese Box," which stars Jeremy Irons as a dying British journalist and Gong Li as a reformed bar girl, Mr. Wang is trying to weave a story of imperfect love and disjointed relationships at a dramatic moment in history. The climax of the film comes for the fictional characters, as for the real city, in the last days of June.
Mr. Wang said he liked to mix the structure of a scripted event with the unpredictability of the moment. But there is so much daily uncertainty in filming "Chinese Box," he said, that he often wonders if the stress and anxiety are going to unhinge him.
"Every day I get up and ask my wife, 'Why am I doing this?' " Mr. Wang said during a break from filming. "And she says, 'You want it this way.' "
"You have to try to use the chaos," he continued, leaning to the positive side for a moment. "Hong Kong people work best on the fly. If you try to plan, it's never as good. But if you ask them, 'Can you do this right away?,' they give you their best work. I guess I'm like that, too."
The result, as one might expect, is that things are not quite going as expected. When he arrived to start filming this year, anticipating a widespread sense of impending calamity, Mr. Wang said, he was surprised to find that events were proceeding more smoothly and peacefully than he had expected.
Mr. Wang was born and reared here before moving to the United States in 1967, and despite frequent visits, he said, the immense changes here make him feel somewhat out of touch. "There aren't any police cracking heads of protesters," said Mr. Wang, who wrote the screenplay for "Chinese Box" with Jean-Claude Carriere ("Belle du Jour," "The Unbearable Lightness of Being"). "But that's O.K. It's more subtle, and I think that works better for the film."
A gentle man with rimless glasses and a dusting of gray in his close-cropped hair, Mr. Wang, who is 48, examined the subtleties of human relations in several of his earlier films, which include "The Joy Luck Club" and "Smoke."
After returning here this year, he said, he began to see the significance of the transfer of rule less in the arrival of Chinese troops and more in the potential for economic change and the danger of losing freedom over the long run. In "Chinese Box," he looks at how that affects human relations.
"I realized how much change has already been going on over the past 10 years," he said. "We tried to bring that into the film."
With the political background calmer than expected, Mr. Wang has found his biggest challenges to be more basic: shooting street scenes with actors as well known here as Gong Li, whose films include "Temptress Moon," "Farewell My Concubine" and "Raise the Red Lantern," and Maggie Cheung, a star of Hong Kong action movies. The filming is constantly interrupted by turning heads, stares and autograph seekers.
"We have to put actors right in the middle of things," said Mr. Wang. "It's very hard to control exactly what happens."
Tonight Mr. Irons shot a scene in Hong Kong's convention center, where many of the 8,000 journalists who came to cover the events are stationed. Since he did not hire them as extras, Mr. Wang asked the journalists to act naturally and not to look at the camera.
But as it turned out, Mr. Wang's biggest problem arose from outsiders' misconceptions about the level of danger in Hong Kong. Lawyers for another film Mr. Irons is shooting in Paris suddenly objected to the plan for the actor to return here for two days of shooting, demanding "political insurance" in case Mr. Irons was injured in a crackdown by China.
With that about as likely as a earthquake swallowing Mr. Irons in Paris, Mr. Wang was outraged.
"They want us to pay $400,000 to insure him for two days," fumed Mr. Wang. "We don't have that kind of money. The whole idea is ridiculous." (Mr. Irons came without the insurance.)
There have been other obstacles, too, that have nothing to do with political events, namely local organized crime gangs, known here as "triads." During one day of shooting in Kowloon City, a crowded section of town, the crew hung sheets of light-diffusing white silk outside a building where they were filming. The chauffeur of a triad leader died unexpectedly that day, and since white is considered the color of death, the triads blamed Mr. Wang and his crew.
"The next day we had to leave," said Mr. Wang. "There was nothing we could do. No amount of money would fix it. We had to find a new location and reshoot the entire scene."
With his background, Mr. Wang has a special perspective on Hong Kong. His parents escaped here from mainland China just 10 days before he was born -- "My anxiety must come from my mother's traumatic pregnancy," he said -- and he was educated in a school run by Irish Jesuits until his parents sent him to the United States.
After studying painting and film in California, Mr. Wang worked as a social worker in Chinatown in San Francisco. In 1982 he made his first movie, "Chan Is Missing," a humorous story based on people he had gotten to know there.
That marked the beginning of what Mr. Wang described as a conscious effort to tell stories about Chinese-Americans: "Dim Sum," "Eat a Bowl of Tea" and "The Joy Luck Club," based on Amy Tan's 1989 best seller.
"I will go off and do something that has nothing to do with China, like 'Smoke,' but I think will always come back to it," said Mr. Wang.
Mr. Wang said he began conceiving a film about Hong Kong in 1997 when he came here to make a quick low-budget movie in 1989 called "Life is Cheap, but Toilet Paper Is Expensive."
"That movie ends with the main character asking 'What's going to happen?' " he said. "That whetted my appetite about the whole issue."
The title "Chinese Box" implies the unknowable nature of China. "Like one of those Russian dolls, you can open layer after layer, but you still never know what's going to be inside," Mr. Wang said. "It's complex, it's secretive."
"Most people aren't going to shed a tear about the British leaving, and they're not so thrilled about the Chinese coming," he said. "But what they appreciate most is the freedom they've always had here. This sense of freedom, of having personal choices, will change. Or at least it remains unclear."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges Against Mark As a Weak Euro Is Foreseen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar surged to its highest level against the German mark in more than three years yesterday, buoyed by concerns about European monetary union.
Over the weekend, the president of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, said sustainable budgetary discipline was a more important goal than meeting the strict fiscal guidelines designed to insure a strong single currency, the euro. 
 Yesterday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany played down a rift with his party's ruling coalition partners over monetary union and said his Government was fully united in its drive to start the single currency on time. The euro is scheduled to begin in 1999.
The remarks convinced the market of Germany's resolve to push ahead with the single currency regardless of its ability to meet the economic requirements for its introduction, weighing on the mark and pushing the dollar higher.
"The feeling is that we're going to have a broad and weak euro," said Bob Savage, chief foreign exchange dealer at Lehman Brothers.
The dollar rose as high as 1.7465 marks before settling in late New York trading at 1.7443 marks, up from 1.7387 marks on Friday, its highest close since February 1994. The dollar also rose to 114.59 yen from 114.55 yen.
The dollar benefited from several strong United States economic reports that suggested that growth could be picking up again after several months of slowing.
Sales of new homes showed robust growth in May, while both Chicago and New York manufacturing indexes posted strong gains for the month of June.
While Federal Reserve policy makers are not expected to raise interest rates when they meet this week, traders said yesterday's data pointed to an August increase.
In other currency trading, the British pound surged against the mark and gained against the dollar.
The Bank of England yesterday reported a strong gain in British consumer credit in May, increasing the odds for higher interest rates.
The pound rose as high as 2.9072 marks, its highest since July 1992. In New York, the pound advanced to $1.6647, from $1.6639 on Friday.

HEADLINE: THE SECOND QUARTER: THE CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Prices Drop, but Brighter Days Are Expected

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Unlike the robust stock market, which led Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to caution against irrational exuberance, the bond market has been a study in understatement in the second quarter and first half of this year. But there are growing expectations that in the months ahead that could change and bonds could make a move of their own.
Still, the idea of long bonds yielding 6 percent, let alone 5 percent, continues to be a tough sell to many fixed-income investors. They are less believing than their stock market counterparts that the economy is in a new era in which technology drives productivity and permits strong growth and low unemployment without setting off inflation. 
The chief question keeping bonds under a tight rein has been whether the economy is too strong and unemployment too low for inflation to remain at bay for long. Bears see these conditions as temporary, while bulls view them as long lasting.
Yesterday the price of the 30-year bond fell 21/32, to 98; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.78 percent from 6.74 percent on Friday. The yield is still lower than the 7.09 percent at the end of the first quarter, but higher than 6.64 percent at the end of 1996.
"It's pretty obvious that the first half of the year has been a roller coaster ride for the bond market," said Patrick R. Ledford, senior fixed-income portfolio manager at Citibank Global Asset Management. One reason, he said, is that growth slowed because some of the first- quarter activity was borrowed from the second quarter. For example, because of unseasonably warm weather retail sales and home building that would normally have taken place in the second quarter were accelerated into the first quarter.
"So now we finish up the second quarter, which is looking weaker than it should have been," Mr. Ledford said. "I don't think there is anything structurally or fundamentally weak about the economy, and I do expect growth will strengthen again in the second half of the year." He predicted this growth would lead the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates by a quarter to a half of a percentage point "over the next three to six months."
The central bank raised the Federal funds target rate by 25 basis points, or a quarter of a percentage point, in March and left it unchanged in May at 5.50 percent.
Mr. Ledford said inflation would not necessarily be a problem in the second half of the year for two reasons: "Global competition is forcing U.S. manufacturers to keep prices down, and productivity will keep profit margins high." Growth will not be so rapid as in the first quarter, he added, "but it will be above trend nonetheless, which will force the Fed to adjust monetary policy."
Today and tomorrow the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee meets. Most market participants are not expecting the Fed to take any rate action this time, but the August meeting might be another matter entirely.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the general perception in the market was that the trend for yield volatility was currently lower, and that it would stabilize below historic levels.
Discussing the quarterly performances of the Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers indexes and their components over the last 10 years, he said: "About half the time they have been negative in the first quarter and you don't see that exhibited in any of the other quarters in the bond market. So you can extrapolate from that that you can expect things to run better the rest of the year.
"When you look at 10-year notes as an example," he continued, "yield levels are close to the beginning of the year, but if you look at where we've been for the year as a whole, rates have generally been higher as whole, and that kind of fits with my earlier observation, which is since mid-April rates have been trending lower, consistent with the notion that the second quarter would be a good-performing quarter for bonds."
According to the Lehman Brothers index, through last week and the year to date, Mr. Donne added, only one category has had a negative return -- the new notes introduced by the Treasury this year as a hedge against inflation. Investors "have not poured money into these inflation indexed notes," he said, and that "shows that inflation is not viewed as problematic."
Judicious Fed policy has been one source of the economy's success, he said. Also, people have not spent a lot, but there has been significant capital investment in the economy, which explains recent good productivity numbers. "I see the last half of the year as more like the second quarter," Mr. Donne said.
Yesterday, the market slumped badly after strong housing and manufacturing reports raised concern that the Fed might indeed make a pre-emptive strike much as it did in March.
The Commerce Department said new single-family home sales jumped 7.1 percent in May after declining in April, while the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago's June index of business activity surged to 61.5, from 56.8 the month before. A reading of 50 or higher usually indicates that more respondents than not see improving business conditions. It also serves as a precursor to the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly index due today.
Markets analysts said yesterday's weekly bill auction was generally in line with expectations, with interest rates up moderately. The three-month bill rose 18 basis points, to 5.12 percent, and the six-month bill increased 9 basis points, to 5.14 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Distributors Of Foods Plan Merger Worth $689 Million

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
JP Foodservice Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Rykoff-Sexton Inc. for about $689 million in stock.
The companies, two of the biggest in the food service industry, said the merged operations would have annual sales of $5.2 billion. The combined company would have more than 130,000 customers among restaurants, hotels and institutional buyers. 
 The purchase will extend JP Foodservice's reach into the Western United States and into manufacturing.
It also enables JP Foodservice to compete more directly with the Sysco Corporation, which has dominated the fragmented $135 billion food distribution industry during the last decade.
Sysco, based in Houston, had 1996 sales of $13.4 billion.
Under the terms of the agreement, Rykoff-Sexton's shareholders will exchange each of their shares for 0.84 share of JP Foodservice. Based on JP Foodservice's closing price Friday, that values each Rykoff-Sexton share at $25.3125, nearly 29 percent above the company's stock price on Friday. Shareholders of both companies will hold almost equal stakes in the combined company.
But shares of JP Foodservice fell $1.4375 yesterday, to $28.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange, giving the deal a value of $689 million. Shares of Rykoff-Sexton rose $3.6875, to $23.3125.
JP Foodservice, based in Columbia, Md., will also assume about $700 million in the debt of Rykoff-Sexton, whose headquarters are in Wilkes-Barre, Pa.
The sale, while still subject to regulatory and shareholder approvals, has already received the consent of about 36 percent of Rykoff-Sexton's shareholders, the companies said.
 The combined companies will continue under JP Foodservice's name.
The purchase, while leaving the company far behind Sysco, enables JP Foodservice to accelerate the growth it has pursued since gaining independence from the Sara Lee Corporation in 1989.
"We view this as the opportunity to leap ahead of the industry, in a No. 2 position," said James Miller, JP Foodservice's chairman and chief executive. "We now have the critical mass."
The food service industry has been consolidating quickly in the last few years as companies hustle to keep old accounts and gain new ones by creating larger economies of scale.
JP Foodservice bought $350 million in companies last year alone, Mr. Miller said, and Rykoff last year completed the acquisition of US Foodservice Inc. for $614 million.

HEADLINE: It's Lonely Being a Deficit Hawk

BYLINE: By Tom Campbell; Tom Campbell, a Republican, is a United States Representative from California.

DATELINE: CAMPBELL, Calif.

 BODY:
I know it's hard for anyone in public office to vote against a tax cut. Nevertheless I was surprised last week when I was the only Republican to vote against the House tax plan.
Indeed, I am against all the tax plans proposed by the House, Senate and President Clinton, because they place more emphasis on cutting taxes than cutting the deficit. 
 For a Congress that said it was committed to balancing the budget, and a President who could have been the first in 30 years to achieve one, this change in emphasis is alarming.
The tax bills that passed the House and Senate last week would increase the deficit by $85 billion over five years. Over 10 years, each would increase the deficit by more than $200 billion. Each plan proposed that the Government increase its debt limit by $500 billion.
Yet conservatives in each house voted for the plan.
President Clinton's proposal isn't much better. In the package he unveiled yesterday, the deficit would also be increased by $85 billion.
The most expensive part of each plan is a $500-per-child tax credit. The House and Senate versions would add $71 billion to the deficit over the next five years. The President wants to extend the child tax credit even more, to low-income families that may qualify for the Earned Income Tax Credit. Conservatives object, arguing that such a cut would constitute a form of welfare. For some reason, however, lowering taxes for groups they wish to favor would not.
There is no difference, in fairness or economics, between lowering taxes on a favored group and spending money on a favored group. The favored group for Republicans is composed of lower-middle-income people with children. A powerful voting bloc, they were promised a tax cut in the Contract With America. The President, on the other hand, wants to favor poor families, a powerful voting bloc for his party.
That's welfare politics -- practiced by Republicans as readily as Democrats.
This is not to say that all tax cuts are simply welfare for one group or another. Some tax reductions spur economic activity. Taxing investment curbs economic growth. The capital gains reduction part of the House tax package would generate $2.7 billion over the first five years, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
A tax cut directed to children, however, does not generate revenue. No one can argue that it would pay for itself. No one argues that it would result in more children or even that more children would be desirable. This tax cut is simply a transfer of money to groups that Congress and the President want to favor.
This supposedly "family friendly" plan actually postpones the day when we stop borrowing from our children. As long as we are running a deficit, tax cuts that cost revenue are welfare for this generation paid for by the next. What a remarkable moral lesson to our children: we'll cut your parents' taxes and make you pay for it later.
But for these tax cuts, a balanced budget could have been achieved in the next two years. That would be an immense psychological and political achievement. Every subsequent President, especially Republican Presidents, would be pressed to hit a zero deficit -- after all, a Democrat did it.
Of course, I recognize tax money comes from people. The Government does not "own" tax money. And when it allows workers to keep more of what they earn, it does not "give it away." But before the baby boomers begin to retire, we must balance the budget. If we fail to do so in excellent economic times, when will we?
Earlier this year, the President and Congress appeared to be in agreement that it was time to balance the budget. We were willing to sacrifice the immediate gain for the long-term good. Now we have returned to the more traditional approach -- immediate gain for important constituencies. I was sorry to see the President revert; I was sorry and surprised to see my Republican colleagues in Congress emulate him.

HEADLINE: Albany Budget Endgame

 BODY:
With New York State rolling in tax revenues, Gov. George Pataki and the State Legislature are rushing to reach agreement on a budget that will probably include something to please every constituency. The danger is that in doling out tax breaks and spending increases, the parties will approve a budget that worsens the state's financial stability and preserves the same basic inequities that have long damaged New York City's interests. The priorities in the final weeks of the legislative session should be to insure adequate financing for health and education and to avoid tax cuts that the state still cannot afford.
Thanks to the boom on Wall Street, these are good times for New York. Since Mr. Pataki introduced his own $66 billion budget in January, tax revenues have surged ahead of expectations and some expenses like Medicaid are coming in under what was projected. Last week, the Governor and legislative leaders reportedly agreed that they had an additional $2.6 billion to play with, enough to avoid the need for some of Mr. Pataki's proposed cuts. There was little chance that the Legislature was ever going to go along, in any case, with Mr. Pataki's initial call for cuts in welfare grant levels, Medicaid payments to hospitals and nursing homes and state funding for higher education. The other spending priorities ought to be the restoration of proposed cuts in mental health programs and of cuts enacted in previous years for services to children from troubled families. 
 The most contentious issue is certain to be the desire of New York City to get an increase in state school aid and at least a down payment on nearly $1 billion in prior claims for education aid. The state has not paid claims dating back to 1989, contending that the city has lagged in submitting the claims and that the money has never been appropriated by the Legislature. Surprisingly, the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, is said to be sympathetic to the city's demands, but there is a catch. In return, Mr. Bruno wants legislative approval of Republican-backed tax cuts that would heavily favor businesses and homeowners in the suburbs.
The main tax cut that Mr. Bruno and Mr. Pataki want is a huge $1.7 billion property tax giveaway, only 12 percent of which would go to taxpayers in New York City. Mr. Giuliani and his main legislative ally in this fight, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, need to drive a hard bargain. There is no point in bringing about more equity in school aid for New York City if city taxpayers are dealt an unfair hand on tax relief. It is far from clear, in any case, that the state can afford the tax cut. As is typical in Albany, it would explode in size in the years ahead, opening up gaping budget deficits that will have to be closed by more program cuts.
In flush times, the state ought to be able to abandon its usual fiscal gimmicks. Albany is nonetheless filled with talk of more borrowing schemes and use of more one-time-only revenues to pay for recurring expenses, the kind of shenanigans that have given New York the worst credit rating in the country. In the past, governors and legislatures have argued that economic downturns necessitated the use of such gimmicks. But there is no excuse this year for reckless budgeting that will weaken the state's fiscal foundation.

HEADLINE: THE SECOND QUARTER: THE UNDERWRITERS;
Stock and Bond Issues Picked Up Speed as Quarter Progressed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A heavy flow of business in June more than made up for what had been a diffident start to the second quarter for stock and bond underwriters.
In the second three months of the year, the volume of stock and bond underwriting rose 15.6 percent from the comparable period a year ago, to $285.08 billion, according to the Securities Data Company. And for the first six months of the year, total stock and bond underwritings reached a record $571.9 billion. 
 As in the first quarter, however, the sale of bonds and other debt was responsible for most of the increase. Equity underwriting, which is far more lucrative for Wall Street firms, rebounded a bit from first-quarter levels, but was well short of those a year earlier. And the pickup in underwriting activity from the first quarter, when $273.3 billion worth of domestic debt and equities were sold, was a modest 4.3 percent.
Still, the performance was better than might have been predicted in late March or April, when concern about rising interest rates and strong economic growth cast something of a pall on financial markets.
"All things considered, this was not a bad quarter for underwriting," said Sallie L. Krawcheck, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "And the big story is June, when there was a big turnaround."
Worries that there would be tightening moves by the Federal Reserve dissipated as data released during the quarter showed that inflation remained remarkably low and economic growth had slowed considerably from its torrid first-quarter pace.
Those developments, in turn, restored confidence to the stock and bond markets, especially last month.
"June was perhaps the most memorable month of the first half of the year and a significant improvement from April," said Scott Sipprelle, head of United States equity capital markets at Morgan Stanley.
"There was a much better sense of the business and a rosier glow from portfolio managers at the end of the quarter than when it started."
A sharp rebound in the volume of initial public offerings reflected the stock market's better mood.
Initial offerings raised $10.36 billion in the second quarter, up sharply from the $5.9 billion underwritten in the first quarter.
"By a mile, June was the best I.P.O. month of the year," said James Hanbury, an analyst with Schroder Wertheim.
Still, the recovery fell far short of the second quarter in 1996, when initial offerings came to $18.9 billion.
Over all, sales of common stock in the United States totaled $23.7 billion, down steeply from the $41.3 billion in stock that was underwritten in last year's second quarter. But it is an improvement from the first quarter of this year, when equity underwritings totaled $21.3 billion.
Maintaining the leadership position it has held since 1988, Merrill Lynch remained Wall Street's top debt and equity underwriter. During the quarter, it underwrote 337 deals that raised just over $47 billion.
The others in the top five underwent something of a shake-up.
Lehman Brothers, which placed fifth in the first quarter, was the quarter's second most active underwriter. Goldman, Sachs, which had been second, fell to third, followed by Morgan Stanley and J. P. Morgan.
The decline in new equity offerings continued to crimp the money that Wall Street firms make from underwritings.
Disclosed fees collected by all underwriting firms totaled $1.72 billion, down 4.5 percent from the first quarter and more than 42 percent from the second quarter of 1996.
For the first half of the year, disclosed fees were $3.6 billion, almost 30 percent less than for the first six months of 1996, according to Securities Data.
Once again, the five biggest firms collected the majority of the fees. Collectively, they accounted for just over 54 percent of all underwriting fees.
On the fixed-income side, a relatively benign interest-rate environment encouraged issuers to price just over $119 billion worth of new securities in the quarter, a 59 percent increase from the comparable period a year ago.
"The quarter was a volatile one," said John Massad, head of debt syndication at J. P. Morgan Securities. "April, the month after the Fed raised interest rates, was a very difficult month. But by the beginning of May, people had decided there would not be a series of tightenings, and the market got much stronger."
Concern about rising interest rates slowed the issuance of new high-yield bonds. Just 29 new underwritings, totaling $5.89 billion, were offered during the quarter, down sharply from 54 issues that raised $10.2 billion in the second quarter of 1996.
In large measure, the negative comparisons with 1996 are misleading, since that was a record-breaking year. Analysts said they still expected to see healthy earnings figures when most Wall Street firms report their second-quarter results later this month.
"The year-over-year comparable figures are probably going to be down for most people," Mr. Hanbury said. "Whether it is as good as last year remains to be seen, but it will be a good quarter."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Remarks By Clinton on Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's remarks today about his plans for a tax cut, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:
America's families deserve a tax cut, and they deserve one that reflects their values. It is, after all, the energy and dedication of the American people that has produced our present prosperity, that has made it possible for us to balance the budget. 
 The American people should receive a dividend from this prosperity because they have produced the strength that has enabled us to achieve it. The dividend should be reflected in policies that help them to strengthen their families and educate their children.
Two different tax cut bills have passed the House and the Senate. The bills contain many good elements, but I do not believe they represent the best way to cut taxes, nor are they consistent with the balanced-budget agreement. They are not close to the roughly $35 billion the agreement explicitly provides to help people provide for higher education costs. They do an inadequate job of opening the doors to college, therefore. They direct far too little relief to the middle class. They include time-bomb tax cuts that threaten to explode the deficit. They do not do enough to keep our economy going. . . .
My plan reflects America's values, helping families pay for college, raise their children, buy or sell a home, pay for health care. It honors the budget agreement. It is the right plan for America.
This reflects the approach of Democratic alternatives that were offered in Congress, but it also reflects the priorities of the Republicans, as well.
The $85 billion tax cut, I submit, has five central elements. First, the tax cut plan will focus on education, our nation's highest priority, with $35 billion in targeted tax cuts. To offer opportunity in the new and rapidly changing economy, we must make the 13th and 14th years of education, the first two years of college, as universal as a high-school diploma is today.
To that end, my proposal will give young people a Hope Scholarship tax credit worth up to $1,500 for the first two years of college. It gives further tax cuts to help pay for four years of college. It provides tax relief to pay for training and learning throughout a lifetime. It will allow parents to save in a tax-free I.R.A. for their children's education, and it will use tax incentives to help communities rebuild and modernize their schools. . . .
Second, my plan gives families a $500 tax credit for every child under 17. This plan, unlike the tax cut proposals put forth by the Congressional majority, would give working people who earn lower salaries the child tax credit as well. A rookie police officer or a starting teacher, a firefighter or a nurse who earns $22,000 deserves a child tax credit. They are some of our hardest-pressed working people. They are paying taxes now, and I will fight to give them the same tax relief that other Americans would receive.
Third, to honor our commitment to bipartisanship, the plan allows taxpayers to exclude 30 percent of their capital gains from taxation. It also gives a capital gains tax cut for buying and selling a home. The capital gains cut is targeted more prudent and less likely to explode the deficit in the years to come than the plan of the Congressional majority.
Fourth, my plan provides estate tax relief to help parents who want to pass small businesses and family farms on to their children.
Fifth, the plan provides tax incentives to encourage businesses to hire people off welfare. It will also provide tax cuts to businesses that clean up urban toxic waste sites, known as brownfields, and convert these sites to productive use. It will create 20 more empowerment zones to attract businesses into disadvantaged neighborhoods, and it includes tax incentives to revive our nation's capital. . . .
In addition, the Senate, by bipartisan agreement, departed from the budget agreement to support a 20-cents-per-pack tax on cigarettes. I will support this change. Unlike the Senate version, however, I believe these revenues should be used entirely in ways that focus on the needs of children and health care.
This tax cut plan that I have just outlined embodies the best ideas offered by Democrats. It reflects many of the priorities of the Republicans, such as the capital gains cut. It is balanced; it is fair to the middle class; it will foster economic growth without hurting our vulnerable citizens. And it is consistent with the budget agreement. It is the right plan for America, and I will do my best and fight hard for it in the weeks to come.

HEADLINE: Office Depot And Staples Merger Halted

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Executives of the office supply giants Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc. said today that their proposed merger was almost certainly dead after a Federal judge issued an order temporarily blocking the $4 billion combination.
Company officials said they were stunned and disappointed by the decision of Judge Thomas F. Hogan of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, who ruled that the proposed merger would drastically reduce competition in the office products business. 
 The judge accepted the Government's contention that office supply superstores constitute a unique market segment and that allowing two of the three major competitors in the field to combine would permit the new company, with more than 1,100 stores and $11 billion in annual sales, to raise prices with impunity.
The judge's order came after the stock market had closed for the day. Staples ended at $23.25, down 25 cents; Office Depot finished at $19.4375, down 12.5 cents. But in after-hours trading, shares of Office Depot tumbled, falling to $14.50. Shares of Staples were little changed.
The decision was a major victory for Federal Trade Commission antitrust lawyers, who brought the case this spring despite sharp conflict within the agency over the wisdom of challenging the merger. The Government's assertion that the Staples-Office Depot combination would give the company near-monopoly pricing power was controversial in antitrust circles because the company would control only 6 percent to 8 percent of the overall office products market.
William J. Baer, director of the F.T.C.'s Bureau of Competition, said he was delighted and relieved at the outcome.
"The judge accepted our market definition and found our pricing studies persuasive," Mr. Baer said in an interview. "The bottom line is that we knew this would be a very difficult case to litigate but we were concerned that if the merger went through consumers would be at risk."
Thomas G. Stemberg, chairman of Staples, said that the merger was now highly unlikely in light of Judge Hogan's ruling. In a telephone conference call with reporters, Mr. Stemberg said that his company, which is based in Westborough, Mass., had spent more than $20 million and "countless hours" putting together the deal with Office Depot and defending.
Mr. Stemberg said that the boards of the two companies would meet in the next few days to consider their course, but indicated it was virtually certain that board members would accept management's recommendation to end the deal.
"We've spent about 10 months of our organization's time and resources pursuing this matter," he said, speaking from a farmhouse in Ireland where he is vacationing. "It has been a tremendous distraction and a tremendous expense. To pursue it for many more months would be a further distraction and a further expense without any certainty of success."
David I. Fuente, Office Depot chairman, made similar comments in a statement issued by company headquarters in Delray Beach, Fla.
"Office Depot has been engaged in a long and frustrating attempt to merge with Staples. We still believe that the decision to merge our two companies was sound, based on the strategic advantages that would have resulted, but today's decision by Judge Hogan means the merger is now unlikely," Mr. Fuente said.
In his opinion, Judge Hogan said that the companies had not sufficiently proved their claims of billions of dollars in savings from the merger. He said that it was possible that office products prices would have fallen after the merger because of reductions in overhead costs. But he noted that the two companies have competed aggressively on price for years and the likelihood of lower prices was greater if the companies remained independent.
The judge said that the F.T.C. had demonstrated through comparative pricing studies and economic models that the merger would "substantially impair competition."
"In light of the undeniable benefits that Staples and Office Depot have brought to consumers, it is with regret that the court reaches the decision that it must in this case," Judge Hogan wrote in his 55-page opinion.
"This decision will most likely kill the merger. The court feels, to some extent, that the defendants are being punished for their own successes and for the benefits that they have brought to consumers. In effect, they have been hoisted with their own petards."
Consumer advocates cheered the decision. Jamie Love, an economist at the Center for the Study of Responsive Law, said that he had expected the merger to be approved even though he believed it would mean higher prices for consumers.
"It was really important test," Mr. Love said. "It shows the F.T.C. can stop a merger when it wants to, even when there is a spirited defense as there was in this case. And it sends signal for others in retail."
Mr. Stemberg, however, said that consumers were the big losers.
"This is a sad day for small businesses and consumers who would have reaped the greatest benefit of all," he said.

PUB-DATE: July 1, 1997

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1057 words

HEADLINE: Fed Expected To Hold Line On Rates, at Least for Now

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve is likely to hold interest rates steady at its two-day meeting this week, but reports issued today suggest that the economy remains sufficiently strong that the central bank could feel compelled to tighten monetary policy later in the year, economists and investors say.
After growing at 5.9 percent in the first quarter, the economy slowed substantially, probably to about 2 percent, in the three-month period ended today, economists said. 
 But today's reports on new-home sales, manufacturing activity in the Midwest and personal consumption and income led some analysts and investors to conclude that the economy retained an unexpected vigor as it headed into the second half. With unemployment at 4.8 percent already well below the level at which inflation has historically tended to pick up during periods of strong growth, analysts said the likelihood was increasing that the Fed would decide to raise rates at one of its next two meetings, in mid-August and late September.
"We agree with pretty well everyone that the Fed is not going to move this week," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan. "But we do think they'll be tightening before long."
The Commerce Department reported that sales of new single-family homes rose 7.1 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 825,000. The increase, the biggest in six months, was higher than most analysts had expected. Some analysts said the drop in long-term interest rates over the last month could keep the housing market strong this summer.
In a sign that manufacturing activity might be picking up, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago reported that its business outlook index rose to 61.5 in June from 56.8 in May. The index often provides an early look at the trend in nationwide manufacturing activity. A similar index for the New York region also increased sharply, to 64.9 in June from 50.8 in May.
The Commerce Department reported that personal consumption and income both increased three-tenths of 1 percent in May, half their pace in the first quarter but strong enough to indicate that a recent slowdown in consumer spending might be bottoming out.
"Other than the consumer spending numbers, there's very little in the way of weakness," Mr. O'Sullivan said.
The flurry of reports sent bond prices lower on concerns that the Fed would feel compelled to push interest rates higher later this year. The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was down 21/32 , to 98, to yield 6.78 percent. Bonds' drop hurt the stock market, which bounced up and down during the day. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 14.93 at 7,672.79.
Today's economic reports were unlikely to have much effect on the deliberations of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee during its two-day meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday, analysts said.
Over the last several weeks Fed officials have said they are encouraged with the economy's slower growth during the second quarter after the extremely strong first quarter, and that they see no big warning signs of a pick up in inflation.
The Fed last raised rates in March, when it nudged its Federal funds target rate up to 5.5 percent from 5.25 percent. That was the first time it had tightened policy in more than two years, and the move was widely seen as preventive to insure that inflation did not infect the economy. The Fed left rates unchanged at a subsequent meeting in May.
With the economy showing almost no signs of consumer price inflation or of its precursor, wage inflation, most analysts believe the Fed is now content to sit tight for another month or two to determine whether the slower growth pace will insure that price pressures remain contained.
Traditional economic theory holds that low unemployment combined with strong growth will generate inflation, because employers will bid up wages to attract the workers they need and then pass the costs along to consumers. But that pattern has broken down during this economic cycle, with unemployment well below what analysts long considered the danger mark and growth well above what Fed officials consider the economy's "speed limit" of 2.25 percent.
Still, many Fed officials and most economists believe that the old relationship between growth and unemployment will ultimately reassert itself. They said that if growth in the second half of the year ran close to 3 percent or more, as now seems possible, and unemployment remains steady or even falls, which is another strong possibility, the forces that had restrained wage and price increases would begin to buckle.
"You have to conclude that we are probably still in an excess-growth year, and we're starting from a point at which economists would have to be looking for inflation heating up 6 to 12 months down the road," said David C. Munro, an economist at High Frequency Economics, an economic consulting firm.
Economists are struggling to determine whether the slowdown in consumer spending will continue through the summer, and whether industrial production will slow after a period in which retailers restocked their inventories after the robust first quarter. On both counts, the outlook is far from clear, and it is complicated by other uncertainties, including whether foreign economies will rebound sharply enough to stimulate demand for American goods.
"We're going to have a period of extreme confusion over the summer," said Ian Shepherdson, an economist at HSBC Markets.
More generally, policy makers within the Fed, like economists generally, are still trying to decide whether the economy has changed so fundamentally that it has altered the relationships among growth, unemployment and price increases. Laurence H. Meyer, an economic forecaster who was named a Fed governor by President Clinton last year, has argued that nothing has really changed, and that strong growth coupled with low unemployment will eventually send inflation up again.
But Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman and still the most influential voice on monetary policy, appears to have adopted a more pragmatic approach, scouring the economy for the ramifications of the complex interplay among the business world's drive for more efficiency, the willingness of workers to accept limited pay increases and the overall economy's growth.
