HEADLINE: World Bank, at U.S. Urging, Postpones Vote on Loan to Croatia

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Under pressure from the United States, the World Bank took the unusual step today of postponing indefinitely a vote on a $30 million loan to Croatia that the country hoped to use to shore up its banking systems and stimulate private investment.
For the last week the Clinton Administration lobbied vigorously to block the loan as a way to express its displeasure with Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, for failing to comply with the 1995 peace accords negotiated in Dayton, Ohio, to end the war in Bosnia. 
 At a meeting here today, the World Bank's executive directors were sharply divided over the loan and, rather than voting on its approval, simply agreed to remove it from consideration for an unspecified amount of time, according to two Administration officials familiar with the discussions.
The United States was joined by its major allies in Europe, as well as Canada and Japan, the officials said. But directors representing other countries accused the United States of using the loan to make a political statement.
Jan Piercy, director for the United States, said after the meeting that it was necessary to postpone consideration of the loan for legal and economic reasons. She argued that Croatia's failure to abide by the Dayton peace agreement raised questions about its commitment to international accords and the stability of its economy.
"In this instance, the economic and political factors are so intertwined as to be indivisible," Ms. Piercy said.
The Administration's success in blocking the loan was a significant rebuff to Mr. Tudjman. In May Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced that the United States would redouble its efforts to force Croatia, Serbia and the Muslims in Bosnia to make peace.
The United States routinely votes against or abstains from loans to certain countries, like those regarded as supporting terrorism, but in most cases those loans go ahead anyway. What made today's step unusual was Washington's ability to rally enough support to at least postpone, if not reject, a vote.
A State Department spokesman, John R. Dinger, said the United States opposed the loan because of Mr. Tudjman's "insufficient compliance" with the promises he made in the Dayton accords. In particular, he cited an unwillingness to allow Serbian refugees to return to their homes in Croatia and a failure to cooperate in efforts to bring those indicted for war crimes to trial by the International Tribunal in The Hague.
The action was welcomed in Congress, where there is a growing sentiment that the Administration should condition its support of loans and other assistance to the Balkans on cooperation with Dayton, particularly on the issue of war criminals.
"We have some economic leverage and we should use it," said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont.
While the loan can come up for consideration at any time, officials doubted it would soon. Other international loans for Croatia, however, are scheduled for consideration, including a $40 million loan from the International Monetary Fund next week.
The Administration officials said the United States would continue to oppose loans until Mr. Tudjman demonstrated a willingness to abide by the peace accords.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance, With the Dow Rising 49.54

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market rose yesterday, bolstered by new evidence that the economy is moderating and that inflation is under control.
A report from the National Association of Purchasing Managers showed that factory activity had eased last month, another indication that the economy is slowing after getting off to a feverish start this year. 
 That touched off a rally in the bond market yesterday, which was carried over into stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 49.54 points to close at 7,722.33, leaving it about 70 points below its all-time high.
Broader market measures also gained. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.89 points, to 891.03, and the New York Stock Exchange Composite index rose 3.57 points, to 466.01.
Because of recent signs that the economy is moderating, Wall Street analysts doubt that Federal Reserve policy makers will raise interest rates today, when their two-day meeting concludes.
"The feeling on the Street is that the Fed won't do anything," said Hildegard Zagorski, a market analyst with Prudential Securities. "As long as the economy is in a slow-growth path, there's really no reason for the Fed to raise rates."
Indeed, many on Wall Street are talking about a resplendent American economy, ideally balanced and efficient -- ingredients that have helped lift all the major stock indexes to record highs.
"This is like a mantra on Wall Street: strong growth, low inflation, positive earnings surprises and tremendous liquidity," said Elizabeth J. Mackay, an investment strategist at Bear, Stearns. "You just have a lot of things going extremely well."
That scenario helped to raise drug and financial stocks yesterday, which were among the year's best performers.
For instance, the S.& P. financials index rose 1.6 percent yesterday, as many banks and financial institutions surged on the news that economy may be moderating.
Citicorp rose 2 3/4, to 123 5/16; Chase Manhattan gained 2 1/2, to 99 9/16, and Fannie Mae soared 1 5/16 to 44 5/16.
Wall Street investment banks also got a lift. Shares of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company rose 1 7/8, to 44 5/16, and shares of Merrill Lynch & Company rose 1 3/16, to 60 13/16.
Among drug stocks, Warner-Lambert soared 7 9/16, to 60 13/16, a 52-week high. For the year, Warner-Lambert, which produces products like Listerine mouth wash and Shick razors, is up 75 percent.
Among Dow stocks, J. P. Morgan rose 3 1/8, to 107 1/2 and Exxon rose 1 3/4, to 63 1/4. In all 21 of the Dow's 30 component stocks gained.
Caterpillar, however, one of the year's best performers, fell 2 3/16.
On the Big Board, winners edged losers, 1,704 to 1,150, on heavy volume of 544.38 million shares.
But technology stocks were weak yesterday, partly because on recent warnings of slower earnings growth.
Shares of Microsoft fell 1 7/16, to 124 15/16, after The New York Post reported yesterday that the company was considering acquiring the CBS broadcasting unit from the the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. Microsoft and Westinghouse both denied the report. Shares of Westinghouse rose 11/16, to 23 13/16.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite fell 3.82, to 1,438.25, and the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization issues fell 2.24, to 394.13.
Yesterday's weakness in technology issues, however, is not unlike some of the weakness that has been felt in the broader market.
In the last seven sessions, stock prices have been volatile. Some analysts attributed the wild price swings to end-of-the-quarter reshuffling, but others said the market was tired.
"At some point the market just has to succumb to an overbought position," said Philip J. Roth, a technical analyst with Morgan Stanley. "The market has had an unusual run-up and few setbacks since the April run-up."
That run-up took the Dow from 6,391 on April 11 to 7,722 at yesterday's close -- a 21 percent gain. That kind of sprint is bound to give way to weakness, analysts said.
Even though the last six sessions of June were volatile, analysts said that the market held together well.
The Dow rose 4.6 percent in June, and the Russell 2000 gained 4.1 percent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 5; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: HONG KONG, CHINA: DIPLOMACY;
Uncle Sam's New Role: Hong Kong's Advocate

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 1

 BODY:
The symbol of British sovereignty, Prince Charles, sailed away from Hong Kong early this morning on a tide of nostalgia tinged with dread, leaving the United States as the most credible and influential judge of Beijing's behavior in Hong Kong.
The Britain that seized, built and nurtured Hong Kong is no longer an Asian power. These days London is more preoccupied with how far it wants to tie its fate to the European Union. 
 But the United States, with its self-confidence, global reach, economic might, military power and vocal push for democracy and human rights, is a different matter. It remains the most important Pacific power, a source of enormous investment, trade and needed technology. And it is one of the few countries that commands Beijing's respect.
Consequently it is the United States to which Hong Kong will inevitably look as arbiter and protector in its relations with Beijing. And if the Administration falters, Congress has already shown itself eager to push for a tougher line.
"We're not seeking to replace Britain as the guardian of Hong Kong," a senior Clinton Administration official said. "But it's a role we cannot avoid. Since we are who we are, and we have so much business here, we will end up by being the first to cry foul."
America has been down this road before, notably in the Middle East and in the Caribbean. In both places Americans have by and large picked up the burden that the British laid down, even if at times they were not quick to understand why it was left to them.
In the case of Hong Kong, China needs decent relations with the United States, and Hong Kong is vital to that larger relationship. The people who hold power in Washington and Beijing understand this.
Meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright on Monday as the British rulers were packing their bags, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen said Beijing was "quite sincere" in its commitments about Hong Kong. American officials say he also stated what has become obvious: that China's "most important relationship in Asia and around the world" is with the United States.
China's President, Jiang Zemin, is eager to go to Washington for a long-delayed state visit this autumn, probably in October. The visit should help seal his pre-eminence among the Chinese leadership after the death of Deng Xiaoping, who invented the formula of "one country, two systems" and promised Hong Kong a "high degree of autonomy."
For political reasons alone, President Clinton needs a summit meeting that produces concrete agreements and not just champagne toasts with Mr. Jiang, senior American officials say.
In her meetings here with Mr. Qian, Ms. Albright pressed for the release of the prominent dissident Wei Jingshen and others, for a resumption of the American-Chinese dialogue on human rights and for prison visits by the International Committee of the Red Cross.
Officials said she had also urged restraint on Chinese sales to Pakistan and Iran of nuclear, chemical and military technology and parts, and products that can have military as well as civilian uses. In particular, she warned Mr. Qian that continued sales of cruise missiles to Iran could trigger sanctions under existing American law.
She also pressed him to take steps soon to make a serious and commercially acceptable offer to join the World Trade Organization.
While the American relationship with China involves a long list of issues, Ms. Albright said, "Hong Kong is very high on that list."
The dozen or so American legislators who came along can be expected to do their utmost to insure that it stays there, aided by the 1992 United States-Hong Kong Policy Act, which requires the President to make reports about whether China is keeping its commitments here.
Beyond politics, the reasons for American engagement are compelling. Hong Kong is the economic gateway to the unrivaled potential of the Chinese market. Already 40,000 Americans live here, and more than 1,000 American companies employ about 10 percent of Hong Kong's work force. With 6.5 million people, Hong Kong is the world's eighth-largest trading economy and America's 11th-largest export market.
China has agreed to let the United States Consulate here be a quasi-embassy, retaining a military attache and staff as well as a large contingent of agents monitoring international crime, drug dealing, copyright violations, money laundering and all the rest.
For all these reasons, Ms. Albright emphasized that what happens here must be judged as it unfolds.
In the Administration's agreed one-liner, uttered by Ms. Albright and by Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, the handover of Hong Kong is "a movie, not a snapshot."
Still, as the hours eroded Britain's hold on its last imperial outpost in Asia, one could chart the increasing vigor and clarity of American statements.
Washington let Britain take the lead on reaction to Beijing's preliminary steps here. Those included the effective appointment of Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, as Governor, and the appointment of a Provisional Council, sworn in early this morning, that replaced one elected under British rule.
Even before the handover, the new council, meeting in China, passed measures that threw out significant, if belated and hesitant, democratic reforms that the British had made here.
The British refused to call the scrapping of the elected council a violation of the 1984 Joint Declaration between China and Britain that is meant to preserve Hong Kong's way of life and a "high degree of autonomy" from Beijing. The American Administration went along, annoying Congress.
But now, Ms. Albright has stated explicitly that Washington expects "free and fair elections," as promised within a year, for a new elected legislature. She said that the acts of the Provisional Council would lack legitimacy and that "the United States is and will remain a friend to democracy in Hong Kong."
Even a few days ago, when China announced that 4,000 troops would march into Hong Kong this morning, Ms. Albright was hesitant to condemn it or even to characterize the message, though she implied that it was unfortunate and said that "the signals and messages that go out" matter as much as China's specific actions in Hong Kong.
It was only after her arrival here, and after the British criticized the move, that she said, "I do not think this is the best way to start off, and I think we have to watch this very carefully."
In part, her initial hesitation came because China has every right to put troops here, so long as they engage only in national defense and not internal security.
If in the future there is a specific breach of the Joint Declaration, then it is for the British to complain, one official said. But there will invariably be questions about the spirit of the agreement, the official said, and Washington "should not hesitate to comment."
"We will be watching to see that the Hong Kong of tomorrow is like the Hong Kong of today," Ms. Albright said. Officials said this meant at least that there could be no rollback of the semi-democracy introduced by the British.
But with Congress pushing, President Clinton will be in the familiar but very difficult quandary of how to credibly balance America's larger interests with legitimate concerns about democracy and human rights here.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 567 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Rises 49.54, Aided by Economic Reports
Bolstered by new evidence that economic growth is moderating and that inflation is under control, the stock market generally rose.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 49.54 points and closed at 7,722.33, about 70 points below its all-time high. Drug and financial stocks paced the advance, and the Standard & Poor's financials index rose sharply. But technology issues were weak, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 3.82, to 1,438.25. [Page D6.] 

Treasury prices rose on expectations that Federal Reserve policy makers would leave interest rates unchanged. [D13.]
 
Thailand Devalues Currency
Thailand effectively devalued its currency, the baht, allowing market forces to determine its value. The move follows weeks of pressure against the baht by currency speculators. In Asian trading this morning, the baht immediately tumbled against the dollar. [D2.]
 
The dollar again rose against the German mark after top American and German officials expressed support for the strength of the United States currency. [D4.]
 
Finance Pinch at Montgomery Ward
As Montgomery Ward negotiates the sale of its most valuable asset, its Signature Group direct-marketing unit, and seeks a refinancing package from its banks, the company has stopped paying many of its vendors, people familiar with the situation say. As a result, a number of merchandise financing companies have told suppliers not to make shipments to the retailer. [D2.]
 
F.T.C. Clears McDonnell Purchase
The F.T.C. said it would not oppose Boeing's proposal to buy McDonnell Douglas. In a joint statement, four of the five commission members said that the acquisition would "not substantially lessen competition or tend to create a monopoly in either defense or commercial aircraft markets." [D3.]
 
Opportunity Seen in Software Niche
Many analysts say that so-called front-office applications, like sales force automation and customer support programs, are the fastest- growing segment of the software industry. And even though some of the stocks of companies that provide such software make Microsoft shares look cheap, analysts still see opportunities. Market Place. [D6.]
 
China Is Said to Misuse Computer
China improperly diverted an American supercomputer to one of its military research facilities earlier this year, prompting complaints in recent days by senior American officials to their Chinese counterparts, American officials said. [A9.]
 
EMI Music Buys Motown Rights
EMI Music Publishing paid $132 million to Berry Gordy Jr. for a half-stake in the publishing company that owns the rights to classic Motown songs like those from Diana Ross and the Supremes. [D5.]
 
Motorola to Stop Making a Chip
Motorola said it would stop making dynamic random access memory chips and would take pretax charges of about $170 million for getting out of the business. [D2.]
 
Court Setback for Kaiser H.M.O.
The California Supreme Court has ruled that Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest H.M.O., manipulated a supposedly neutral arbitration system under which patients can file malpractice claims. [D2.]
 
Soybean Prices Down Sharply
Soybean prices fell, reflecting expectations that farmers would harvest a record crop following the heaviest planting pace since 1982 and excellent growing weather. [D4.]

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE BILLS DON'T MEET GOALS, BUDGET AIDES SAY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Estimates by the Congressional Budget Office suggest that health care bills passed last week by the House and the Senate would fall far short of the goal of guaranteeing coverage for half of the nation's 10 million uninsured children.
Lawmakers of both parties said they were surprised and dismayed by the preliminary estimates, which indicated that fewer than 1.5 million uninsured children would gain coverage. The lawmakers insisted that more children would benefit from the legislation. 
 The House voted to spend $16 billion on a new health program for children in the next five years. The Senate set aside $24 billion, including $8 billion from an increase in tobacco taxes. In talks starting next week, negotiators from the two chambers will try to work out their differences and guarantee coverage for as many children as possible.
The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said that large numbers of children expected to receive aid under the two bills -- perhaps 40 percent -- would already have insurance coverage from other sources, including private employers. So, it said, the net increase in children with insurance would be smaller than the members of Congress had assumed.
The budget office said that the House bill, in particular, would give states so much discretion that they could substitute Federal money for state money already being spent on health programs. Governors insist they will use the money as Congress intended, to insure more children.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Utah Republican who has been leading efforts to expand health insurance for children, said the estimates of additional coverage were "coming in very meager."
Referring to experts at the Congressional Budget Office, Mr. Hatch said, "I am not sure why, but they have been consistently scoring the major children's health proposals as helping very few children."
In their efforts to get more money for children's health care, lawmakers and advocates for children have not always paid close attention to questions about how the new program should be designed.
Thus, the budget office said, some of the new Federal money might be used to provide health insurance for children who would otherwise have received it from private employers or from state-financed health programs. House and Senate leaders said they wanted to avoid such a substitution but neither bill would flatly prohibit it.
The Congressional Budget Office said the House bill would provide Medicaid or other health insurance coverage to 865,000 children a year. But it said, "Forty percent of these children would have had health insurance coverage even without the enactment of a national child health assistance program." So the net increase in the number of insured children, it said, would be 520,000.
Governors prefer the House bill, which would give them more discretion than the Senate bill in deciding how to spend Federal money.
Jennifer E. Baxendell, a health policy analyst for the National Governors' Association, said: "We can't understand the reasoning of the Congressional Budget Office. It seems to assume a worst-case scenario, giving the governors no credit for good intentions or for trying to do the right thing with this Federal money."
Ms. Baxendell predicted that millions of children would gain coverage under the House bill. House Republicans share this view, but House Democrats disagree.
Stan Dorn, director of the health division at the Children's Defense Fund, described the choice this way: "Will the money be used for health insurance, or is it a slush fund? The stakes are huge. This could be a tremendous step forward for uninsured children. Or a historic opportunity could be wasted."
Under the House bill, states could use Federal money to expand Medicaid, enroll children in private insurance plans or purchase health care services through direct payments to doctors, hospitals and clinics. States would have the leeway to decide which children were eligible and what benefits they would receive.
Under the Senate bill, the states could not use Federal money to buy health care services directly but would have to use it for health insurance, with a package of benefits specified by the Federal Government. Governors say they should be free to make such decisions to meet local needs.
The budget agreement negotiated in May by President Clinton and Congressional leaders earmarked $16 billion to "be used in the most cost-effective manner possible to expand coverage and services for low-income and uninsured children, with a goal of up to five million currently uninsured children being served."
House Republicans say that some states will want to use their share of the money for services provided by community health centers, rural clinics or children's hospitals.
But the Congressional Budget Office said that some of the Federal money provided under the House bill would probably be used for "existing state activities." In addition, it said, some of the money might be used to offset cuts in Federal Medicaid payments to hospitals serving large numbers of low-income patients.
Representative Lucille Roybal-- Allard, Democrat of California, said the $16 billion in the House bill could become a general revenue-sharing program, like the one that existed from 1972 to 1986. "The money does not have to be used to cover uninsured children," she said.
Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, "While $16 billion is better than nothing, it is estimated that the plan is far short of reaching one-half of the 10 million children who are without health coverage."
Mr. Dorn, of the Children's Defense Fund, described the House bill as "an invitation to states to divert money to purposes unrelated to children's health care."
The Senate bill, like the House bill, would initially have set aside $16 billion for a child health program in the next five years. The Congressional Budget Office said that this version of the Senate bill would have provided coverage for 1.3 million children, including 800,000 who were previously uninsured.
The bill was changed on the Senate floor in several ways. Now it would guarantee specific benefits. In addition, the Senate version of the tax bill would provide $8 billion of additional money for children's health insurance initiatives, making a total of $24 billion. So it seems plausible to estimate that the net increase in the number of children with insurance would be about 50 percent higher than the initial estimate -- that is, in the range of 1.2 million children. But the budget office is still working on the calculations.
Liberal Democrats said it was essential for Congress to specify the health benefits provided to children under any program subsidized by the Federal Government. The Senate bill stipulates that such benefits must be at least equivalent to those offered to the children of Federal employees and must include hearing and vision services. It would also require coverage for mental illnesses to be comparable to that for physical illnesses, in most cases.
But Ms. Baxendell, the health policy analyst at the National Governors' Association, said: "Hundreds of thousands of additional children could be covered if states were given flexibility in designing the benefits. The more expensive you make the package for one kid, the fewer kids you can cover over all."

HEADLINE: Postage Rates Likely to Rise For First Class

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Sending a birthday card could cost a penny more next spring, but Americans would get a break on the cost of paying bills under new rates proposed by the United States Postal Service today.
The basic first-class stamp would go up 1 cent, to 33 cents. But, in a rare price cut, bills paid using preprinted envelopes would drop to 30 cents. The current 32-cent letter rate took effect on Jan. 1, 1995. 
 The unusual plan to lower the price of paying a bill is expected to meet some of the competition from electronic bill paying, which has become increasingly popular.
It will not mean a special new stamp, though. Instead, businesses like utility companies would offer customers the option of buying prepaid reply envelopes, charging an annual $3.60 fee for the 12 envelopes with 30 cents postage already imprinted. The lower rate reflects the fact that the preprinted envelopes are cheaper to handle because they can be read and sorted by machine.
The overall rate increases drew prompt criticism from John F. Robinson of the Coalition to Make Our First-Class Mail First Class, who complained that postal officials "should not be trusted with any more of our money."
The rate proposal will be sent to the independent Postal Rate Commission next week, but because of the complex legal process required to get changes approved, the new rates will not take effect until at least May 1998.
Besides first-class mail, increases are also proposed for other classes of mail, including magazines and catalogues, parcels and junk mail.
The proposed increases for all types of mail are expected to raise the Postal Service's income $2.5 billion a year. While the agency made record profits in the last two years, it faces declining revenue and rising costs in coming years.
The penny rise in first-class mail represents a 3.1 percent increase in prices, less that one-third of the inflation rate since the current price took effect, Postmaster General Marvin Runyon said.
Millions of stamps with the letter "H" instead of a price have already been printed for use until stamps showing the new rate can be prepared. Stamps without prices that are used when a new rate takes effect carry letters of the alphabet. The last one was "G."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Got Another Penny for a Stamp?"

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Cooking Scholarships for 9

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Nine New York City high school students have received scholarships totaling more than $115,000 to some of the country's culinary schools based on their performances at a recent cooking competition.
The scholarships were awarded last month by a nonprofit organization in Manhattan called the Careers Through Culinary Arts Program, which teaches students the basics in sanitation, safety and food preparation. Of the 2,000 home economics students in 30 New York high schools that the program reached this year, 14 students were chosen to compete in a cooking competition at the New York Restaurant School. 
 With a two-hour time limit, the students prepared poached guinea hen with chive sauce, and crepes with chocolate and cream sauce -- from memory. Nine won scholarships, and five received gifts and awards worth about $8,000.
The top three winners were Stephanie Grajales of John Dewey High School in Brooklyn, who received a four-year, $40,000 scholarship to Johnson & Wales University; Milton Gotay of Park West High School in Manhattan, who received a $22,760 scholarship to the Culinary Institute of America, and Deana Giordano, of Tottenville High School in Staten Island, who received a $20,000 scholarship to the French Culinary Institute.
 DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A few big winners are seen in front-office software stocks.

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher

 BODY:
WHAT is the fastest-growing segment of the software industry? Many analysts say that would be so-called front-office applications, like sales force automation and customer support programs. Though the field is crowded, and the stocks expensive, some analysts say investors can still share in this growth if they pick carefully among the contenders.
Companies like Siebel Systems Inc., the Vantive Corporation, Scopus Technology Inc., Clarify Inc. and the Remedy Corporation are hardly household words, but that does not mean they are undiscovered. Shares in Siebel, a Wall Street favorite, are trading at an astonishing 136 times projected 1997 earnings. It almost makes the Microsoft Corporation, at more than 40 times, or the Oracle Corporation, at a similar multiple, look cheap. 
 Analysts say investors are not paying for earnings with these companies, however, but for growth. They cite studies by the Gartner Group and International Data Group projecting that the market for front-office applications will grow to $3 billion by 2000 from about $600 million this year. With the inevitable consolidation, the 40 or 50 public and private companies in this field will be winnowed down to two or three dominant suppliers that will grow at extraordinary rates, these analysts say.
The big appeal of these companies' products is that in contrast to traditional back-office applications like accounting packages, they aim not to reduce costs but to increase revenues. The products achieve such gains by increasing and improving the kind of information available to salespeople in the field so that they can complete bigger and more complex sales more quickly or by improving interaction with existing customers, resulting in more repeat business.
"All of these products really focus on the customer, which is very different from the past, where applications all focused on transaction processing and financial accounting," Eric Upin, an analyst at Robertson, Stephens & Company, said. "Sales and marketing are the biggest operating expense for most companies, 35 to 40 percent of revenues, and they are also the least automated."
"We believe we're at the very beginning of a very large market opportunity," he said.
Mr. Upin estimates that there are more than 20 million potential users of front-office programs in the United States, and that the top five front-office companies have fewer than 2,000 customers among them, representing at most only 200,000 users. So the growth potential is real; what is more difficult is identifying likely winners.
To find them, Mr. Upin said he would look first at management skill, next at the customer base, then at the company's sales and marketing and ability to install the programs, which are large and complex, and only last at the technology.
Applying these criteria, he currently recommends Siebel Systems, which is managed by a group of early Oracle executives and counts Charles Schwab, Compaq Computer and American President Lines among its reference customers. Siebel started in sales force automation and has lately been moving into customer support and internal help desk software, which is used to answer employees' questions about company operations.
Mr. Upin also recommends Vantive, which started in help desk and is moving toward sales force programs with its own cadre of talent that came from Oracle; it has a roster of prominent customers similar to that of Siebel.
"This is a multibillion-dollar opportunity and both companies have the potential to be dominant players," Mr. Upin said. Both companies were also brought public by his firm, Robertson, Stephens.
Edgar P. Bierdeman, research director at Dakin Securities, applies a similar set of criteria, but adds, "You really want to invest in companies that have identifiable and defensible market niches."
Mr. Bierdeman, too, likes Siebel and Vantive, but he also favors Remedy, which focuses on the internal help desk market, and has the fledgling industry's highest operating profit margins, at 28 percent. "This is an excellent case study in defining a market niche, developing a well-formulated strategy and sticking to it until the company achieves market dominance," he said.
"You don't value these companies on earnings," he added. "They're too young for that. They're expensive, but they're like an Oracle. You need to buy them judiciously."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Price Sinks as the Fed Stands Pat on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Gold fell to its lowest price on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange in more than four years yesterday after Federal Reserve policy makers left United States interest rates unchanged.
In other markets, rice and cocoa fell. 
 For some traders, the Fed's vote signaled that policy makers and the chairman, Alan Greenspan, were content that the American economy was not growing too fast and that inflation was under control. That diminished demand for gold, an asset traditionally viewed as a hedge against a surge in inflation.
"When the Fed doesn't raise rates, people interpret that to mean there is no specter of inflation looming ahead," said Leonard Kaplan, a chief bullion trader at the Monex Deposit Company in Newport Beach, Calif. "That deters people from investing in gold."
Gold for August delivery fell $2.80, to $332.30 an ounce, in New York, its lowest since March 1993.
Expectations that European central banks may sell gold reserves to reduce budget deficits to qualify for the European single currency, or euro, also shadows the market.
Rice futures fell after Thailand, the world's largest rice exporter, devalued its currency, making its grain cheaper on the world market and increasing competition for world buyers.
Rice for September delivery fell 0.25 cent, to 9.135 cents a pound, on the Chicago Board of Trade, the lowest price since February 1996.
Cocoa fell as rains soaked West African crops, raising expectations that this year's harvests would yield adequate supplies.
Last month, cocoa prices rose to a nine-year high amid concern that several countries' crops would be smaller than expected because of dry growing conditions. Now, soil moisture is up for crops in the Ivory Coast and good conditions exist in the Pacific Rim and parts of Brazil, according to the Weather Services Corporation of Lexington, Mass.
Cocoa for September delivery fell $71, to $1,614 a metric ton (1.2 tons), on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
Last year's Ivory Coast crop produced 1.2 million metric tons of cocoa. Forecasters have put this year's crop at 750,000 to 1.1 million tons.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges Against Mark But Plunges in Pound Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar again surged against the German mark yesterday, but fell sharply against the pound after Britain's Labor Government released its first budget.
The pound initially stumbled when the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, began his budget speech by saying that he shared British industry's concern about the strength of the pound. 
 But as the details of the budget emerged, the pound began a sharp climb, rising almost 3 cents against the dollar and as much as 5 pfennigs at its peak against the mark.
Currency traders said the budget did not appear to have gone far enough in curbing strong consumer-led growth in Britain, leaving the door open for an increase soon in interest rates that would benefit the pound.
"Brown's initial remarks took sterling down to the lows, but the rest of his comments were well received and we saw heavy buying of sterling," said Cynthia Johnson, managing director of foreign exchange at CIBC Wood Gundy.
"I think people perceived the budget as leaving the door open for higher interest rates."
The pound rose as high as $1.6785 before settling in New York at $1.6731, up from $1.6581 on Tuesday and its highest level since Jan. 16. The pound also surged to a new five-year peak above 2.94 marks. The weakness in the mark bolstered the dollar against the German currency.
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7550 marks, its fourth consecutive three-and-a-half-year high against the mark, before settling at 1.7536 marks, up from 1.7467 marks on Tuesday.
Also helping the dollar against the mark was a report showing that German industrial production had fallen by a surprising two-tenths of 1 percent in May.
The dollar ended weaker against the Japanese yen, which rose during Asian trading hours after the Bank of Thailand announced it was dropping its pegged exchange rate system and letting its currency float freely. The yen often acts as a safe haven currency in times of turbulence in other Asian markets.
In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 114.49 yen, down from 114.88 yen on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
German Effort On Digital TV Moves Ahead

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 2

 BODY:
Germany's troubled efforts to introduce digital television received an important boost today, as the nation's dominant cable provider and the two biggest German entertainment companies agreed to end years of feuding and support a common system.
The agreement calls for Deutsche Telekom to make its network available for digital television programming offered by Kirch Group and by Bertelsmann A.G., the publishing and broadcasting conglomerate. 
 The agreement appears to end the long stalemate among three powerful companies, each of which controlled essential building blocks for a successful business in advanced television but which feuded in a struggle to control the new industry.
Today's agreement comes a week after a related collaboration announced by Kirch and Bertelsmann. If the two agreements hold up -- and analysts warned that Europe is littered with scrapped media alliances -- they could pave the way to a big expansion in advanced pay-per-view and multimedia services in what is by far Europe's biggest economy.
Under the agreement, Deutsche Telekom announced that it would adopt Kirch's technology for set-top decoders and customer verification and that it would provide capacity over its modernized cable network to carry some 50 channels envisioned by Kirch and Bertelsmann.
Telekom's role is crucial, because the company provides cable service to more than 16 million households and Kirch has thus far had to transmit its fledgling digital service, called DF-1, over satellite.
Digital television services here are similar to what satellite direct television provides in the United States, offering many channels of regular programming as well as pay-for-view movies and sporting events.
Bertelsmann and Kirch, meanwhile, agreed to merge their dueling pay-television ventures. Premiere, which offers one analog channel of pay-per-view movies and has 1.4 million subscribers, will be united with DF-1, which has about 29 channels but only 40,000 subscribers.
Premiere has been owned jointly by Bertelsmann, Kirch and Canal Plus, a major pay-television company in France. (Canal Plus announced today that its board had approved the sale of its 37.5 percent stake in Premiere to Kirch in exchange for Kirch's 45 percent stake in Telepiu, the Italian pay-TV broadcaster.)
Each partner in Premiere has a veto on all important decisions, and Bertelsmann has thus far refused to let Premiere and its customers be absorbed into DF-1.
But Kirch Group, which has spent billions of dollars buying up rights to movies and television from Hollywood studios, controls vast quantities of programming that are crucial to the long-run success of pay-per-view television.
Today's agreement appears to put the pieces of this puzzle -- the network, the customer base and the movies -- back together. "This opens up the prospects for digital television, which up until now had been questionable," said Helmuth Runde, a spokesman for Bertelsmann.
But Ivor Jones, a media analyst with Salomon Brothers in London, warned that the future of digital television, along with more exotic new services like high-speed Internet access and interactive television, was still cloudy because German customers already had nearly 30 channels of television available at low cost.
The deeper problem is Kirch's financial health. Privately controlled by the entrepreneur Leo Kirch, the company has spent more than $1 billion to start DF-1 and has yet to generate anything close to significant revenue. The company had been hoping to sign up 200,000 customers in its first year, but has yet to get much past 40,000. And industry executives say the company needs at least one million subscribers to break even, two million customers to be solidly profitable.
Kirch executives have acknowledged in recent weeks that they are looking for new sources of financing, and that they have been talking to potential strategic partners. But the company displayed surprising confidence last month by announcing that it had paid another $500 million for yet another batch of movie rights from Hollywood.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The air standards are set, but how clean is clean enough?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
SEEMINGLY trapped between environmental groups, which view the Administration's proposed pollution standards as a make-it-or-break-it test of the White House's commitment to virtue, and business lobbies, which see the standards for ozone and ultrafine soot particles as a colossal waste of money, President Clinton found some room to wiggle.
The final rules, issued last week by the Environmental Protection Agency, were not softened. But they will be applied in what the E.P.A. terms "flexible and affordable ways," with oceans of time to adjust. "It will be 2009 -- after President Gore's second term is completed -- before the regulations really bite," predicted Paul R. Portney, the head of Resources for the Future, a Washington-based research group. 
 The mix of tough standards and long lags in enforcement certainly makes political sense, repairing the Administration's frayed ties with environmentalists while making it easier to dismiss business alarms and give moderate Republicans an excuse to look the other way. But it does nothing to resolve the difficult question of how clean is clean enough. And it put in place regulations that many economists argue should not be enforced. "Anybody who thinks the new ozone standard is cost effective must be smoking something," said Robert Crandall at the Brookings Institution.
Most important, perhaps, it would greatly expand regulators' effective power. "Since the ozone standard cannot be met in some cities," Robert Hahn of the American Enterprise Institute said, "the E.P.A. will end up with broad discretion on where and when to enforce the law."
The clean air act requires the E.P.A. to set pollutant standards that would eliminate risks to health, and then periodically update them to reflect the latest science. So earlier this year the agency proposed to tighten the screws on ozone, a component of urban summer smog, and to create a standard for tiny soot particles.
Not surprisingly, the oil and auto industries protested. More striking, the E.P.A.'s independent panel of scientists was badly split on the value of the new standards. And both the Treasury and the President's economic advisers argued vociferously that the costs would exceed the benefits.
Vice President Al Gore, who has done most of the heavy lifting on environmental policy, was apparently caught unprepared by the vigor of the opposition. Indeed, until last week he distanced himself from the rules, leaving it to the E.P.A. to defend the proposal. But with pressure mounting from environmental groups, the White House finally adopted the cause as its own.
The two pollutants in question present very different challenges. Little is known about the consequences of exposure to very small particles of soot because they are typically present in high concentrations only when other pollutants are also plentiful. What's more, the authors of a key study on which the E.P.A. apparently relied have yet to disclose their data to skeptics.
Still, Lester B. Lave, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University, thinks the evidence is strong enough to begin the long process of measuring the presence of small particulates and limiting human exposure. "You want to do some technology-forcing early on," he suggests, before industry commits to plants that may eventually require costly modification.
By contrast, it is widely conceded that ozone affects health in concentrations well below the old standard of 120 parts per billion. There are two catches, though. The number of people who could be helped is not large: the new standard would reduce hospitalizations for asthma by just 1 or 2 percent. And the costs could be astronomical: The President's Council of Economic Advisers estimated that the annual cost of cutting ozone to 80 parts per billion would be $11 billion to $60 billion.
The tighter standard would add an element of farce to enforcement in cities including Los Angeles, Houston and New York, where even radical limits on emissions would not suffice. "We just don't know how to get from here to there," Mr. Portney said.
But most of the players in this game will probably not be around to face the political music. "States and counties participating in the regional pollution control strategy will have at least until the year 2004 to meet the need standard," an E.P.A. news release said.
The hiatus with soot is even longer. Washington is allowing five years to collect data, three years more for the states to plan controls and 18 months for the E.P.A. to review the plans. Even then, the E.P.A. noted, "it will be several more years before many areas will actually have to comply."
With Congressional Republicans loath to be tarred as pro-pollution, these delays should put the issue to rest for a while. But Robert N. Stavins, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, suggests that the "generic" problem isn't about to evaporate. "It was easy when you couldn't see the car ahead of you on the freeway," he argued; "in a relatively clean environment, it will become ever more difficult to justify further economic sacrifice."
And then there is a question of governance. Since many localities cannot possibly meet the new standard, the need for E.P.A. waivers will mushroom -- as will the temptation to use them to reward political friends and punish enemies. "Enforcement shouldn't depend on whether Al Gore or Dan Quayle is President," Mr. Hahn said.
"One way or another, costs always slip into the deliberation," said Richard L. Schmalensee an economist at M.I.T. who was a key player on environmental issues in the Bush Administration. Demanding that agencies weigh costs against benefits "would push the question into the realm of open discourse," he added.

HEADLINE: G.M. June Sales Off 13.3% Amid Industrywide Decline

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 2

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that its sales fell 13.3 percent last month, leaving the auto industry as a whole on track to end the second quarter with a whimper, following a stellar first quarter.
The weak G.M. sales reflect lackluster demand for new cars and trucks industrywide, Wall Street analysts said. Sales of the company's pickup trucks, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles fell 7.7 percent, while car sales plummeted 16.7 percent in June, compared with a year earlier. 
 The auto industry's slow sales puzzle analysts because they come at a time when economic factors seem so favorable: interest rates are low and stable, unemployment levels are at record lows, and measurements show strong consumer confidence and high personal income levels. Despite it all, "car sales stink," David B. Healy, an auto analyst with Burnham Securities, said.
Other analysts said the weak June auto sales were an indication that the Federal Reserve was correct in deciding today not to raise interest rates to slow the economy. "The Fed was on the mark," David M. Garrity, an analyst at Smith Barney, said.
Smaller auto makers reported sales gains today. Mazda Motor of America said its sales rose 28.2 percent in June. BMW of North America Inc. said its sales rose just one-tenth of 1 percent. The Mercedes-Benz unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., reported a 14.6 percent increase in sales.
Final results for the industry are expected on Thursday, when the Ford Motor Company and a few other manufacturers release their June sales figures. Analysts predict Ford's sales will be down slightly.
Other auto makers announced their June sales results today, and together registered a decline. The Chrysler Corporation said its sales fell 4.0 percent, the Toyota Motor Company said its sales dropped 2.3 percent, the Honda Motor Company said its sales rose 8.9 percent and the Nissan Motor Company said its sales rose 2.4 percent.
Analysts said G.M.'s results were partly hampered by a lengthy strike at a Pontiac, Mich., truck factory, where the company builds its popular Chevrolet C/K pickup. Still, "any way you slice it, they are poor numbers," Mr. Healy said.
General Motors' results varied widely by division. For instance, Chevrolet sales fell 20.5 percent last month, with only the Chevrolet Express van and two new models -- the Malibu sedan and Venture mini-van -- registering gains from a year ago.
Others fared better despite the weak market. Cadillac sales rose 9.3 percent. Buick sales fell just 2.1 percent even though the division dropped the Roadmaster, a model it sold last year. Sales of four of the six other models rose, partly because of a promotion that ended Monday and offered rebates and other discounts on Buicks, analysts said.
G.M. this year has introduced 15 new models during the current model year, and many have sold briskly, compared with the models they replaced. The company is relying on their sales steadily improving to win back market share lost to other auto makers in past years.
Pontiac sales rose 4.8 percent in June, mainly because the sporty Grand Prix sedan has proved so popular since its 1997-model redesign. Sales of the Grand Prix, which sells for $20,000 to $24,000, have more than doubled since last year.
Michael Coy, the general manager of a Pontiac dealership in a suburb of Portland, Ore., said that he had not only sold every Grand Prix shipped to him by the Kansas City factory but had even reached sale agreements for all 12 of the 1997 Grand Prixs that he had been promised by the end of the model year in September.
"People want the Grand Prix because it has the new styling," Mr. Coy said. "The car kind of stands out in a crowd; it looks more expensive than it is."
G.M. recently acknowledged that despite some market share gains earlier this year, it would not meet its target of increasing its share of the auto market to 33 percent. G.M. has said that is because strikes so far this year cost it 96,000 units of production in the second quarter.
The lost production, G.M. said, would also result in charge of $490 million, or 67 cents a share, after taxes against second-quarter earnings. The company is scheduled to report its second-quarter results on July 16.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Hang Seng Salvation

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
As they lowered the Union Jack here, marking the end of 156 years of British rule, and the band played "God Save the Queen," the thought occurred to me that while God may save the Queen, who will save Hong Kong? The answer is two of the most basic human emotions -- greed and ego. The greed of the supermarkets and the ego of the last Communists. God save them both.
Let me explain. At Sunday night's pre-handover dinner, the head table was stacked with politicians and statesmen from around the globe. Now all of these were powerful people, but alone they won't exercise the decisive influence over China's handling of Hong Kong. If the Hong Kong government had really wanted to intimidate the Chinese it would have invited the heads of the Moody's and Standard & Poor's credit rating agencies, Fidelity and Vanguard mutual funds, Merrill Lynch, Barclays, Salomon Brothers, Morgan Stanley, Deutsche Bank and Mitsubishi. 
 That is to say, there is great concern that China live up to its obligations to preserve Hong Kong's unique capitalism and democratic freedoms. But there is only so much that foreign governments can do to influence events in Hong Kong. The U.S. can punish you by dropping bombs, but there is nothing to bomb here. Moody's, though, can punish you by dropping your credit rating, and there will be plenty of opportunities for that if things go wrong here.
In that sense, Hong Kong will be a largely self-sanctioning diplomatic problem. Because if the Chinese start to mess with Hong Kong -- either by fiddling in its stock market or seriously restricting the free flow of information -- then China will be punished by that most brutal, efficient and immediate of diplomatic tools: the A.T.M. machine.
There is more than $100 billion in foreign investment here, most of it in highly liquid funds, and long before foreign governments respond to any downward spiral here, the Hong Kong economic elite will move their money out by electronic transfer. And the Chinese know it. Lu Ping, China's top official in Hong Kong, bluntly warned his own countrymen Tuesday that China will not allow regional "warlords" (amazing that he used that term to apply to renegade Chinese provincial governors and business conglomerates) to come into Hong Kong and "mess things up."
Hong Kong is the ultimate post industrial diplomatic challenge, because Hong Kong today is really the capital of a huge cyber-community: "Maritime China." This community includes families, coastal trading houses, business alliances between merchants and officials (including intelligence and army officials), as well as some underworld groups. It stretches from Hong Kong to China to Macao to Taiwan to all of the ethnic Chinese communities of South Asia.
It is not a single network or conspiracy. Rather it is a source of great economic vibrancy in Asia, with many competing alliances. The real long-term threat to Hong Kong is less from the iron fist of Imperial China and more from the dark side of Maritime China -- the alliances between Chinese warlords, military chiefs, triads and business that involve everything from smuggling to shady, sweetheart stock deals. It's not that governments are powerless to deal with such a cyber-community, but the supermarkets will probably be a much more efficient disciplining force.
Ego comes in because China's leaders are desperate to prove that now that they have recovered Hong Kong they can run it every bit as well as the British did. Moreover, to complete the total reunification of China, they want to demonstrate to Taiwan, as China's Prime Minister, Li Peng, said Monday, that "one country, two systems" can work for Hong Kong, and therefore "it can also work for Taiwan." China's leaders are keenly aware that they are taking over Hong Kong at a time when property prices and the Hang Seng stock index are soaring. A top Hong Kong official told me the Beijing team is already concerned that they will be blamed (and hurt economically) if the bubble here bursts. That alone is a huge incentive for China to keep Hong Kong in good working order.
It is a fitting irony that the reputation of China's leaders is now linked to the Hang Seng index. It may not be pretty, but it could be Hong Kong's salvation. God save Mao's legacy and Merrill Lynch.

HEADLINE: Asia's Hope for Hong Kong: More Business as Usual

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 2

 BODY:
For some Asian countries that were once British colonies themselves, the end of Britain's 156-year rule over Hong Kong was a proud moment. And in South Korea, which faces hostile North Korea across a heavily armed border, there was a tinge of envy that China and Hong Kong could be reunited so peacefully.
But as Asian neighbors observed the fireworks in Hong Kong on Monday night, their thoughts were far from the issue that has preoccupied the United States -- whether Communist China will crack down on civil liberties in Hong Kong. 
 "That is not our priority," said Chang Chul Kyoon, deputy director general for Asia-Pacific affairs in South Korea's Foreign Ministry. "As far as Hong Kong is concerned, economics is the No. 1 issue for the Korean Government."
South Korea, which became democratic only in the last decade, knows what it feels like to be pressed by Washington on human rights. And many other Asian nations still have authoritarian governments.
The difference in the attitude toward the human-rights issue reflects philosophical differences over economic development. While the United States and Western Europe tend to believe that political freedom goes hand in hand with capitalism, many governments in Asia, as exemplified most by Singapore, believe that free-wheeling personal liberty is not necessary for economic development and might even be inimical to it.
The Straits Times, a Singapore newspaper, practically gloated over the fact that Hong Kong had not already collapsed in the years leading up to this week's return to Chinese rule.
"The British nation's surrogate mourners -- the Western media, human rights lobbyists and crusading politicians in Washington and parts of the European Union -- had intimated what they wished to see happen to Hong Kong in the run-up to July 1, 1997," the newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday. "An exodus of talent, the stock and property sectors on their knees, civil unrest, hostile noises from Beijing."
But, the newspaper said, the Hong Kong stock market is at a record high, property prices are soaring, and emigres are returning to a vibrant Hong Kong from "sleepwalking" places like Australia and Canada. "And China will no doubt again thwart the ill-wish of its detractors in the months and years ahead," it said.
If there is concern in Asia about Hong Kong's future, it does not seem to be so much about whether the press will remain free but about whether Hong Kong and China will be a harder place in which to do business.
Optimists say they expect Hong Kong to remain a capitalist bastion and to influence China to adopt more economic reforms.
"People say that Hong Kong might be China-ized, but on the contrary, we expect that China will be Hong Kong-ized," said Takeshi Kondo, general manager of the office of political and economic research at Itochu Corporation, a huge Japanese trading company with many investments in Hong Kong and China.
Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the Japanese consumer electronics giant known for its Panasonic brand, plans to expand its Hong Kong operations to help manage the more than two dozen factories it has built in China over the last decade, said Yukio Shotoku, a manager in charge of China.
But many Japanese business executives apparently believe that Chinese rule will make it more difficult to do business in Hong Kong, replacing the rule of law established by the British with China's more arbitrary Government decision-making.
In a poll of companies with Hong Kong operations taken by the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading financial newspaper, 31 percent of the Japanese companies thought Hong Kong's business environment would be worse in five years than it is now, while 16 percent said it would be better and 52 percent predicted it would be unchanged. That made the Japanese companies as a whole more pessimistic than the American and European companies, only 18 percent of which thought the business environment would worsen.
China has attracted huge outside investments because its 1.2 billion people make it potentially the world's largest market. But it is no fun to do business there, what with corruption, the emphasis on connections, restrictions and tariffs, and the pressure to transfer one's technology to a Chinese company in return for being allowed to set up shop.
Japanese automobile manufacturers, which raced into Southeast Asia and now control nearly 90 percent of some markets in the region, have been so wary about moving into China that they have fallen behind European and American rivals there. And some companies that invested heavily in China are having second thoughts as profits have proved elusive.
Direct investment in China from Japan fell 35 percent in the last fiscal year, according to Japan's Ministry of Finance. Investment in Hong Kong continued to rise, but that, too, could change, said C. H. Kwan, an Asian economy specialist at the Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo.
"The recent trend is that many companies are losing interest in China," Dr. Kwan said. "If you lose interest in China, the importance of Hong Kong declines."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Rise in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, as the Federal Reserve opted to keep monetary policy unchanged and more economic data pointed to a slowing economy, with low inflation.
The 30-year bond rose 13/32, to a price of 98 31/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.71 percent, from 6.74 percent on Tuesday. 
 While the market was relieved by the decision of the Fed's Open Market Committee not to raise interest rates, analysts said investors were equally interested in scrutinizing today's report on the labor market for signs of inflation, which erodes the value of bonds.
But adding to the picture of a slowing economy, the Government reported yesterday that factory orders in May fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, more than the two-tenths of 1 percent decline that was expected. The April factory orders were revised upward to 1.4 percent, from 1.2 percent, and served only to underscore the decline in May.
"While the economy's apparent sluggishness in the second quarter, coupled with a still decelerating rate of inflation, kept the Fed at bay, there are still a number of developments in the economic picture that suggest caution in the months ahead regarding another round of Fed tightening and a potential backup in bond yields," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
"Most notable is the obvious dichotomy between the buoyant measures of consumer psychology on one hand and the recent three successive monthly declines in retail sales on the other."
Indexes of consumer confidence compiled by the Conference Board, a business research group, and by the University of Michigan, have been at extremely high levels, he noted, indicating that the weakness at retailers, which has also been evident in sluggish automotive sales, may be broken.
While another rate increase by the Fed cannot be taken for granted, it is probably best for investors to lean toward such a move in their expectations, Mr. Fine said. And some market participants said they believed that politics might have played a role in yesterday's decision. Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, noted that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, has testimony scheduled for July 22 before the House Banking Committee. A rate increase yesterday could have meant a lot of criticism from lawmakers concerned that higher rates could choke off economic growth.
While investors' attention is always riveted on a meeting of the Open Market Committee, today's labor report will also be instructive in gauging the direction of the economy, and of the bond market. Mr. Fine said the consensus expectation is for a gain of 225,000 jobs to payrolls in June, which is virtually identical to the average monthly increase for the year so far, and would imply no change in trend of strong growth in employment.
The unemployment rate, at 4.8 percent in May, was at its lowest point in nearly a quarter of a century, and while the consensus forecasts calls for it to remain unchanged, a further decline would not be all that surprising, Mr. Fine said.
As the markets gear down for the long Fourth of July weekend, the Treasury market will close at 3 P.M. today and will be closed all day tomorrow. PSA-the Bond Market Trade Association has also recommended the early closing time today and a full close tomorrow for trading of municipal bonds and secondary money market trading.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Wrongly Jailed And Released? Now Pay Price

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
AFTER more than 11 years in prison for a rape he didn't commit, David Shephard landed a job at City Hall. He starts work at 7 A.M. and spends the day moving furniture, changing light bulbs, keeping the grounds of Newark's gold-domed building ready for company. It's honest work, and he is grateful for it.
"I usually spend my lunch hour right here, on the steps," he said, all dimples, as he stood outside City Hall in his Dallas Cowboys cap and a blue uniform with "Shep" embroidered on the shirt pocket. He looked like a man without a care. 
 But looks, as Mr. Shephard learned the hard way, are tricky little devils. At 33 years old, two years into this job, he earns almost $10,000 less than the $26,000 he was earning guiding planes on the runways at Newark Airport when he was arrested at age 20. Moreover, for about eight months, his paycheck has been docked $150 every two weeks by Essex County. The county says Mr. Shephard owes $18,000 in child support payments he didn't make to his fiancee for their son while he was in prison.
"It wouldn't be so bad if my girlfriend were getting the money," he said. "But this is reimbursement for welfare." He chuckled. "I thought everything would be all right when I got out. You'd think I'd have known better."
MR. SHEPHARD has the burly build of a bouncer and laughs this big man's laugh every time he tells this story. But he is not really amused. This year, his Federal income-tax refund was $1,878, enough for a security deposit and first month's rent on an apartment. But the county took the check. He will have to wait months and months, at least, before he has enough money saved to move out of his rented room and into his own place with his girlfriend, their now-13-year-old son and their 1-year-old daughter.
On the other hand, things could change soon if the Governor signs a bill that would allow persons wrongly convicted and imprisoned to collect up to $20,000 a year for each year of incarceration (or double their annual salary, whichever is more). Mr. Shephard, who inspired the bill, would be entitled to about $227,000.
His lawyer, Paul Casteleiro of Hoboken, says the bill "looks solid." But Mr. Shephard is not counting any chickens. Luck, it seems, has always been in short supply.
He had just landed his job at the airport, his son was five months old and he had big plans to save money for a place for his young family when the police arrested him. Never in trouble before, he was accused of being one of two men who kidnapped a woman from the Woodbridge Mall and drove her to Hillside, where they beat, raped and robbed her.
Based on the victim's identification (there were no other witnesses, no other suspects), Mr. Shephard was convicted and sentenced to a youth prison for up to 30 years, with a minimum of 12. He was a prison leader, football coach and researcher in the law library, almost eligible for parole, when DNA testing, done after his repeated requests, exonerated him.
WHEN Mr. Shephard started working at City Hall, three weeks after he was released, he and his fiancee planned to take up where they left off. She was living with their son and her parents, he with his uncle. Mr. Shephard applied for a $2,500 loan to use as a security deposit for an apartment. He learned from PNC Bank that he owed money for child support.
Louis Miron of Westfield, a lawyer with whom Mr. Shephard collaborates on talks to schoolchildren about the justice system and prison life, then began making phone calls for him. "I felt like the buck was kind of being passed," Mr. Miron said.
Weeks later, Mr. Shephard's paycheck was garnished based on a court order he had signed when he was unemployed so that his girlfriend could collect welfare.
Mr. Miron argues that since Mr. Shephard had found a job that would have allowed him to support his child before he was wrongfully incarcerated, he should not be penalized for payments he couldn't make while in prison.
"Finally, we were able to negotiate a consent order with the Essex County Counsel stopping the garnishment until a court could hear the case," Mr. Miron said yesterday morning. "The order was supposed to be signed and delivered last week, but as of today, I'm still waiting."
Yesterday afternoon, after a call from a reporter, the Essex County Counsel's office faxed a consent order to Mr. Miron. Nicholas Grosch, an assistant counsel, said that Mr. Shephard will now have to wait for the Probation Department to change his file.

HEADLINE: TALKING BUSINESS: With Gerald T. McQueen;
Javits Center, Cleaned Up, Considers Expanding to 42d Street

 BODY:
As a veteran police executive and specialist in organized crime, Gerald T. McQueen finds himself in a different role as president of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Instead of routing out corrupt union practices at the center, as he was hired to do in 1995 as its inspector general, he is now presiding over a campaign to expand the center.
 Mr. McQueen was named chief executive of the Manhattan exhibition hall in January, succeeding Robert E. Boyle, who became head of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The management change came at a time of rapid growth for the convention business in other cities, a surge in business travel and tourism in New York and abundant evidence that a bigger convention center in Manhattan could be filled. 

 The evidence includes a report by Coopers & Lybrand that suggests that the size of the Javits Center, which is owned by New York State, should be almost doubled. Already, the center provides the core of a convention industry that generates $1.3 billion a year in spending by delegates in Manhattan.
 Mr. McQueen, 60 years old, whose career has included such posts as commanding officer of a Manhattan detective unit and chief investigator for the Ethics Committee of the House of Representatives, discussed his plans for the center with Thomas J. Lueck.

Q. The Javits Center is only 11 years old, so why the urgent need to expand?
 
A. We are operating at capacity and there are a lot of shows that we have to turn down. And we have fallen far behind other cities. The Javits Center is currently the 12th largest major exhibition hall in the country. And our research shows that if we do not expand, we will drop to 16th. That is based on the expansion that is already taking place in other cities, not just being talked about.
 
Q. Why has the city fallen so far behind places like Cleveland and Louisville, Ky.?
 
A. I doubt that expansion was part of the thinking here, because the Javits Center had other problems to deal with. The priority was to clean up what we had and better accommodate the business that came in. When I arrived in 1995, there were people sleeping on the loading docks, and you couldn't get any service unless you gave somebody a $100 bill. Then, the Governor stepped in and said clean it up or he'd close it. We interviewed over 2,000 people, brought in new employees and the change has been like night and day.
 
Q. The improvement was reflected in an audit last year by the state's Comptroller, Carl McCall, but has the message gotten through to the people who book conventions and trade shows?
 
A. Very much so. For one thing, we are getting letters galore from people praising our work force. For another, our bookings are up 19 percent for our fiscal year that began in March. That's the first increase in four years. We've got nine new shows, and we have had to turn others away.
 
Q. Some of the spillover has been going to the New York Coliseum and Manhattan's two passenger ship terminals. Can that continue?
 
A. No. The Coliseum and the terminals will close this year. And to make matters worse, many of the hotels that used to book small trade shows are doing away with that part of their business because there are so many demands on their meeting rooms. So the city is really strapped.
 
Q. How much expansion do you propose, where would it go and what would it cost?
 
A. We now have 760,000 square feet of exhibition space, and the most reasonable plan would be to go to 1.3 million square feet. We are looking at different ways to go about it, but this would probably mean acquiring three blocks, from 39th Street to 42d Street, between 11th and 12th Avenues, and expanding in that direction. That would give us the opportunity to be part of the revitalization of 42d Street. Our best estimate is that it would cost $700 million to $750 million. Now, that's a lot of money, but you have to consider the benefits when New York becomes the top place to go. There have been offers of private financing for the expansion, but we are not leaning that way. It would be some form of public financing by the state.
 
Q. Won't people in the State Legislature object, saying the center has been such a hornet's nest of corruption that no more public financing should be approved?
 
A. I hope we will be able to get our ducks in a row and people will see the improvements that have taken place. It should become obvious that the competition is not on the horizon, it is there. And when you think about the economic impact that an expanded Javits Center would have as a mecca for the city and state, you realize that every week or month that you don't build you are losing a lot of money. This project will take four to five years to complete, so I would expect to have a final proposal before the Governor and the Legislature within a year, if not sooner.
 
Q. Even if you expand the Javits Center, don't you still have the problem of access to the building on public transportation? And wouldn't conventioneers still have to deal with a shortage of hotel rooms because the center does not have a hotel of its own and rooms are hard to find nearby?
 
A. It is true that almost every other convention center has a hotel that joins its property. And we think our expansion plan would solve that problem. We've already talked to two or three companies that I'm not prepared to name that have said, essentially, they will be ready to start work on a hotel the same day we announce that the expansion has been approved. As for public access, we are looking at several possibilities. One would be a rail link -- a monorail -- that would move people from the center to Penn Station. But we are leaving our transportation options open, trying to take one step at a time.
