HEADLINE: Cars, Loaded With Incentives, Are Most Affordable in Years

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 2

 BODY:
Car shoppers might not notice it without looking closely at the ads, but the auto industry is in the thick of a price war, with more rebates, cut-rate loans, cheap lease deals and other discounts than ever. And with family incomes rising at a hefty clip, these discounts have made new cars more affordable than they have been in nearly a generation.
For the first time since early 1981, the average car costs less than half a year's pretax income for the average American family, according to Comerica, the biggest Michigan bank. As recently as 1994, the average family paid the equivalent of 30 weeks' income for a new car. 
 But in the three-month period ending June 30, it took just 25.4 weeks of gross income to buy a new set of wheels. That, of course, is still well above the 18 weeks it took in early 1974 when cars were most affordable; incomes had risen briskly through the 1950's and 1960's while Government emission controls and safety regulations had not yet added much to the price of cars.
Yet the current figures are still a big improvement. The calculations do not include sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickups, which have also been getting more affordable lately, although not as quickly as cars, and carried record discounts in June.
Darcy Norris, a 41-year-old administrative assistant in Houston, just took a low-rate lease on a Jeep Cherokee after doubling her salary when she left her old job as a dermatologist's receptionist. "I see a lot of people able to buy homes, buy cars, things that were not in their reach two or three years ago," Ms. Norris said. "It has just been wonderful."
Darrel L. Resleff, 56, an insurance agent in Vancouver, Wash., bought a bright red Pontiac Trans Am two weeks ago because his insurance agency is prospering and Pontiac offered a five-year loan at just 3.9 percent. "I live in a high-growth area and things are going well for us," Mr. Resleff said. The low-rate loan "allowed me to buy a nicer car for my dollar than I could have otherwise."
To be sure, new cars are still not cheap. With an average price approaching $20,000, a midsize sedan remains beyond the reach of millions of middle-class American families. And many sport utility vehicles, at $25,000 to $35,000, are distinctly luxury items. But most models are getting more affordable -- partly because low used-car prices provide stiff competition, partly because there is a glut of practically everything but the biggest sport utility vehicles.
Some of the most generous deals are on the most expensive models. Lexus and Acura are offering dealers rebates of up to $1,000 on most of their sedans, Chrysler has a $1,500 customer rebate on its premium LHS sedan, Oldsmobile is giving dealers a $2,000 rebate on the top-of-the-line Aurora sedan and the Bravada sport utility vehicle, and Lincoln is offering $3,000 customer rebates on its Continentals and Town Cars in some regions. Low-rate loans are available on most cars and a few popular sport utility vehicles, like the Jeep Grand Cherokee, while Cadillac is now leasing its Catera sedan for only $399 a month, down from $520 last winter.
Less expensive models also carry discounts. The Toyota Corolla has a $700 rebate, while the Ford Taurus and the Dodge Grand Caravan and Plymouth Grand Voyager mini-vans all carry $1,000 rebates.
But while this is good news for car buyers, for the auto industry the myriad discounts are nothing to celebrate, representing forgone profits at a time when a vigorous economy should be producing strong earnings.
Comerica calculates that the average discounts on new vehicles have never been larger -- nearly $1,500 apiece for cars and a little less for mini-vans and other light trucks. That does not mean buyers will find unusually large discounts on particular models; the striking thing is that so many cars -- mini-vans, medium-size sport utility vehicles and compact pickups -- carry at least some discount.
While Detroit's Big Three have on occasion offered more generous deals, never before have Asian and American manufacturers alike offered such a wide range of discounts at the same time, said Suzanne B. Kinsler, an auto incentives expert at Coopers & Lybrand, the consulting firm. With the beginning of the 1998 model year approaching on Oct. 1, auto makers may offer even more generous deals on 1997 cars.
"This summer they're going to set some more records" on the level of incentives, Ms. Kinsler predicted. According to Coopers & Lybrand, discounts in six of the last seven months set records for those months. The level of discounts in June was the second highest ever, according to Coopers & Lybrand figures released today, only slightly trailing a peak last December. But the June incentives were more remarkable because they came during the late spring selling season, when most of the previous model year's cars have usually already been sold and big summer clearance specials have not yet begun.
According to Comerica, the incentives this spring have been even higher than at the end of last year.
A separate measure of affordability calculated by the American Automobile Manufacturers Association shows that the number of weeks of work to buy a car is the lowest since 1982, but that measure is narrower than Comerica's because it excludes the effects of low-rate loans.
After years of rising considerably faster than inflation, new-vehicle prices -- not sticker prices, but what people actually pay after discounts -- are up just six-tenths of 1 percent over the 12 months through May, according to the Consumer Price Index. Per-capita disposable personal income has climbed 4.3 percent over the same period.
David L. Littmann, a senior economist at Comerica, said that rising incomes explained less than half the improvement in car affordability. The time an average family has to work to buy an average car has dropped by two weeks so far this year, and only six days of that reflect rising incomes, he said. Rebates, low-rate loans and leases account for the other eight days.
Auto executives offer several reasons for the flood of discounts:
*A growing number of reliable, late-model cars are coming off lease, pushing used-car prices down and presenting millions of Americans with an alternative to new cars.
*Foreign manufacturers continue to build factories in the United States, while domestic manufacturers are keeping factories open, producing a glut of new vehicles.
*More customers are buying the largest sport utility vehicles and full-size pickups, which are in short supply, instead of buying cars, which the bulk of the industry's factories are still set up to manufacture, forcing auto makers to discount cars to sell them all.
*Most auto makers are aggressively cutting production costs, and are being forced by the competition to pass along part or all of those savings to customers.
*The strong dollar has allowed Asian and European auto makers to ship cars and car parts more cheaply to the United States, allowing these companies to be particularly aggressive in setting prices.
*Industry sales have slowed from the torrid pace in January, February and March, at least partly because many affluent households have already bought a new car or two in the last year and do not need another.
The seeds of the current discount war were sown last fall, when Japanese auto makers introduced new models that were less expensive to produce and when the dollar was appreciating sharply against the yen.
Reluctant at first to cut suggested retail prices, Japanese auto makers began offering temporary rebates, low-rate loans and subsidized leases on a scale they had never tried before. Some Nissan dealers, using a variety of discounts, began offering leases on small pickups as low as $99 a month. One exception to the sales incentives has been the Toyota Camry, for which the suggested retail price dropped $900 and which soon became America's best-selling sedan.
Detroit's Big Three initially ignored all these deals, then grew alarmed as their market shares began to erode. Over the last several months they have offered a succession of generous deals, like the $1,500 rebates on the 1997 Buick Park Avenue, Ford Mustang convertible and Eagle Vision TSi. The discounting is all the more remarkable because spring is normally the industry's selling season, when millions of Americans are preparing for summer vacations and are more willing to pay full price.
"It's reflective of an increasingly competitive environment which is aided by a still-undervalued yen," said W. Van Bussmann, the Chrysler Corporation's top economist.
James E. Press, a senior vice president at Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc., played down the yen's importance. With so many factories turning out cars, "there's more capacity chasing the customers that are out there," he said, while adding that "the late-model used cars are competing with the new cars."
Only European auto makers, benefiting from already high sales, have remained largely aloof from the fray, although Volvo has offered a few discounts.
So cutthroat has the competition become that when the General Motors Corporation came out with a new line of mini-vans early this year, Chrysler, which has dominated this market for more than a decade, immediately cut prices on its own mini-vans to keep G.M. from getting a bigger foothold.
Some Wall Street analysts have already reduced their estimates of industry earnings this year, but auto executives contend that this is premature. The spending on rebates and other discounts coincides with a variety of cost-cutting moves and with a general reduction in discounts offered to fleet buyers, like rental car companies, said Lloyd E. Hansen, Ford's controller for marketing and sales.
"We don't see the money we're spending really having much impact on our financial results," Mr. Hansen said. Ford's marketing costs, including retail and fleet incentives, have inched up to 8.5 percent of revenues this year from 8 percent last year, and have been higher in the past.
One reason the record discounts are nearly invisible is that auto makers emphasize them less in advertising these days, having concluded that loud talk of rock-bottom prices only cheapens a brand. The discounts have also become so widely and continuously available that some customers take them for granted.
Fred Peavy, a 38-year-old software consultant in Houston, questioned whether incentives encouraged people to run out and buy cars. "I don't think it makes a difference any more," he said.

HEADLINE: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
After considering evidence that growth is slowing from its torrid pace early in the year, the Federal Reserve decided today to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that the economy could continue to enjoy low unemployment without inflation.
The decision had been widely expected among economists and investors, who argued that there was no justification for raising rates when the economy was cooling and there were no signs of substantial price increases. 
 As is its custom when it leaves rates unchanged, the central bank's policy-making committee gave no explanation for its decision after completing its two-day meeting this afternoon. It last raised rates in March, near the end of a quarter in which the economy grew 5.9 percent, when the Fed raised its target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, to 5.5 percent from 5.25 percent.
But Fed officials undoubtedly debated the conundrum of the day: Why the economy, now in its seventh year of expansion, is no longer following the old rule that mixing strong growth and low unemployment inevitably leads employers to push up wages and then pass along the costs in the form of higher prices to consumers.
"I don't think they understand -- and I certainly don't understand -- how we could have sustained growth for this long with no evidence of inflationary pressures," said Joseph Liro, an economist at CIBC Wood Gundy, an investment firm. "Whatever is happening, it's wonderful, and they understand that the Fed has no mandate to upset an apple cart that is moving along nicely and is stocked with very nice apples."
The Fed's decision to leave rates unchanged helped start a rally in the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 73.05 points to close at 7,795.38, with most of the increase coming after the Fed announcement. Bond prices also edged higher for the day, although most of the gain came before the Fed statement.
The Fed is next scheduled to meet on Aug. 19, and some analysts say that any signs that growth is speeding up again or that unemployment is dipping below its current 4.8 percent rate may lead the Fed to raise rates by a notch then, even if there are no concrete signs of rising inflation.
Today's decision was announced after the Commerce Department reported that orders placed with factories declined somewhat more than expected in May, the latest sign that growth was moderating to a more sustainable pace.
Orders fell by seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted level of $323.3 billion, after rising 1.4 percent in April. The April figure was revised upward from 1.2 percent.
The department said shipments fell 1 percent in May and that the level of unfulfilled orders was unchanged.
The first major indicator of the economy's strength in June will be issued on Thursday, when the Labor Department will report the month's unemployment rate and the number of jobs created.
To some degree, the economy's deceleration was helped by a rise in the long-term interest rates set in the bond market this spring after the Fed raised short-term rates. But long-term rates have dropped in the last month, and it is unclear whether they will continue to act as a brake on growth, especially with consumers reporting high levels of confidence about their economic prospects.
Since the beginning of last year, growth has averaged 3.7 percent, far above the 2.25 percent range that most Fed officials consider the economy's "speed limit." At the same time, unemployment has fallen steadily, and at its current level it is well below the point at which wage pressures have historically tended to accelerate.
But while increases in wages are picking up somewhat, most measures of inflation have shown absolutely no increase in inflation at the consumer or producer level, and business executives say they are continuing to offset wage increases by cutting other costs rather than by raising prices.
The cost-conscious business environment plus other factors like a squeeze on health care costs, productivity improvements from investments in technology and a temporary surge in the growth of the labor force have convinced some economists that the economy is capable of sustaining growth rates of well above 2.25 percent without igniting inflation.
"Since we believe the U.S. economy's noninflationary growth potential to be at least 3 percent a year, we don't see any pickup in inflation," Bruce Steinberg, Merrill Lynch's chief economist, said in a report today that predicted growth in the second half of 2.5 percent or slightly higher.
"But with the unemployment rate at 4.8 percent, the Fed will be hyper-sensitive to any signs of labor market excess, so every monthly employment report risks provoking a response from the Fed," Mr. Steinberg said.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1768 words

HEADLINE: Fakes Blot A Nation's Good Names;
In Italy's Piracy Culture, Black Market Is Thriving

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: ROME, July 2

 BODY:
In February, the Italian police raided leather workshops in Milan, Florence and parts of Tuscany, confiscating thousands of bags with brand names like Chanel, Prada and Dior marked for export to Spain, Switzerland and countries as far afield as Japan.
The bags were not cheap rip-offs. Many were indistinguishable from the genuine article. And for good reason: The same craftsmen who lovingly stitched together the originals for the luxury market were in many cases churning out bootleg copies on the side for the black market. 
 For decades, Italian luxury-goods makers have had to fight a flood of counterfeits made in Asian factories -- a nuisance, but not a real threat because the shoddy quality of the bogus handbags, shoes, shirts and scarves gave them away to discerning eyes. Increasingly, though, industrial piracy is taking root at home, with the unnerving result that one of the most skilled sectors of the Italian economy is now competing against itself on world markets.
That is because most Italian luxury-goods companies farm out production to small, specialist workshops scattered throughout the countryside. And the temptation for some of these outfits to cheat on their corporate partners can be overwhelming. "I make a thousand bags and put them on the books," said Nicola Cerrato, the chief anti-piracy prosecutor in Milan, mocking their attitude, "and another thousand, no."
Actually, Italy's leather-making artisans are only joining a national pastime -- skirting bothersome laws to make a fast, tax-free buck. In Italy itself, an enormous market for pirated goods of all kinds has sprung up, rivaling those in East Asian countries like Taiwan and Thailand. This underground bazaar offers up everything from fake Gucci bags and belts to illegal copies of American software, music recordings and books. Experts estimate the size of the illegal commerce at $6 billion a year and growing. "The revenues in this business are becoming enormous," Mr. Cerrato said.
Much of the pressure to crack down on the counterfeiting is coming from the United States. Software companies, mainly American, lose an estimated $350 million a year in Italy because of piracy: the music industry, also heavily American, says it loses $100 million.
The office of the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, keeps Italy on its watch list -- a formal notification of Washington's displeasure that can lead to economic sanctions if trade offenses are not addressed.
In a report published in April, Ms. Barshefsky praised the Italians for stepping up efforts against piracy in the last year but urged a stiffening of penalties, which she said were "among the lowest in Europe." The maximum punishment, three years in prison and a $4,000 fine, compares with five years and an unlimited fine in Germany and six years and $77,000 in Spain.
The counterfeit trade thrives in a culture that winks at breaking rules and regulations. Lorenzo Mazza, the head of the Federation Against Musical Piracy, a trade organization in Milan, said that most Italians do not think twice about infringing some faraway corporation's trademark, patent or copyright.
"People copy software; people copy books; they don't pay television fees," Mr. Mazza said. "It's a society of shrewdies. If you can get something without paying for it, you do."
The dynamics of Italian business also make counterfeiting an easy game, according to Salvatore Casillo, a professor of industrial sociology at the University of Salerno. More than most European countries, Italy remains a nation of entrepreneurs, giving counterfeiters a vast potential supply of nimble and imaginative partners in crime.
The professor, who heads the Institute for the Study of Fakes at the university, said that pirate manufacturers were often "not true companies," but shifting alliances of investors and manufacturers. "There may be three or four people, and each puts in 50 million lire," or about $30,000, he said. "They purchase the raw materials, and contact willing craftsmen."
"They invented just-in-time" inventory, he added with a laugh. "They have no warehouses, and maybe 20 points of sale."
Counterfeiting has become so widespread that it anchors some local economies. According to Professor Casillo, its prevalence helps explain why some areas with high official unemployment, like Naples, have escaped social unrest: Many jobs exist that are not on anybody's books.
Francesco Zerilli, a police officer who oversees anti-piracy raids in Rome, offers the example of a criminal ring there, cracked earlier this year, that made black market watches bearing brand names like Bulgari, Rolex and Cartier. A circle of financiers commissioned the manufacture of cheaper, imitation parts, often from trained jewelers. The timepieces were then assembled in abandoned villas on the edge of Rome, delivered to legitimate jewelry shops for a fraction of the cost of "la cosa genuina" -- the real thing -- and sold to unwitting customers at supposedly bargain prices.
Mr. Zerilli said that in just the four months it operated, the ring pulled in between $3.5 million and $4.5 million. And the jewelry shops, which paid $300 or so for watches that retail for $2,500 or more, made a lot of money even after selling them at huge "discounts" from the prices for legitimate goods.
Similar manufacturing networks exist for shoes, handbags or luggage, he added. In Milan, workshops even use cheap Chinese labor to assemble the final products.
In Rome, pirated leather goods, sunglasses and other accessories are hawked openly. The peddlers, usually illegal immigrants from Africa, line up along the entrance to the subway station at Piazza di Spagna or along the bridge that leads across the Tiber to the huge Castel Sant'Angelo, the papal fortress. Occasionally, the arrival of a pair of patrolmen sets them flying in all directions, like pigeons shooed by cats.
Designer houses are loath to discuss the problem for fear of tarnishing their products' image and damaging the bonds of trust they have established with the craftsmen they rely on.
A Gucci Group executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity for those reasons, acknowledged that the "most problematic aspect" of piracy today is the emergence of black markets for Italian-made luxury goods in East Asia, Japan and the United States. The counterfeits, the official said with a note of exasperation, "are identical products, not of low quality."
Still, some legitimate businesses are starting to fight back. Raids like the one in February are increasing, and fashion houses are working closely with customs officials around the world to seize unauthorized shipments. In 1993, the Government in Rome established teams of specialized anti-piracy prosecutors in major cities like Milan, Florence, Rome and Naples. At the same time, legislation was enacted by which Italy put into effect European Union norms against intellectual piracy. Now fresh legislation is being debated in Parliament to stiffen criminal penalties.
Giuseppe Corasaniti, the chief anti-piracy prosecutor in Rome, said that recent law enforcement efforts have scared away many traditional investors in black-market ventures, with the perverse effect that organized crime is getting into the act.
"Through extortion and drugs, new capital is flowing, and they're investing in new technologies," he said. "Three years ago, we never found computers in Mafia hideouts. Now we find laptops."
Yet the software business illustrates how legislation can make a difference. In the early 1990's, according to estimates, more than 90 percent of the software used in Italy was pirated. Large corporations like the Montedison chemicals group, major banks, and even Government agencies like the national highway authority failed to pay license fees. But lobbying by software producers forced Rome to put into effect a 1992 intellectual property ruling from the European Union. Today, the threat of fines and even jail has brought the theft rate down to 55 percent.
While that is more than double the rate in America, the progress is real. "The market is understanding the legal risks and the technological risks, like viruses, lack of guarantees, damage to your image," said Nuria Vea, a former Microsoft executive and the president of the Italian branch of the Business Software Alliance, an industry group.
Mr. Mazza's organization, the Federation Against Musical Piracy, was set up last year by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry in London. In April, to emphasize the seriousness of the problem in Italy, the member companies held three days of talks in Rome, highlighted by a rally at which 150,000 pirated tapes and compact disks were destroyed.
Dump trucks heaped the contraband on a piazza atop Rome's Pincian Hill and then, in a carnival atmosphere, Italian rock singers danced on the pile, some whacking at it with hammers. Later, a small steamroller climbed the mound and began crushing the recordings, but skidded and got stuck in the slippery plastic. In the end, the recordings were swept up and carted away.
Despite such efforts, pirated recordings accounted last year for 21.5 percent of the Italian music market. That was down from 33 percent in 1995, but still represented losses to the industry of about $100 million.
Many loopholes exist. San Marino, the tiny republic in central Italy, belongs neither to the European Union nor to the World Trade Organization, so the absence of anti-piracy laws has made it a musical pirates' cove. Earlier this year, when a grand jury in Florida indicted 13 members of a ring accused of smuggling bootleg compact disks into the United States, the trail led through San Marino. One of the accused was Italian, and two were citizens of San Marino.
Some law enforcement officials say they are up against an unsympathetic public, which tends to view counterfeiters as modern-day Robin Hoods pitted against deep-pocketed corporations like the Walt Disney Company or Gianfranco Ferre, the Italian luxury fashion designer. "People say, 'Why are you protecting Disney and Ferre, and antagonizing kids who are just playing games?' " said Mr. Corasaniti, the Rome prosecutor.
What they don't realize, he said, is how badly piracy burns the consumer. Each year, Mr. Corasaniti noted as an example, the cloning of cellular phone chips alone costs consumers of the phone chips that were duplicated at least $18 million, and the practice is spreading. He warned it would be an uphill fight.
"It's like emptying the sea with a cognac glass," he said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1378 words

HEADLINE: Blair Gains Tax Cut for Business, But the Rest of Britain Must Wait

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: LONDON, July 2

 BODY:
The new Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair gained passage of its first budget in Parliament today, giving top priority to a tax cut that will give British big business the lowest tax rate of any Western industrial country.
In that way, business was reassured by the governing Labor Party that it would remain the locomotive of an expanding economy, while the middle class waits for tax relief and the working class fares only a little better. Indeed, many people will find they are paying more in indirect taxes under the new budget and getting less in tax relief for things like mortagage payments. 
 It was the first budget drawn up by a Labor Government in 18 years, and it set Britain further apart from countries like Germany and France, which are still struggling with pugnacious unions, restrictive investment climates and expensive welfare benefits.
Echoing themes often heard in the United States and among adherents of a global economy, Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown told Parliament that old jobs, old skills and old industries "have gone and will never return." Instead, he said, the road to a better future lies in fiscal discipline and strict control of inflation as the only means to achieving "stability, investment, work and opportunity for all."
The budget included a windfall tax on profits from privatized utilities, with the proceeds to go toward retraining workers displaced from their jobs during the Conservative Government that Labor defeated. This was one of Labor's central promises during the election campaign.
Still, the budget's overall emphasis was striking for how little it differed from that of former Prime Minister John Major and the Tories.
As Labor also promised in its campaign, Britain will keep its focus on spurring profits and investments by private business as the keys to global competitiveness, at the expense of new welfare and social spending.
Reaction in the City of London, Britain's financial center, was predictably triumphant.
"It strikes me as a very conservative budget on balance, with an accent on growth," said David Freud, a managing director with the investment firm of SBC Warburg, in an interview after the one-hour budget speech.
"This is very good news for the country because we have got fundamentally two parties now far more like the Democrats and the Republicans, instead of socialists and capitalists."
By far the biggest winners were large businesses, which received a further cut in the top tax rate charged on their profits from 33 percent to 31 percent. The comparable rate in the United States is 35 percent.
Small businesses will see their tax rates lowered from 23 percent to 21 percent. Capital allowances for buying equipment were doubled on plants and machinery in the first year of new businesses. The British film industry will get tax breaks amounting to nearly $50 million over the next three years.
And in a step meant to increase investments, the new budget immediately abolished an estimated $4.8 billion in tax credits previously allowed on dividends paid on pension funds. This is intended to force companies to plow the money back into their business activities, instead of paying them out as dividends.
The new budget included a variety of indirect taxes on gasoline, liquor and cigarettes and a cut in tax benefits on mortgages and private health plans. These will be shouldered largely by the middle class, which will have to await an even stronger economy before getting any tax breaks.
There were a few nods to the hard-pressed working class, in the form of more money for training the unemployed and for education in general, but they were coupled with a further tightening of welfare benefits. With nearly 300,000 people enrolled in largely ineffective training programs over the past few years, the move was seen as more symbolic than practical.
Labor set the tone for its business-oriented policies within days of taking office two months ago, when it freed the Bank of England to control inflation by raising interest rates without consulting the Government. Since then Mr. Brown has come to be popularly known as the Iron Chancellor, a man who delivers tough remedies wrapped in velvet words.
He displayed that style in his address today, with his mixed pro-business message and ackowledgment of Labor's traditional egalitarian values. "The central purpose of this budget is to insure that Britain is equipped to rise to the challenge of the new and fast-changing global economy," he said, adding that benefits should include "not just a few of us, but everyone".
The Chancellor, who ranks second in power to Mr. Blair, stressed that the Government's primary concern was to preserve the momentum created, in effect, by the Tories' policies of austerity and limited spending.
In fact, those policies fell hard on the poor and the working class, which bore the brunt of downsizing and cuts in welfare, even while they enabled Britain to achieve the lowest unemployment level in Europe.
On the Continent, average unemployment hovers between 10 percent and 16 percent of the work force and growth has slowed in the past few years. By contrast, Britain has a jobless level that hovers around 6.5 percent and the country is expected to reach a growth rate this year of 4 percent of gross domestic product. Inflation is about 2.5 percent.
Mr. Brown's message was that this situation is not good enough. Warning that consumer spending is galloping ahead of new investment and savings, he said the Government would raise some $9.1 billion in new taxes this year and about $7.6 billion next year to cool down the economy.
"I will not ignore the warning signs and I will not repeat past mistakes," Mr. Brown said, adding to Tory jeers in Parliament that "this and future budgets will be addressed to laying the foundations for tomorrow's wealth."
In the budget, Mr. Brown moved to slow down inflation in the housing market by slashing tax breaks allowed on mortgage interest payments from 15 percent to 10 percent and increasing fees paid on the purchase and sale of new houses from 1.5 percent to 2 percent. Tax benefits on private medical care for those 60 years of age and above were abolished because, Mr. Brown said, they had proved ineffective.
In addition, new taxes were imposed on liquor, tobacco, gasoline and diesel fuels; in general they raise prices by less than 10 percent.
To mitigate these measures, which represent a blow of sorts to the middle class and consumers in general, Mr. Brown said sales taxes, known here as VAT, or value added tax, would be lowered on fuel and power from 8 percent to 5 percent.
He also disclosed a tax on privatized utilities based on the vast profits they made by moving from the public sector to the private sector in the past four years. It will bring the Government a total of about $7.6 billion to be paid in two installments this year and next year.
The tax was a principal part of the Labor Party's election platform. The money will be used in a welfare reform program aimed primarily at strengthening retraining programs for hundreds of thousands of long-term unemployed -- victims of the significant revamping undergone by the British economy in the past decade, under Conservative leadership, when heavy industries collapsed and new service industries requiring different skills and paying lower salaries took their places.
Among other welfare reforms announced today was a reshuffle of benefits designed to subsidize firms that hire some of the unemployed. There was also increased financial support for single working parents and benefits designed to push youngsters to take jobs that become available instead of relying on unemployment benefits.
But under the new rules, benefits will be cut if those opportunities are spurned.
There is considerable doubt that such programs and appeals to corporations to live up to their civic duty by hiring the hard-core unemployed can work. The programs have existed for some time without significantly alleviating unemployment among the hardest-hit sectors of society, and appeals to corporate generosity in France and Germany have failed to alter the status of those left behind by globalization.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 2835 words

HEADLINE: James Stewart, the Hesitant Hero, Dies at 89

 BODY:
James Stewart, whose movie portrayals of decent, idealistic and naive small-town Americans made him a beloved national icon, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 89.
He died from a blood clot in his lung, The Associated Press reported. 
 Mr. Stewart's performances in some 80 movies earned him every major award bestowed for his craft, and consistent acclaim and popularity for more than half a century. He was the last of that rare breed of male stars whose careers certified the star system as it operated virtually from the beginning of the sound era. Actors like Mr. Stewart, Spencer Tracy, Gary Cooper, Clark Gable, Cary Grant, John Wayne and Henry Fonda were larger than life, and because the fusion of the performers' public and private personalities created something bigger than the sum of the two parts, something mythical.
The lanky actor with unruly hair and an ungainly stride had a boyish grin and an engaging manner. The Stewart way of speaking -- laconic, with a hesitant, nasal drawl -- is instantly recognizable by virtually every American. His early screen image, like his personal life, epitomized a Middle American ideal in a confusing, sophisticated world.
"America lost a national treasure today," President Clinton said yesterday. "Jimmy Stewart was a great actor, a gentleman and a patriot."
His archetypal role (and his own favorite) was that of George Bailey, the small-town banker in "It's a Wonderful Life," Frank Capra's moralistic fantasy in which the hero is rescued from suicide by a pixieish angel who shows him how much meaner life would have been in his hometown without him. The 1946 feature-length Christmas card was a failure among audiences, who dismissed it as overly sentimental, but in later decades it became one of the most popular movies ever made and a holiday staple on television.
After viewing "It's a Wonderful Life," President Harry S. Truman concluded, "If Bess and I had a son, we'd want him to be just like Jimmy Stewart."
But, as Mr. Stewart matured, the diffident innocents he played in the late 1930's and 40's gave way to more subtle and complicated roles -- troubled, querulous protagonists torn between firmness and vulnerability, roles in conflict with his accepted image.
Mr. Stewart's subtle and seemingly effortless work prompted the critic Vincent Canby of The New York Times to hail him in 1990 as a great behavioral actor who absorbed each role into his own physical frame, shaping the mannerisms, the voice and even the intelligence to coincide with those of his own persona. "This he does with such simplicity and ease that, for many years, the initial response was to say that what he does isn't acting, followed up by the damp, desperate criticism that he is always the same," Mr. Canby said.
The roles for which he was best remembered include a naively heroic young senator in "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" (1939), a part that earned him major stardom; a forthright reporter redeeming a headstrong heiress (Katharine Hepburn) in "The Philadelphia Story" (1940) and a relentless defense attorney in "Anatomy of a Murder" (1959).
Also in the Stewart gallery of folk heroes were a gun-shy marshal who tamed a town -- and Marlene Dietrich -- in "Destry Rides Again" (1939); Monty Stratton, the Chicago White Sox pitcher who returned to the mound after losing a leg, in "The Stratton Story" (1949); a beloved big-band leader in "The Glenn Miller Story" (1954) and Charles A. Lindbergh, a boyhood hero, in his solitary 1927 trans-Atlantic flight in "The Spirit of St. Louis" (1957).
 
Ungainly, Self-Effacing And Somehow Debonair
Later in his career, a tougher, more worldly Stewart emerged in such Anthony Mann westerns as "Winchester '73," "The Far Country," "Bend of the River," "The Naked Spur" and "The Man From Laramie." Alfred Hitchcock used him against type in such films as "Rope" and "The Man Who Knew Too Much" and especially as a voyeur photographer in "Rear Window" and as a retired detective entranced by two forms of a mythic Kim Novak in "Vertigo."
When interviewed about his techniques, the self-effacing actor replied characteristically, "I don't act, I react," and described himself as an "inarticulate man who tries," without having "all the answers, but for some reason, somehow, I make it." He offered his criterion for success: "If you can do a part and not have the acting show."
His modest appraisal was challenged by Donna Reed, his co-star in "It's a Wonderful Life." "He's so natural, so realistic, that I never knew whether he was talking to me or doing the scene" she observed. "He's the most demanding actor I've ever worked with."
Joan Crawford, another co-star, praised Mr. Stewart as an "endearing perfectionist" with "a droll sense of humor and a shy way of watching you to see if you react to that humor."
Weighing Mr. Stewart's work opposite such matchless actresses as Margaret Sullavan in Ernst Lubitsch's "Shop Around the Corner," Jean Arthur in Capra's "Mr. Smith," Ms. Hepburn in George Cukor's "Philadelphia Story," Marlene Dietrich in George Marshall's "Destry Rides Again" and Grace Kelly in "Rear Window," Mr. Canby said: he "reveals a quality that at first seems out of sync with the shy, stammering personality favored by nightclub imitators. He is debonair. He has the same humor and lightness of touch that Fred Astaire expresses only through dance. Mr. Stewart is debonair when dousing Miss Dietrich and Una Merkel with a bucketful of water ('Destry Rides Again') or confined to a wheelchair with one leg in a plaster cast ('Rear Window'). He is debonair even when wrestling with terrible guilt and a sense of loss in 'Vertigo.' Also like Astaire when he dances, Mr. Stewart is best seen on the screen in full figure, with all of the lean 6-foot-3 1/2-inch man captured in a single frame. He acts with his whole body. The slight stoop and the way his wrinkled jacket hangs from his shoulders are as integral to his performance in 'Harvey' as any of playwright Mary Chase's lines."
 
As Best Friend To an Invisible Rabbit
One of the actor's most admired performances was that of the gently eccentric tippler Elwood P. Dowd in "Harvey," whose companion was the title character, a giant, invisible rabbit. The actor played the film role in 1950 after appearing in the whimsical comedy on Broadway in 1947, then played the role again in a triumphant 1970 revival in New York and London that co-starred Helen Hayes.
Mr. Stewart appeared in half a dozen Broadway plays and in occasional television dramas. Also on television, he starred in two of his own series in the early 1970's, first as a family patriarch and college professor in "The Jimmy Stewart Show," a bucolic sitcom, and then as "Hawkins," a shrewd country lawyer.
Mr. Stewart received the American Film Institute's eighth life-achievement award in 1980, a Kennedy Center Honor in 1983 for lifetime contributions to the performing arts, a special 1984 Academy Award for "50 years of meaningful performances, for his high ideals, both on and off the screen," a 1985 Presidential Medal of Freedom, which is the nation's highest civilian honor, and the 1990 annual tribute by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
In receiving the honorary Oscar to a standing ovation, Mr. Stewart singled out for special thanks Capra and other directors "who so generously and brilliantly guided me through the no man's land of my own good intentions." He had also won an Academy Award for the best performance by an actor in 1940 for "The Philadelphia Story" and four other Oscar nominations, for "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington," "It's a Wonderful Life," "Harvey" and "Anatomy of a Murder." Among many other honors were film festival and critics' citations, a Tony Award and the 1968 Screen Actors Guild Award for "fostering the finest ideals of the acting profession."
Young performers, he believed, should start on the stage and get as much theater experience as they can in stock companies and road shows. Adapting to a live audience, he advised, is an actor's toughest hurdle.
After getting his professional start on Broadway, he honed his craft in Hollywood's big-studio era of the 1930's and 40's, whose leaders he credited with great judgment, the courage to take chances and deep affection for movie-making. The studio system, he said, was "a wonderful training ground for actors and actresses."
"I came out here as a contract player at MGM, and I went to work every day," he said. "It might be a big part in a little picture, or a little part in a big picture. You learned your craft by working at it. You crawled before you walked."
Early on, Jimmy Stewart became a symbol of patriotism as the first top Hollywood actor to enter the service in World War II. Determined to become a combat pilot, he first logged 300 hours of flying because at the age of 33 he was too old to be an aviation cadet. He put on 10 pounds to meet the Army's minimum weight requirement for his tall, thin frame.
Mr. Stewart was inducted in March 1941, nine months before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and the United States' entry into the war. He qualified quickly as a pilot. Assigned to the Second Combat Wing of the Eighth Air Force in England, he was successively the operations officer, chief of staff and squadron commander.
He eventually led 20 bombing missions over Germany, hitting targets in Bremen, Frankfurt and Berlin. He won a cascade of decorations, including the Distinguished Flying Cross twice, one of them for piloting the lead plane in a spectacular raid on key aircraft factories in Brunswick, Germany. He also received the Air Medal, a succession of oak leaf clusters, six battle stars and the Croix de Guerre with Palm.
When the war ended he was mustered out a colonel but remained in the Air Force Reserve and, in 1959, the Senate approved his promotion to brigadier general, making him the highest-ranking entertainer in the American military. He retired from the Reserve in 1968.
After a long tenure as Hollywood's most eligible bachelor, Mr. Stewart was married in 1949, at the age of 41, to Gloria Hatrick McLean, a former model. They lived for decades in a Tudor-style house in Beverly Hills, at first with two boys, Ronald and Michael, from Mrs. Stewart's previous marriage, and then with their own twin girls, who were born in 1951. First Lieut. Ronald W. McLean was killed in Vietnam in 1969. Mrs. Stewart died in 1994. Mr. Stewart is survived by his other stepson, Michael, of Phoenix, and his daughters, Judy Merrill of San Francisco and Kelly Harcourt of Davis, Calif.
The actor was born James Maitland Stewart on May 20, 1908, in the western Pennsylvania town of Indiana, to Alexander Stewart and the former Elizabeth Ruth Jackson, who were of Scotch-Irish descent. The Stewart family had owned and managed a prosperous hardware store for half a century, and his father served in both the Spanish-American War and World War I.
Jimmy and his two younger sisters, Mary and Virginia, were taught the value of responsibility, prudence and frugality. When not doing chores, the spindly, spectacled youth wrote and staged plays and played the accordion.
At prep school, the Mercersburg Academy in south-central Pennsylvania, he went out for football, track, dramatics and music. During summer vacations he was a construction laborer. Then, at Princeton, he joined the Triangle Club, rising quickly from accordionist to leading roles in musicals. He graduated in 1932 with a bachelor's degree in architecture.
 
A Career Alternative To Architecture
The Depression era offered little demand for architects, so he tested his avocation, accepting an invitation from a college friend, Joshua Logan, to join the University Players at Falmouth, Mass., on Cape Cod. The summer stock company included Henry Fonda, who was to become a lifelong friend even though Mr. Stewart was a conservative Republican and Fonda a fervently liberal Democrat. The friendship endured, Mr. Stewart said in 1983, because "50 years ago we agreed not to discuss politics."
Mr. Stewart won his first major role on Broadway in 1934, as a gallant soldier-guinea pig in "Yellow Jack," Sidney Howard's drama about research on yellow fever, and then played a youth stunned by the adultery of his mother (Judith Anderson) in "Divided by Three." Brooks Atkinson of The New York Times acclaimed the neophyte's performance as "a minor masterpiece."
In 1935 he won a contract with MGM, where he made his feature debut as a cub reporter in "The Murder Man." The crime melodrama starred Spencer Tracy, who spotted the newcomer's tenseness, told him to "forget the camera is there," and later recalled how "that was all he needed; in his very first scene he showed he had all the good things."
Mr. Stewart's intelligent, deceptively casual acting in two dozen movies over the next five years earned him stardom. Among these early films, mostly comedies and romantic dramas, were "Wife vs. Secretary," "Born to Dance" (in which he struggled gamely to sing Cole Porter's "Easy to Love" to Eleanor Powell), "Vivacious Lady," "The Shopworn Angel," "You Can't Take It With You," "Made for Each Other" and "No Time for Comedy."
Returning from war in late 1945, Mr. Stewart insisted that his military exploits not be publicized. He avoided studio contracts and freelanced, earning increasingly high salaries and becoming a pioneer of the percentage deal, under which he reportedly received up to half the profits of his movies.
On screen, he shook off his country-boy manner and assumed a new persona, a complex, sometimes cryptic image that was shaped in collaborations in the 1950's and 60's with directors like Hitchcock, Mr. Mann and John Ford. The actor played a cold bounty hunter in Mr. Mann's "Naked Spur" (1953), a dedicated reporter in "Call Northside 777" (1948), a clown wanted for murder in "The Greatest Show on Earth" (1952), the photographer turned sleuth in Hitchcock's "Rear Window" (1954), the obsessive romantic in Hitchcock's "Vertigo" (1958) and a cynical marshal in Ford's "Two Rode Together" (1961).
 
Stumping for Reagan And Other Conservatives
Other later movies included "Broken Arrow," "The Far Country," "Strategic Air Command," "The F.B.I. Story," "How the West Was Won," "The Flight of the Phoenix" and "The Shootist," a 1976 valedictory to the career of a longtime friend, John Wayne.
Mr. Stewart shunned publicity, but was invariably good-humored with interviewers. In later years, he was a leading spokesman for conservative political and economic causes and a frequent campaigner for Republican political friends like Richard M. Nixon, and Ronald Reagan.
One of Hollywood's most astute businessmen, he became a multimillionaire, with diversified investments including real estate, oil wells, a charter-plane company and membership on major corporate boards.
On television he appeared in commercials for several years for Firestone tires under a contract said to be worth $1 million. Questioned about it, a spokesman said Mr. Stewart had "warm personal relations with the Firestone family" and admiration for their charitable gifts. In the late 1980's and early 90's, his grandfatherly inflections were heard on commercials for Campbell's Home Cookin' Soups.
In 1989, the actor broke into print with "Jimmy Stewart and His Poems," a 32-page book of verse that became a best seller. In later years Mr. Stewart became an advocate of protecting and preserving classic American movies against computerized coloring or re-editing for television. In 1988, he testified before Congress on behalf of a bill that later established a national panel to designate major films for conspicuous labeling to alert the public that they had been colored or otherwise altered.
His favorite movies were westerns, he said, "because they're told against the background of a very dramatic period in our history" and "give people a feeling of hope, an affirmative statement of living."
As he approached his 80th birthday, he was asked how he wanted to be remembered. As someone, he said, who "believed in hard work and love of country, love of family and love of community."
 
Mr. Smith Went To Hollywood
James Stewart made more than 80 films, ranging from frothy comedies to westerns and dramas of suspense. These are among the most memorable.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stock Rally Pushes Some Indexes to Records
The stock market surged as the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady helped lift some secondary indexes into record territory but left the Dow Jones industrial average just short of a new high.
The Dow ended up 73.05 points, at 7,795.38, which was just below its record close of 7,796.51 on June 20. [Page D7.] 

G.M. Sales Are Down Sharply
General Motors said that its sales fell 13.3 percent last month, leaving the auto industry on track to end the second quarter with a whimper, after a stellar first quarter. [D6.]
 
Warnings on an H.I.V. Test
In the months before a Johnson & Johnson unit removed a home H.I.V. test from the market, Federal regulators issued stern directives to the company to clean up its quality control procedures, Government records show. [D4.]
 
Air Rules Leave Residue of Confusion
The new limits on smog and on emissions of fine particles of soot that were announced by the Clinton Administration appear to be generating more anxiety than anger in American industry. Few companies say they have the vaguest idea what the standards might mean for their operations. Still, it appears that utilities in the Midwest and South are likely to bear the brunt. [D2.]
 
Despite strong lobbying by business, the new rules were not softened from the proposals. But they will be applied in flexible ways, with oceans of time to adjust.
Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
German Progress on Digital TV
Germany's troubled efforts to introduce digital television got a big lift as the main cable provider made peace with the two biggest entertainment companies. [D4.]
 
AT&T and Stet of Italy in Pact
AT&T and Stet, the Italian phone company, announced an agreement to cooperate in Latin America and Europe. [D3.]
 
Implant Negotiations Proceed
A judge has overturned a ruling in the Dow Corning bankruptcy case that had threatened to unravel months of negotiations by requiring the appointment of a new committee to negotiate on behalf of women claiming damages for injuries from the company's breast implants. [A16.]
 
Tax Cut for British Business
British big business will have the lowest tax ceiling of any Western industrial nation, after the new Labor Government gained passage in Parliament of its first budget. [A1.]
 
The pound rose against the dollar after details of the budget emerged. Traders said the budget did not appear to go far enough in curbing growth, leaving the door open for an increase in interest rates that would benefit the pound. [D5.]
 
'Safe' Smoke: Now More Likely?
Supporters of the proposed tobacco settlement say it could help bring about so-called safer cigarettes, long an objective of anti-smoking advocates and industry researchers, though not necessarily of tobacco executives. [A16.]
 
2 Retailers Name Ad Agencies
Activity on advertising accounts is accelerating again, with marketers like Barnes & Noble and Wal-Mart Stores among the latest to make decisions regarding their agencies. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]
 
Companion Fare for Youngest Fliers
American Airlines said that it would offer a 50 percent discount on fares for children under 2, a move that was matched by other airlines and that offers a new choice for parents who must decide whether to buy an extra seat for their babies or hold them on their laps. [A16.]

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Limited NATO Expansion Gets France's Blessing
France said it would go along with President Clinton's wish to limit NATO expansion to Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. But it reiterated its opinion that Romania and Slovenia fulfilled the conditions for joining the alliance. A1 

Labor Party Cuts British Taxes
Britain's Parliament approved the first budget of the new Labor Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair, prompting cheers from the business community. A corporate tax cut will give big businesses the lowest tax rate in any Western industrial country. A1
 
Six I.R.A. Members Convicted
Six men, one of them an American citizen, were convicted of being part of an Irish Republican Army plot to bomb electrical power stations in England. Each was sentenced to 35 years in prison. They were found last year with plans and equipment for what prosecutors said was intended to be the I.R.A.'s biggest operation ever on the British mainland. A5
 
Albanian Clings to Power
Sali Berisha refused to step down as Albania's President, ignoring his own promise to resign after his party lost elections. Nonetheless, he said he looked forward to being in the opposition. He also called for armed forces to encircle Tirana. Various armed groups prowled around the city, some of them temporarily surrounding the offices of Bashkim Fino, the Socialist Prime Minister. A8
 
Housing on Hong Kong Agenda
In his first press conference as Chief Executive of Hong Kong, Tung Chee-hwa warned that rising property prices jeopardized the city's competitive edge as a regional business center. A poll published in a local newspaper found 78 percent of Hong Kong residents in favor of the Government taking steps to bring down real estate prices, which have jumped by 30 percent just since the beginning of this year. A10
 
Big Oil Spill in Tokyo Bay
A tanker ran aground in Tokyo Bay, causing a major oil spill. More than 130 ships were mobilized to clean up hundreds of thousands of gallons of crude oil. The ship, Diamond Grace, was refloated and arrived at its original destination, a refinery near Tokyo. The ship is registered in Panama but is owned by Japan's largest shipping company. Officials suspected that human error caused the accident, which happened in an area known for its shallow waters. A3
 
C.I.A. Issues Weapons Report
A new report issued by the Central Intelligence Agency named China and Russia as the two biggest exporters of technology used by third-world nations that build ballistic missiles, chemical weapons or nuclear bombs. India, Iran, Pakistan, and Syria were said to be among the top importers of such technology. The report is part of the C.I.A.'s efforts to track the spread of weapons of mass destruction. A10

Kite, according to the Air Force, made two mistakes as supervisor of military police for the 509th bomber wing on Whiteman Air Force Base: he fell in love with Rhonda Kutzer, now a civilian, when she was still in the Air Force, and he initially tried to hide the relationship from superiors. He faces a court-martial and a potential prison sentence of up to 14 years. A1

No Risk Seen in Power Lines
A large study has found no evidence that electric power lines cause leukemia in children, researchers said. The study was a collaboration between scientists at the National Cancer Institute and childhood leukemia specialists from the nation's leading medical centers. A1

A new study casts doubt on the safety of inhaled steroids as a mainstay of medical treatment for asthma, suggesting for the first time that they may cause cataracts. Experts were quick to warn, however, that patients should not stop using inhalers, which are effective in reducing the airway inflammation that can lead to fatal asthma attacks. A17

HEADLINE: Assisted Suicide Decision Looms in Florida

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 2

 BODY:
After the Supreme Court left it up to individual states to deal with the legal and ethical morass of whether to allow doctor-assisted suicide, few find the stakes higher, the debate richer or the question more immediate than Florida.
The Florida Supreme Court could rule as early as Thursday on the case of Dr. Cecil McIver and Charles E. Hall, a doctor and an AIDS patient who sued the state last year seeking to collaborate on Mr. Hall's death without the risk of criminal prosecution. Earlier this year a Palm Beach County Circuit Court judge sided with the plaintiffs and found that Florida's privacy rights laws outweighed the state's prohibition of "assisting self-murder," a second-degree felony. 
 The same ethical, religious and practical concerns that have made assisted suicide so divisive across the country have appeared in the legal briefs and arguments presented to Florida's highest court, the first such court to review an assisted suicide claim since the United States Supreme Court ruled last week that states may continue to ban the practice. But underlying the issue in Florida is also fear that in a retirement state where about 1 in 5 residents is 65 or older, the potential for abuse is tremendous, pitting countless terminally ill patients and others against the forces of ageism, economic coercion and depression.
"If you legalize assisted suicide in Florida, it'll spread like a wildfire to populations beyond the terminally ill," said H. James Towey, a former Florida health and rehabilitative services director who now heads the Commission on Aging with Dignity, a private group.
"You're talking about the depressed, the chronically ill, people with aches and pains who on any given month may have a bad month," Mr. Towey said. "In a state with a frail safety net for the elderly poor and with people thousands of miles away from family, it'd be a disaster."
Polls have shown strong support among the elderly and other age groups for the taking of life to end the suffering of the dying. But disagreement over physician-assisted suicide is sharp enough that the American Association of Retired Persons has refused to take a stance.
Drew Smith, a senior analyst for the Public Policy Institute at the retired people's association, said that beyond the moral questions, opinions among the elderly were split between empathy for those who want to be released from pain, and anxiety over the new mindset that assisted suicide would bring to the older patient's bedside if doctors, family members and the patients themselves accept a physician's role in hastening death rather than alleviating pain as one more option.
"There's fear of any kind of institutionalization of assisted suicide, that people might feel that somehow it becomes a duty to die," said Mr. Smith, who said that the retired persons' group had chosen to focus on improving the care of the dying.
People 65 and older have the highest rate of suicide among any age group in United States.
In Florida, Mr. Hall's legal arguments for assisted suicide hinge on a state constitutional amendment approved by voters in 1980 that asserts a stronger right of privacy than that offered in the United States Constitution. With few exceptions, the amendment says, "every natural person has the right to be let alone and free from governmental intrusion into his private life." The state Attorney General argues that the amendment never contemplated a privacy right for doctors who assist suicides.
Other states offer similarly broad privacy rights, and legal experts say state supreme courts are likely to become a popular target for constitution-based efforts to legalize assisted suicide.
While the Florida Supreme Court can limit its ruling to Mr. Hall's case, lawyers for the state say a finding for Mr. Hall would inevitably be seen as a precedent and would discourage prosecutions of doctors who aid in suicide. But even if the state court upholds Florida's ban on assisted suicide, both sides expect more litigation and debate.
"The question of the right to die with dignity is not going to die easily no matter what this court does," said Laurence H. Tribe, the Harvard professor of constitutional law who argued before the United States Supreme Court in favor of assisted suicide.
Mr. Hall, 35, a former restaurant owner who said he acquired H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, through a blood transfusion, is still mentally competent, his lawyers say, but he is deteriorating physically. Mr. Hall testified this year at his Palm Beach County trial that although he was not yet ready to die, he wanted Dr. McIver to give him a fatal dose of prescription drugs when he faced only extended suffering. He said that without a doctor's assistance, an attempt on his life could fail and might only worsen or prolong his suffering.
Dr. McIver, 74, a retired Jupiter doctor who is a member of the Hemlock Society, which paired him with Mr. Hall, is not willing to risk prosecution for manslaughter under the current law. But he defends assisted suicide for patients whose lives doctors cannot make tolerable.
"My responsibility to the patient is to do what's in his best interest," Dr. McIver said in an interview. "Usually his best interest is to live. But when it is to die, isn't it my responsibility to help him die?"
But the state Attorney General's office argues that it would be impossible to impose safeguards to limit assisted suicide to the patients for whom it was intended. The difficulties cited include determining mental competence and defining terminal illness, the role of depression in a patient's choice to die, coercion by relatives and fear that cost control factors could enter into the equation in the age of managed care.
The state considers elderly and disabled people the most vulnerable to abuse.
"Fifty percent of Medicare expenses is spent during the last six months of an elderly person's life," said Michael A. Gross, the Assistant Attorney General handling the appeal to the State Supreme Court.
Susan A. MacManus, a professor of political science at the University of South Florida, in Tampa, who is an expert on issues of the elderly, said older Americans might become less supportive of assisted suicide as they become increasingly concerned with cost controls in medical care.
"The growing disgruntlement among the elderly with H.M.O.'s is something that's going to enter into the Florida equation very fast," Ms. MacManus said.
But among about 40 friend-of-the-court briefs in Mr. Hall's case, the only senior citizen group to file one has sided with the patient. Members of the Florida Silver-Haired Legislature, a group that drafts mock bills dealing with concerns of the elderly and then promotes them among real legislators, call the purported danger for abuse "a red herring" for moral and religious arguments.
"It's like saying we shouldn't have money because somebody would steal it," said Monroe W. Treiman, 77, who is the head of the group.
"The elderly are abused for money and everything else," Mr. Treiman said. "But to say because that happens you're going to demand under law that they don't have a relief to get out of life when they want to is thwarting their rights. We say this is completely and absolutely wrong."

HEADLINE: Traffic Reports: Many From Few;
Most Radio News of Roads Comes From 2 Services

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

 BODY:
Let's say it is an early summer afternoon and you want to know why you are idling in comatose traffic near some commuter gantlet like the George Washington Bridge.
You turn on a popular 24-hour news radio station, WINS-AM (1010), and hear a traffic reporter, Matt Ward, tell you that a game at Yankee Stadium is clogging major arteries. Wanting an update minutes later, you change stations, and hear another reporter, Thom Rivers, give a similar report on a major New Jersey talk radio station, WKXW-FM (101.5). 
 Next you might listen to WQXR-FM (96.3), the classical musical station, where Melissa Sperling delivers road news. Spinning across the airwaves, you could hear Melissa Exelberth with a parallel report on a New York talk radio station or, if your Spanish is good enough, you might catch just plain Melissa issuing dire bridge warnings on a Spanish-language station.
To hear the torrent of traffic reports, you might think the metropolitan region is a veritable Tower of Traffic Babel, with competing reporters and helicopters thick as flies buzzing around summer fruit.
You would be wrong.
The vast majority of the area's traffic reports come from just two fiercely competitive sources, Metro Networks in a midtown Fifth Avenue building and Shadow Broadcast Services in an office park in Rutherford, N.J. Together, their 90-plus reporters provide traffic news 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to more than 100 area radio and television stations.
But to make it sound as if each station fields exclusive reports, the Shadow and Metro announcers often use two or three pseudonyms apiece. Some reporters keep their separate names taped next to their control switches for each radio station lest they forget. Mr. Ward said it was WKXW that came up with his pseudonym Thom Rivers, a play on the name of the New Jersey town, Toms River.
"Originally, they were going to have me use a different town's name each week," said Mr. Ward, an announcer at Shadow. "I was going to be Laurence Harbor one week and Bud Lake the next. I was afraid they were going to call me Elizabeth at some point."
The stations can also give the helicopters their own monikers: the same Metro helicopter is known as Chopper 95, Jet Copter 77 and the Island Chopper. The traffic reports have their own names, too.
"You can call it Fast Traffic, Slow Traffic or No Traffic, whatever you want to call it, we don't care," said Martin S. Quinn, who until recently was an operations manager at Shadow traffic.
Metro operates two helicopters; Shadow traffic shares its airborne reports with CBS News Radio 88, which has its own helicopter. Helicopters tend to fly only during rush hours because they cost $750 an hour to keep aloft. The rest of the traffic report is developed by reporters who monitor the flow from booths on the ground, using computerized data and remote cameras.
Traffic reporting resources have become so concentrated in part because the demand for up-to-the-minute information can only be met with the use of increasingly high-tech, expensive Big Brother-like tools. To maintain a constant vigil on major roads, both traffic services are investing heavily in remote cameras. Metro, for example, has a camera on top of the Empire State Building that can zoom in on three miles of roadway leading into the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
With no space or financing for major new roads, science is deemed the best way to relieve the bumper-to-bumper blues. The city's Department of Transportation says the number of cars entering New York City rose to 1.035 million per day in 1995, the latest year available, from 971,000 in 1986. In the first three months of 1997 alone, some 850,000 more cars used the six crossings managed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey than in the same period in 1996. Officials ascribe the change to improved economic activity.
"If we can increase the level of information about specific incidents, then we can reduce the backups they cause," said Matthew Edelman, the general manager of Transcom, a traffic report clearinghouse run by the Port Authority.
But broadcasting more information generally does not include giving details about the gruesome accidents that snarl traffic. Instead, airborne reporters focus on giving hundreds of thousands of daily commuters a sense of how long any collision will take to clear.
They prefer to recall the wackier moments of traffic jams. Like the time a pack of wild dogs roved the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx, blocking traffic for hours.
Or the time a truck littered the Bruckner Expressway with five-gallon ice cream containers. Traffic reporters overhead declared the roadway cleared when sanitation trucks swept the containers onto the shoulder, but their bosses ordered them back to the scene because commuters were calling on their cellular phones to complain about delays. Other drivers, it turned out, were haphazardly parking their cars to grab the ice cream.
With or without the technology, there are certain immutable rules for traffic reporters.
The day before Thanksgiving is known as Armageddon. (The Fourth of July tends to be slightly better because departures are more staggered.)
Good weather often creates worse traffic than bad, especially on summer Sundays, with more cars and more careless drivers. "Any time I see a beautiful sunny morning I get nervous because we really get in trouble," said Pete Tauriello, a veteran Shadow reporter who pumps out roughly 20 reports per hour during the morning rush.
Commuters with cellular phones do report problems -- and both Metro and Shadow depend heavily on them -- but drivers call less often in the morning rush to work than they do in the evening, when they are eager to get home.
The metropolitan area is something like the Balkans of traffic control, with 14 autonomous agencies ruling some piece of the road network. Rather than trolling for road reports from the various agencies and the police, traffic reporters have come to rely on remote cameras in strategic locations over the last year.
Beyond cameras, the next addition to traffic reporting hinges on the expanding E-Z Pass electronic toll collection system. Transcom plans to install E-Z Pass monitors at fixed intervals along 100 miles of major arteries in all five boroughs within a year. The system will calibrate the time that a car, with an E-Z Pass tag and following the speed limit, should arrive at each monitor. If traffic is markedly slower, the monitor will transmit both the actual speed and a warning to Transcom and the pertinent agencies that something is amiss. (Transcom officials said the monitors will scramble the E-Z Pass numbers, so the monitors will not be used to ticket speeders.) The system will still likely require airborne reporters to assess bottlenecks.
Most New York and New Jersey stations demand that each traffic report cover the three Hudson River crossings in a minute, leaving scarcely enough time to squeeze in about three other areas.
Using the remote cameras, the reporters at headquarters can pick up the landmarks needed to predict crossing times. The Hilton Hotel in Fort Lee is the mark for a 15-minute delay crossing the George Washington Bridge, while Dickinson High School in Jersey City serves the same purpose for the Holland Tunnel. At the Lincoln, a backup to the top of the helix winding down to the tunnel is a 15-minute delay in the morning, when four lanes are pouring in, but 30 minutes in the afternoon when the number is halved.
"Traffic changes every minute, so it requires you to be like an omnipresent god looking at every single thing at every minute of the day," said Mr. Tauriello.
For Connecticut and Long Island radio stations, the Hudson River crossings might as well be in South Dakota, but traffic reporters said it would still take five minutes to report on every major roadway. Instead they highlight the bottlenecks that affect the most drivers.
Even with all the high technology, however, traffic-casting remains something of an art rather than a science. "To put a time on the crossing is pretty hazardous," said Neal Busch, a 30-year veteran of airborne reporting for CBS. He said even drivers who benefit from miscalculated times call to complain. "It is highly variable. If I say it is 25 minutes, some guy down on Route 1 and 9 will say, 'Oh yeah? It only took me 15 minutes."

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By William Grimes 

 BODY:

Outlining Arguments for 'Rent' Trial
The battle lines are drawn in the "Rent" war. Late last week, lawyers submitted pretrial memorandums outlining their arguments in the lawsuit that pits Lynn M. Thomson, the dramaturge who worked on "Rent" when it was being developed at the New York Theater Workshop, against the family of the writer and composer Jonathan Larson. The trial, which begins in United States District Court in Manhattan on July 21, will determine whether Ms. Thomson should be named a co-author of the musical and receive the 16 percent of author's royalties earned by the show that she is demanding.
L. Peter Parcher of Parcher, Hayes & Liebman, a Manhattan firm, will argue that Mr. Larson, who died just before "Rent" opened at the workshop, is the sole author of the musical, and that Ms. Thomson's contributions to the work were covered by the $2,000 contract she signed with the workshop. Those contributions, he argues, fall within the normal range of services provided by dramaturges, who typically work with writers to iron out problems in their plays. 
 In building his case, Mr. Parcher leans heavily on the decision in a 1991 case, Childress v. Taylor, the most recent statement by the courts on artistic collaboration. In that case, Clarice Taylor, an actress, enlisted a playwright, Alice Childress, to develop a script she had written about Moms Mabley into a play. Ms. Taylor tried to produce the play without permission and without crediting Ms. Childress. The case wound up in court, with Ms. Taylor unsuccessfully claiming co-author status.
Mr. Parcher argues that the court's decision in that case requires Ms. Thomson to prove that she and Larson both intended her to be the co-author of "Rent" and that she contributed copyrightable material to the musical. "She cannot prove either," the memorandum reads, asserting that her contributions to "Rent" consisted of uncopyrightable "ideas and suggestions regarding character, structure and theme."
Mr. Parcher also argues that all versions of the play, and programs for the Off Broadway and Broadway productions of the show list Ms. Thomson as a dramaturge, not an author, and that her case essentially relies on remembered conversations with Larson in which she says he told her that he planned to reward her for her work.
Mr. Parcher will attempt to portray Ms. Thomson as an opportunist. "Failure to assert her baseless co-authorship claim until well after Larson's death is a telling indication that she is simply taking advantage of Larson's inability to speak for himself," the memorandum states.
Russell Alexander Smith, representing Ms. Thomson, argues that Ms. Thomson was in every sense of the word a collaborator on "Rent," that the term "dramaturge" does not exclude the activity of play-writing and that Childress v. Taylor does not require two collaborators to refer to each other as co-authors, to bill themselves as such or even to make equal contributions in order to be considered co-authors by the courts.
Mr. Smith, enumerating Ms. Thomson's contributions, says that of the 2,542 lines in the final script of "Rent," 1,212 were entirely rewritten or substantially altered by Ms. Thomson and Larson together, and that 48 percent of the final script is either totally new or substantially different.
Two ranks of expert witnesses have lined up to argue the function of the dramaturge and the nature of collaboration in the theater.
Robert Brustein, the artistic director of the American Repertory Theater, and Bernard Gersten, the executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater, have given depositions for the Larsons. Mr. Smith has enlisted a nine-member team including Anne Cattaneo, the dramaturge at Lincoln Center; Mark Bly, the chairman of the play-writing department at the Yale School of Drama, and the playwrights Craig Lucas and Tony Kushner.
 
Actor, Lawyer and Actor Again
 Think of it as a very long intermission. The last time Donald Grody stepped out on a Broadway stage, it was 1959 and the musical was "Bells Are Ringing," with Judy Holliday.
After a slight career detour, he has returned, in the role of Poole, Dr. Jekyll's manservant, in "Jekyll and Hyde." For theater insiders, the face should ring two bells, since Mr. Grody served as the executive secretary of Actors Equity from 1973 to 1980. As for landing the part of Poole, Mr. Grody said simply, "I auditioned like anybody else."
Back in the 1950's, Mr. Grody was doing well enough as an actor, appearing on Broadway in shows like "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" and "Wonderful Town." But with two children, he wanted to do better.
"One day, I thought, 'What's a nice Jewish kid from the Bronx doing in a business like this?' " he said. He entered law school, studying during the day and performing at night. When it came time to leave "Bells Are Ringing," Holliday arranged for him to be dismissed so he could collect unemployment benefits.
A long career as a labor lawyer and labor arbitrator followed. Besides negotiating contracts for Actors Equity, he served as an assistant to the executive director of the National Football League Players Association.
He also began writing a play about a black American actor of the 19th century, Ira Frederick Aldridge. "The more I worked on Ira, the more I was drawn back to the theater," he said.
In 1990, he eased back into acting, playing Escalus, a judge, in the Shakespeare Theater Company's production of "Measure for Measure" at Westbeth Theater Center. Then he landed the part of Arvide in the national tour of "Guys and Dolls."
"It had been 33 years since I was on a big stage, and that was a rush," he said. "This has really revived my life."
