 *Julie Andrews is not finished with "Victor/ Victoria." Tony Adams, a producer of the show, said the show's producers were in final negotiations for Ms. Andrews to step in again when the touring production travels to Houston and Seattle for six-week runs beginning in late August.
*Big bucks. The Theater Development Fund sold 1,658,251 tickets through its two half-price TKTS booths in the fiscal year that ended June 30. That total, the highest since 1982-83, translated into $53 million. The surprise is not so much the money as the fact that sales are made. A sampler: "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Farm," "Sex and Lodging," "Miserable Blob" and "Phantom of the Operator."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Spaniard Who Has Carved a Niche Beyond Modern and Minimal

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
CRISTINA IGLESIAS, a sculptor from the Basque region of Spain, is making her New York City debut on a very big stage: the upper regions of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. Perhaps this is as it should be. Although Ms. Iglesias has never had a solo show here, she has already had, at the age of 41, nearly 30 solo shows in Europe and elsewhere (including Greece, Canada and Seattle). Among those were exhibitions at important museums in Amsterdam, Dusseldorf, Germany, and Bordeaux, France, as well as in the Venice Biennale, where she represented Spain in 1993.
Nonetheless, this exhibition of works almost entirely from the last four years feels premature, as if it has more to do with the Guggenheim's new commitment in Bilbao, business capital of the Basque region, than the actual merits of Ms. Iglesias's work. On view are roughly a dozen slablike or gridded sculptures in materials ranging from cast aluminum or iron to concrete, glass, alabaster and wood, which are shown with seven big grainy photographs of related sculptural models. While these works introduce an intriguing and sizable artistic ambition, they don't as yet add up to a convincing performance. At this point in her career, Ms. Iglesias's art is seldom more than the sum of its many influences and precedents. 
 Ms. Iglesias might be called a post-modern post-Minimalist. Like many sculptors since the 1970's, she has taken Minimalism, the last major sculptural chapter of modernism, as her point of departure, but she has assiduously contradicted its pursuit of order and wholeness. In sculpture after sculpture, she has reduced the style to a series of idiosyncratic fragments that hover between architecture and sculpture while contrasting the industrial with the natural or the domestic, occasionally intimating the body and attempting, it seems, some form of social critique.
Several works involve thick vertical slabs of fiber cement that hug the wall, elements suggestive of a factory or a bunker in their material, and of a painting in their proportions and positions. The left-hand edges of these slabs curl outward as much as a few feet to reveal backing made of material from another time and place: a tapestry of a floral pattern or a hunting scene. Facing flat against the wall might be a third material: a sheet of clear glass or aluminum that provides a faint reflection of the tapestry.
Thus, these sculptures form partly opened sandwiches of materials and meanings that viewers encounter privately, one at a time, almost furtively. Transparency is opposed to ponderous opacity, the modern rubs up against the ancient regime and the decorative softness of woven textile, redolent of grand interiors, competes with austere, staunchly outdoor stuff.
While Ms. Iglesias's points are fun to juggle in the mind, they are also obvious and emanate from what are, in effect, little more than surface adjustments made to familiar sculptural configurations. One thinks of Richard Serra's hulking slabs, of Bruce Nauman's confining corridors, of Joseph Beuys's opulent stacks of felt and copper. It's never clear whether Ms. Iglesias is commenting on the works of her predecessors, adding a sense of history, economics and feminine intimacy to their efforts, or simply working in their shadows.
Several sculptures are just plain inert, particularly two installations in which bas-relief depictions of a bamboo forest and dense eucalyptus plants -- works that are, in essence, unusually tactile tapestries cast from life -- span the corners of small galleries. While the subject of these weighty, clearly expensive surfaces may be the modern world's destruction of nature's delicate fecundity, herewith rendered indestructible, the effect is corporate and anonymous, like some highfalutin form of lobby art.
A very few works indicate Ms. Iglesias's sculptural potential. One is a large, levitating ceiling in cast fiber cement that appears to replicate a shell- or lichen-covered surface; it can invert the gallery, making one feel like a deep-sea diver swimming toward the bottom of the ocean. Another is a four-part canopy of iron and translucent sheets of alabaster that casts the corner of the gallery in a lovely aqueous light, while suggesting a glamorous entrance that leads nowhere. Most impressive of all is "Untitled (Jealousy)," a giant cage of bronze-colored wood whose grid is so full of decorative variations that one cannot see into it. Playing on the Spanish and French words for louvered window ("celosia" and "jalousie," which also mean jealousy), the piece is a visual analogue for the emotional trap of jealous feelings and for the way they turn in upon themselves, multiplying and expanding beyond control.
Ms. Iglesias is also on firmer ground in photography, where she makes large, somewhat Romantic pictures of what appear to be small, hand-built models. These works add to the history of set-up photography, which includes Americans like James Casebere and Laurie Simmons, as well as European artists like Anselm Kiefer, who photographed toy destroyers floating in a bathtub. In photographs of thickly troweled monoliths, enclosures of shadowy grillwork similar to the gridded cage or a succession of post-and-lintel arches evocative of Mr. Kiefer's large architectural images, Ms. Iglesias evokes a flimsy monumentality that is mysterious and mock-heroic and that reduces the grand ambitions of sculptors and architects to child's play.
It interesting to think about Ms. Iglesias's own ambitions, where they might lead and what this exhibition might have looked like a few years down the road. In the meantime, it is at best an unwarranted survey of early work, blessed with a promising ending.
"Cristina Iglesias" remains at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, through Sept. 7. It will travel to the Renaissance Society in Chicago (November to January 1998).

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Untitled (Jealousy)" by Cristina Iglesias, from an exhibition of her sculpture at the Solomon R. Guggenheim. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York Skyscrapers As Ancient Temples

BYLINE: By MICHAEL FRANK; Michael Frank has written about architecture and design for Architectural Digest and Metropolis.

 BODY:
IMAGINE the death of Manhattan. It is far off, perhaps a millennium distant. The center of gravity has shifted away from this queer and querulous lozenge of real estate and settled in another part of the world, a cyberworld maybe, maybe a world still unimagined -- or unimaginable. Time and wind and water have ravaged the natural and the man-made alike, and the city's familiar face has eroded in some places to the skeleton underneath. Manhattan strikes the future observer the way ancient Athens or ancient Rome strikes us now -- as fragmentary, enigmatic, a memento mori at once powerful and poignant.
What does this future visitor see? Strange extrusions reaching gallantly toward the heavens, a veritable forest of them. Some, he concludes, were embellished, some plain. Some were brick, some limestone, others glass. Many have an unusual ziggurat shape, stepping back at mysterious intervals; others are slabs. Some are moderate, others taller, still others aspire to be the tallest of them all. Most are divided into floors of equal height, and these floors are further divided into cubicles of unequal size. Many people congregated in these buildings. Here they transacted business, here they sought shelter from the elements, here they lived and they died. 
 The visitor beholds, of course, a graveyard of skyscrapers. They are our temples, after all, our Parthenon and our Pantheon; only the god worshiped in them is Mammon. Ruined or whole, skyscrapers certainly say as much about the city and culture -- and sensibility -- of Manhattan as those venerable ancient edifices say about the civilizations that produced them.
Now imagine that, by some act of instantaneous, Pompeii-like preservation, two current exhibitions, one at the new Skyscraper Museum on Wall Street and the other at the Museum of the City of New York, were sealed up and saved for our future visitor. What would he learn from them about these magnificently complex structures? What do we?
The Skyscraper Museum's debut exhibition, "Downtown New York: The Architecture of Business/The Business of Buildings," approaches the skyscraper from the inside out. Carol Willis, the curator and founder of the museum, is the author of "Form Follows Finance" (Princeton Architectural Press), and both at the museum and in her book she emphasizes the machinery of the skyscraper -- its financial underpinnings, engineering feats and the program of its interiors -- over the facade. Her slant is fresh, rigorous and informative, although in its zeal to chart new ground it tends to diminish somewhat the role of design in the finished building.
The Skyscraper Museum fills a surprising gap in the city's inventory of museums. The history of New York begins downtown, of course, and after Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, a visitor should, Ms. Willis says, experience Wall Street to understand how New York became the center of capitalism. "A tour of these downtown canyons is essential," she observed recently. "And so is understanding how they came about."
Ms. Willis has arranged the inaugural exhibition in a kind of canyon of its own, in a vacant banking hall at 44 Wall Street, a skyscraper completed in 1926. Two panoramic views of Broadway, from Bowling Green to Liberty Street, set the scene: one is from 1909, the other from 1996. They hang overhead, facing each other as if to constitute the actual street, while beneath them the space has been divided into separate rooms, each featuring a different aspect of the "business of buildings," among them rent, height, real estate cycles and the office. The installation tells its story with maps, models, period photographs and postcards, construction records and abundant edifying text.
A quote from Cass Gilbert, the architect of the 1913 Woolworth Building, provides the tone for much of the museum: "A skyscraper," he remarked in 1900, "is a machine that makes the land pay." And it pays more the closer it is to Wall Street -- or did in 1903, when land values were highest ($350 to $400 a square foot) at Broadway and Wall, while only two blocks away they fell precipitately (to $25 a square foot), as a vintage map documents. The importance of location, a real estate adage, is confirmed once again.
Yet even at a choice site, unchecked development is not always profitable: at some point, making a building taller becomes more expensive than it's worth; the money gained in rent does not cover the investors' costs. The exhibition explores this relationship, which Ms. Willis calls "economic height," while at the same time addressing the other kind of height -- engineering -- that makes skyscrapers feasible. Using evocative images of notable skyscrapers under construction, along with contractors' records and wall text, the exhibition charts the progress of skyscraper engineering.
We learn how the use of caissons made the excavation for early skyscrapers possible; how hot-driven rivets enabled them to rise higher; how the challenge of wind bracing was met in different generations, and how "building skyscrapers is the nearest peacetime equivalent of war." This remark is from William A. Starrett (Starrett Brothers & Eken were the contractors for the Empire State Building), one of Ms. Willis's "all-time heroes." Why such exalted stature?
"Because of the way the Starretts ran a truly armylike team of workmen, managed vast materials and worked with supreme efficiency," she replied. Indeed, the progress schedule of their work on 40 Wall Street, which is on display, is a formidably meticulous document, recording every step, from wrecking and excavation to masonry, finish carpentry and the installation of mail chutes.
 
Limits of Light and Air
 Two key factors in the evolution of the skyscraper were the zoning laws and the widespread application of fluorescent lighting and air-conditioning. Between 1889, when the development of steel-cage construction enabled the first skyscrapers to rise up and out of lower Manhattan, and 1916, when the first zoning law was passed, there were no rules: the speculator's borrowing ability (rather than the sky) was the limit.
Concerns about the loss of natural sunlight and air, both within buildings and on the streets below, along with worries about fire, produced the zoning laws of 1916. These regulated buildings by districts (commercial, residential and unrestricted) and limited the height and bulk of a skyscraper by requiring setbacks. (Height remained unchecked if the building occupied only 25 percent of its lot.) Zoning laws passed in 1961 made sheer towers permissible if set in a plaza or accompanied by other public amenities, and these rules helped bring on the hegemony of modernism with its severe glass-sheathed boxes.
Because of the way the museum insists on looking at its subject from the inside out, it's impossible not to think about how much the need for light and air determined the form of the early skyscrapers. In the first decades of this century, offices depended on sunlight for illumination, since incandescent bulbs generated considerable heat; the maximum depth from the building's exterior windows to its corridor wall remained fixed at 20 to 28 feet. When cool and abundant fluorescent light became available after 1940, the layout of offices and office buildings was much freed, although interestingly, the hierarchy of an office with a window (or better yet, a corner office) remains entrenched to this day.
Indeed, the Skyscraper Museum deftly, in some places downright nostalgically, depicts this hierarchy together with other characteristics of early office life. Skyscrapers feel like such quintessential inventions of the modern world that it's easy to forget how old they are by now and how much the work habits developed within them have evolved. We've come a long way from the roll-top desk (don't its cubbyholes now seem to anticipate computer files?), the Remington Noiseless Typewriter and even the I.B.M. Selectric II, whose rotating ball of type once seemed so futuristic. (Examples of all are at the museum.)
Similarly remote now is the tone of a magazine spread from Fortune in 1930, which depicts the offices of different executives and informs us that "particularly if a man be married, his office is more his castle than his home." An ad for Dictaphone from the same era appeals to "secretaries who leap like stricken deer at every blast of the buzzer," while one for Alcoa aluminum desk chairs is pitched differently to women than it is to men. Women, those delicate creatures, should buy aluminum because they worry about splinters and runs in their silk stockings; men, on the other hand, move around a lot in their chairs and need something "strong to stand up in the battle of big business."
Also evoking the past, though in a more sober way, is a fascinating architectural model of lower Manhattan, made as a planning tool by the preservationist Theodore Conrad in the late 1960's and early 70's. Cutting across SoHo is the once proposed but thankfully finally defeated Lower Manhattan Expressway, which would have ranked with the demolition of Penn Station as one of the great blights on the city's reputation. The model serves as a kind of loose coda for the whole museum: at once illuminating and cautionary, it compels the viewer, home-grown and tourist alike, to take a new look at Manhattan's primary component.
 
'Splendor and Lift'
Taking a different approach, another author and curator, John Tauranac, has helped mount "A Dream Well Planned: The Empire State Building," a modestly scaled but engaging exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York. Mr. Tauranac, whose book "The Empire State Building: The Making of a Landmark" (St. Martin's Griffin) has just been issued in paperback, is not so much interested in advancing a thesis as in celebrating what he calls the "splendor and lift" of what is unarguably the world's most famous skyscraper. As a result, the show is somewhat less provocative but more visual than its counterpart downtown.
The making of the Empire State Building is a classic New York story that can be told anew to every generation. It contains many of the themes seen as essential to the genre at the Skyscraper Museum -- finance, speculation, height and zoning -- as well as some that belong to it specifically, chiefly with regard to its totemic identity. This evolved, it seems, during construction. In a 1930 photograph, a sign at the site announces the erection of "An Office Building of Character" -- not yet the "World's Tallest," which was to come a few months later, out of a competitive struggle with the Chrysler Building for the distinction.
The site of the Empire State Building was a farm until the mid-1850's, when William Astor built a brownstone mansion at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 34th Street. It was here that his wife, Caroline Schermerhorn Astor, held her famous balls in the art gallery: the room could hold 400 people, and they became the 400 of New York society, the milieu much anatomized by Edith Wharton in "The Age of Innocence" and other novels and stories.
 
Deadline of 18 Months
By the mid-1880's, the house had been replaced by the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel (represented here by a large and vivid 1896 watercolor, by Hughson Hawley, of a hotel piano and a spittoon). The site was bought during the boom years of the late 1920's, when its developers gave the architects, Shreve, Lamb & Harmon, and the contractors 18 months to complete the project, from the first drawings to opening day. This was strictly scheduled for May 1, 1931, because May 1 was the traditional date on which new leases were signed in 1930's New York.
Exquisite elevations from the architects' drafting table show the evolution of the building from its initial 65 stories to 80 and then 85. Finally, boldly and most impractically (except perhaps as a piece of public relations and an esthetic flourish), the dirigible mooring mast was added, pushing the building to 102 stories and a height of 1,250 feet. Lewis Wicks Heine's handsome photographs document the construction, as do the maquette of an eagle from one of the columns flanking the Fifth Avenue entrance, a much-chipped wooden model showing the building's massing and the Starrett Brothers' General Summary of Estimate (total: $26,069,000).
Also depicted, inevitably, is the difficulty of leasing space during the Depression, when the Empire State Building had the misfortune to open. Its initial occupancy stalled at 23 percent, earning it the nickname the Empty State Building. In 1935, lights were turned on in vacant offices to reduce the morguelike aura of a largely dark facade, as illustrated in a vintage image. But even during this difficult early period, the skyscraper attracted favorable attention. Other photographs capture Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt surveying the observation deck and a moody and dapper King of Siam making a state visit with his entourage.
Despite its rocky financial beginning, the Empire State Building lodged deep in the city's collective imagination. It did this while it was still being built. How many other structures have been filmed as they rise, floor by floor, like a child learning to sit up, then crawl, then walk? This silent movie, an effective piece of early boosterism, plays continuously at the museum. Nearby, a case of souvenirs attests to the building's great and long popularity: postcards, models, china, King Kongiana, sculptures, lamps, salt and pepper shakers and the like.
Still, no tchotchke, elevation, photograph or reel of film can replace the experience of standing atop this august, shimmering structure, amid the swirl of clouds and wind and sunlight -- or moonlight or city light -- that opens up so infinitely and sparklingly from the observation deck. If only a single skyscraper remains intact when we're well into the next millennium, one has to hope that it will be the Empire State Building. There can be no finer vantage point from which to contemplate the city, whether ruined or vital, present or future. In many ways, the whole of Manhattan can be seen as a vast open-air skyscraper museum in which the Empire State Building will surely always be the most beloved, and telling, exhibit of all.

Books
 
"FORM FOLLOWS FINANCE: SKYSCRAPERS AND SKYLINES IN NEW YORK AND CHICAGO," by Carol Willis (Princeton Architectural Press, $35 hardcover, $22.50 paperback). The author argues that skyscrapers in both cities are best understood as "vernaculars of capitalism," structures whose forms are much guided by forces of real estate speculation and zoning.
 
"THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING: THE MAKING OF A LANDMARK," by John Tauranac (St. Martin's Griffin, $14.95 paperback). A lively narrative account of the conception, design, construction and unfolding history of Manhattan's most prominent edifice.
 
"RISE OF THE NEW YORK SKYSCRAPER, 1865-1913," by Sarah Bradford Landau and Carl W. Condit (Yale University Press, $52.50 hardcover). A generously illustrated, beautifully detailed account of the first generation of skyscrapers and how they were received by apprehensive New Yorkers. MICHAEL FRANK

HEADLINE: Now About The Ones That Didn't Get Away

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

 BODY:
LORD BYRON had it right. "Man marks the earth with ruin," he wrote in "Childe Harold's Pilgrimage," but "his control stops at the shore."
The 32-foot work boat trembled away from the dock shortly after dawn, paused, rocking in the gentle sway of the channel off Freeport on Long Island, then groaned to life, picking up speed along the edge of East Bay and squeezing under the Loop Parkway. A few small craft hugged the rocky shore, overseen by kibbitzing gulls.
"Sit down on those cushions or on the cooler, anywhere you want; it'll take us about an hour to get out there," Mike Barnett, captain of the Codfather, shouted from the bridge. 
 It was an all-day deep-sea fishing charter: $500 plus a 15 to 20 percent tip for the mate; bait and tackle provided.
Mr. Barnett was rubbing sunblock on his face, listening to the crackle of the radio and staring toward the gently bouncing horizon. At a bait table affixed to the stern, Frank Cusma, the mate, was whacking a dozen mackerel into bloody chunks for chumming.
The rest of the charter was me, a photographer, an art critic and a magazine editor. To each his own, of course, but personally I would not attempt such an expedition without having an art critic along.
The cluttered smell of the land was lost first in a burst of marine fuel vapors, then in the clean churn of the water, agitated by the charter boat's passing. The windows of the waterfront houses caught the morning sun and burst into flame, one after another, as we passed near the looming water tower on Lookout Point, through the Jones Inlet and into the sea.
It was a clear, hot day in June, a little too early for shark season but perfect for bottom-fishing sea bass or, as we were doing, heading into the deep waters of the New York Bight to catch and release as many bluefish as we could manage.
I must admit, when I first called up Codfish Fishing Charters, I had visions of sharking off the continental shelf. "Look, I don't want to talk you out of anything, but this is what I tell all first-timers," Mr. Barnett had said when I booked the charter, the result of a string of word-of-mouth referrals that began with an ad in the back of a fishing magazine. "Shark fishermen, the guys who really love it, know that you can be out there all day and get only one decent hit. For first-timers, I recommend bluefish. This is definitely the way to go for people who just want to bend rods and have a good time."
So we found ourselves heading for 17 Fathoms, a fishing area about 12 miles off the New Jersey coast and 17 miles from the Jones Inlet, in the heart of the Bight, a kind of Levittown for bluefish.
Bluefish are nasty little specimens with sharp teeth and dense, oily flesh. In their favor, they are often almost eager to jump onto the hook, given modest encouragement, and once impaled they put up a good fight. "Bluefish are one of the best fighting fish out in this ocean, pound for pound," Mr. Cusma said. Small ones run 3 or 4 pounds; good-size ones 10 to 20 pounds; trophy sizes a bit bigger.
Here's how it started: someone had asked me what I really wanted to do this summer, if there was any activity that I'd fantasized about but had never got around to doing.
The answer spilled out: deep-sea fishing.
Who knows where ideas come from? My father, who was a steelworker all his life, kept a sacred box of South Pacific mementos in a loft out in the garage. These included a pith helmet bearing the carefully written name of every island he visited during World War II, a star indicating a battle. He once told me that if he hadn't married and started a family, he probably would have bought a small houseboat and wandered up and down the Great Lakes, a kind of handyman doing odd jobs. We actually owned a small boat once, a wreck with an outboard that we wrestled into Lake Michigan every so often, the steel mill's bleeder stacks licking at the smog-darkened sky. But we never went fishing, not once that I can recall.
When I pictured myself deep-sea fishing, as I did often when I got near the ocean, the scenes were Hemingway via Hollywood, Humphrey Bogart in "To Have and Have Not," George C. Scott in "Islands in the Stream," even Robert Shaw in "Jaws." It was a test of character, somehow; the sea sorted it all out.
If the result was less Ernest Hemingway than "Ernest Goes to Camp," the fault was not the sea's.
 
Bending Many Rods
We passed a few commercial fishing boats on the way out, but we were early enough to beat the first of the big party boats that come out of Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn and a half-dozen other marinas along the coast of Long Island. These are so-called head boats, because fishermen pay by the head, usually about $45. Many also charge extra for bait and tackle and other amenities. The boats are quite large and the owners pack on as many heads as they can, on weekends often resulting in something that looks like a floating porcupine.
"We call it animal fishing," Mr. Barnett said dismissively. "No one gets out of your way. It's frustrating. You catch a fish and try to follow it and they just stand there."
Of course, he's not exactly unbiased. His business, and that of all of the charter-boat skippers, depends on the qualitative difference between cramming onto a head boat and having your own vessel to go where you want and satisfy your whims.
Just about the time the jagged skyline of the Rockaways in Queens was receding into the murky horizon, the steep bluffs of the New Jersey Highlands rose up to the west. Where the two coastlines nearly meet, at the entrance to New York Harbor, a huge platform presides over the ocean like a preacher's pulpit. This is the Ambrose Light, the gatekeeper, guiding ship traffic into New York City.
Mr. Barnett slowed the engine and the Codfather began to bob with the swells. "Let's give it a try," he called. The bucket of mackerel was filling up. Mr. Cusma opened a cooler and pulled out a frozen chum bucket, a commercial preparation of frozen fish bits that he lowered over the side. Slowly, as the ice melted, a cloud of bloody speckles floated out behind the boat. He added a few chunks of mackerel to the stew.
"I think we'll try drifting for a while first," Mr. Barnett said. "See what happens. If that doesn't work, we'll anchor."
The sea is more crowded than you might think, even out at that distance. A couple of head boats were nearby; about a mile away in another direction some commercial draggers worked the bottom relentlessly, and almost everywhere there seemed to be grids of lobster pots, their black pennants dipping and swaying.
We slid a hunk of mackerel onto our hooks and lowered them into the ocean, where they sunk past the cloudy chum layer and disappeared into the dark green. Bit by bit, we pulled line from the open reel and let the force of the drift draw the bait farther out and down.
The photographer, who is also an avid saltwater fisherman, chatted amiably with the captain. "I troll a lot," one said. "I do a lot of bait, but I don't like to troll," the other answered. Then they started on engines.
Mr. Cusma sent out a couple of lines and periodically dropped more hunks of mackerel into the water. The captain parked himself near the wheel, chatting now and then on the radio with other charter captains ("Anything happening out your way?") and keeping an eye on the color scope, which displays the ocean at various depths and shows schools of fish as eruptions of red in a field of greens and blues.
The magazine editor, who does not eat fish, did not intend to touch any fish and was along mainly to feel the fishes' pain, parked herself on an upholstered bench beneath a blue sun umbrella and read a book about 18th-century European culture.
It gives me great pleasure to report that the art critic, who is the sort of infuriating character who can beat you at any game you name, did not catch the first fish. I did. Me. And I see no reason to mention his name, which is almost certain to cause him discomfort and embarrassment. Michael Kimmelman.
 
Suddenly, a Bite
My line was drifting in the general direction of a row of lobster pots, as were my thoughts. I wondered if any of that "Zen and the Art of Archery" stuff might work, if I should try to become the hook (Melville wrote in "Moby-Dick" that "meditation and water are wedded forever"), when my line suddenly veered in a different direction. I watched, frozen, as the line buzzed away.
Mr. Cusma looked at me with something close to pity. "I believe you have a fish," he said.
I sprang into manly action. "What do I do?" I pleaded. Everyone on the boat began to shout instructions: "Follow it around!" "Keep the line taut!" "Let it run!" "Reel it in!" "Go under his line!" "Don't let it go under the boat!"
The fish fought back with amazing force, the rod bending nearly in half. I tucked the end of the rod under my left arm, gripped my left hand just above the reel and began winding furiously with my right hand, pulling back forcefully and then reeling as the rod moved back forward, just as I'd seen Robert Shaw do in "Jaws."
Gradually, the fish lost its fight. "You turned it around," Mr. Cusma informed me. A few minutes later, it broke the surface, flapping up a churn of foam. "Good-size one," he said, leaning forward with a net. "Just bring it over a little closer to me."
The bluefish landed with a thud on the deck, spilling out of the net, flapping a couple of times, then gasping in the air while the hook was removed. "Don't put your fingers too close," Mr. Barnett warned. "That baby will jump up on you. Look at its teeth." They were impressive.
 
Of Fish and Men
A nautical chart showing the fishing grounds in the New York Bight is a fascinating document, speckled with shipwrecks and an exotic array of names for the fishing areas: Chicken Canyon, the Mud Hole, Fifty-Nine Pounder, Cholera Bank, the Tin Can Grounds.
We spent the rest of the day in and around 17 Fathoms. There were strange lulls when nothing happened and the current disappeared and we baked in the open sun. Then, just as mysteriously, the sea would shift and the bluefish would start hitting again. "Hey, if we knew everything there was to know about it, it wouldn't be any fun," Mr. Barnett said.
We got three dozen or so fish on the hook, ended up landing about 10 of them, the smallest about 3 pounds, the biggest about 12 pounds. I got the largest one (maybe I caught 6); my friend Michael had the one with the most fight; the magazine editor peered up from her book now and then to say, "Hurry, put it back in the water."
On the way back in, as the New Jersey Highlands receded and the water tower at Lookout Point grew on the northern horizon, Mr. Barnett talked about the path that led him to the sea. He worked for 17 years in Manhattan, and then his company suffered an economic crunch and he grabbed a buyout and escaped. "I thought, hey, I might as well take a risk and try to do what I always wanted to do," he said. Mr. Cusma had come to the sea along a similar path; his company had shut down his department a year ago.
I wondered whether my father, if he had been downsized out of the steel mill, might have done the same, at long last living out that Travis McGee fantasy on the Great Lakes.
The inlet was crowded now, fishermen clogging all the tight passages, a couple of jet skis whizzing across the intersecting wakes. Slap, slap, slap. The gulls were still kibbitzing over the rocks near Jones Beach.
"Anybody who goes into the charter business for the money is crazy," Mr. Barnett said. "But you know what? I worked for 17 years, going in on the L.I.E. or the Long Island Rail Road, and it was just disgusting.
"And now, I don't need an alarm clock to wake up at 5 o'clock in the morning. I can't wait to get out on the boat."
 
Going for the Catch of the Day
Charter boats for deep-sea fishing can run from $300 to $600 for a day trip to more than $1,000 for two-day excursions. Party boats generally charge $20 to $45 a person for a day trip.
In New York City, boats leave daily from the New York Skyports Marina, at East 23d Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan; Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn; 160th Avenue and Cross Bay Boulevard in Howard Beach, Queens, and City Island in the Bronx.
On Long Island, charter and party boats sail from Freeport, Point Lookout, Captree State Park, Moriches Bay, Shinnecock Bay, Montauk, Greenport, Orient Point, Mattituck Inlet, Port Jefferson and Huntington Harbor. The Long Island Recreational Fishing Guide, a free 50-page booklet published for the first time this spring by the New York Fishing Tackle and Trade Association, offers a comprehensive list of party and charter boats: for a copy, write to the association at 265 West Main Street, Patchogue, N.Y. 11772.
In New Jersey, charter and party boats leave from the Atlantic Highlands Municipal Marina, (908) 291-1670; Belmar Marina, (908) 681-2266; Bogan's Brielle Basin, (908) 528-8377, and Ken's Landing in Point Pleasant, (908) 892-9787.
In Connecticut, a listing of charter and party boats appears in a 31-page free guidebook, "Connecticut: Mystic and More," published by the Southeastern Connecticut Tourism Department. For a copy, call (800) 863-6569.
In addition, many boat owners list their boats with local chambers of commerce.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Laughing In Beijing

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
How delightful it must be these days to be a member of the Chinese Communist Politburo! Every time they get together they must laugh and laugh and laugh.
Every day they hear the highest American officials, members of Congress, the press, intellectuals, the lot of them, mesmerize themselves speculating on whether China will remodel Hong Kong or Hong Kong will remodel China. 
 The men of the Politburo know all these heavy-duty thinkers still have not grasped the new historic reality that Beijing has brought about: China is remodeling America.
Beijing has changed the thinking and behavior of America's President, political parties, top business executives, journalistic and academic seers, even of the guardians of its security.
Most delicious to the Communists, China has reshaped and diminished the value America places on itself -- its democratic and religious values, even its military security values.
Let's dispense with the question of whether the Communist rulers will dominate China's future or kindly allow one of its cities, the least trusted, to take over.
Why on earth should they? China and other dictatorships have shown throughout modern history that they can expand economically without expanding liberty -- as long as the democracies are so submissively ready to transfer their capital and technology to them.
About Hong Kong's own liberties -- China made its intentions clear before its flag went up. Beijing wiped out the elected legislature, bullied the local press into self-censorship and announced that 4,000 troops would be arriving, for starters. Foreign and Hong Kong investors danced and feasted. America mewed.
The chatter that investors will want China to be more "liberal" about human freedoms, and that this will bring some kind of contest between them, comes from a mixture of guilt at deserting dissenters and the muddy-minded assumption that investors in China care about anything except profits.
So back to reality -- the remodeling of America. (Our allies needed no reshaping to put money uber alles.)
Beijing could not remodel America by itself. It got American cooperation.
China did what America would not. It made human rights a tough part of its policy -- but the Communist way. Knowing its rule increasingly depended on total control, Beijing deepened repression. Then it added real international pressure: if Western companies said a critical word, or failed to urge appeasement on their governments, they would lose trade and contracts.
In America, the China trade lobby was Beijing's instrument of pressure, persuading Mr. Clinton to kill human rights as a part of U.S. policy. From that, all else flowed.
As an appeaser of China, the U.S. could not expect its allies to oppose repression elsewhere. America's sanctions against small dictatorships like Cuba and Burma became a mockery.
American politicians reshaped their thinking about foreign interference. Official and business life in China revolves around favoritism, bribes, payoffs. So it was natural for China to infiltrate American politics with money -- and for remodeled American politicians to accept.
The new U.S. Government and business thinking instructs us that a $50 billion trade deficit is good for workers; be happy. Remodeling also helps business sacrifice jobs in the future. China demanded and got from American businesses the technology and equipment to produce their products itself. After all, we couldn't make deals with them if we only looked out for American workers, right?
The new Clinton line was that if the U.S. was more understanding about Beijing, China would be less disruptive internationally.
The New York Times headline, July 3: "China Is Top Supplier to Nations Seeking Powerful, Banned Arms." The authority is the Central Intelligence Agency, the nations include Iran, Syria and Pakistan, the "supplies" are technology and materials, and the weapons are ballistic, nuclear and chemical.
The Administration knew about these deals but courteously accepted Chinese statements that it knew nothing about them and would not do it again.
America's new-think is dangerous to its ideals and security. But at least it is good for laughs in Beijing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A 15,000-Worker Presence in the Region

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The name Grumman, because of its long and deep role in the New York region's economy, still has a mystique -- especially on Long Island, where the company was founded. Lockheed Martin, while quieter and more dispersed, now has a comparable presence.
While both Northrop Grumman and Lockheed Martin have shed thousands of jobs over the last few years, the companies said that on the whole, they did not expect the merger to result in a loss of jobs. 
 "They really do not anticipate any significant effects," said James Taft, a spokesman for Northrop Grumman.
Between them, the two companies still employ more than 15,000 people in places ranging from Bethpage, N.Y., to Yonkers, Syracuse, Owego, N.Y., and Moorestown, N.J.
Lockheed Martin alone has about 10,000 employees in New York State -- mostly upstate -- and 3,300 in New Jersey. Northrop Grumman has 3,500 employees and 500 contract workers, all on Long Island.
Officials of the two companies said they expected the most immediate effect of the merger to be felt in Los Angeles, where Northrop's headquarters will be closed. Lockheed is based in Bethesda, Md.
Northrop's work on Long Island is mostly concentrated on design and support functions for two lines of military aircraft. Lockheed does systems integration work for ballistic missiles programs and optical and infrared navigation and guidance work on Long Island. Its New Jersey operation works on the Aegis air defense systems for Navy surface ships.
But while those programs have survived, both companies have been cutting jobs rapidly as the end of the cold war has reduced the military contracting pie. For Northrop Grumman, many of the cuts have been concentrated on Long Island. The old Grumman Aircraft, founded by Leroy R. Grumman in a Baldwin, N.Y., garage in 1930, was Long Island's largest private employer for many years before its purchase in 1994 by Northrop. Its work force, which peaked at 25,000 workers in the mid-1980's, is expected to fall to 2,700 by 1999. Lockheed Martin's operations in Lake Success, on Long Island, have receded on a similar scale, from 6,000 employees in the early 1980's to 630 today, heading toward about 500 by early next year.
Lockheed has about 480 workers in Yonkers and another 3,300 at in Moorestown, near Philadelphia. The bulk of its work force in New York is upstate, especially in Owego, where it has 2,600 workers, and in Syracuse, where it employs 2,100.

HEADLINE: Peso Crisis Bites Into Mexico's Long-Ruling Party

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: CUERNAVACA, Mexico

 BODY:
Teresa Lasso, who owns a beauty parlor and is married to a veterinarian, intends to vote for a leftist candidate when Mexico elects a new Congress on July 6. To explain why, she grabs a pencil to scribble the disturbing arithmetic of their $79,000 bank loan.
When Mrs. Lasso and her husband, Guillermo, took out their variable-rate loan in pesos six years ago to build a house, they and Mexico were prospering, and for four years they made monthly payments, in pesos, that were equivalent to about $660. But after President Ernesto Zedillo's Government devalued the peso in 1994, interest rates soared and Mr. Lasso's veterinary practice collapsed. 
 "People were just letting their dogs and cats die," Mr. Lasso said. Their loan payments completely overwhelmed their monthly income. Today their combined earnings are the equivalent of about $1,250 a month, but the payments on their loan -- if they were making them -- would amount to more than $2,125. They owe the bank $113,000.
"We think the economy is in crisis," Mrs. Lasso said, setting down her pencil. "President Zedillo says no, but nobody can pay their debts."
Like the Lassos, millions of Mexicans are preparing to vote against the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, perhaps more than at any time since the party was formed in 1929. They cite many motives, among them a simple desire for new leadership after decades of single-party rule. But the biggest reason is that they continue to nurse wounds from an economic crisis the Government insists has long since passed.
Before the crisis began two and a half years ago, the Mexican peso was worth about 29 American cents. In the course of a year, the peso's value eroded to about 13 cents -- and with it the savings of millions of Mexican families. Prices on basic items like electricity, gasoline and even tortillas surged. About a million Mexicans lost their jobs, bringing the number officially out of work to about two million; unofficial estimates put the figure at three times that. The economy contracted by 6.2 percent in 1995.
Partly with the help of a $12.5 billion American bailout loan, the Zedillo Government has succeeded in nursing the economy's figures back into recovery, and today, the PRI is in trouble despite an economy that looks robust -- on paper. Last year it grew by 5.1 percent, official unemployment and inflation are dropping and the stock market is booming. The problem is that many Mexicans don't yet feel the recovery.
"Our challenge is to convince the people that the economy is as good as the numbers say," said a senior adviser to Mr. Zedillo.
Up for election on July 6 are all 500 seats in the Chamber of Deputies, 32 Senate seats, six state governorships, and for the first time, Mexico City's Mayor, who has previously been appointed by the President. Support for the PRI has eroded more completely in Mexico City than anywhere else, so the dominance of the mayoral race by Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, of the leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution, or P.R.D., was not totally unexpected.
But the PRI has run into trouble in many parts of Mexico where it has previously faced little competition, including Cuernavaca. A city of 320,000 residents an hour's drive south of Mexico City, Cuernavaca has never in modern times elected an opposition congressman. But this year voters have grown ornery, and the candidates from the P.R.D. and from the conservative National Action Party, or P.A.N., both have a chance to wrest Cuernavaca's congressional seat from the PRI.
Under Mexico's seat-allotment system for the Chamber, 300 deputies are elected directly from districts while 200 others are distributed to parties according to their percentage of the national vote. A party must win at least 167 seats directly and earn more than 42 percent of the vote to gain a majority; polls suggest that no party will.
In a national survey published on Friday by the newspaper Reforma, 37 percent of those polled preferred the PRI, 30 percent preferred the P.A.N. and 26 percent the P.R.D.
"Life in Mexico will change dramatically if the PRI loses its congressional majority," said Scott Morgenstern, a political scientist studying the Mexican Congress.
Lacking the votes to impose their will, the PRI and President Zedillo would have to negotiate the national budget, and opposition lawmakers for the first time could set up committees with the power to investigate corruption.
The governing party's support has eroded partly because Mr. Zedillo's economists have stabilized Mexico's economy but have failed to raise real wages, which according to a recent report by HSBC James Capel, a securities company, continue a 30-month decline. Mexico's minimum daily wage is worth about $3, and the number of workers earning less than that is growing.
The Lassos' gripe is that the Government works to bail out the bankers, while seeming to do little to help small-time debtors, and thousands of other Mexicans agree. A debtor's group that has joined forces with the P.R.D. asserts it has 600,000 members and estimates that some 12 million other Mexicans are up to their ears in debt.
If the Lassos plan to vote for the left, many others in financial trouble are turning to the conservatives.
Consuelo Martinez Gonzalez, 77 years old, and her daughter, Hilda, 46, have pasted a campaign poster for the P.A.N. into the window of their cement-floor home here, where Hilda earns a meager living by selling little black clay figurines of flowers and animals.
Both women were once PRI voters. But they turned against the party when Hilda's ceramics business all but collapsed in 1995, in the weeks after former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari left office, the peso devalued, and Mr. Salinas's older brother was charged with corruption and murder.
"Salinas did a job on all of us," Hilda said, slapping her cheek to demonstrate how the crisis felt to her.
"We went hungry, and the PRI showed us no mercy," her mother said.
The two women like the conservatives' image of honesty and efficiency, and in municipal elections in March, they voted for the P.A.N. candidate who became Cuernavaca's first non-PRI mayor, and they have become enthusiastic volunteers for the P.A.N.'s congressional candidate.
Some PRI stalwarts remain, like Alfredo Castaneda, the governing party's representative in Tetela del Monte, a working class Cuernavaca community that sprawls across a rocky hillside.
"Whatever you think of the PRI Government, its certainly helped us," he said. "We had nothing, but now Tetela has sewer lines, paved streets, running water. Its all come from the PRI Government."
Mr. Castaneda's role has been to channel public works to Tetela, and to deliver neighbors' votes to the PRI in exchange for the right to hand out patronage jobs. But since the PRI lost Cuernavaca's City Hall to the opposition in March, he no longer has jobs to give.
So prospects for the July 6 balloting are uncertain, he said.
"Before, we could tell people who to vote for," Mr. Castaneda said. "But now people vote for whomever they want."

HEADLINE: Angling for Foreign Tourists;
Some U.S. Cities Team Up to Attract Overseas Dollars

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
With its many cultural institutions, fine dining, elegant 19th-century architecture and daily nonstop flights to five European cities, Cincinnati would seem to have much of what it takes to become a prime destination for international tourists -- a record 46.3 million of whom visited the United States last year.
But it isn't, of course. What traveler would mention this Ohio River town in the same breath with Yellowstone or the Everglades or the Lincoln Memorial? Not that Cincinnati is totally lacking in foreign tourists -- it gets at least 200,000 a year. But that is dwarfed, for example, by the roughly 500,000 foreigners who trek each year to Pigeon Forge, Tenn., a hamlet of just 3,600 or so residents that has cashed in handsomely from its six outlet malls; Dolly Parton's theme park, Dollywood, and its proximity to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. 
 The Queen City, as Cincinnati is known, is trying mightily to put itself on the tourist map. But it is well aware that it cannot do it alone -- and that it will never be one of the first destinations of a foreign traveler. So in May it joined forces with two cities with the same goal -- Louisville, Ky., 100 miles to the southwest, and Indianapolis, 100 miles to the northwest.
On the theory that the whole can be greater than the sum of its parts, this triangle of cities is marketing itself as a package to foreign tourists -- initially from Britain, France and Germany but perhaps later from Japan and other increasingly affluent Asian locations. The campaign aims to convince foreign tourists that these cities would make ideal stops on a second or third trip after a traveler has seen the Golden Gate Bridge and the lights of Broadway.
Foreign tourist dollars are increasingly coveted across the nation, even by places that would seem unlikely tourist destinations. With many midsized cities establishing themselves as centers for business services and entertainment for the surrounding region, the international tourist trade offers an ideal way to add a dollop of frosting -- especially since these are outside dollars, not just local dollars recycled through local businesses.
Consider: The 46.3 million international travelers who visited the United States last year, according to the Commerce Department's Tourism Industries Office, spent $84 billion and supported about a million full-time jobs.
Domestic travel expenditures by United States residents grew a respectable 77 percent in the decade from 1986 to 1996 to $383 billion, according to the Travel Industry of America. But in that same period, foreign tourists' total travel expenditures in the United States more than tripled.
Wherever those tourist billions land, they create jobs, help pay for schools and libraries, and help keep taxes on local residents down. Cincinnati, with 3.5 million to 4 million total tourists annually, calculates that visitors spent $2.1 billion last year, accounting for the equivalent of 73,000 full-time jobs.
But like most cities with pride in what they have to offer, Cincinnati wants even more tourists -- and the more free-spending visitors from abroad, the better. Despite the recent strength of the dollar, the United States remains a veritable bargain basement for tourists from Europe and Asia.
"We're saying to foreign visitors, 'You've already seen New York, Disneyland and San Francisco,' " said Dan M. Lincoln, vice president for tourism at the Greater Cincinnati Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Now spend at least two or three days in Cincinnati, another few days in Louisville, a Southern city, seeing horse farms and other attractions, and a few days in Indianapolis, a Midwestern city, the motor car racing capital of the U.S."
Joining forces to lure tourists is nothing new. There are almost a dozen regional trade and tourism alliances in the United States -- from Travel South, involving 11 Southern states, to Mississippi River Country USA, made up of 10 states from Minnesota to Louisiana.
But the Cincinnati-Louisville-Indianapolis experiment is the first long-term three-city, three-state partnership aimed solely at foreign tourists.
Even cities whose popularity is not in doubt are forming alliances. On July 1, Phoenix, San Diego, and Las Vegas, Nev., kicked off a three-year marketing plan aimed at enticing foreign visitors to sample desert, beach and gambling casinos in one visit. The alliance partners will focus on Europe the first year, on Japan and other Asian nations the second year, then perhaps Latin America.
"There are not many stand-alone tourist destinations," said Robert M. Lander, vice president for marketing at the Phoenix and Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Not too many tourists will travel long distances to visit one destination or one or two sites. That's why you're going to see more and more of these strategic alliances."
Las Vegas already attracts 29.6 million visitors a year, including 5.3 million from abroad, but it is looking for even more foreigners to fill its casinos, restaurants and hotels.
It is not just a matter of luring visitors, of course. Travel industry officials say foreigners could quickly sour on visits to cities or sites that are ill prepared to receive them, whether because they lack currency exchanges or guidebooks in their languages. But with English gradually becoming the language of international tourism as well as of commerce, others say, the problem is becoming ever more manageable.
Industry officials also say it is not cost effective for widely separated cities to forge partnerships aimed at domestic travelers. Weekend travel accounts for 52 percent of all domestic travel, according to the Travel Data Center of the Commerce Department, up 10 percentage points from 1986, so Americans rarely have time to visit more than a single city on one trip.
Still, all the alliance cities welcome domestic tour groups, especially escorted bus tours, whose one- to three-week itineraries make multicity visits possible. While such tourists are not as ready to part with money as foreign visitors are, the American Bus Association estimates that passengers on a fully loaded bus (about 46 passengers) spend $5,000 to $7,000 during the typical overnight stay. Altogether, the direct economic impact of the group tour business in 1996 exceeded $11.6 billion.
Memphis recently concluded two unusual marketing alliances. Together with New Orleans and St. Louis, it is promoting the 700-mile stretch along Interstate 55 ("America's Music Corridor"), inviting foreigners to visit the cities that gave birth to the blues, ragtime, jazz and rock 'n' roll. And after KLM Royal Dutch Airlines -- in a code-sharing agreement with Northwest Airlines -- inaugurated a daily Memphis-Amsterdam nonstop flight two years ago, Memphis proposed an alliance with the Mississippi State Department of Tourism to promote "America's Blues Alley."
"We felt it was time to open the Mississippi Delta to international marketing," said Kevin Kane, president of the Memphis Convention and Visitors Bureau. "We know Memphis isn't a five-night, four-day tourist destination. But we're a good three-night, two-day destination."
Memphis and Mississippi are promoting to European travelers historic Memphis attractions like Beale Street, the house of W. C. Handy, and Graceland, Elvis Presley's home for 20 years. But it is also pushing Mississippi attractions like the house of the blues singer Muddy Waters, the ranch of the rock legend Jerry Lee Lewis and Gulf Coast beaches.
"Foreign visitors, especially Europeans," Mr. Kane said, "are also interested in antebellum houses, cotton plantations, and Civil War battle sites in Mississippi, as well as the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis, on the site of the Lorraine Motel, where Martin Luther King Jr. was murdered."
Memphis gets 8 million to 10 million tourists a year, Mr. Kane said, 14 percent of whom are foreigners. "We'd like even more," he said, "but in 1988 that figure was only about 8 percent, and most of our growth has come in the past couple of years."
Most city alliances are marketed through foreign tour operators or wholesalers, who bundle tours and itineraries into packages that are sold to individual vacationers or groups through travel agents and airlines. Like Americans who buy tour packages to England or France, say, foreign tourists can elect to travel alone, with companions or as part of a group.
By marketing directly to tour operators and wholesalers, cities that belong to such partnerships keep costs low. Mr. Lander of Phoenix said the partnership with Las Vegas and San Diego would cost the cites not much more than $100,000 each the first year. The biggest expense is usually the cost of a representative in one or several foreign cities. The Cincinnati-Louisville-Indianapolis group has a sales representative in London, while Memphis-Mississippi has a marketing representative in both Paris and Frankfurt, as well as a public relations representative in London.
The cost of familiarization trips, on which foreign travel writers are invited to sample local sights, is often underwritten by airlines, local hotels, restaurants and attractions. To call attention to its $11 million Splendors of Versailles exhibit, starting next April at the Mississippi Arts Pavilion, Jackson, Miss., will sponsor two media tours to Versailles, France, in September.
While Jackson is not usually thought of as a major tourist city, a strong Mississippi economy and tax revenue from the state's riverboat casinos have helped push it into the bigger leagues. The city's Palaces of St. Petersburg: Russian Imperial Style exhibit last year, also at the Arts Pavilion and also costing $11 million, drew 553,894 tourists, many from overseas, netted the state more than $4 million in sales tax revenue, and brought in $68 million over all.
"It raised the profile of Mississippi as a state with cultural enrichment," said Jack Kyle, executive director of the Mississippi Commission for International Cultural Exchange.
It also resulted in eight other cities affiliating with Jackson for next year's exhibit, including New Orleans and Baton Rouge, La.
"It's a wonderful way for cities to cross-promote," said Beverly Gianna, a spokeswoman for the New Orleans Metropolitan Convention and Visitors Bureau. "We're planning exhibits and lectures tied to our French heritage, and we're arranging to have historic houses opened that have never been open before. The exhibit's almost a year away, but this is already shaping up as the most exciting promotion I've worked on in 23 years."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Forget Lady Liberty, Visit Elvis's Grave"
While many midsized cities continue to grow as regional centers for business services and entertainment, they are increasingly looking for ways to appeal to the 46.3 million international tourists who spent $84 billion in the United States last year. Cincinnati and Memphis, for example, have formed alliances with different neighboring cities in an attempt to alter the perception many travelers have of their cities.

HEADLINE: Unions at G.E. Approve 3-Year Contract

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 3

 BODY:
Two unions representing about 27,000 workers at the General Electric Company have tentatively agreed on a three-year contract calling for raises totaling 8.75 percent, the company said today.
Under the agreement, the first raise -- 3.75 percent -- took effect Monday and will be followed by an increase of 2.5 percent in June 1998 and 2.5 percent in June 1999, General Electric said in a statement. 
 The unions' members will vote on the contracts next week.
The tentative agreements were reached on Sunday by negotiators representing G.E., the International Union of Electronic Workers and the United Electrical Workers of America after five weeks of bargaining, the company said.
The general pay increases, six cost-of-living adjustments and a wage structure increase for higher-wage employees are expected to raise the pay of the average employee by more than 13 percent over the contract period -- assuming 2.9 percent for annual inflation, G.E. said.
The contract mainly covers workers who build aircraft engines, locomotives, appliances and other products.
The contract also contains provisions for the two sides to negotiate over subcontracting and similar actions.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Plunges as Central Bank In Australia Sells 167 Tons

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Gold prices plunged yesterday to an 11 1/2-year low on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange after Australia's central bank said it had sold 167 metric tons from its reserves.
The sale raised speculation that other central banks could cut their holdings as gold loses its allure as a haven from economic and political turmoil. 
 On other commodity markets, crude oil and cocoa dropped.
The sale by the Reserve Bank of Australia represented about $1.784 billion in gold, based on prices before the announcement. The move was the latest in a series of central bank gold sales. Belgium and the Netherlands both sold gold last year and Belgium, along with Switzerland, recently announced plans for more sales.
"People are going to be asking 'Who's next?' " said Jeffery Ralph, a trader with the Royal Bank in Toronto. "Other central banks that have large gold reserves are going to ask themselves why they have so much money tied up in an asset that is declining in value."
Gold for August delivery fell $7.10, to $325.20 an ounce, in New York, the lowest since December 1985.
Crude oil prices fell on expectations that Iraq would submit an aid distribution plan to the United Nations, leading to the resumption of oil sales, possibly within a month.
The United Nations has approved a distribution plan for northern Iraq and is waiting for the Iraqis to submit a plan for the rest of the country. The plans are aimed at reducing delays in aid distribution.
Iraq said last month that it would not resume oil shipments under a renewed accord with the United Nations allowing limited oil sales to pay for food and medicine until its complaints about delays in delivering the aid for its citizens were resolved.
Crude oil for August delivery fell 78 cents, to $19.56 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Cocoa sank for a second day as rain replenished dry crops in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest producer. Recent storms have fostered growth in the crops, easing concern that helped prices last month rally to a nine-year high. Cocoa for September delivery tumbled $52, to $1,562 a metric ton, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Extends a Strong Move Against Mark Before Slipping

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched another three-and-a-half-year high against the German mark yesterday before retreating to end mostly lower on unexpected weakness in the United States jobs data. The British pound surged for the fourth consecutive session.
Traders said that the pound was likely to keep strengthening on widening expectations that interest rates in Britain must rise, perhaps as early as the Bank of England's policy-making meeting next Thursday, to thwart inflationary pressure in the country's vibrant economy. Rising rates tend to enhance a currency's value. 
 "Everybody's looking for higher rates in Britain," said Jan Alvarez, senior currency trader at Corestates Bank in Philadelphia. "Everybody thinks the pound is a heck of a buy."
Demand for pounds intensified on Wednesday after Britain's new Labor Government introduced a budget that was far less austere than expected. A strong rally in the London stock market yesterday further increased the appetite for pounds.
The pound rose as high as $1.6915, its highest since Jan. 10, before settling in New York at $1.6906, up from $1.6705 Wednesday and up nearly 3 cents for the week.
The dollar rose as high as 1.7567 marks, the strongest since February 1994. The dollar later retreated, settling in New York at 1.7535 marks, down from 1.7536 Wednesday.
The dollar also finished at less than 114 Japanese yen for the first time in a week, settling at 113.80 yen, down from 114.49 yen.
The main force driving the dollar lower was the Labor Department's report on June employment, which indicated that the jobless rate in the United States rose to 5 percent after falling to 24-year lows of 4.8 percent in May and 4.9 percent in April. Forecasters had expected no change.
The report, coming a day after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, provided new evidence that the economy has slowed, further diminishing prospects for rising rates.
Traders used the report as an opportunity to sell dollars and secure profits from the currency's latest flexing of strength against the mark. Many also wanted to reduce their bets on a higher dollar before the Fourth of July holiday, when United States markets are closed.

HEADLINE: Embattled Bosnian Serb Leader Orders Parliament Dissolved

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PALE, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 3

 BODY:
President Biljana Plavsic tried to dissolve the Bosnian Serb Parliament today "to protect the state from total disaster," but supporters of Radovan Karadzic, the former president who is wanted on war-crimes charges, immediately challenged the decision.
A television report that Dr. Karadzic and his wartime commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, who is also charged with war crimes, were to be seized on sight fueled tensions as both sides vied for public support. 
 Dr. Karadzic accused Ms. Plavsic of treachery and of plotting his arrest by NATO peacekeeping troops. But both NATO and the United States denied any change in orders regarding the arrest of war crimes suspects.
In Washington, Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, told reporters in a daily briefing that the report was "absolutely and unequivocally false."
He said the rule remained that if any of those troops "encounter people who they know to be indicted war criminals they are to detain them for transfer to civilian authority so they may be arrested and then turned over to The Hague for prosecution."
President Plavsic said the intention of the reports was to discredit her with the people, who get most of their news from the television which is controlled by hard-liners.
The hard-liners, who also control the police, were expected to go ahead with a Parliament session today to try to remove her from office.
Robert S. Gelbard, the United States special representative to the region, appealed for restraint by both camps.
The feud highlighted antagonism between hard-liners, who are based in the nationalist stronghold in Pale outside Sarajevo, and Ms. Plavsic's supporters in the northern town of Banja Luka who believe Western peacemaking cannot be defied indefinitely.
The document ordering the dissolution of Parliament said the police had organized smuggling with the Muslim-Croat Federation in Bosnia. It also condemned Prime Minister Gojko Klickovic's refusal to work with President Plavsic.
Both men are proteges of Dr. Karadzic who has continued to wield power despite being driven from office last year by the peace accord.
President Plavsic, saying the conflict "threatens the very survival of the Bosnian Serb republic," set new elections for Sept. 1 and began trying to form a national government.
Mr. Gelbard, who had talks with the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, earlier, met Momcilo Krajisnik, a Serb member of Bosnia's multiethnic presidency in Pale.
Ms. Plavsic accused Mr. Krajisnik and Dr. Karadzic, the two most powerful figures in the Bosnian Serb fight against Bosnian independence, of using their influence to enrich themselves through their control of the economy.
Mr. Gelbard said the activities of Dr. Karadzic, Mr. Krajisnik and the Bosnian Serb Interior Minister Dragan Kijac "have been extremely dangerous."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Unexpected Rise in Jobless Rate Spurs a Rally for Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
An unexpected jump in the unemployment rate sparked a rally in the Treasury market yesterday, as the jobs report eased concerns that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates any time soon.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond, rose 1 2/32 , to 100 1/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, slid to 6.62 percent, from 6.71 percent on Wednesday to the lowest level since 6.57 percent on Feb. 19. For bond investors, the day's gains amounted to more than $10 for every $1,000 invested. 
 The rally came in a shortened session ahead of the Fourth of July holiday. The market will be closed today and will reopen on Monday.
Bond prices rose after the Labor Department said that the unemployment rate rose to 5 percent in June from 4.8 percent in May, and also reported that the economy added 217,000 nonfarm jobs in June. Analysts had expected an unemployment rate of 4.8 percent and a gain of 230,000 jobs.
The data "indicate that despite the continued tightness in the labor market, wage pressures decelerated during the second quarter of the year," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.
Coupled with the Fed's decision on Wednesday to leave interest rates unchanged, yesterday's employment and unemployment statistics raised the odds that the Fed policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, would keep rates steady when it next meets in August.
"We've been waiting for this to happen and it virtually guarantees that there will not be a rate hike at the next F.O.M.C. meeting in August and possibly in September," said Scott F. Grannis, director and chief economist at the Western Asset Management Company of Pasadena, Calif., which manages more than $18 billion in fixed-income assets. "It would take a dramatic change in the economy at this point to trigger a tightening in September."
"I think we're getting close to what was once unthinkable: the possiblity that the Fed could ease at some point," he added. "Inflation has declined considerably and the economy is softening. Meanwhile, the market is still pricing in a future tightening with no chance for an ease yet, but if these numbers continue to be soft over the course of months, the market will likely raise the chance of an easing."
Other analysts contended that the Fed could still raise rates again in August. Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said that while the jobs report was an important signpost to the Fed's direction, policy makers were also looking carefully at consumer spending and other signs of potential inflation.
"At some point, the Fed will see consumer demand spurt enough to again have strong demand as a publicly defensible reason to undertake the pre-emptive tightening that they probably want to undertake because of low unemployment -- a publicly indefensible reason for tightening," Mr. Harris said.
"However, at this point we do not foresee this happening until the first quarter of 1998," he added. "That's when we will again have the special purchasing power circumstances of year-end bonuses and tax refunds that fueled the sharp early '97 retail sales spurts that prompted the Fed to tighten at the end of March."
The next clue to Fed monetary policy could come on July 22, when the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, gives his semiannual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony about the state of the economy to Congress.
Elsewhere, the Government plans to sell $8 billion of its new Treasury inflation-protection securities on Wednesday; these notes will have a five-year maturity. In when-issued trading late yesterday, they were offered at a price to yield 3.53 percent.

HEADLINE: Indexing Capital Gains: Its Virtues, and Cost

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
While President Clinton is talking compromise on taxes, the White House has made no secret of its bitter opposition to a handful of provisions in the bills generated by the House and Senate. High on the Administration's 10-worst list is an item in the House version that would index capital gains after 2001 to offset the effects of inflation.
By encouraging taxpayers to make a one-time payment in 2002 to qualify for indexing, the provision would generate substantial revenue in 2002 -- and thus allow the House to lower other taxes even as it meets its legal obligation to produce a balanced budget. But indexing would lead to large and growing revenue losses thereafter unless more generous treatment of capital gains unleashed a frenzy of productive investment. "It's just a cynical budget gimmick," concluded Len Burman, an economist at the Urban Institute.
That is not quite the end of the story, however. While the battle over tax cuts is being fought with smoke and mirrors, many experts who are removed from the politics see merit in adjustments for inflation. "If you're going to tax income, you certainly ought to measure it properly," argued David Bradford, an economist at Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton.
The more difficult question is whether indexing one component of income without indexing others would increase the fairness and efficiency of the tax system as a whole. "In the imperfect world of taxation, those who start from first principles have an awfully hard time figuring what to do," said Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan Business School.
Both the House and Senate tax bills would reduce the top effective tax rate on capital gains to 20 percent from 28 percent. But under the House tax bill, gains on the sale of assets bought after Jan. 1, 2001, would be taxed only on "real," inflation-adjusted appreciation.
Indexing plainly reduces future tax revenue unless it somehow induces far greater realizations of capital gains. How, then, was the House able to declare the indexing provision a revenue winner for the 1997-2002 budget years?
Under the proposed law, investors sitting on capital gains earned before 2001 would become eligible for future indexing if they chose, in that year, to pay the taxes accrued until then on the paper appreciation. Budget alchemists figure that this inducement to pay some taxes sooner in order to reduce taxes later would generate $6 billion extra in revenue in 2002. But the indexing provision is expensive in the long run, adding billions to the cost over the next decade. That explains President Clinton's preference for the Senate approach. However, it does not touch the question of whether indexing is good or bad for the economy.
Most economists would undoubtedly prefer a tax system in which inflation had no effect on how much taxes are paid or when. And in flush times, Congress apparently shares the sentiment: Legislation passed in 1981 indexed tax brackets to prevent inflation from pushing families into higher marginal rates.
Stephen Moore, director of fiscal policy at the Cato Institute in Washington, sees a similar logic in indexing capital gains today. "It's just not fair to tax people on inflationary gains," he argued. What's more, he notes that indexing is a more progressive way to grant tax preferences to capital gains than simply cutting rates, because a relatively high proportion of the gains realized by middle-income Americans is linked to inflation. Indeed, a study by the Congressional Budget Office showed that the average taxpayer with total earnings below $50,000 who declared capital gains actually suffered a capital loss when the asset value was adjusted for inflation.
Other economists who glimpse virtue in capital gains indexing see it as a way to reduce investment risk. Under the current system no one knows what the effective rate of taxation on capital income will be because no one knows what the rate of inflation will be. Indexing would eliminate this risk -- and in the process probably make stock prices less vulnerable to the vagaries of changing inflation rates.
But Herbert Stein, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, wonders whether this would amount to overkill. He noted that with money pouring into the stock market, "we don't seem to be suffering from excessive aversion to risk."
Besides, indexing one part of the tax code without indexing the rest can produce some decidedly odd results. Under the House bill, investors would be able to claim full deductions against ordinary income for interest payments on loans used to buy assets, even though their tax liability on capital gains from the sale of these same assets would fall. In fact, if the inflation component of both interest and capital appreciation were high enough, said William G. Gale, an economist at the Brookings Institution, "you could end up with an effective capital gains rate of less than zero."
Then there is the question of complexity. "In the computer age," Mr. Moore said, adjusting capital gains for the effects of inflation should be "no big deal." But there would inevitably be ambiguities in sales of partnerships and other, less tangible assets; in these situations, what was actually owned and when would become key issues. And the House provision that gives investors an incentive to declare asset values without actually selling them could help many a tax accountant meet his mortgage payments.
Given the choice, Mr. Moore would start with indexing and then cut rates if it still fit the budget. Indeed, some economists would happily trade the whole mess of preferences now accorded to capital gains in return for inflation indexing. But tax intellectuals are not likely to play a key role in deciding the outcome of this latest skirmish over capital gains.
For supply-side ideologues, any reduction in the effective capital gains rate would bring the economy a step closer to nirvana. For opponents, including Mr. Gale of the Brookings Institution, any of the contemplated changes "would merely take an existing tax loophole and make it bigger."
