HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE INCREASES TO 5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point in June, to 5 percent, easing the tightest labor market in a quarter century, Government figures showed today. A moderate 217,000 jobs were added to payrolls.
While the figures showed a blip up in the jobless rate after trending downward for many months and a slowdown in the recent rapid rate of job creation, they were just what the White House and Wall Street wanted. Financial markets reveled in the news because it suggested that the economy was still growing solidly but no longer at the breakneck pace of earlier in the year that threatened to fan fears of inflation. Interest rates tumbled by about one-eighth of a percentage point and stocks, as gauged by the Dow Jones industrial average, soared more than 100 points to another record in shortened pre-holiday trading. [Page D1.] 
 At the White House, the President's chief economic adviser, Janet L. Yellen, exulted in the latest set of figures, which represented a near-perfect combination of decent growth and stable prices.
"Unemployment hovers in a decades-low range, jobs are being created at a robust pace and there are still no signs of inflationary pressures," Ms. Yellen said in a statement.
The chief dark spot in the job picture was the fact that the ranks of the unemployed grew by 302,000, more than offsetting May's improvement. Despite the rise in the unemployment rate, though, the job market remains in healthy shape, analysts said. And after hitting a 24-year low of 4.8 percent in May, a modest rise in unemployment could provide some breathing room to let the economy, now in its seventh year of uninterrupted growth, expand for a longer period without a recession.
Today's Labor Department report was also seen as supporting the Federal Reserve in its judgment earlier this week that the economy was winding down enough from its first-quarter pace of 5.9 percent that no increase in interest rates was needed to hold down prices. Officials said that the central bank had only a fragment of today's figures during its deliberations on Tuesday and Wednesday, those covering the factory workweek.
Despite the enthusiasm of the markets, however, various economists predicted that the Fed would decide to raise rates later in the summer, when the economy is expected to pick up again and grow faster than the second quarter's estimated rate of 2 percent.
Official minutes published today showed that Fed officials agreed unanimously at their May 20 meeting to lean toward higher rates in the belief that "the risks were in the direction of a potential need for some tightening" of policy to counter rising inflation pressure. One member, J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, wanted to raise short-term rates immediately.
Daniel Laufenberg, a senior analyst at American Express Financial Advisers in Minneapolis, described the economy's second-quarter slowdown as a brief "pause" that would soon give way to reacceleration, "if it hasn't already." The labor market, he declared, remains "very tight" and workers are getting decent, though not high, increases in pay.
"We're looking for consumers to come back," Mr. Laufenberg said, "with the wherewithal to spend."
Average hourly earnings rose 4 cents for the second consecutive month in June to put the 12-month increase at 3.5 percent, comfortably above the pace of consumer inflation. For the year through March, on the other hand, hourly earnings rose a markedly higher 4.1 percent, providing ammunition for those who see a risk that wage pressures will force the Fed to raise rates again.
Employer payrolls swelled by 217,000, somewhat less than most analysts had expected. But interpretation of the figure was clouded by a 78,000-job surge in local government, much of this related to the ending of the school year. The Bureau of Labor Statistics concedes that its efforts to adjust the figures for seasonality are highly inexact.
At the same time, May's job increase was revised upward by 28,000.
Factories added 14,000 jobs in June, continuing slow but steady gains since September. Retail trade rebounded to add 58,000 jobs, about half of these in restaurants and bars.
But construction and temporary help were little changed, and health services generated only 8,000 new jobs after averaging 21,000 during the first five months of the year. The financial sector added 11,000, lifting the 12-month increase to more than 100,000 jobs.
The index of aggregate weekly hours, a guide to industrial production for the month, climbed a modest four-tenths of 1 percent, to 140.7.
Today's report also suggested that people's confidence in their marketability had been tempered. The proportion of the unemployed who quit their latest job, typically in hopes of getting a better one, remained at 12.2 percent last month after a full-point jump in May.
Much of the rise in unemployment last month was concentrated among adult men, whose jobless rate bounced back to April's 4.2 percent from the 3.8 percent to which it had dropped in May.
In contrast to the expansion of employer payrolls, the department's survey of households tallied a 275,000-job decline, a divergence for which officials had no explanation other than normal statistical "noise."
This, combined with a small rise in the labor force, meant that the jobless rate moved back up to 5 percent, the first increase since January.
Regionally, the unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percent in the West and one-tenth of a point elsewhere. The West now stands at 5.6 percent, with the Northeast at 5.7 percent, the South at 5.1 percentand the Midwest at an impressively low 3.8 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Lockheed Martin to Buy Northrop for $8.3 Billion
Lockheed Martin, the maker of the F-16 fighter, plans to buy Northrop Grumman, which builds the MX missile, for $8.3 billion. It is expected to be the final chapter in the dizzyingly rapid consolidation of big American military contractors. 

 The deal would reinforce Lockheed Martin's position as the largest weapons supplier to the Pentagon -- ahead of Boeing and Raytheon -- and would create a company with annual revenue of about $35 billion and more than 230,000 employees. [Page A1.]
 
The merger, while further reducing competition, is unlikely to face a serious regulatory challenge, experts said, because of a Clinton Administration policy of explicitly supporting consolidation as the military contracting pie shrinks. [D2.]
 
Though both Northrop Grumman and Lockheed Martin have shrunk, they remain major presences in the New York area, and few further reductions were seen as an immediate consequence of the merger. [D2.]
 
Jobless Rate Rises to 5%
The unemployment rate climbed two-tenths of a percentage point in June, to 5 percent, after hitting a 24-year low in May. Financial markets liked the news, which indicates that the economy is still growing but not as quickly as it did earlier this year. Payrolls grew by a moderate 217,000 jobs. [A1.]
 
Treasury securities rallied on the unexpected jump in the unemployment rate. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond slid to 6.62 percent from 6.71. [D14.]
 
Mississippi Accord on Tobacco Cost
Four cigarette producers agreed to pay Mississippi $3.6 billion to resolve a suit over health care costs associated with smoking. The agreement, the first with any of the states seeking to recover Medicaid funds spent on smoking-related illnesses, could affect the proposed national tobacco settlement. [A1.]
 
$674 Million for Duty-Free Shops
BAA, the British airport operator, seeking to remain competitive in the growing market for duty-free retailing, plans to buy Duty Free International for $674 million. [D15.]
 
Ford Sales Increase in June
Incentives pushed auto sales at Ford Motor up 4.7 percent in June. The results contrasted with the weak trend at the other car makers; industrywide, sales fell 3.4 percent. [D3.]
Deal for Electronics Distributor
Veba of Germany agreed to buy Wyle Electronics of the United States for $609 million to increase its share of the worldwide electronics distribution market. [D2.]
 
Pepsico to Sell Pizza Chain
Pepsico has agreed to sell its California Pizza Kitchen restaurant chain to Bruckmann, Rosser, Sherrill, an investment fund, for a price that several industry executives estimated at nearly $100 million. [D16.]
 
Stocks of Cereal Makers Climb
Stock prices of cereal companies rose after General Mills announced that it would increase prices by an average of about 2.6 percent, or 10 cents a box. [D3.]
 
Batting 8,000
Batting averages and stock averages may have little in common, but since the start of the baseball season, the performances of the Dow industrials and the New York Mets have looked eerily similar, at least on graph paper. A scorecard. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Conducting A Search For Origins Of 'One Fare'

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
New York's two leading elected officials -- who know enough to stay away from trouble -- are never seen on the city's buses and overcrowded subways, but as city transit takes its biggest economic leap forward in 50 years this week, both of them have stepped forward to accept the public's gratitude for the long-anticipated introduction of free transfers.
Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have spent public money on ads that link them to the free transfers between buses and subways that begin today. The Mayor, who is also running a commercial that claims credit for the plan he calls, "One City, One Fare," is scheduled to be outside of Manhattan to greet commuters for the first rush hour under the new system on Monday morning. 
 Hardened transit riders, amazed that a promise made at the dawn of the $1.50 fare was actually kept, may be shocked into accepting some of the claims being thrown around. Indeed, riders who don't suffer from short-term memory loss might find it hard to give credit to Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani for one reason: when their re-election campaigns were further away both were cutting money from mass transit.
An examination of recent history shows that despite any claims to the contrary, it is difficult to draw a straight line between any elected official and the free transfers. The political origin of the Metrocard transfer is a foggy tale of shared responsibility, setbacks and large doses of hyperbole.
The dream of ending the much-hated two-fare zones had been planned long before either the Mayor or the Governor were elected. As far back as 1982, Richard Ravitch, then the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, began thinking about an automated turnstile system that would allow riders in Queens, Brooklyn, the Bronx and all of Staten Island to pay one fare for a ride to Manhattan.
By the end of the 1980's, the M.T.A. began planning in earnest for the Metrocard, a technical innovation that promised such other benefits as monthly passes and bulk discounts. In 1992, Peter E. Stangl, the next M.T.A. chairman, proposed what he called the "fare deal," which would have provided discounts and free transfers in exchange for a 25-cent fare hike.
Many transit advocates and even some officials at the M.T.A. believe the transfers plan could have gone into effect two or three years ago had not the Mayor and the Governor slashed their transit subsidies by hundreds of millions of dollars. At the time, years from their re-election campaigns, both were in full budget-cutting mode, with Mr. Giuliani in particular asserting that the agency could end two-fare zones simply by becoming more efficient.
The M.T.A. said it couldn't happen, and eventually won back a portion of the money that was cut. By 1995 it was ready to try again, and the current chairman, E. Virgil Conway, proposed a plan that included both the $1.50 fare and an end to two-fare zones. The plan passed, but the Mayor's four appointees to the board voted against the increase and the transfers.
Deputy Mayor Randy M. Mastro said Mr. Giuliani has long believed that two-fare zones are unfair to those who live outside Manhattan -- his core constituency -- and strongly advocated that the M.T.A. eliminate them after the fare went up. But considering that the M.T.A. was clearly inclined to do so already, Mr. Mastro's assertion that the two-fare zones could not have disappeared without Mr. Giuliani appears to be more of a boast. Former Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, a Giuliani appointee to the M.T.A., acknowledged as much, saying that the administration's pressure probably made the transfers happen about a year earlier than planned (conveniently, a few months before the election).
"I'm not denying that from the Mayor's point of view it's better to do it now," Mr. Dyson said, "but it's also better from the citizens' point of view."
But all sides give credit to the Mayor for allowing free transfers from the private bus lines in Queens and Brooklyn and from the Staten Island Ferry. Those riders, from some of Mr. Giuliani's favorite neighborhoods, will be among the few in the city who know exactly whom to thank.

HEADLINE: Clinton Makes Firm Denial In Sexual Harassment Case

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 3

 BODY:
President Clinton today denied Paula Corbin Jones' accusation that he propositioned her in a hotel room in 1991 when he was Governor of Arkansas, contending in a motion to dismiss her lawsuit that her accusation was intended to harm him politically.
In his first formal response to the accusations in Ms. Jones' sexual harassment lawsuit in Federal District Court here, Mr. Clinton said he did not recall ever meeting her and denied every allegation in her complaint. 
 "At no time did the President make sexual advances toward the plaintiff or otherwise act improperly in her presence," said the response filed by Mr. Clinton's lawyers.
In a memorandum accompanying Mr. Clinton's motion for dismissal, the President's lawyers said that, for argument purposes only, even if the President had propositioned Ms. Jones, it should be considered "a single overture, one abandoned as soon as she stated it was unwelcome."
While categorically denying each of Ms. Jones' accusations, Mr. Clinton's lawyers argued that her assertions did not represent a violation of the law.
Ms. Jones seeks $700,000 in damages. She contends that Mr. Clinton summoned her to a hotel room in Little Rock in 1991, exposed himself to her and asked her to perform a sex act. She was a state employee at the time.
She said in her lawsuit that she could identify distinguishing characteristics in the President's "genital area." Mr. Clinton's response said that she could not but did not elaborate.
The memorandum said Ms. Jones had political and financial motives for filing her lawsuit, saying she had joined "with longtime political opponents of the President who sought to discredit him and his Presidency."
"This, we believe, was done to maximize plaintiff's potential to derive economic benefit and simultaneously to harm the President politically," it said.
The case could go to trial in 1998. Judge Susan Webber Wright, a former law student of Mr. Clinton's, said in May that she would schedule the case soon after receiving the President's response. The typical time for a case to come to trial is 10 to 12 months.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: ARKANSAS, USA (93%);

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
645 Modular Houses Going Up in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Over the next three years, 645 homes for low- and moderate-income families will go up for 25 blocks west of Pennsylvania Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. But instead of being constructed using traditional techniques, they are being manufactured in a factory five miles away and assembled at the construction site.
On-site assembly began in April, and 26 of the 1,320-square-foot, two-story homes are visible along Snediker Avenue between Dumont and Livonia Avenues. They will be sold at an average price of $73,000 to families earning between $22,000 and $58,000, depending on family size. 
 The homes are being manufactured by the Capsys Corporation, which opened its factory last February in an industrial building that is as long as a football field and has 50-foot-high ceilings at the Brooklyn Navy Yard industrial park.
The venture is the latest to test the concept of factory-built houses, also known as modular homes, in New York City. Though the concept is considered an effective way to produce affordable housing because costs can be held down, such factories have not survived the ups and downs of the housing cycle in the city.
Capsys is producing the 645 steel-frame homes for East Brooklyn Congregations, the sponsors of the Nehemiah housing plan, named for the biblical figure sent to rebuild Jerusalem. The plan pairs city subsidies with private capital to produce modest row houses on land donated by the city. From 1983 to 1991, 2,200 Nehemiah houses were built in East New York and Brownsville, helping to revive the area.
The new homes will rise on the blocks sandwiched between the earlier houses. A second phase of 500 more homes ultimately will be built in nearby Spring Creek. This is the first time East Brooklyn Congregations, a coalition of churches, is using factory-built homes.
Construction financing is coming from a $6 million interest-free-loan fund put together with contributions from the coalition and the Community Preservation Corporation, a private, nonprofit consortium of New York-based banks and insurance companies.
New York City is providing $20,000 in subsidies per home, keeping the purchase price down. Below-market rate mortgages will also be available through the State of New York Mortgage Agency and conventional lenders. Buyers must make a $5,000 down payment and pay $5,000 to $7,000 in closing costs.
For Capsys, the $70 million, 645-unit first phase of the project was large enough to shoulder the risk and the cost, about $1 million, of setting up the factory, said Alan Bell, a principal with Nicholas Lembo, William Fowler and Peter Hansen in the company. All the partners have backgrounds in residential development in New York City. Mr. Lembo is also president of Monadnock Construction, which is assembling the houses.
"With a project in so large an area where it is difficult to maintain a consistent level of quality, factory-built housing made the most sense," said Mr. Lembo. This way, he said, quality can be improved because the homes can be produced year-round and under closer supervision. The cost to produce them can be about 10 percent lower than traditional houses, largely because of greater operating efficiencies and lower labor costs, Mr. Lembo said.
That appealed to East Brooklyn Congregations. The three-bedroom homes are 20 percent larger than the earlier ones and are of a higher quality, said Michael Gecan. He is lead organizer for the group in the project and a member of the Industrial Areas Foundation, a national community organizing group in Chicago.
Last year, 2,200 modular homes were produced in New York State, about 400 of which were put up in New York City, said Fred Hallahan, a Baltimore-based consultant who works with the modular industry. That represents about 6 percent of the state's overall housing production, he said.
In New York City, modular housing has a legacy of disappointments because of, among other things, development constraints, conflicting regulatory controls and union resistance to out-of-city, nonunion manufacturers. While major projects have given rise to factories, none survived downturns in the market.
Capsys addressed those issues by entering into a contract with the industrial division of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners and having its houses meet both state manufactured-housing codes and the city building code.
The factory turns out half of a house a day, or 125 houses a year, a figure Mr. Lembo said he intended to double. The brick- and aluminum-faced homes will have a basement, driveway and front and rear yards.
Jerome and Wanda Hannah will close on their home this month. "There is not a house more economical to meet the poor working-class person's purse," Mr. Hannah said. The couple's monthly mortgage will be slightly higher than the $650 they pay in rent, he said, adding, "We have something we can call our own."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Employees of the Capsys Corporation assemble a modular home at its headquarters in the Brooklyn Navy Yard industrial park. Over three years, 645 homes will go up in the East New York section of Brooklyn. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Racial Politics Lets Flawed Candidate Find Allies

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 3

 BODY:
As President Clinton spoke at a rally at the Daley Plaza here, days before his re-election last November, a senior White House aide groused privately that the President had had no choice but to share the stage with Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, once the pride of the Democratic Party and now one of its bigger embarrassments.
Ms. Moseley-Braun was an electoral sensation in 1992 when she catapulted from obscurity as the Cook County Recorder of Deeds to became the first African-American woman elected to the Senate. But her tenure as Illinois' senior Senator has been marred by a rash of miscues and episodes of questionable judgment, including disclosures about her financial practices and her private life and her secret visit to Nigeria last summer to meet with the country's brutal dictator, drawing negative publicity just as her party was about to assemble for its national convention in this city. 
 Now, Ms. Moseley-Braun, a 49-year-old lawyer, is viewed as perhaps the most endangered Senator running for re-election next year; so much so that Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, summoned this state's popular Governor, Jim Edgar, to Washington last week to entice him to challenge her. Days earlier, The Chicago Tribune had published a poll that found that among people who usually vote in Illinois elections, only a third wanted Ms. Moseley-Braun re-elected. The survey said her support among white suburban women, who were crucial to her election, had hemorrhaged. And her favorable rating was a rock-bottom 37 percent, compared with 64 percent for Governor Edgar.
Yet for all of her vulnerability, Democrats from here to Washington have acted early to embrace Ms. Moseley-Braun and discourage Democrats from challenging her. In a crucial move that has scared off rivals, Mayor Richard M. Daley bestowed an early endorsement on Ms. Moseley-Braun. And Mr. Clinton, returning last week for a fund-raising event that helped her erase a four-year-old campaign debt, declared that "she deserves your support."
The turnabout among Democrats reflects the sensitive politics of race rather than the accomplishments of Ms. Moseley-Braun. Many Democrats said they would be wary of the backlash if they took her on, particularly since this state has no other highly visible black politicians. Several Democrats also said they had no appetite to reopen the racial tensions of a decade ago, when a black mayor, Harold Washington, was elected in Chicago over two white challengers and the politics of race upended the city's once-monolithic Democratic machine. Some said they were acting out of self-interest; if black voters were alienated, they might not turn out for other Democratic candidates.
The decision to close ranks around Ms. Moseley-Braun so early also reflects the Democratic Party's problems in recruiting appealing candidates; the Illinois Democratic Party has been little more than a shell since many of the state's most promising Democratic elected officials were wiped out in the 1994 elections. Moreover, several Democrats said that finding a more formidable candidate was not worth the upheaval it would cause the state party.
"There's this aura of having messed up," said Dawn Clark Netsch, an Illinois Democrat who unsuccessfully challenged Governor Edgar in 1994 and who once introduced Ms. Moseley-Braun in the 1992 campaign as "a national heroine."
"All of these distractions have clearly crippled her effectiveness. The way you hear it expressed most often is that 'She messes up her personal life' and 'If she'd just get her act together.' What substance she's been involved with she has a hard time getting out because the rest of it overwhelms."
Explaining that she would still vote for Ms. Moseley-Braun against a Republican, Ms. Netsch said, "What else can we do?"
In an interview here, Ms. Moseley-Braun was lively and composed, and dismissed her missteps with hearty laughter. "For every blessing you get," she said, "the devil's going to try to take it away."
Ms. Moseley-Braun (pronounced MO-se-lee-Brawn) acknowledged that she had had difficulty making the switch to a national stage, and she still appears surprised that United States senators are held to higher expectations than ordinary citizens. "One of the most wrenching parts of the transition to the Senate has been coming to grips with not having a private life," she said, largely attributing her misfortune to having "not been a very good self promoter."
She said her meeting with Gen. Sani Abacha, Nigeria's dictator, for which she was rebuked by the State Department and criticized by human-rights advocates for lending legitimacy to that regime, was a mistake only because she had not announced it at news conference first.
"It frankly did not occur to me at all," she said. "It was like going to the hardware store with no makeup on. It wasn't a secret." Then, turning to a reporter, she asked, "Do you call a press conference when you go on vacation?"
She has described the Nigerian trip as an effort at "quiet diplomacy" on environmental and human rights issues. The Senator's companion on the trip was Kgosie Matthews, her former fiance and former campaign manager, who has been tied to many of her troubles and who has been registered with the Justice Department as an agent for Nigeria.
Among the tempests that have swirled around Ms. Moseley-Braun:
* Just before her election, it was disclosed that Ms. Moseley-Braun and her siblings had accepted a $28,750 inheritance from her mother, who was in a nursing home on Medicaid. She had not reported the money for tax purposes and paid the state about $15,000 to clear up the matter.
* After her election, Ms. Moseley-Braun took a monthlong vacation in Africa and England with Mr. Matthews, infuriating supporters who expected her to use the time to assemble a staff.
*Her office has been in upheaval uncommon even by Senate standards; she has gone through four chiefs of staffs in four years.
*Her former campaign treasurer, Earl Hopewell, has filed a lawsuit against her accusing Mr. Matthews of using $39,000 in campaign money to pay Ms. Moseley-Braun's credit card bills. Ms. Moseley-Braun dismissed Mr. Hopewell as "a disgruntled employee who wants money."
In the interview, Ms. Moseley-Braun said the Federal Election Commission had found "zero irregularities" in her 1992 campaign. But her press secretary, Michael Briggs, interjected to remind her that thousands of dollars in improper contributions had been returned.
"They did find some things you might call an irregularity," Mr. Briggs told his boss.
"Like what?" the Senator asked.
"Like you gave back some money that was in excess of the contributions" limits, Mr. Briggs said.
"Oh," she said. "That was bookkeeping errors. But that's not, quote, financial irregularities."
The only Democrat who has been openly weighing a challenge to Ms. Moseley-Braun is Michael Bakalis, a former state comptroller who has not been active in party politics for years. "The Senate is all about judgment, and there's been a whole series of lapses in good judgment," Mr. Bakalis said. "I don't think you can hide behind race and gender."
In an interview with a suburban newspaper last summer, Ms. Moseley-Braun warned: "I'm the only African-American in the United States Senate. Anybody who is going to take me on in this state, a Democrat, is going to have a hard time getting elected in November."
But in the interview this week, Ms. Moseley-Braun insisted, "I wasn't threatening anybody. It was a statement of fact: I am the only black person in the Senate."
In her own election, Ms. Moseley-Braun had no qualms about taking on an incumbent. She knocked off a two-term incumbent, Senator Alan J. Dixon, in the primary, capitalizing on the outrage over Mr. Dixon's support for Clarence Thomas's confirmation to the Supreme Court. The economic woes in Illinois then helped Ms. Moseley-Braun defeat her Republican challenger, Richard S. Williamson, a conservative businessman.
This time, Mayor Daley's support is crucial. Since Mr. Daley faces a primary less than four months after the 1998 election, his advisers said he would avoid alienating black voters, particularly since a black lawmaker, Representative Bobby Rush, is considering challenging him. Moreover, Mr. Daley and many of his Democratic peers have never viewed the Senate to be as important as local offices, where politicians hold much sway over patronage jobs.
Republicans may not be as unwilling to take on a politician who has become a symbol for blacks and for women. "At one time there would be a reluctance to take on an African-American women who has a lot of charm and a great smile as Carol does," Ms. Netsch said. "I don't know that it would hold anyone back this time."
Many Democrats said they hoped Governor Edgar does not enter the race, leaving Ms. Moseley-Braun to compete with a more conservative rival than the Governor who voters would view as too extreme. But the Governor said he was thinking seriously about running.
"For an incumbent, she's vulnerable," Mr. Edgar said in an interview. "I don't think she's automatically beatable, but she's got some real problems."
Ms. Moseley-Braun said she would implore voters to focus on her work in the Senate. "I have a legislative record second to none in my class," she said. She has a liberal voting record and has been an eloquent advocate for minorities and women. In a stirring floor speech in 1993 in which she took on Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, Ms. Moseley-Braun successfully opposed a bill to renew the patent on the United Daughters of the Confederacy's insignia, which includes the Confederate flag. And, as she vowed in the campaign, Ms. Moseley-Braun has focused on improving the nation's crumbling schools.
In his speech here, Mr. Clinton praised Ms. Moseley-Braun for votes that had helped him carry out his agenda, including his first-term economic package and legislation on crime, deficit reduction, the recovery of big cities and medical leave for workers.
Still, John P. Pelissero, a political science professor at Loyola University here, said Ms. Moseley-Braun is best known for "all these character issues." As for this state's Democrats, Mr. Pelissero said: "Everybody's thinking about their own career. People who aspire to Moseley-Braun's seat may view the election as a referendum on her and not the party. And if she's defeated, so be it."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on July 4 about Senator Carol Moseley-Braun's political future misstated the circumstances of a $15,000 payment that Ms. Moseley-Braun, an Illinois Democrat, made to the state authorities in 1992. It was to cover Medicaid expenses improperly paid to her late mother, not to pay unreported taxes.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Dollar Up in Foreign Trading; Stock Prices Abroad Are Mixed

BYLINE: By Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against major currencies yesterday in trading that was kept thin by the Fourth of July holiday in the United States. Against the German mark, the dollar touched its highest level in nearly 41 months.
In stock markets abroad, prices rose in Frankfurt but declined in London and Tokyo. 
 The American currency stood at 1.7589 marks in late London trading, up from 1.7535 marks in New York on Thursday. It reached an intraday high of 1.7592 marks, its highest since Feb. 10, 1994, when it traded as high as 1.7645 marks.
Against the yen, the dollar was quoted at 113.82 yen, up from 113.80 yen.
Dealers said the dollar's outlook for next week was positive, even though the American employment figures released Thursday showed nothing that would point to an increase in interest rates. Higher interest rates would support the dollar by increasing the returns available from fixed-income investments denominated in dollars.
The mark continued to be hurt by worries about the inability of Germany to cut its budget deficit, while the pound continued to draw most of the market's attention after the British budget statement on Wednesday, which increased expectations of higher interest rates.
The pound rose to 2.9658 marks from 2.9599 marks in London Thursday. But it fell to $1.6861 from $1.6906 in New York on Thursday.
British stocks declined. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 issues fell 18.90 points, to 4,812.80; it had been up as much as 50 points during the session but moved downward as banking stocks, which had been providing much of the support, retreated.
On the Frankfurt exchange, stocks rose to a record for the fourth consecutive session. The DAX index of 30 shares gained 55.14 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,942.53.
In Tokyo, stocks closed lower, and the Nikkei index of 225 issues fell below 20,000 for the first time since May 27. News that the Tokai Kogyo Company, a contractor, was filing for protection under Japanese bankruptcy law led to selling of the shares of banks and construction companies.
The Nikkei average declined 153.41 points, to 19,968.00.

HEADLINE: New Twist Makes Corporate Stock Options Even Sweeter

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
With the bull market going strong, stock options have become one of the sweetest deals available in the board rooms and corner offices of corporate America. And they are supposed to be good for outside investors, too, by encouraging directors and executives to generate big profits for the company so that they can generate big gains for themselves.
The only problem -- for the recipients anyway -- is the income tax that normally is due upon exercising the options. So, over the last few years, companies have developed a variety of ways to allow many executives, directors and valued employees to defer income taxes, often well into retirement, on the profits from exercising stock options. 
 And now, in a new twist on the tax deferral game, a handful of major corporations have come up with a method that not only lets those with stock options safely acquire their shares but also permits them to shed them and buy a diversified portfolio of other investments without paying taxes for years.
The question critics raise is whether this new strategy, by making it less costly for executives to dispose of their own company's stock, continues to serve one of the central purposes of stock options, which are special opportunities to acquire company shares at a set price and benefit from the rise in their market value.
Nell Minnow, an investment fund manger at Lens Inc., said that the new diversification approach, which was recently introduced at the Chrysler Corporation, "shows that you really can have your cake and eat it, too."
Under the Chrysler plan, which is only available to outside directors, board members can turn a profit when they acquire Chrysler shares through stock options. They are then able to eliminate the risk of continuing to own them by converting the gains into shares of other companies. And all this can be done without any taxes being owed for as much as 15 years.
The makers of accounting rules are looking into whether diversification strategies such as the one adopted by Chrysler should invalidate the favorable accounting treatment afforded to stock option plans. But mindful of the last time they tried to curb options and were squashed by pressure from Congress and high-technology business groups, those who set the standards are likely to be highly reluctant to act.
So far, only a handful of companies have adopted plans similar to Chrysler's, according to Brian Foley, an executive compensation consultant in White Plains. But dozens more have engaged consultants to draw up such plans.
Paul P. Bountras, a partner at Hale & Dorr, a Boston law firm that designed such a plan for Analog Devices Inc., an electronic switch company based in Norwood, Mass., said that such tax deferral efforts were perfectly justified. The Internal Revenue Service has long allowed executives to switch from one investment to another within a deferred compensation account, he said, so there should be no objection when company shares are acquired in a deferral account and then are effectively sold to buy the shares of other companies.
But such plans have plenty of detractors, too, even among those who might benefit from them.
Lester C. Thurow, the economist and a director of Analog Devices, said that he knew that the company allowed for tax deferral of exercised stock options. But he said he was unaware that Analog Devices also allowed executives and directors to continue the deferral after diversification.
"Maybe there is an argument, although dubious, that you can defer taxes on a stock option exercise if you stay" invested in the company's stock, said Mr. Thurow, who holds options on 66,500 Analog Devices shares. "But letting you move into another investment without paying taxes is just unfair."
Stock options have exploded in recent years, with the total value of shares set aside for options rising from some $60 billion in 1985 to about $600 billion today, according to Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. They have become an increasingly popular way to pay directors and executives because they are so cheap, creating a corporate income tax deduction without a corresponding expense, and because they provide a strong performance incentive for executives. The main disadvantage is that they can dilute the value of shares held by regular stockholders.
Under the Chrysler plan, outside directors receive options to acquire 3,000 shares annually. Traditionally, the profits from exercising a stock option were taxable immediately, but Chrysler lets outside directors exercise their options in a way that delays income taxes for up to 15 years. The key is that the company does not formally deliver the newly acquired shares to the director until he or she retires.
That tax deferral approach has become widespread in the last four years, even though no statute, court decision or I.R.S. ruling specifically authorizes it.
Chrysler's plan then introduces a further element by allowing directors to choose to shed their Chrysler shares and invest the proceeds in a diversified portfolio of stocks. Again, the operating theory is that delivery of this portfolio is delayed until the director retires.
Laurie McTavish, a Chrysler spokeswoman, said that the tax deferral was legitimate because the company was not required to actually sell the Chrysler shares acquired by the outside director.
Instead, Chrysler essentially makes a promise to pay, upon retirement, the value of the other stocks the director chooses. The company can actually acquire the shares or not, but it must make good on the promise, even if the prices of those stocks go up so much that Chrysler has to dip into its own funds to fulfill its pledge.
Chrysler's plan, among others, has attracted the attention of the emerging issues task force of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the body that defines generally accepted accounting principles.
The committee's 13 members -- 11 of whom must agree if the committee is to declare such plans inconsistent with accounting principles -- displayed deep divisions on the issue during a recent meeting to examine the arcane financial reporting issues raised by the new tax deferral plans.
Their debate also touched fleetingly on whether allowing top executives and directors to dispose of their company stock without paying an immediate tax undermines the whole idea of encouraging stock options as a way to help align the interests of directors with those of shareholders.
While the accounting standards board continues to examine the issue, the I.R.S. has not challenged any of the handful of plans similar to Chrysler's, executive compensation experts say.
But even if the Government is not concerned, Ms. Minnow, the shareholder advocate, said, investors should complain if their companies adopt such plans. "This puts risks onto companies that should properly be borne not by shareholders but by the executives," she said.
Ms. McTavish, the Chrysler spokeswoman, defended the company's plan. She said that Chrysler required directors to own at least 10,000 company shares, which is plenty to assure that the motivations of directors are closely tied to the fate of Chrysler's stock. There is no good reason, she said, to forbid directors to dispose of shares above that amount.
Still, some companies are worried that such tax deferral plans go too far.
For instance, the American Home Products Corporation, a maker of over-the-counter medications and pharmaceuticals based in Madison, N.J., authorized such a plan last year. But it soon terminated it, said Lowell Weiner, a company spokesman, because of uncertainties about the accounting issues.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

European Panel Opposes Takeover by Boeing
The European Union's antitrust advisory committee has come out against the $14 billion takeover of McDonnell Douglas by Boeing. It said the planned takeover would strengthen Boeing's "existing dominant position and therefore should be prohibited," people familiar with the decision said. 
 The recommendation does not end the European investigation into the impact the merger would have in Western Europe. A decision is expected later this month from the full European Union. Earlier this week, the Federal Trade Commission said it would not oppose the acquisition of McDonnell Douglas by Boeing. [36.]
 
The Lure of Inner Cities
People are spurning the suburbs and moving to inner cities like those of Detroit, Houston, Cleveland and Chicago where new developments look like suburban subdivisions with well-manicured lawns, backyards and white picket fences. [1.]
 
Bertelsmann Mum on Compuserve
The German media giant Bertelsmann refused to comment on a report that it may be teaming with America Online to acquire Compuserve, its rival in on-line computer services. Bertelsmann, which already has alliances with America Online, would provide the needed cash for the purchase of the money-losing division of H & R Block. [36.]
 
Germany has approved a law banning cyberspace smut and Nazi propaganda, but critics contend it is too vague on the responsibilities of companies that provide on-line services. [36.]
 
Bad Loans Plague Japan Banks
Japanese banks, savings institutions and agricultural cooperatives are still struggling to rid themselves of the 27.9 trillion yen, or $240 billion, in bad loans that have plagued them since the collapse of the real estate market earlier this decade. [37.]
 
A Town Suffers From a Long Strike
Few people were celebrating America's birthday yesterday in Mingo Junction, Ohio, which has been troubled by a 10-month strike by 4,500 workers of Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel. It is not just the 400 families in the small town along the Ohio River who have felt the stress because of the loss of income. The town, suffering from a loss of fees from water it supplies the local plant, has been forced to lay off municipal workers, and businesses are bemoaning the lack of customers. [6.]
 
Dollar Rises Against Yen
The dollar rose against most major currencies in thin trading because of the Fourth of July holiday. The American currency stood at 113.82 yen, up from 113.80 yen Thursday, and at 1.7589 marks in London, up from 1.7535 marks in New York Thursday. The mark continued to be hurt by worries about the inability of Germany to cut its budget deficit, while the pound continued to draw most of the market's attention after the British budget statement on Wednesday, which increased expectations of higher interest rates. [37.]
 
A Japanese bureaucrat, Eisuke Sakakibara, with strong influence over the currency markets was appointed vice finance minister for international affairs. The promotion will make him Japan's top bureaucrat in global finance. Mr. Sakakibara, who is currently in charge of the Finance Ministry's International Finance Bureau, is widely credited with orchestrating the dollar's 1995 recovery from its lowest levels since World War II. [37.]
 
Ex-Dai-Ichi Officials Indicted
Tokyo prosecutors indicted a former vice president of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Ichiro Fujita, and a former managing director, Tateo Fukushima, in connection with illegal loans that the bank purportedly made to a corporate racketeer. Separately, NHK television said that prosecutors had arrested Tadashi Okuda, the bank's former chairman. [37]

HEADLINE: Demand for Single-Family Homes Helps Fuel Inner-City Resurgence

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 4

 BODY:
M. C. and Debra Hampton plan to move next week to their corner of the American Dream: a newly built house in a well-kept, middle-class neighborhood, the kind of home that for decades here has meant moving to the suburbs.
But like more and more people nationwide, the Hamptons are not steeling themselves for an hourlong commute. Instead, they are moving into a new two-story colonial house in the inner city, where few new houses were built for so long. 
 "All of our roots and family are still within the city," said Mr. Hampton, 42, who is moving with his wife from an older house elsewhere in Detroit. "We didn't want to go to the suburbs."
In cities like Detroit and Houston, Cleveland and Chicago, developers are discovering for the first time in decades a demand for new houses in inner-city neighborhoods. Most of the houses cost $85,000 to $250,000, with some priced at more than $500,000. The new neighborhoods tend to look like suburban subdivisions, with well-kept lawns, backyards and cul de sacs.
"There's a downtown housing boom" in several cities, said Bruce J. Katz, director of the Center on Urban and Metropolitan Policy at the Brookings Institution.
Mr. Katz and other housing experts said the new inner-city subdivisions had been spawned by several disparate factors -- like an increase in available financing and a backlash against suburban sprawl -- that had brought government and market forces to bear at the same time.
In Detroit, buyers recently drove through blighted neighborhoods to the gates of a planned subdivision nearby, then waited in line all night for the chance to put deposits on houses costing $350,000 to $600,000. In Cleveland, it has become trendy to replace abandoned houses with large custom-built houses.
Houston hopes to spur the building or renovation of 5,000 houses a year in poorer neighborhoods, and in Chicago home building has also been on the rise in recent years, with 830 building permits for new houses issued last year, nearly twice as many as in 1991.
Most of the houses match the style of their neighborhoods. In sprawling cities like Detroit and Cleveland, new single-family homes are sprouting in neighborhoods that traditionally had them. In denser cities like New York and Baltimore, they are town houses or row houses.
A coalition of churches and synagogues in Brooklyn helped build 2,300 town houses in recent years, 1,200 in the Brownsville section and 1,100 in the East New York section, with another 1,200 single-family homes under construction in East New York.
And the New York City Partnership, a business group, has been building houses for middle-income buyers in the city's poor neighborhoods, including blocks of row houses in the South Bronx. In Newark, 800 town houses have been built and several hundred more are planned.
While few of the new privately developed homes are intended for lower-income people, the Federal Government is trying to stabilize inner-city neighborhoods by encouraging the very poor to buy homes. The Clinton Administration last month outlined a five-year pilot program under which up to 75,000 poor people who receive Federal rental vouchers would be eligible for "empowerment vouchers." If Congress passes the proposed legislation, which has fallen by the wayside in the previous four years, those who work and are able to contribute toward a down payment could apply their Federal subsidies to mortgage payments instead of rent.
Housing experts said the new private developments indirectly helped the poor because they tended to attract new grocery stores, drugstores and other businesses to neighborhoods with few such conveniences. Because the houses are built in underpopulated neighborhoods, they generally do not displace poor residents.
"They are being built in neighborhoods of abandonment and on sites that are literally vacant land or abandoned buildings," said Marc A. Weiss, special assistant to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. "This is not the urban renewal days where you're going into neighborhoods and throwing people out of their homes."
Homeowners who have already moved into the new city neighborhoods said the latter had proved safe, confounding stereotypes of the inner city. In Detroit, the new subdivisions tend to have a guarded entrance and to be fenced off from less prosperous neighborhoods nearby.
Henry C. Dace, 48, who has lived since 1995 in Victoria Park, a new 157-house subdivision that was the first built in Detroit since the Eisenhower Administration, said: "I love it. It is serene and peaceful."
To be sure, the number of new houses built in central cities does not come close to reaching the number built in the suburbs, and it has only slowed the continuing stream of people moving out of cities. But housing experts say the number of new central-city houses is notable because it represents the first downtown housing boom in decades.
The trend is most noticeable in Detroit and Cleveland, cities better known for the startling number of residents who have moved out, shrinking each city by one-third in just three decades. From 1988 to 1990, only one building permit for a single-family home was issued in the entire 139-square-mile city of Detroit. Since then, 360 building permits have been issued for single-family homes. In Cleveland, nearly 1,000 building permits for single-family homes have been issued since 1992, four times the number in the previous four years.
Perhaps the most striking transformation in the nation is under way in one of Cleveland's most downtrodden neighborhoods, Hough, where luxury houses are replacing abandoned ones.
Ronnie A. Stephens, 44, a civilian manager for the Defense Department in Cleveland, plans to move this autumn -- too late to open his swimming pool -- to the 4,200-square-foot colonial-style house he is building in a neighborhood that used to prompt passing motorists to lock their car doors.
People said he was crazy to build in that neighborhood, recalled Mr. Stephens, whose new house will cost about $500,000 and cut his nearly half-hour commute from the suburbs to eight minutes. But times have changed.
"That area now is really like a status symbol," Mr. Stephens said.
About 100 custom houses have been built in Hough in the past decade, and the pace has picked up in recent years, with the houses growing larger and more lavish and expensive.
Mr. Stephens said he had been lured downtown in part by the financial incentives offered by the city. To rebuild its neighborhoods and its tax base, Cleveland has been demolishing abandoned city-owned houses and selling the empty lots for $100, then giving the owners property tax abatements of 10 to 15 years while promoting a private mortgage program that offers interest rates about one percentage point below market rates.
"We are literally reknitting the fabric of inner-city communities one house at a time," said Mayor Michael R. White of Cleveland, who said about 40 percent of new downtown home buyers had moved from the suburbs, with the rest moving from elsewhere in the city.
In Cleveland and Detroit, many but by no means all of the buyers are black professionals.
While falling rates of crime and increased optimism about the cities have encouraged people to buy downtown, plenty of hurdles remain, the biggest of which seems to be the troubled public schools. Both Mr. White in Cleveland and Mayor Dennis W. Archer of Detroit acknowledged that concern about the schools had discouraged families with school-age children from moving in.
Instead, buyers tend to be childless couples, people with grown children or people who plan to send their children to private schools.
Gordon T. Ford, 28, a suburbanite who waited all night to put a deposit on a $450,000 waterfront home in Detroit, said he and his wife, Tina, who have not had children yet, had always planned to send them to private schools. Still, Mr. Ford recalled, some friends were shocked that the couple would consider moving downtown, warning them, ' "You're going to get killed.' "
While attitudes can take a long time to change, home buyers, real estate agents, builders, politicians and housing experts offered several reasons for the increase in new houses in cities around the country. Among them are these:
*It is easier for buyers to get home loans in the inner city, partly because of the strong economy and partly because of more strictly enforced lending laws.
*Decades with so few houses being built have created a pent-up demand for new city homes.
*Some cities have begun heading back up economically after seeming to hit bottom, inspiring confidence that the houses will prove a good investments, and many cities have grown safer as well.
*The large-scale abandonment in the past decades has left cities with low land prices and plenty of available space.
*As the suburbs and exurbs have grown more distant, cities have become attractive for their far shorter commuting distances to jobs and quick access to restaurants, theaters and sports stadiums.
*Cities have experimented more in recent years with partnerships between government and developers instead of relying solely on government programs to spur building.
While many of the new housing developments take advantage of Federal, state and local money available under urban homesteading provisions, the more houses that are built, the fewer subsidies seem to be needed. Buyers for many of the new houses in Houston are eligible for a $9,500 loan toward the down payment, with 20 percent forgiven for each year they live in the house. One skeptical builder insisted the down-payment loans be available for potential customers. To his surprise, "the houses were virtually all sold without the down-payment assistance," said Michael S. Stevens, a developer who is paid $1 a year to run Houston's housing program.
The housing boom has tapped feelings of community pride in home buyers, who like the idea of helping long-suffering cities that they believe are trying to revive themselves.
"You can actually be a part of the renewal," said Joanna V. Masten, 41, a software company executive who, with her husband, Herschell, will soon move into a new three-story waterfront house in Detroit.
Other home buyers say they hope their new homes will help their less fortunate neighbors improve their lot. "There is some low-income housing behind me," said Mr. Stephens, who is building the half-million-dollar house in Cleveland. "To put these type of houses around them gives people an incentive to want to do better."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Betsy's Place: An Oasis Fit for Bogart

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia

 BODY:
In Casablanca, everybody went to Rick's. In Tbilisi, they go to Betsy's Place.
On a narrow, steep and crumbling side street of the once raffish and now mostly ravaged capital of Georgia, there is a small hotel. Diplomats, World Bank analysts and consultants stay there. Le tout Tbilisi and visiting jet-setters drop in for dinner. In June, Shahpari Khashoggi, the wife of Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi financier and former arms trader, had dinner there with the owner, daintily sampling lobio and satsivi by candlelight on the rooftop terrace. 
 The proprietor of the elegant Betsy's Place is in her own way as improbable an expatriate as the one played by Humphrey Bogart. Betsy is actually Elizabeth Haskell, an exquisitely dressed, impeccably coiffed former Baltimore debutante in her late 50's who most days looks as if she just stepped out of a garden club meeting in Georgetown.
"I wanted to call the hotel '21,' as in its address, 21 Gogibashvili, you know, like '21' in New York," she explained in brisk, upper-class tones. "But people kept calling it 'Betsy's Place,' and I figured I had better register before somebody stole the name."
The story behind Betsy's Place could not be more different from the founding of "21" in Manhattan. In 1994, Tbilisi, not yet recovered from civil war with neighboring Abkhasia, was in the throes of a power struggle between rival private armies. It was a city under curfew, with no heat, running water or electricity and gunfire echoing through the night.
That summer, Kalashnikov-toting paramilitary men loyal to Jaba Ioseliani, a charismatic bandit-rebel who is now in jail, took over the lobby of the Metechi Palace, a huge luxury hotel built by an Austrian chain in 1989. Combatants had a habit of spraying the lobby with bullets, leading the United States Embassy to decide it would be imprudent to continue putting up its visiting officials and humanitarian aid workers there.
"The embassy asked me if I could find someplace else," Ms. Haskell, who was then running her own real estate company here, recalled. "I had this wonderful house for rent, with bathrooms on every floor, so I said yes." Three weeks later, she opened for business.
Peace has been restored under President Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Prosperity, however, remains elusive. Foreign investors are not yet flocking in droves, and the occupancy rate of the $300-a-night Metechi Palace hovers at 20 percent.
The 13 rooms and two suites that make up Betsy's Place, however, are booked months in advance and cost $100 to $130 a night. Guests are greeted by cool stone and gleaming hardwood floors, plush Oriental carpets, antique furniture and fresh flowers.
Ms. Haskell installed a diesel-fueled furnace to provide heat and hot water for showers -- one of the few houses in Tbilisi with such a luxury. She has a generator -- and candles -- to deal with the frequent power failures. Telephone service in Tbilisi remains erratic, and guests cannot make trans-Atlantic calls from their rooms. Ms. Haskell is arranging to provide all guests with rented cellular phones.
She said she still had to ship in most supplies from Turkey, even cleaning products, sheets, towels and glassware. "The cost of business is high because everything is imported," she said. "It's like living on Nantucket."
With Georgian and foreign backers, she has also opened a swanky private business club, the Transcaucasian, in a stately mansion belonging to the composers' union. Worried that hotel guests will weary of the local fare of eggplant, tomatoes and cucumber, she is starting her own farm to grow peas and asparagus for her restaurant. "You can get bored with the food," she said with a small sigh. "There isn't much variety."
Ms. Haskell, a former labor organizer who is divorced and was widowed twice, has led a varied life, but she had never run her own business until she moved to Tbilisi five years ago. She had never even lived overseas.
When the Berlin wall came down and the Soviet empire began to crumble, Ms. Haskell was ensconced in Georgetown, running an exchange program to promote understanding between American politicians and their Soviet and Eastern European counterparts.
"Betsy would sweep these foreign dignitaries from the airport in her Chevrolet convertible, take them around and entertain them with fabulous dinner parties at her house," said Ann Polk, a friend in Washington. "Of course, they were all just enchanted."
But the exchange program shut down soon after the failed 1991 coup against the Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. Ms. Haskell said that without the program to run, she grew bored and restless in Washington. When a young Georgian politician came to her for advice on how to foster democracy under the rule of Georgia's first, authoritarian President, Zviad Gamsakhurdia, she ended up traveling to Tbilisi to organize a seminar on business planning and foreign investment.
Upon her return to Washington, she won a $250,000 grant from Metromedia, the communications giant, to encourage private investment in Georgia. That led to the opening of her real estate firm in 1993 with two female Georgian partners. Asked whether she knew anything about real estate before she started, Ms. Haskell airily replied, "No, but I moved a lot -- after a while, you just sort of know." She said it was easy. "After a month, we had a huge data base," she said. "Basically every house was available -- Georgians always have three houses."
She sold the firm to her partners last year to manage the hotel full time. The secret of her success in the uncharted and Byzantine world of Georgian business, said the confident and well-connected Ms. Haskell, is that she is a sole proprietor, unfettered by the shifting rules that can stymie major joint ventures.
"I'm not a winery or a bottling plant -- I'm a small-business blip," she said. She laughed when asked about corruption, saying, "Corruption can also work your way."
Ms. Haskell, who drives herself around town in a new, teal blue Russian-made Lada, said her only regret was that Tbilisi has nothing in the way of Chinese food, Western movie theaters or shopping.
"There are no real stores here," she said. "I order my clothes from Talbots."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The rooms at Betsy's Place, owned by Elizabeth Haskell, are booked months in advance. As a sole proprietor, Ms. Haskell is unfettered by the shifting rules that can stymie other businesses in Tbilisi, Georgia. (James Hill for The New York Times)(pg. 37)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: In Congo, Drivers Find They Can't Get There From Here

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: EPULU, Congo

 BODY:
In a country that may have the worst roads in the world, Sam Onzima was busy doing what drivers often do here in Congo. He was stretched out beneath his Land Rover in the middle of the jungle, hammering away and going nowhere.
"I've been stuck here three weeks," Mr. Onzima, a lanky 37-year-old with an understandably untrimmed beard, said as he stood and stretched beside the road, 20 miles west of the town of Epulu in northeastern Congo. "I hit a pothole and that broke the rear axle." 
 To carry passengers and cargo on these roads, as Mr. Onzima does, requires the patience of Job and the ingenuity of Edison, but most drivers seem equipped with both. Mr. Onzima salvaged a rear differential from another Land Rover that had been stripped and abandoned down the road. Then he lugged everything to Epulu, where someone let him use welding equipment.
"Finding that rear differential really saved me," Mr. Onzima said enthusiastically. "I figure I'll be here another couple of days and then I'll be on my way."
Congo itself is also trying to get back on its way, with the end of decades of rule by the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, and one of its central challenges is to build a transportation network. Congo, which was known as Zaire under Mr. Mobutu, is one-third the size of the United States and mostly in the same state of jungle that existed 1,000 years ago.
Roads are a problem for most of Africa -- the entire continent has only one-quarter as many miles of roads as the United States, even though Africa is three times the size -- and the consequences are profound. In much of Congo, for example, it is impossible to get goods to market, to distribute vaccines, to get children feverish with malaria to a clinic.
"Zaire's roads are maybe the worst, but its problem is representative of the problems in much of the continent except southern Africa," said Salih Booker, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. "This is a big bottleneck for all African countries when it comes to achieving more rapid economic growth."
There is an old joke that Mr. Mobutu once warned the leader of neighboring Rwanda, after a coup attempt there, "That's what happens when you start building roads." But even if impassable roads helped keep freeze the country politically and keep Mr. Mobutu in power, they also fossilized the interior and sent living standards spinning backward.
"The Mobutu regime totally neglected infrastructure, and so there are many villages that have been completely cut off, completely isolated," mused Lobela Alauwa, the Mayor of the hub city of Kisangani. "Those villages never see a truck, never see a bicycle."
Mr. Alauwa jabbed at a torn and faded map dating from 1958 -- the only map of Kisangani available -- and thrust his forefinger at an area where the roads are so overgrown that they have faded into jungle.
"This area is full of forgotten villages," he said. "Nobody even knows about them anymore."
Perhaps it is a commonplace to say that roads are to a nation what arteries and veins are to a human body, and that without circulation there is no development and only decay. But it seems a more profound truth after spending six days traveling across northeastern Congo and into Uganda, after bouncing over huge rocks, after pushing the vehicle through countless mudholes, after catching malaria on the route.
The road, ornamented by the carcasses of little engines that couldn't, plagued by bandits with machine guns, punctuated by submarine bogs that recall the Everglades, is not some minor track. On the contrary, it is now the only supply line across eastern Congo, a crucial link across central Africa, the kind of highway that merits a thick red line on maps.
But for the last few years it had been totally impassable. This spring the rebel soldiers forced their prisoners of war, the troops of the Mobutu Government, to repair the road, and so four-wheel-drive vehicles are again beginning to get through.
Still, a driver needs an assistant to jog ahead of the car for long stretches and wade through mud puddles to make sure that they are not too deep. If the puddles rise to a man's chest, it is time to pull out a machete and carve a bypass through the jungle.

Pockets of Isolation
 
A Provincial Town Is Now Unreachable
In 1960, when Belgium gave up this colony and it became independent, the country had 88,000 miles of usable roads. These days, particularly in the rainy season, there are almost no roads anywhere in the country that can be negotiated by an ordinary car.
In other words, as most of the world is getting smaller, Congo is getting larger.
The city of Buta is a provincial center that used to be just a six-hour drive by ordinary car from Kisangani. Now Congo has expanded so much that Buta is unreachable.
"There are no vehicles going to Buta anymore," Yambello Komba, the chief of a long-distance bus station in Kisangani, said with a look of incredulity. "If you want to go, first you'd have to buy gas for the ferry halfway there and pay it to take you across the river, because the ferry has stopped, too. Then on the other side of the river, the road is so bad that to get to Buta it would take a month, maybe two or three."
Cities like Buta spin off into their own economic universe, cut off from the rest of the world. The isolation is compounded because this region of eastern Congo no longer has postal delivery or inter-city telephone service. In the last year, even intermittent air service has ceased.
Because the roads of Congo are so awful, vehicles are rare on the road from Kisangani to Uganda, about one every two hours in each direction -- which is just as well, since it is a one-lane road. But there are dozens of bicycles for every motor vehicle, and the bicyclists are the real heroes of commerce in this country.
"This is very tough work," grunted Porluku Trofimo, a 30-year-old man who was sweating in the tropical heat as he struggled to push his bicycle and its load of flip-flops and clothes. "But it's the only thing I can do. It's better than stealing."
Mr. Trofimo's bicycle has no pedals, but it does not matter much. Most of the way he must push the bicycle rather than ride it. In any case, if Mr. Trofimo seemed in bad shape, his companion, Ezekiel Kitaholia, was doing even worse.
"I've got malaria," Mr. Kitaholia said weakly as he leaned on his bike during a brief stand-up rest. Looking as if he was about to collapse, he added, "I'm not feeling so good."
Alternately pushing their bicycles and riding them, from dawn to dusk, it takes the two men one week to carry their goods from the market town of Butembo to Isiro, a distance of about 250 miles. Then they sell the goods to shopkeepers in Isiro and buy palm oil to carry back home to Butembo.
They sleep by the side of the road, hiding themselves and their bicycles so bandits will not trouble them, and covering themselves with a tarpaulin when it rains.

The Road Hazards
 
Drivers Watch Out For Bandits, Mines
This concern about banditry -- whether by thieves, guerrillas or Government soldiers -- is a major impediment to commerce in Africa, particularly in Congo.
Under the Mobutu Government, the worst thieves were the soldiers, and the new troops who have defeated Mr. Mobutu's forces are clearly better-mannered. But at nearly every checkpoint, they ask for a donation before moving the barrier from the road; there is no direct threat, but it still seems churlish to refuse a man a gift when he is holding an AK-47 on you.
This particular road, because of the civil war of the last few months, offers a few special concerns.
"This road was mined for the next 60 kilometers," or 35 miles, the driver explained calmly as he left Kisangani for the east. "But I think the mines have probably been discovered, and in any case I'll just follow in the tracks of cars that have gone ahead of us."
A mile later, large mud puddles became frequent, so the driver started swerving to each side to avoid them, producing gasps from the passengers.

The Accidents
 
Trucks and People Get Little Help
In some stretches of the road, travelers spend less time driving than trying to extricate their vehicle from the mud. Trucks also sometimes topple over and block the road, for they are often so overloaded that the center of gravity is far off the ground.
"We just don't have roads," moaned Sammy Ruhigwa, a 32-year-old driver whose truck was stuck near another that had overturned, scattering its contents into the bush. "And without roads, how can you have development?" Mr. Ruhigwa is a mechanic, but even so the challenges of keeping a vehicle going are almost unimaginable. The new Government of Congo has said that improving roads is a major priority, but it would take billions of dollars and many years to establish a modern transportation network. The country needs not only asphalt but much more as well, for along Mr. Ruhigwa's entire route there are no auto supply stores or repair shops, no real gas stations, no tow trucks, no electrical outlets and no telephones.
And when there are accidents or illnesses, there are no doctors.
One quiet afternoon in Epulu, as villagers listlessly tried to sell meals of rice and beans to passing motorists or bicyclists, a group of men struggled to fix a 12-ton truck with axle trouble. It had been jacked up and was resting on sections of logs as several men lay underneath.
Then one of the props gave way. For several moments there was only shocked silence, and then an unearthly scream.
The village erupted as everyone nearby rushed to the truck and braced to lift it up, straining and sweating, precariously lifting it inch by inch, seeing it fall back a bit, and then pushing again, and suddenly it was up and somebody had put a new block under the chassis and two others were pulling out a man whose mouth was gushing blood.
The rescuers rushed him to the nearby clinic. But the clinic is a rudimentary one with no doctor, only a young nurse, who bandaged the man's head and unsuccessfully tried to halt the bleeding. It is unclear if he survived.
All the dangers to life and property naturally add to the cost of transportation. There are very few people in Congo with a good four-wheel-drive vehicle, and few want to risk such a valuable possession by sending it out into the bush.
"That's why things are so expensive out here, because of transportation," said Eduard Steffens, a 57-year-old Congo native who spent 18 years living in the United States.
"By the time you get to Kisangani, your truck is ready to be overhauled," sighed Mr. Steffens, who now makes a living trucking goods across eastern Congo in his pickup. "We're using the vehicles as bulldozers, pushing and scraping our way through."
The town where Mr. Steffens was passing the night, Nia-Nia, underscores the way regions have been almost lost to the jungle because of the decrepitude of the roads. A "Shell" sign still stands guard over the carcass of the local service station, but the building has been abandoned and now a mud hut stands where attendants once pumped gas.

HEADLINE: Mingo Junction Journal;
As Strike Wears On, Town's Life Ebbs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: MINGO JUNCTION, Ohio, July 4

 BODY:
Archie Wilfred, a bartender at the Schutzen Club, was sweeping the sidewalk and said he had not served a customer all day. Sitting in a corner of the Hometown Luncheonette, which she runs with her husband, Thelma Peterson wondered if the July 4th Special for $3.50 -- one hamburger or two hot dogs, plus macaroni salad, potato salad and baked beans -- would draw any customers.
Lou Lane, who has run Lane's Lounge for 50 years, said business has fallen off so much "there hasn't been a card game in the back room for six months." 
 "Never seen anything like this before," Mr. Lane said from behind the front counter. "This is the worst, and it's been tough on everybody."
Mingo Junction, a town of 4,300 people three miles south of Steubenville, sits at ground zero of the longest steelworker strike in American history. More than 10 months ago, 4,500 workers in eight plants owned by the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation walked out in a dispute that largely centers on pension benefits. The largest of the plants is here in Mingo Junction. It employed 2,600 of the striking workers, members of the United Steelworkers of America, who made a range of products from car parts to girders.
Periodic negotiations, some with a Federal mediator, have failed to resolve the differences, and caught in the middle are dozens of steel towns along the Ohio River in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. Here and elsewhere, businesses are closing, and families are stressed. The authorities have even attributed several suicides to the strike.
Today was the nation's birthday? It was hardly festive here in Mingo Junction, where the plant runs the length of town and touches virtually everything and everybody, one way or another. Few felt like celebrating. Even backyards in the hills overlooking Main Street and the plant were bereft of family gatherings and barbecues.
"You know, people tell me all the time they are tired of talking about the strike," said Chief Mike J. Maguschak of the Police Department. "But almost every conversation ends with people talking about the strike. It's affecting everything around here."
The town population includes 2,200 families, 400 of which have someone who works for Wheeling-Pitt, as it is known here, giving Mingo Junction one of the highest concentrations of steelworkers among towns in the Ohio Valley. As a result, the impact of the strike has been especially widespread and dramatic.
Not only have local residents lost income from jobs that pay $17 an hour and more, Mayor John A. Corrigan Jr. said Mingo Junction was losing $4,400 a day in fees the plant pays for water when fully operating, money that accounts for about a quarter of the town's $8 million annual budget. Without the money, Mayor Corrigan said, the town has laid off 20 employees, including a firefighter and 2 of its 12 police officers. The strike has also wiped out a summer jobs program that traditionally provides minimum wage work for as many as 80 of the town's young people.
Signs of stress are evident along Main Street. A poster hanging in a flower shop said almost every item was half-price. Down the street at Mazalick's Carryout Deli there was little to carry out. The shelves were empty of most items, except for candy, potato chips, newspapers and ice.
"We're just hanging on," said the owner, Betty Mazalick. "I opened in December and thought the strike would last only a couple of months. I was taking in $400 a day. Now, I'm down to $85. People can't even afford to buy candy."
Gino Ardito, a Mingo Junction native who has run a Main Street hardware and paint store for more than 40 years, said he had been closing up three and four hours early every day because no one had money to spend. He estimated that his business was off 50 percent, "and I'm struggling to keep it open."
Chief Maguschak said that crime had not increased in the last 10 months, but that alcohol-related incidents had. Officers, he said, have responded to more bar fights and domestic calls from "upset wives."
"The general feeling is that a lot of guys are mad," the Chief said. "They're mad about the situation with the company, and that more or less spreads to a lot of things they do."
At an entry to the plant, five strikers gathered for a daily vigil that passes for picketing. They gave up carrying signs long ago and now just hang out as a show of solidarity.
"The biggest thing for me is that I can't save any money," said Jim Guiliano, 43, a pipe fitter and welder who has worked at the plant for 22 years and has a 13-year-old son. "Let's face it, my life is about over, and I'm not going to be able to do anything different. But I would like to set him up so he could maybe go to college."
Several workers said they had known Kelly Lonetta, a 51-year-old crane operator who shot himself in the head about a month ago. Mr. Lonetta had told friends he was "obsessively depressed" over the strike and could not understand why the company was taking such a hard line. He left a wife and two children.
John Wiater, a company spokesman, sympathized with residents of Mingo Junction and other Ohio Valley towns, saying, "No doubt this has been a hardship on all the families."
But Mr. Wiater added that Wheeling-Pitt, a subsidiary of the WHX Corporation, was also at risk, uncertain whether its former customers will return.
That rationale was of little consequence to Mayor Corrigan, who could scarcely hide his depression.
"We're a one-industry town," he said. "Wheeling-Pitt is the heart of Mingo Junction. Right now, the heart is dead, and Mingo Junction is dying."
