HEADLINE: Anti-Drug Tax Lifts Kansas City

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
When weekends turn rowdy, Preston Washington arranges for his clients to leave home and move temporarily into a halfway house to avoid violating their parole.
"They're living in surroundings where there's a lot of drugging and drinking on weekends," said Mr. Washington, a former policeman and parole officer who runs Opportunity to Succeed, a program that helps ex-convicts find jobs, housing and a drug-free life. 
 "None have barriers like convicted felons," Mr. Washington said. "The opportunity is here for them to make that transition as productive citizens."
Opportunity to Succeed is one of an ingenious array of local programs that are partly financed by tacking a modest quarter of a percent onto the local sales tax imposed in Jackson County, which includes half of Kansas City and all of its inner-city neighborhoods.
Seven years after it went into effect, the county's anti-drug tax remains highly unusual in financing drug treatment and prevention along with law enforcement. At a time when politicians vie to cut taxes, the Jackson County prosecutor, Claire McCaskill, concedes that "the prospect of passing a new tax appears daunting to most people."
Yet the surtax remains popular even though it raises the combined state and city tax to about 6.5 percent in Kansas City and 6 percent elsewhere in the county.
The anti-drug tax was approved by Kansas City voters in 1989 in response to a surge of violent crime that was linked to crack cocaine. But the county's former prosecutor, Albert Riederer, who championed the tax, had no detailed plan for spending the new revenue. More than $400,000 went to buy new computers for the prosecutor's office, while money earmarked for drug prevention and treatment took a long time to reach the street.
The tax's image was hardly enhanced by the choice of a hypodermic syringe as its symbol.
After Ms. McCaskill became prosecutor in 1993, she gave the anti-drug tax an aggressive and acronymic name, Combat, for community-based anti-drug tax. A clenched fist replaced the syringe, and an experienced public health administrator, James T. Nunnelly, was hired to run the program for the prosecutor's office.
The tax itself has been credited with some results. Last year, the number of drug cases filed for prosecution rose to 2,212, from 515 in 1989. Violent crime has declined 30 percent since 1991, pushing Kansas City, which once ranked as the third-most-violent city in the nation, off the list of the worst 10. And as many as 700 people a month have entered or returned to drug treatment, Mr. Nunnelly said.
But with drugs still a problem, other dividends are less tangible. "How do you prove that which you have prevented?" Ms. McCaskill asked.
To find out how voters felt, she organized another referendum to renew the tax in 1995, two years before it was to have expired. This time, 71 percent of the voters approved it, compared with 63 percent the first time around. Some actively campaigned for it, to little opposition.
"With Combat, we taxed our own selves," said Ethel Sutton, the chairwoman of the Vineyard Neighborhood Association, which represents an impoverished downtown area. "We knocked on doors because we wanted the tax."
Some Kansas City residents say the self-imposed tax has strengthened a willingness to work across racial and economic lines to resolve the drug problem.
"It has reinforced the glue that brings people together," said Ron McMillan, an outreach worker for the Kansas City Free Health Clinic, which provides health care for the indigent. "A lot of this is about getting people in the neighborhoods to say, 'Hey, we want to do something about this ourselves.' "
Ricardo Lucas, another outreach worker for Project Neighborhood, a group that steers people with drug-related problems into available programs, said, "Where can you find me, an ex-felon, sitting down with the Mayor and the prosecutor to get things done, not just pitty-pat conversation?"
Of the approximately $16 million raised annually by the tax, about $9.2 million goes to arrest and prosecute drug criminals.
"Combat has allowed us the manpower and resources to attack retail drug sales," said Maj. David M. Barton, the commander of the narcotics and vice division of the Kansas City Police Department.
The tax enables Major Barton to put 27 more detectives on the street and to hire two forensic chemists and several clerical workers.
"It has allowed us to expand and work both ends of the drug chain -- traffickers and retail markets," he said.
The tax has also paid for 19 prosecutors to expedite criminal cases through the court.
The tax supports a county drug task force that pursues drug trafficking outside Kansas City, and another response team that uses local housing codes, unpaid utility bills and neighbors' complaints to close down houses where drugs are sold.
The remaining $6.8 million in annual revenue is spent on drug treatment and prevention as forms of crime deterrence, including a drug court offering nonviolent felons with addiction problems the option of going into treatment instead of prison. Before, only limited state-supported programs were available.
"When people hurt people, we're going to lock them up for as long as we can," Ms. McCaskill said. "When people don't hurt people, we're going to save our money and force them to become good taxpayers. It is the only way this country is going to come to grips with this crisis."
The tax is even used to get truants back in school and to drug-test any juvenile who runs afoul of the criminal justice system.
Mrs. Sutton's Vineyard group received Combat money to enlist unemployed young people in a watch group against vandalism and drugs, and to help build a community center.
"If you live in a raggedy neighborhood, you're going to think raggedy," Mrs. Sutton said.
An alliance between police officials and such community gadflies is rare enough for most cities, but as Ms. McCaskill observed wryly, "There's nothing like money to force collaboration."
Combat money has also been used to match outside grants for drug treatment and prevention, including a summer program to teach computer and social skills to teen-agers.
"Combat is like a magnet that has the capacity to attract national dollars that otherwise wouldn't come into the community," said the Rev. Keith Brown, the director of Project Neighborhood.
Mr. Nunnelly said he did not worry about overextending Combat's resources.
"There are too many people who go at this thing with a one-shot approach, and they don't build a foundation for change," he said. "Don't be in a hurry. Really give it an opportunity to grow."
Mr. McMillan said he came to Kansas City to be treated for a cocaine problem because the waiting list in New York City was so long. He stayed on to do the same for gang members, prostitutes and other street people.
"Combat gives teeth to what I do," Mr. McMillan said. With the programs financed by the tax, he added, "I can take a person and get him into treatment the same day."
Ms. McCaskill said the tax had changed her views about drug abuse.
"This is such a multilayered problem that you've got to cover the waterfront," she said. "We've let the public think that we can take care of the problem. I understand the seduction of telling people what they want to hear, but the criminal justice system is not equipped to take care of the underlying causes of crime and drugs."

HEADLINE: Tiny Rover, Built on the Cheap, Is Set to Explore Mars

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Space probes used to cost $1 billion a pop. No more. Struggling to slash costs while raising quality, NASA has built an unassuming gadget the size of a child's riding toy to rove across the dry Martian landscape, doing exploration on the cheap.
Despite its relative simplicity, the vehicle, named Sojourner, is to be the first to roam the surface of another planet. If it proves adept, the Sojourner will wander for a week, taking close-up pictures of rocks and analyzing their chemical makeup, shedding light on the inner nature of Mars. And if it is highly successful, it will do so for a month. 
 "It's the culmination of a lifelong dream for me," said Dr. Donna L. Shirley, the vehicle's designer and head of Mars exploration at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.
"Going vicariously is not quite as good as being there," the 55-year-old engineer said of robotic exploration. "But it's a lot easier."
It's a lot cheaper, too, especially as mission designers have kept a sharp eye on cutting expenses, mainly by using "off the shelf" parts rather than developing new ones.
Costing a mere $25 million, the six-wheeled rover has small motors and a modest computer brain (with just 6,500 transistors, compared with 5.5 million in the best Pentium models).
The first hint of its birth came in the 1980's as Dr. Shirley dreamed of putting roving vehicles on Mars, seeking a way to follow up on the successful but expensive Viking missions of the 1970's, which cost the equivalent of $3 billion in today's dollars. She eventually headed a panel that said a return to Mars, if ever to be more than a dream, had to pinch pennies.
NASA balked at that advice. But in 1992, Daniel S. Goldin was appointed Administrator of the space agency and started a campaign to revitalize it by making its projects smaller, cheaper, faster and better.
Rather quickly, Dr. Shirley's plan got a thumbs up. And she was chosen to coordinate the new Mars push.
The rover that developed under Dr. Shirley's guidance is the heart of the $266 million Mars Pathfinder mission. It weighed only 34.2 pounds at launching and a mere 23 pounds once mobile on the Martian surface, where gravity is relatively weak.
At top speed, the vehicle crawls along at just 16 inches a minute, or 80 feet an hour. It has three cameras -- a forward stereo pair and a rear-looking one.
Its solar-power cells have an area of 1.9 square feet, sufficient to energize the rover for several hours a day, even in the worst dust storms. As a backup, the rover also has D-cell batteries. For the sake of simplicity and economy, they are not rechargeable.
The rover's brain is an Intel 80C85 processor, selected for its low cost and ruggedness. In speed and power, it lags behind many processors in the commercial computer market.
The rover carries an alpha proton X-ray spectrometer that will be pressed against soil and rock outcroppings to study their composition. Collecting data for each sample will take up to 10 hours, providing the first chemical analyses of what Mars is made of, as well as insights into its evolution and geologic history. The previous Viking landers conducted biological tests, which failed to detect any unambiguous signs of life.
The rover is to talk to the lander over a radio modem operating at 9,600 baud, which is slow compared with many terrestrial wireless data systems. The transmission range is up to about a third of a mile, but early operations are expected to be much closer, within a few dozen feet of the lander. The lander will then relay the images and data to Earth.
The time for radio signals to travel round-trip from Mars to Earth to Mars is about 20 minutes. This delay rules out ground operators on Earth controlling the rover in "real time." So the designers included a system to detect and avoid such hazards as hitting big rocks or driving off a cliff.
The system uses video images, laser-ranging and sensors of vehicle motion to help the rover detect obstacles in its path and avoid them.
John B. Wellman, the head of experiment operations for Mars Pathfinder, said that doing the mission on the cheap was "a challenge for all of us," and added, "All the people involved have been rather ingenious at doing things at lower cost."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: A Bargain in Planetary Exploration"
The Sojourner's primary mission is to test how a self-powered, self-guided rover can make its way around the poorly understood terrain of Mars. It is also designed to take pictures and analyze rocks. HEADLINE: Clinton and Internet

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Qualified congratulations are due the policy adviser Ira C. Magaziner and the rest of the Clinton Administration for taking a largely hands-off approach with regard to taxation and regulation of the Internet and electronic commerce (Business Day, June 30).
Let the Internet thrive and grow, and we'll position the United States at the forefront of the information economy in the 21st century.
For once, Washington seems to be resisting its we-know-best impulse to regulate. 
 I'm cautiously optimistic that deeds will follow words and that, in this case, President Clinton will prove Ronald Reagan wrong. ("If it moves, tax it. If it keeps moving, regulate it. And if it stops moving, subsidize it.")
 
MARC D. BEAUCHAMP
Falls Church, Va., June 30, 1997

HEADLINE: In Congo, Drivers Find They Can't Get There From Here

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: EPULU, Congo

 BODY:
In a country that may have the worst roads in the world, Sam Onzima was busy doing what drivers often do here in Congo. He was stretched out beneath his Land Rover in the middle of the jungle, hammering away and going nowhere.
"I've been stuck here three weeks," Mr. Onzima, a lanky 37-year-old with an understandably untrimmed beard, said as he stood and stretched beside the road, 20 miles west of the town of Epulu in northeastern Congo. "I hit a pothole and that broke the rear axle." 
 To carry passengers and cargo on these roads, as Mr. Onzima does, requires the patience of Job and the ingenuity of Edison, but most drivers seem equipped with both. Mr. Onzima salvaged a rear differential from another Land Rover that had been stripped and abandoned down the road. Then he lugged everything to Epulu, where someone let him use welding equipment.
"Finding that rear differential really saved me," Mr. Onzima said enthusiastically. "I figure I'll be here another couple of days and then I'll be on my way."
Congo itself is also trying to get back on its way, with the end of decades of rule by the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, and one of its central challenges is to build a transportation network. Congo, which was known as Zaire under Mr. Mobutu, is one-third the size of the United States and mostly in the same state of jungle that existed 1,000 years ago.
Roads are a problem for most of Africa -- the entire continent has only one-quarter as many miles of roads as the United States, even though Africa is three times the size -- and the consequences are profound. In much of Congo, for example, it is impossible to get goods to market, to distribute vaccines, to get children feverish with malaria to a clinic.
"Zaire's roads are maybe the worst, but its problem is representative of the problems in much of the continent except southern Africa," said Salih Booker, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. "This is a big bottleneck for all African countries when it comes to achieving more rapid economic growth."
There is an old joke that Mr. Mobutu once warned the leader of neighboring Rwanda, after a coup attempt there, "That's what happens when you start building roads." But even if impassable roads helped keep freeze the country politically and keep Mr. Mobutu in power, they also fossilized the interior and sent living standards spinning backward.
"The Mobutu regime totally neglected infrastructure, and so there are many villages that have been completely cut off, completely isolated," mused Lobela Alauwa, the Mayor of the hub city of Kisangani. "Those villages never see a truck, never see a bicycle."
Mr. Alauwa jabbed at a torn and faded map dating from 1958 -- the only map of Kisangani available -- and thrust his forefinger at an area where the roads are so overgrown that they have faded into jungle.
"This area is full of forgotten villages," he said. "Nobody even knows about them anymore."
Perhaps it is a commonplace to say that roads are to a nation what arteries and veins are to a human body, and that without circulation there is no development and only decay. But it seems a more profound truth after spending six days traveling across northeastern Congo and into Uganda, after bouncing over huge rocks, after pushing the vehicle through countless mudholes, after catching malaria on the route.
The road, ornamented by the carcasses of little engines that couldn't, plagued by bandits with machine guns, punctuated by submarine bogs that recall the Everglades, is not some minor track. On the contrary, it is now the only supply line across eastern Congo, a crucial link across central Africa, the kind of highway that merits a thick red line on maps.
But for the last few years it had been totally impassable. This spring the rebel soldiers forced their prisoners of war, the troops of the Mobutu Government, to repair the road, and so four-wheel-drive vehicles are again beginning to get through.
Still, a driver needs an assistant to jog ahead of the car for long stretches and wade through mud puddles to make sure that they are not too deep. If the puddles rise to a man's chest, it is time to pull out a machete and carve a bypass through the jungle.

Pockets of Isolation
 
A Provincial Town Is Now Unreachable
In 1960, when Belgium gave up this colony and it became independent, the country had 88,000 miles of usable roads. These days, particularly in the rainy season, there are almost no roads anywhere in the country that can be negotiated by an ordinary car.
In other words, as most of the world is getting smaller, Congo is getting larger.
The city of Buta is a provincial center that used to be just a six-hour drive by ordinary car from Kisangani. Now Congo has expanded so much that Buta is unreachable.
"There are no vehicles going to Buta anymore," Yambello Komba, the chief of a long-distance bus station in Kisangani, said with a look of incredulity. "If you want to go, first you'd have to buy gas for the ferry halfway there and pay it to take you across the river, because the ferry has stopped, too. Then on the other side of the river, the road is so bad that to get to Buta it would take a month, maybe two or three."
Cities like Buta spin off into their own economic universe, cut off from the rest of the world. The isolation is compounded because this region of eastern Congo no longer has postal delivery or inter-city telephone service. In the last year, even intermittent air service has ceased.
Because the roads of Congo are so awful, vehicles are rare on the road from Kisangani to Uganda, about one every two hours in each direction -- which is just as well, since it is a one-lane road. But there are dozens of bicycles for every motor vehicle, and the bicyclists are the real heroes of commerce in this country.
"This is very tough work," grunted Porluku Trofimo, a 30-year-old man who was sweating in the tropical heat as he struggled to push his bicycle and its load of flip-flops and clothes. "But it's the only thing I can do. It's better than stealing."
Mr. Trofimo's bicycle has no pedals, but it does not matter much. Most of the way he must push the bicycle rather than ride it. In any case, if Mr. Trofimo seemed in bad shape, his companion, Ezekiel Kitaholia, was doing even worse.
"I've got malaria," Mr. Kitaholia said weakly as he leaned on his bike during a brief stand-up rest. Looking as if he was about to collapse, he added, "I'm not feeling so good."
Alternately pushing their bicycles and riding them, from dawn to dusk, it takes the two men one week to carry their goods from the market town of Butembo to Isiro, a distance of about 250 miles. Then they sell the goods to shopkeepers in Isiro and buy palm oil to carry back home to Butembo.
They sleep by the side of the road, hiding themselves and their bicycles so bandits will not trouble them, and covering themselves with a tarpaulin when it rains.

The Road Hazards
 
Drivers Watch Out For Bandits, Mines
This concern about banditry -- whether by thieves, guerrillas or Government soldiers -- is a major impediment to commerce in Africa, particularly in Congo.
Under the Mobutu Government, the worst thieves were the soldiers, and the new troops who have defeated Mr. Mobutu's forces are clearly better-mannered. But at nearly every checkpoint, they ask for a donation before moving the barrier from the road; there is no direct threat, but it still seems churlish to refuse a man a gift when he is holding an AK-47 on you.
This particular road, because of the civil war of the last few months, offers a few special concerns.
"This road was mined for the next 60 kilometers," or 35 miles, the driver explained calmly as he left Kisangani for the east. "But I think the mines have probably been discovered, and in any case I'll just follow in the tracks of cars that have gone ahead of us."
A mile later, large mud puddles became frequent, so the driver started swerving to each side to avoid them, producing gasps from the passengers.

The Accidents
 
Trucks and People Get Little Help
In some stretches of the road, travelers spend less time driving than trying to extricate their vehicle from the mud. Trucks also sometimes topple over and block the road, for they are often so overloaded that the center of gravity is far off the ground.
"We just don't have roads," moaned Sammy Ruhigwa, a 32-year-old driver whose truck was stuck near another that had overturned, scattering its contents into the bush. "And without roads, how can you have development?" Mr. Ruhigwa is a mechanic, but even so the challenges of keeping a vehicle going are almost unimaginable. The new Government of Congo has said that improving roads is a major priority, but it would take billions of dollars and many years to establish a modern transportation network. The country needs not only asphalt but much more as well, for along Mr. Ruhigwa's entire route there are no auto supply stores or repair shops, no real gas stations, no tow trucks, no electrical outlets and no telephones.
And when there are accidents or illnesses, there are no doctors.
One quiet afternoon in Epulu, as villagers listlessly tried to sell meals of rice and beans to passing motorists or bicyclists, a group of men struggled to fix a 12-ton truck with axle trouble. It had been jacked up and was resting on sections of logs as several men lay underneath.
Then one of the props gave way. For several moments there was only shocked silence, and then an unearthly scream.
The village erupted as everyone nearby rushed to the truck and braced to lift it up, straining and sweating, precariously lifting it inch by inch, seeing it fall back a bit, and then pushing again, and suddenly it was up and somebody had put a new block under the chassis and two others were pulling out a man whose mouth was gushing blood.
The rescuers rushed him to the nearby clinic. But the clinic is a rudimentary one with no doctor, only a young nurse, who bandaged the man's head and unsuccessfully tried to halt the bleeding. It is unclear if he survived.
All the dangers to life and property naturally add to the cost of transportation. There are very few people in Congo with a good four-wheel-drive vehicle, and few want to risk such a valuable possession by sending it out into the bush.
"That's why things are so expensive out here, because of transportation," said Eduard Steffens, a 57-year-old Congo native who spent 18 years living in the United States.
"By the time you get to Kisangani, your truck is ready to be overhauled," sighed Mr. Steffens, who now makes a living trucking goods across eastern Congo in his pickup. "We're using the vehicles as bulldozers, pushing and scraping our way through."
The town where Mr. Steffens was passing the night, Nia-Nia, underscores the way regions have been almost lost to the jungle because of the decrepitude of the roads. A "Shell" sign still stands guard over the carcass of the local service station, but the building has been abandoned and now a mud hut stands where attendants once pumped gas.

HEADLINE: Mingo Junction Journal;
As Strike Wears On, Town's Life Ebbs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: MINGO JUNCTION, Ohio, July 4

 BODY:
Archie Wilfred, a bartender at the Schutzen Club, was sweeping the sidewalk and said he had not served a customer all day. Sitting in a corner of the Hometown Luncheonette, which she runs with her husband, Thelma Peterson wondered if the July 4th Special for $3.50 -- one hamburger or two hot dogs, plus macaroni salad, potato salad and baked beans -- would draw any customers.
Lou Lane, who has run Lane's Lounge for 50 years, said business has fallen off so much "there hasn't been a card game in the back room for six months." 
 "Never seen anything like this before," Mr. Lane said from behind the front counter. "This is the worst, and it's been tough on everybody."
Mingo Junction, a town of 4,300 people three miles south of Steubenville, sits at ground zero of the longest steelworker strike in American history. More than 10 months ago, 4,500 workers in eight plants owned by the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation walked out in a dispute that largely centers on pension benefits. The largest of the plants is here in Mingo Junction. It employed 2,600 of the striking workers, members of the United Steelworkers of America, who made a range of products from car parts to girders.
Periodic negotiations, some with a Federal mediator, have failed to resolve the differences, and caught in the middle are dozens of steel towns along the Ohio River in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. Here and elsewhere, businesses are closing, and families are stressed. The authorities have even attributed several suicides to the strike.
Today was the nation's birthday? It was hardly festive here in Mingo Junction, where the plant runs the length of town and touches virtually everything and everybody, one way or another. Few felt like celebrating. Even backyards in the hills overlooking Main Street and the plant were bereft of family gatherings and barbecues.
"You know, people tell me all the time they are tired of talking about the strike," said Chief Mike J. Maguschak of the Police Department. "But almost every conversation ends with people talking about the strike. It's affecting everything around here."
The town population includes 2,200 families, 400 of which have someone who works for Wheeling-Pitt, as it is known here, giving Mingo Junction one of the highest concentrations of steelworkers among towns in the Ohio Valley. As a result, the impact of the strike has been especially widespread and dramatic.
Not only have local residents lost income from jobs that pay $17 an hour and more, Mayor John A. Corrigan Jr. said Mingo Junction was losing $4,400 a day in fees the plant pays for water when fully operating, money that accounts for about a quarter of the town's $8 million annual budget. Without the money, Mayor Corrigan said, the town has laid off 20 employees, including a firefighter and 2 of its 12 police officers. The strike has also wiped out a summer jobs program that traditionally provides minimum wage work for as many as 80 of the town's young people.
Signs of stress are evident along Main Street. A poster hanging in a flower shop said almost every item was half-price. Down the street at Mazalick's Carryout Deli there was little to carry out. The shelves were empty of most items, except for candy, potato chips, newspapers and ice.
"We're just hanging on," said the owner, Betty Mazalick. "I opened in December and thought the strike would last only a couple of months. I was taking in $400 a day. Now, I'm down to $85. People can't even afford to buy candy."
Gino Ardito, a Mingo Junction native who has run a Main Street hardware and paint store for more than 40 years, said he had been closing up three and four hours early every day because no one had money to spend. He estimated that his business was off 50 percent, "and I'm struggling to keep it open."
Chief Maguschak said that crime had not increased in the last 10 months, but that alcohol-related incidents had. Officers, he said, have responded to more bar fights and domestic calls from "upset wives."
"The general feeling is that a lot of guys are mad," the Chief said. "They're mad about the situation with the company, and that more or less spreads to a lot of things they do."
At an entry to the plant, five strikers gathered for a daily vigil that passes for picketing. They gave up carrying signs long ago and now just hang out as a show of solidarity.
"The biggest thing for me is that I can't save any money," said Jim Guiliano, 43, a pipe fitter and welder who has worked at the plant for 22 years and has a 13-year-old son. "Let's face it, my life is about over, and I'm not going to be able to do anything different. But I would like to set him up so he could maybe go to college."
Several workers said they had known Kelly Lonetta, a 51-year-old crane operator who shot himself in the head about a month ago. Mr. Lonetta had told friends he was "obsessively depressed" over the strike and could not understand why the company was taking such a hard line. He left a wife and two children.
John Wiater, a company spokesman, sympathized with residents of Mingo Junction and other Ohio Valley towns, saying, "No doubt this has been a hardship on all the families."
But Mr. Wiater added that Wheeling-Pitt, a subsidiary of the WHX Corporation, was also at risk, uncertain whether its former customers will return.
That rationale was of little consequence to Mayor Corrigan, who could scarcely hide his depression.
"We're a one-industry town," he said. "Wheeling-Pitt is the heart of Mingo Junction. Right now, the heart is dead, and Mingo Junction is dying."

HEADLINE: Anti-Drug Tax Lifts Kansas City

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
When weekends turn rowdy, Preston Washington arranges for his clients to leave home and move temporarily into a halfway house to avoid violating their parole.
"They're living in surroundings where there's a lot of drugging and drinking on weekends," said Mr. Washington, a former policeman and parole officer who runs Opportunity to Succeed, a program that helps ex-convicts find jobs, housing and a drug-free life. 
 "None have barriers like convicted felons," Mr. Washington said. "The opportunity is here for them to make that transition as productive citizens."
Opportunity to Succeed is one of an ingenious array of local programs that are partly financed by tacking a modest quarter of a percent onto the local sales tax imposed in Jackson County, which includes half of Kansas City and all of its inner-city neighborhoods.
Seven years after it went into effect, the county's anti-drug tax remains highly unusual in financing drug treatment and prevention along with law enforcement. At a time when politicians vie to cut taxes, the Jackson County prosecutor, Claire McCaskill, concedes that "the prospect of passing a new tax appears daunting to most people."
Yet the surtax remains popular even though it raises the combined state and city tax to about 6.5 percent in Kansas City and 6 percent elsewhere in the county.
The anti-drug tax was approved by Kansas City voters in 1989 in response to a surge of violent crime that was linked to crack cocaine. But the county's former prosecutor, Albert Riederer, who championed the tax, had no detailed plan for spending the new revenue. More than $400,000 went to buy new computers for the prosecutor's office, while money earmarked for drug prevention and treatment took a long time to reach the street.
The tax's image was hardly enhanced by the choice of a hypodermic syringe as its symbol.
After Ms. McCaskill became prosecutor in 1993, she gave the anti-drug tax an aggressive and acronymic name, Combat, for community-based anti-drug tax. A clenched fist replaced the syringe, and an experienced public health administrator, James T. Nunnelly, was hired to run the program for the prosecutor's office.
The tax itself has been credited with some results. Last year, the number of drug cases filed for prosecution rose to 2,212, from 515 in 1989. Violent crime has declined 30 percent since 1991, pushing Kansas City, which once ranked as the third-most-violent city in the nation, off the list of the worst 10. And as many as 700 people a month have entered or returned to drug treatment, Mr. Nunnelly said.
But with drugs still a problem, other dividends are less tangible. "How do you prove that which you have prevented?" Ms. McCaskill asked.
To find out how voters felt, she organized another referendum to renew the tax in 1995, two years before it was to have expired. This time, 71 percent of the voters approved it, compared with 63 percent the first time around. Some actively campaigned for it, to little opposition.
"With Combat, we taxed our own selves," said Ethel Sutton, the chairwoman of the Vineyard Neighborhood Association, which represents an impoverished downtown area. "We knocked on doors because we wanted the tax."
Some Kansas City residents say the self-imposed tax has strengthened a willingness to work across racial and economic lines to resolve the drug problem.
"It has reinforced the glue that brings people together," said Ron McMillan, an outreach worker for the Kansas City Free Health Clinic, which provides health care for the indigent. "A lot of this is about getting people in the neighborhoods to say, 'Hey, we want to do something about this ourselves.' "
Ricardo Lucas, another outreach worker for Project Neighborhood, a group that steers people with drug-related problems into available programs, said, "Where can you find me, an ex-felon, sitting down with the Mayor and the prosecutor to get things done, not just pitty-pat conversation?"
Of the approximately $16 million raised annually by the tax, about $9.2 million goes to arrest and prosecute drug criminals.
"Combat has allowed us the manpower and resources to attack retail drug sales," said Maj. David M. Barton, the commander of the narcotics and vice division of the Kansas City Police Department.
The tax enables Major Barton to put 27 more detectives on the street and to hire two forensic chemists and several clerical workers.
"It has allowed us to expand and work both ends of the drug chain -- traffickers and retail markets," he said.
The tax has also paid for 19 prosecutors to expedite criminal cases through the court.
The tax supports a county drug task force that pursues drug trafficking outside Kansas City, and another response team that uses local housing codes, unpaid utility bills and neighbors' complaints to close down houses where drugs are sold.
The remaining $6.8 million in annual revenue is spent on drug treatment and prevention as forms of crime deterrence, including a drug court offering nonviolent felons with addiction problems the option of going into treatment instead of prison. Before, only limited state-supported programs were available.
"When people hurt people, we're going to lock them up for as long as we can," Ms. McCaskill said. "When people don't hurt people, we're going to save our money and force them to become good taxpayers. It is the only way this country is going to come to grips with this crisis."
The tax is even used to get truants back in school and to drug-test any juvenile who runs afoul of the criminal justice system.
Mrs. Sutton's Vineyard group received Combat money to enlist unemployed young people in a watch group against vandalism and drugs, and to help build a community center.
"If you live in a raggedy neighborhood, you're going to think raggedy," Mrs. Sutton said.
An alliance between police officials and such community gadflies is rare enough for most cities, but as Ms. McCaskill observed wryly, "There's nothing like money to force collaboration."
Combat money has also been used to match outside grants for drug treatment and prevention, including a summer program to teach computer and social skills to teen-agers.
"Combat is like a magnet that has the capacity to attract national dollars that otherwise wouldn't come into the community," said the Rev. Keith Brown, the director of Project Neighborhood.
Mr. Nunnelly said he did not worry about overextending Combat's resources.
"There are too many people who go at this thing with a one-shot approach, and they don't build a foundation for change," he said. "Don't be in a hurry. Really give it an opportunity to grow."
Mr. McMillan said he came to Kansas City to be treated for a cocaine problem because the waiting list in New York City was so long. He stayed on to do the same for gang members, prostitutes and other street people.
"Combat gives teeth to what I do," Mr. McMillan said. With the programs financed by the tax, he added, "I can take a person and get him into treatment the same day."
Ms. McCaskill said the tax had changed her views about drug abuse.
"This is such a multilayered problem that you've got to cover the waterfront," she said. "We've let the public think that we can take care of the problem. I understand the seduction of telling people what they want to hear, but the criminal justice system is not equipped to take care of the underlying causes of crime and drugs."

HEADLINE: Tiny Rover, Built on the Cheap, Is Set to Explore Mars

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Space probes used to cost $1 billion a pop. No more. Struggling to slash costs while raising quality, NASA has built an unassuming gadget the size of a child's riding toy to rove across the dry Martian landscape, doing exploration on the cheap.
Despite its relative simplicity, the vehicle, named Sojourner, is to be the first to roam the surface of another planet. If it proves adept, the Sojourner will wander for a week, taking close-up pictures of rocks and analyzing their chemical makeup, shedding light on the inner nature of Mars. And if it is highly successful, it will do so for a month. 
 "It's the culmination of a lifelong dream for me," said Dr. Donna L. Shirley, the vehicle's designer and head of Mars exploration at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.
"Going vicariously is not quite as good as being there," the 55-year-old engineer said of robotic exploration. "But it's a lot easier."
It's a lot cheaper, too, especially as mission designers have kept a sharp eye on cutting expenses, mainly by using "off the shelf" parts rather than developing new ones.
Costing a mere $25 million, the six-wheeled rover has small motors and a modest computer brain (with just 6,500 transistors, compared with 5.5 million in the best Pentium models).
The first hint of its birth came in the 1980's as Dr. Shirley dreamed of putting roving vehicles on Mars, seeking a way to follow up on the successful but expensive Viking missions of the 1970's, which cost the equivalent of $3 billion in today's dollars. She eventually headed a panel that said a return to Mars, if ever to be more than a dream, had to pinch pennies.
NASA balked at that advice. But in 1992, Daniel S. Goldin was appointed Administrator of the space agency and started a campaign to revitalize it by making its projects smaller, cheaper, faster and better.
Rather quickly, Dr. Shirley's plan got a thumbs up. And she was chosen to coordinate the new Mars push.
The rover that developed under Dr. Shirley's guidance is the heart of the $266 million Mars Pathfinder mission. It weighed only 34.2 pounds at launching and a mere 23 pounds once mobile on the Martian surface, where gravity is relatively weak.
At top speed, the vehicle crawls along at just 16 inches a minute, or 80 feet an hour. It has three cameras -- a forward stereo pair and a rear-looking one.
Its solar-power cells have an area of 1.9 square feet, sufficient to energize the rover for several hours a day, even in the worst dust storms. As a backup, the rover also has D-cell batteries. For the sake of simplicity and economy, they are not rechargeable.
The rover's brain is an Intel 80C85 processor, selected for its low cost and ruggedness. In speed and power, it lags behind many processors in the commercial computer market.
The rover carries an alpha proton X-ray spectrometer that will be pressed against soil and rock outcroppings to study their composition. Collecting data for each sample will take up to 10 hours, providing the first chemical analyses of what Mars is made of, as well as insights into its evolution and geologic history. The previous Viking landers conducted biological tests, which failed to detect any unambiguous signs of life.
The rover is to talk to the lander over a radio modem operating at 9,600 baud, which is slow compared with many terrestrial wireless data systems. The transmission range is up to about a third of a mile, but early operations are expected to be much closer, within a few dozen feet of the lander. The lander will then relay the images and data to Earth.
The time for radio signals to travel round-trip from Mars to Earth to Mars is about 20 minutes. This delay rules out ground operators on Earth controlling the rover in "real time." So the designers included a system to detect and avoid such hazards as hitting big rocks or driving off a cliff.
The system uses video images, laser-ranging and sensors of vehicle motion to help the rover detect obstacles in its path and avoid them.
John B. Wellman, the head of experiment operations for Mars Pathfinder, said that doing the mission on the cheap was "a challenge for all of us," and added, "All the people involved have been rather ingenious at doing things at lower cost."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: A Bargain in Planetary Exploration"
The Sojourner's primary mission is to test how a self-powered, self-guided rover can make its way around the poorly understood terrain of Mars. It is also designed to take pictures and analyze rocks. Chart lists specifications on the rover and gives an illustration of the rovers design. (Source: Nasa)(Illustration by John Papasiar)

HEADLINE: Clinton and Internet

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Qualified congratulations are due the policy adviser Ira C. Magaziner and the rest of the Clinton Administration for taking a largely hands-off approach with regard to taxation and regulation of the Internet and electronic commerce (Business Day, June 30).
Let the Internet thrive and grow, and we'll position the United States at the forefront of the information economy in the 21st century.
For once, Washington seems to be resisting its we-know-best impulse to regulate. 
 I'm cautiously optimistic that deeds will follow words and that, in this case, President Clinton will prove Ronald Reagan wrong. ("If it moves, tax it. If it keeps moving, regulate it. And if it stops moving, subsidize it.")
 
MARC D. BEAUCHAMP
Falls Church, Va., June 30, 1997

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: For Richer, for Poorer

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, the former Secretary of Labor, is University Professor and Maurice Hexter Professor of Social and Economic Policy in the Heller Graduate School at Brandeis University. His most recent book is "Locked in the Cabinet."

 BODY:

MONEY
 Who Has How Much and Why.
 By Andrew Hacker.
 254 pp. New York:
 Scribner. $25. 
 Jerry Seinfeld gets at least $22 million next year. Is he worth it? NBC thinks so. It pulls in more than $1 million a minute from advertisements during the show. The laundry worker down my street earns around $13,500 a year. Is he worth it? The laundry thinks so. Even though the economy is booming, it can get someone to replace him if he demands a penny more.
In his engaging book "Money," Andrew Hacker, a professor of political science at Queens College, examines who earns what, and why they do. He shows that most Americans are more like the person who does my laundry than like Seinfeld. If $30,000 is set as a minimum middle-class income, fewer than a third of all employed Americans can be considered middle class. Even at $20,000, only about half can.
At the very top, with yearly incomes over $1 million, sit some 68,000 of the nation's highest rollers (from whose ranks, Hacker tells us, came one-quarter of all the delegates to the most recent Republican National Convention), including 1,500 people on Wall Street, 600 chief executives, 246 professional football players, 241 baseball players and a collection of inventors, entertainers, entrepreneurs, financial wizards and heirs. Just under them come America's richest professionals -- the top 1 percent of all earners, with yearly incomes starting at $200,000 -- featuring not only star doctors and lawyers but also heads of charitable foundations (the Ford Foundation pays its president $839,139), university presidents (more than half a million dollars at Boston University) and even a football coach ($975,000 at Florida State, including endorsements).
These generous incomes are mostly explained by the special skills or education of their recipients. In Hacker's view, the substance of what they learned in college is less important than the style. "The years at college and graduate school pay off because they burnish students' personalities. The time spent on a campus imparts cues and clues on how to conduct oneself in corporate cultures and professional settings." Professors themselves, although hardly in the top ranks, are paid comfortable salaries "not so much for teaching subjects like history and philosophy as for being a professional presence that students can emulate."
The rest of Hacker's explanation for why the very rich got that way has even less to do with their expertise. He argues that when organizations or individuals want to demonstrate they are getting the "best," they hire people who are already paid the most. A similar ratcheting-up occurs with corporate boards, which always want to pay their chieftains just above the norm in order to prove that the company is ahead of the rest of the pack; or with Wall Street investment bankers, who conventionally receive a 1 percent commission on all deals and so promote the biggest ones conceivable. In any event, a payment of tens of millions of dollars just doesn't seem that extravagant when one is presiding over billions. How else to explain Michael Ovitz's $128 million severance package for about 60 weeks' work at Disney?
The bottom 80 percent of the population, meanwhile, receives a smaller share of the nation's total income than it did 20 years ago. The shift began in the early 1970's, when the median earnings of men began dropping. Middle-income households avoided downward mobility only by sending wives to work and by postponing both marriage and children. At the same time, the poor have become poorer. Some of this downdraft has been caused by technological advances and globalization, hurting those with few or outmoded skills.
Here, too, Hacker suggests additional culprits. Long-term contracts and wage-setting institutions that once shielded blue-collar workers, teachers and low-level civil servants from the labor auction block are disappearing. Meanwhile, the lowest economic rungs, on which most two-income families had once perched, are now occupied by single-parent households. In 1995, 31.3 percent of American children lived with just one parent or with someone other than a parent, up from under 15 percent in 1970. Largely as a result, a third of America's children now live in households earning less than $25,000. One in five children lives in poverty. For all its riches, the United States now has a greater percentage of its citizens in prison or on the streets, and more neglected children, than any other advanced nation.
This story isn't new, but Hacker embellishes it with rich detail. In 1970, for example, 3.1 percent of American households lived in trailers or mobile homes; by 1990, it was 7.2 percent. Sometimes the precision and profusion of his detail overwhelm his argument. (In 1995, the average sewing-machine operator earned $13,052; a hotel clerk, $15,028; and an orthopedic surgeon, $304,000. The median household income in West Virginia was $24,880, while in Connecticut it was $40,243. The poverty threshold for one person living alone was $7,763.)
From such an abundance of data, Hacker draws some provocative conclusions. He argues, for example, that certain states have intentionally low-balled welfare allowances in order to create "a ready pool of women to work at a minimum wage as household servants, motel maids and in food-processing plants." Some of his verdicts are simply bizarre, as when he states that "the farther a country is from the United States, the more likely will its immigrants be to secure higher-paying employment" because "it takes more resources, either financial or personal, to get here from India or the Philippines than, say, Mexico or the Dominican Republic." Canadians and Cambodians alike would find this statement curious.
Hacker is appropriately concerned about the corrosive consequences of growing disparities in wealth and earnings among Americans. "With the legacy we are now creating," he writes, "millions of men, women, children are prevented from being fully American, while others pride themselves on how much they can amass." But he is curiously silent about what we might do to reverse the trend. His skepticism about the substantive purposes of higher education and his awareness of the difficulties in countering any of the institutional or sociological reasons for the widening gap lead him to the brink of suggesting, perhaps by default, a far more progressive system of taxation.
Hacker notes, for example, that as recently as 1979, rich Americans paid an average of 47 percent of their income in Federal taxes. By 1994, the effective rate had declined to 32 percent.
In theory, economic winners could redistribute much of their earnings to losers and yet still come out far ahead. As an extreme example, he observes that an income ceiling of $100,000 per year, affecting approximately the top 7 percent of American families, would yield $285 billion annually -- a sum that, if transferred to the poorest 20 percent, whose incomes now average $7,764, would establish a floor of $22,219 per family.
But Hacker hastily warns us off any such fanciful thoughts. His book "should not be read as a plea for income redistribution," he protests near its end. "The reason is straightforward: if people are disinclined to share what they have, they will not be persuaded by a reproachful tone." One worries that the elevated tone he chooses instead may be too high to be heard.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 3; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2368 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
True Grits in Nashville

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV; ERIC ASIMOV writes the $25 and Under dining column for the Weekend section of The New York Times

 BODY:
SATURDAY night is rush hour in downtown Nashville. Cars stand bumper to bumper on Broadway, as police officers on bicycles wind slowly through the crowd. A gawking couple steps out of a horse-drawn carriage in front of the Old Spaghetti Factory, a franchise restaurant down the block from Hooters and around the corner from Planet Hollywood and the Hard Rock Cafe.
This is born-again Nashville, or "Nash Vegas," as denizens call it, where the prefabricated glitz of franchise clubs and packaged country entertainment is proving an irresistible siren to tourists. 
 I was hoping to find another city, where the music was more bourbon than Perrier, where the Southern restaurants still featured the Tennessee trinity of pork, pig and ham, and where lard, salt and "I'll have another beer" weren't dirty words. After all, it was just going to be a three-day weekend. And it was going to be cheap. In Nashville, music and food, judiciously chosen, are bargains.
The problem was getting there. Because I was arranging my trip on short notice -- just three days ahead -- a reasonable air fare between New York and Nashville was hard to find. American Airlines, one of the few airlines with a direct flight, quoted a fare of $992.
I tried the airline consolidators, those companies that acquire tickets in bulk and make them available at cut-rate prices, and easily found considerably cheaper round trips, $295 plus tax, but no direct flights. Then a solution appeared before my eyes.
Recently, I had subscribed to Net Saaver, a free weekly E-mail newsletter from American Airlines available through the American Web site, www.americanair.com. Net Saaver arrives each Wednesday, announcing last-minute discount fares available only on the coming weekend. These fares require departure on a Friday after 7 P.M. or anytime Saturday, with return the following Monday or Tuesday. The list of available tickets changes every week, and, from a New Yorker's perspective, the choices were always slim, with fares between New York and anywhere scarce.
This week, though, I was in luck. The current Net Saaver offered a round trip between New York and Nashville for a mere $129 plus tax! What's more, I could also rent a Hertz economy car with unlimited mileage for $24 a day through Net Saaver (I spent an extra $2 a day for a more comfortable compact).
So there I was, leaving Nashville International Airport on a Saturday morning in a Nissan Sentra -- not the Ford Escort I had been promised, but all I really cared about was that it had a decent radio.
I discovered two things right away: It's not as easy as you might think to find country music on the radio in Nashville, and it's even harder to find your way around. A good map ($4.95 at a newsstand) was essential.
I still got lost on my way to the Pancake Pantry, a Nashville institution. Even as the rest of the country has decided it has no time to eat in the morning, the South still venerates breakfast, especially in Nashville. This airy farmhouse-style restaurant on a block of low-slung stores and offices in the West End, near Vanderbilt University, offers 20 types of pancakes. My meal, deliciously coarse, granular cornmeal pancakes and rich country ham ($7.25), was the perfect welcome to Nashville, right down to the waitresses who called me "Hon" and replenished my iced tea unbidden.
Fueled up, I tried to get my bearings. My motel, a Shoney's Inn, was in the Music Row section, a center of the recording studios and industry offices. By simply stepping out of my functional but characterless room I could hear the quavering strains of a country ballad. A man in a nearby parking lot was belting out the song for tips, backed by a taped musical accompaniment in a kind of country karaoke. A little trolley plied Demonbreun Street, shuttling tourists between the nearby Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum and the sights downtown. Across the street were gift shops and quasi-museums advertising their prize possessions: "Barbara Mandrell's gown," "Hank Williams Jr.'s Cadillac," "George Jones's gold record." Each seemed to sell more local delicacies -- Goo-Goo Clusters and Moon Pies -- than musical trinkets.
I headed in another direction, to visit the Carl Van Vechten Gallery of Fine Arts at Fisk University, which houses a collection of paintings and sculptures once owned by Alfred Stieglitz. The collection was donated by his widow, Georgia O'Keeffe, in 1949 and includes works by Cezanne, Renoir and Diego Rivera, although I was more interested in less familiar modern artists like Marsden Hartley and John Marin, whose work Stieglitz had shown in his galleries.
My hope was to avoid the big country music tourist attractions -- the Grand Ole Opry, the Ryman Auditorium and the Wildhorse Saloon -- and to figure out where Nashvillians themselves go for music.
After a quick dinner at Rotier's, a dark, clubby West End bar and grill that serves the traditional Nashville "meat and three," meat with a choice of three vegetables ($5.75), I headed for the Station Inn, a nondescript stone building with a plywood floor, where Keith Little and Friends, a bluegrass group, were to play at 9 P.M. The cover charge was only $5, and Budweisers were $2.50, but with only 20 souls in the audience, the energy level was low. I moved on to 12th and Porter, a bar and restaurant that not only seemed to attract all of pierced, tattooed Nashville, but also offered valet parking.
It was packed, and waitresses in leather skirts and studded collars were squeezing through the crowd to serve dishes with names like Low Death Factor Fettuccine, the Nashville equivalent of spa cuisine. But the nightclub adjacent to the restaurant, done entirely in pink and black, was almost empty.
The band, Pat Gallagher and the Atomic Playboys, began a set of mellow love songs, the gentle lyrics settling like dew drops over the empty seats. A few more people trickled in, and as the band wound up its set, I left, having spent $3.50 for a Bass ale and $1 as tip for parking.
Could it be that all of Nashville had been invited to a party, and I hadn't gotten my invitation?
I found the party at my next stop, Exit-In, a club near Vanderbilt that specializes, I learned later, in the sort of alternative rock that appeals to a college audience. Exit-In was packed and pulsing, with a throng of young people who had paid $7 to hear Man or Astroman?, a psycho-surf thrash band, complete with props like cheesy Van de Graaff generators and big-screen televisions that flash footage from old science fiction movies. It was entertaining, but not what I was looking for. Besides, it was late, and I was hungry again. I headed out for Prince's Hot Chicken.
A friend had told me not to miss Prince's, but only chuckled when I asked him to describe it. Four or five other groups were waiting inside the largely takeout operation in a rundown storefront in northern Nashville. As chicken fried in huge, black frying pans, I read some warnings posted on the wall: Don't eat and drive at the same time. Don't touch the chicken and then touch your eyes, you could burn yourself. I ordered my chicken mild, with lemonade ($4.25), and took it back to my motel.
As I ate, the heat began with a tingling in the lips and tongue that rose into the sinuses and traveled down the throat. The plump, juicy chicken breast was undeniably a culinary treat, but perhaps not the best bedtime snack.
Particularly because I had to get up early on Sunday for breakfast. For years I had heard praise for the Loveless Motel and Cafe, most recently in "Eat Your Way Across the U.S.A." by Jane and Michael Stern. Now I was taking the 20-minute drive from Music Row to the Loveless in southwest Nashville.
Much of central Tennessee seems to congregate at the Loveless on Sunday mornings. Those without reservations are kept waiting in a little anteroom, or they may choose a buffet breakfast in an adjoining building. Those with reservations (like me) are seated right away in the homey dining room, where dishes of preserves, chunky peach and tart blackberry, sit on red-and-white checkered tablecloths.
I ordered country ham and eggs with red-eye gravy ($8.95) and a side order of grits ($1). Red-eye is a Southern specialty invented to go with grits and eggs: The salty, musky drippings from country ham are blended with a little coffee and cooked down. The eggs came with a platter of a dozen fluffy biscuits, which I tried with the jams, dipped in gravy and as a sandwich with the country ham, which had the proper leathery texture. The waitress clucked sympathetically when I told her I couldn't finish the last two. "Would you like me to pack 'em up for you?" she asked. I declined.
Later that morning I visited the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum. I almost missed the building, which was dwarfed by the B.M.I. building next door. The fascinating little museum ($10.75 admission) traces the history of country music from the Grand Ole Opry to the present, with an emphasis on the most commercially successful, of course. Among the tidbits I learned were that the early country players had been persuaded to trade in their formal attire for hillbilly costumes by George D. Hay, the founder of the Opry, who believed it would make them more accessible to their audience; that one of the early Opry stars was DeFord Bailey, a black harmonica player (the Opry also featured musicians in blackface); that Johnny Cash's hit "A Boy Named Sue" was written by Shel Silverstein; that when it came to outlandish customizing, Elvis Presley's gold Cadillac, with record player and cocktail cabinet, had nothing on Webb Pierce's 1962 Pontiac Bonneville, with its tooled leather upholstery, six-gun trim and silver-dollar decor.
I spent more than three hours at the museum, and could easily have dawdled longer, watching historic film clips of Roy Acuff and early Opry stars like Uncle Dave Macon. But I was eager to check into my room at the Union Station Hotel, which had been built in a beautifully refurbished Romanesque Gothic train station. I justified the $109 tab on two grounds. First, I was getting a good Sunday night deal; my room usually went for $175. Second, everything else had been a bargain in Nashville, so I had earned a treat.
The room seemed unadorned but not plain, with a king-size bed, comfortable armchairs and A-shaped struts that gave an unusual archlike feel to the room. A big picture window offered a view of a rail yard and a highway, and I could see that a rainstorm had begun. Tonight, I decided, I would look for music in the heart of Nash Vegas.
Maybe because of the rain, or maybe because it was Sunday, downtown Nashville seemed barren. Like a carnival barker, a woman in front of the empty Planet Hollywood tried to coax me in. But I was heading for the dives of old Nashville, like Robert's Western World, a venerable Western-wear shop turned nightclub that achieved local fame a few years back as home base to BR5-49, a retro country band that's gone on to recording-contract glory.
Onstage, the Lonnie Waters Band was playing to a dozen or so people, energetically picking its way through Hank Williams, Hank Snow and Elvis Presley. If the music wasn't original, it was played with verve and charm. As in all the older places along Broadway, the band played for tips, the people listened for the price of a beer.
At Tootsie's Orchid Lounge, which for decades served as the backstage bar for the Grand Ole Opry, Scott Wayne and the Boys were taking requests to the delight of the small crowd in an improbably bright, rundown room. I felt satisfied, as if I had finally found the music I was looking for. As the band finished its set, I left to get something to eat.
Easier said than done. After 9 on Sunday night, Nashville closes down. I stumbled on to Red, Hot and Blue, a shiny Memphis-style barbecue restaurant in the West End. There was one other person there, sitting at the bar. I sat down alongside.
"This is the only place I could find that was still open," I said.
"Viva Nash Vegas!" he replied.
 
The bottom line for music fans
 
Getting There
I spent an average of about $140 a day in Nashville, not including transportation. My round-trip ticket between New York and Nashville was $135, with tax, through American Airlines' Net Saaver, a free weekly E-mail list of discount fares. To receive Net Saaver, visit American's Web site: www.americanair.com.
 I rented an economy car for two days from Hertz through Net Saaver for a total of $54.44, with unlimited mileage, including a 5 percent discount as an American Aadvantage member and tax. A Rand McNally Easy Finder road map ($4.95) was a necessity.
 
Lodging

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Public Housing Tenants Trade Rents for Mortgages

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
IRA P. JACKSON, a 54-year-old clerk and mother of five grown children, will be writing her last rent check to the Jersey City Public Housing Authority this month. In August, Ms. Jackson will be closing on the two-family home she purchased with her daughter and son-in-law from the authority.
It is the same four-bedroom house she and her family have lived in for the last two years at the Dwight Street Homes, 50 two-family houses on scattered sites over three blocks in the city's Greenville section. Ms. Jackson will be the first resident to go from renter to owner, under a program sponsored by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development that enabled the authority to sell the homes to tenants who live there. 
 "This program gave me the opportunity to own a home," said Ms. Jackson, who has lived in public housing for 27 years. "Without it, I don't think I would have taken the chance."
Maria T. Maio, deputy executive director of the Jersey City Housing Authority, said the goal is that by 2000, all 50 of the two-family homes will be purchased by tenants. She said 15 more tenants are enrolled in the program.
The authority built the 100 apartments in the 50 town-house-style two-family houses, and has 400 more units in two- and three-family homes under way or planned. Forty of the homes will also be sold to tenants. All of the houses are part of the authority's plan to replace the apartments in six of the seven high-rise towers that it has razed or will raze at Curries Woods, a 712-unit public housing complex.
The high-rise complex, like others in New Jersey and elsewhere in the country, had become a symbol of a failed housing concept. Such projects were developed in the 1950's as an economical form of housing, but many of them -- beset by crime, neglect and mismangement -- became the dumping ground for the poorest of families. The Federal Government no longer supports the building of high-density housing towers.
Their replacements, like the Dwight Street Homes, are low-rise structures, which are considered more humane places for low-income families. High-rise buildings that can be are being renovated.
Housing officials in Washington are now accelerating efforts to encourage the sale of public housing, thinking that home ownership allows low-income tenants to take more control of their lives. It also supports the Clinton Administration's strategy to increase home ownership across the nation. Since 1993, HUD has approved the sale of 4,700 public housing units and plans to sell 25,000 more by 2000.
"This is a wise investment that strengthens families and helps more hard-working Americans enter the middle class," Andrew Cuomo, HUD Secretary, wrote in a statement. His department has several programs through which local housing authorities can help turn tenants into homeowners.
SUCH efforts are happening throughout New Jersey, which has 53,000 public housing units, said the Newark office of HUD. Newark is putting up 1,777 town houses to replace apartments in 12 of its high-rises as part of a 1989 settlement of a Federal lawsuit by a coalition of tenants and housing groups.
So far, 753 of the town houses have been built and occupied, and 196 more are in various stages of development, said Harry Robinson, a spokesman for the Newark Housing Authority. He said the authority was in the early stages of working with some tenants to buy their units.
The authority, using a $50 million grant from HUD, is also planning 630 more town houses, replacing apartments in high-rises that will be razed. As part of that effort, the New Community Corporation in Newark, among the state's largest nonprofit housing groups, will use a $25 million Federal grant to build 206 town houses that public housing tenants will be able to buy or rent with an option to buy. Work on the first 103 units is to start this fall. "This is another step in what we can do," said Msgr. William J. Linder, founder of New Community.
Paterson also received Federal money to raze two 10-story buildings with a total of 160 public housing units by the fall of 1998. Residents will receive Section 8 rent vouchers to move into private homes. Those vouchers, under pending Federal legislation, could be used to make mortgage payments, enabling tenants to buy homes, said Felix Raymond, executive director of the Paterson Housing Authority. He said the authority was also applying for Federal money to tear down another public housing complex, with 498 units. The plan, said Mr. Raymond, is to replace those apartments with an undetermined number of rental units and one- and two-family houses that will be sold to former tenants.
The idea of selling public housing to tenants has been tried before on a limited basis. In 1985, Brooks-Sloate Terrace, a 242-unit low-rise complex in Paterson, was one of 18 public housing authority projects in the country selected by HUD to take part in a demonstration to sell units to tenants. It was made a co-op, and in 1992 the Paterson Housing Authority turned over the complex to tenants. Today, 202 apartments at Brooks-Sloate have been sold.
In Jersey City, public housing residents at the Dwight Street Homes now have the chance to buy their units. The 50 vinyl-sided houses, with wrought iron fences and window shutters, look no different from other homes in the neighborhood. Each family has a separate front entrance to its three- or four-bedroom unit, with 1,100 to 1,200 square feet of space, and each unit has a small yard in front and back. Two-family homes "provide home ownership opportunities for low-income working families and retain rentals for those with lower incomes," said Ms. Maio of the housing authority.
The development was completed in 1995, and in the next two years the authority devised a plan, approved by HUD last month, to sell the units to eligible tenants. Twenty-five of the families earn no more than 80 percent of the median income in Jersey City, which translates into $35,000 for a family of four. The rest earn 50 percent or less of the median income, which is $24,000. Potential buyers must also complete a counseling program, covering such issues as money management and responsibilities of homeownership. Job training is also available. "It is a different approach that has the potential to be duplicated," said Diane Johnson, HUD's New Jersey coordinator.
The homes, priced at $140,000, will be sold first to the higher-income families "who have the financial wherewithal to buy and have a good shot at success," Ms. Maio said. Thirty-year mortgages at below market rate and zero percent down will be made available to eligible buyers through the New Jersey Housing Mortgage Finance Agency for $70,000. The Jersey City Housing Authority will provide a second no-interest loan for the remaining $70,000.
To receive the financing, buyers must agree to continue to rent the second apartment to public housing tenants, who if eligible will receive Federal Section 8 rent subsidies. That will make up the difference between what tenants now pay, which averages $225 a month, and market rents, averaging $800. Ms. Maio said the rental income is counted as part of buyers' income and will help them meet mortgage payments.
Buyers also must agree to live in the home for 10 years, and each year they do so the mortgage from the authority is reduced by 10 percent. If they leave before that time, there is a ceiling on the sale price that limits profit from appreciation.
Of buying one of the Dwight Street Homes, Ira Jackson said: "This is the begining of a new life for us. Something we can build upon for the future."
