HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Why Fix What's Not Broken?

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
INVESTORS who were grumbling at the year's start and threatening to funnel their mutual fund money into index funds are singing a different tune now. While the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index still holds an edge, rising 19.49 percent in the first half of the year, the market's riches flowed over all types of stocks in the second quarter.
The results are a far cry from those of the first three months of the year, when investors could barely eke out decent returns anywhere apart from the S.& P. stocks. And it is a testament to the value of carefully constructed long-term portfolios and the ability to stick by them during tough times. 
 That has been the approach of the five professional money managers who created hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times, and they have been justly rewarded for keeping the faith.
"What a difference a quarter makes," said Harold R. Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., whose portfolio rose 10.4 percent, to place fourth for the quarter. "It restores one's belief in diversification."
Mr. Evensky said that when he called the manager of one of his holdings, Compass Small Cap Growth, to discuss its 20 percent loss in the first quarter, the manager said he believed in what he was doing and planned no changes. That belief was vindicated: Compass roared back with a 21.7 percent gain. And Mr. Evensky's other first-quarter drags have also bounced back.
He conceded that balancing funds whose returns are poorly correlated with one another in a single portfolio may never produce eye-popping returns. But, he added, "it's comforting for those who have a long-term market view and whose goal is enjoying life and sleeping well."
Diversification is particularly good for these tricky times, agreed Eric M. Kobren, president of Insight Management and the editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter in Wellesley, Mass. The economy looks solid, but investors, who continue plowing money into mutual funds, face two gnawing questions, Mr. Kobren said: How much better can the economic environment get? And how high can the market value of the largest public companies rise?
"While nirvana may continue for a while longer, I feel very comfortable spreading my bets around in small-cap value, real estate and international stock funds," he said.
MR. KOBREN, who invests solely in Fidelity funds, took third place for the quarter, with a portfolio return of 11.6 percent. His top performer was Fidelity Dividend Growth, up 16.5 percent this quarter. He said its new manager, Charles Mangum, had transformed it into a more typical, large-cap growth fund.
Mr. Kobren cautioned that his laggard, Fidelity Real Estate, up a meager 5 percent this quarter, "serves as an anchor in the portfolio and that it should not be expected to reproduce last year's extraordinary gains." Over all, Mr. Kobren said he was happy with his portfolio and was not planning any changes.
Indeed, only one of the managers is planning even minor adjustments. The five portfolios have risen an average of 80 percent since they were created four years ago. That compares with a 119.6 percent cumulative four-year return for the Vanguard Index 500 fund, which mimics the S.& P. 500.
The performance of the hypothetical portfolios is tracked each quarter by Lipper Analytical Services, of Summit, N.J. It excludes sales charges, transaction costs and tax considerations because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The five managers can choose any fund open to new investors and can shift money quarterly, though the portfolios are intended to grow for 20 years.
All five portfolios made money in the second quarter, with an average gain of just over 12 percent. Still, just one came close to the 15.4 percent average for diversified domestic equity funds followed by Lipper.
That portfolio is the "socially responsible" fund assortment created by Jack A. Brill, a San Diego investment adviser. It rose 15.1 percent for the quarter, helped by a large chunk in the Domini Social Equity fund. That fund owns stocks that meet certain social criteria and are culled from the S.& P. 500 and from the second 500, to mimic the sector distribution of the S.& P. 500 as closely as possible, and also include small- and micro-cap stocks. Domini gained 17.3 percent in the second quarter.
"During the past year, screening out tobacco stocks helped the Domini Social Equity fund outperform the S.& P. 500," Mr. Brill said.
John Rekenthaler, the publisher of Morningstar Mutual Funds in Chicago, was particularly pleased with the performance of his portfolio, which was up 14.4 percent and ranked second this quarter. "Since many of these funds fare relatively well when stocks are declining, I'm very happy with their bull-market results," he said.
Mr. Rekenthaler is the one manager who is altering his portfolio for the third quarter, but the change is small. "My portfolio is already heavy on the smaller-company and international stocks that have somewhat lagged the past few years' gains, so I'm already tilted toward those assets that I think are ready to play catch-up," he said.
He will replace Third Avenue Value with Third Avenue Value Small Cap, a new offering managed by Martin Whitman, who runs the original fund, and by one of his proteges, Curtis Jensen. "I love the idea of a smaller, nimbler version of Third Avenue Value," Mr. Rekenthaler said.
His hypothetical portfolio may not be changing much, but its management is. Mr. Rekenthaler is leaving Morningstar to join the John Nuveen Company as its vice president and manager of its investment strategies. For the next quarter, his portfolio responsibilities will be assumed by Susan Paluch, the new editor of the Morningstar Investor newsletter.
Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y., retains the overall lead among the five managers, with a gain of nearly 98 percent since the exercise began, on July 7, 1993.
But for the second quarter, his portfolio was in last place, even though it rose a respectable 8.8 percent. Mr. Jacobs says he is comfortable with his portfolio as it is.
"It's about at the level of risk I want, and while some of the funds didn't do as well in the second quarter as they had done in the first quarter, you have to stay with your selections," Mr. Jacobs said. "There is a lot of rotation in the market."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Camaro SS;
At 30, Still a Diversion for Consenting Adults

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
THE car is spectacular, I'll give it that. It is a 30th-anniversary Camaro SS, Arctic white with "hugger orange" stripes, a houndstooth interior, huge tires and a snarling V8 under the hood. It is a car for superlatives. But at the moment it was totally inadequate.
"Let's try the stroller this way," I said to Mischa, rearranging things under the gaping hatch for, perhaps, the fifth time. And it fit, sort of. 
 Mischa is my daughter-in-law, visiting from her native Germany with my grandsons -- Hunter, 3, and Travis, 3 months -- and I was making good on my promise to take Hunter fishing. I dote on Hunter, you understand, and I am very proud that he is bilingual. Actually trilingual, if you count the "dises" and "dats" that sprinkle his English with what seems to be Brooklynese.
But this lovely car was not cooperating. Camaros are not made for two adults, two children, a pair of child-safety seats, a stroller, a tackle box and a couple of casting rods. And I realized why, given all the cars I have owned, I have let three decades of cramped Camaros pass me by.
I surveyed the remaining space and asked Hunter to pass me the bucket of worms.
"I do dat," he said.
This seems, incidentally, to be a year for anniversaries, what with America's oldest nameplate -- Olds, fittingly -- marking its 100th birthday; with Saab and Ferrari turning 50; with Toyota celebrating 40 years of sales in the United States, and with Mercury marking the 30th year of its Cougar with the announcement that this year's model will be the last, at least for now.
But the Camaro, along with its Pontiac Firebird stablemate, which also turns 30 this year, occupies a special corner of America's sporting heart. The Ford Mustang beat the G.M. models to market by more than two years, establishing the name for the pony-car group, and others like the Plymouth Barracuda grabbed the public fancy for a while. But the Camaro and Mustang and Firebird have been the stalwarts and survivors, and each has gotten better with age.
Dick Almond, Chevrolet's brand manager for Camaro, says the biggest problem with sporty cars has always been high insurance rates. But he said improvements in safety and anti-theft systems are making the cars more attractive to customers, and he sees a resurgence in sales of performance models. "Camaro has dropped out of the list of the 10 most-stolen cars," he said. "But it still offers something most cars don't -- it's flat-out fun, and the acceleration, cornering and handling are alive and well."
Still, the popularity of sporty cars has declined over the years and they now represent only about 8 percent of the passenger car market. Eight states, including New York, account for almost half the sales. The others are Florida, California, Texas, Michigan, Illinois, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
When the Camaro appeared in 1967, the craze for agile personal cars was in full flower. Its name, one of about 5,000 considered, is loosely based on the French word for comrade, and its friends over the years have been legion. As of now, more than 4.2 million Camaros have been built.
There have been just four generations of the car, beginning with the series that lasted from 1967 through 1969. Those cars, based on the Chevy II, were offered as coupes and convertibles, and prices started at a paltry $2,466. And while those little originals have become classics, the later models proved the staying power of good design.
In February 1970, the Camaro was radically restyled as a more aerodynamic coupe, and that design sold for a dozen years. In 1982, a new model rolled out with more chiseled lines, and the convertible returned in 1987 after an 18-year absence.
The current car has changed little since its birth in 1993, and it can be had in four flavors: plain Camaro, Camaro RS, Z28 and -- for the first time in 24 years -- as an SS, which stands for Super Sport. All are available as coupes, convertibles or T-tops with removable roof panels.
Prices, including delivery, start at $16,740 for a coupe with a 3.8-liter V6. That engine has just one more cubic inch of displacement than the six-cylinder '67, but it produces 200 net horsepower, compared with the original car's 140 gross horsepower. An anniversary-model Z28, with a 5.7-liter V8 that puts out 285 horses, is a bargain in today's market at $23,461. And the glowing orange-and-white SS test car, with an air-induction hood that lets the engine suck cool air and produces 305 horsepower, had a sticker that said $27,460.
Considering the car's power, fuel economy is reasonable, rated at 16 city, 27 highway. The SS likes 92-octane premium, but it will make do with less. And the big money buys more than zoom. There are the extra niceties of a beefier suspension, a limited-slip differential, a Hurst shifter for the six-speed stick, a 12-disk CD changer for the 200-watt stereo, and very nice floor mats.
Chevrolet says the Z28 will go from zero to 60 in 5.3 seconds, and the SS shaves that figure to 4.9. This is one quick car, but for all its strength the V8 can be amazingly civilized -- at least when you are at the wheel. For anyone behind the car, the thunderous exhaust is wondrously anti-social.
In fact, the SS is almost worth buying just for the sound, and it reminded me of the time I recorded half an hour of exhaust tunes at the rear of a friend's '59 Corvette. Call me crazy -- my wife did -- but I could sit on the couch and listen to that car all night. This Camaro is like that.
It is more fun on the road than on the couch, of course. The car's 17-inch wheels carry tires that are 9 inches wide, and the suspension glues the chassis to the asphalt -- as long as the surface is dry. In the wet, the tires' large contact patches spread the Camaro's weight over the water and send the car skittering. One must be careful, too, when approaching driveway ramps or when parking head-on against a curb; the low air dam in the front often scrapes bottom.
This is, of course, a toy. It is not meant for bad weather or as a family's only car. And as a toy, it is splendid. For 1997, there are new bucket seats, with contours redesigned to relieve fatigue on long trips. A new dashboard is swoopier and friendlier to the driver. There are four new cup holders and an extra lighter socket for your coffeepot (or, more probable, for your radar detector).
The body, mostly plastic and built on a steel unit-frame, is solid and relatively quiet, and even the 56-inch-wide doors don't judder or creak in the way of older Camaros. Those huge doors also make getting into the back seat less of a chore, and there is more room back there than any past pony-car could boast.
That still doesn't make it a vehicle for a fishing expedition. And, no, we didn't catch anything, but we had a good time. When we got home, Hunter ran for the house, stopped and looked back. Waiting for me, I thought. But what he said was, "I want dat car."
 
INSIDE TRACK: Even at 30, a teen dream for all of us.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 16; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1626 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
The Roller Coaster Known as Micro Cap

BYLINE: By ANNE TERGESEN 

 BODY:
MICRO-CAP mutual funds took investors on a wild ride this spring.
Since a brutal correction last summer in the market for small stocks and for its micro-cap subset, investors have favored blue chips. From January through April, funds specializing in micro caps -- stocks of companies with market values of less than $250 million -- trailed those investing in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by an average of about 14 percentage points. 
 In fact, the micro-cap funds had an average loss of 5.6 percent during that time, compared with an 8.8 percent gain for the index funds.
That prompted Satya Pradhuman, manager of United States quantitative analysis at Merrill Lynch, to wonder whether managers of the most beaten-down portfolios retained enough confidence to seize the opportunities he saw coming. "Investment managers have been traumatized," Mr. Pradhuman wrote in early May in a report to investors.
By the end of May, such concerns seemed misplaced. Almost overnight, the smallest stocks had transformed themselves from Wall Street's wallflowers into the life of the party, taking the funds that invest in them along for the ride. But when blue chips returned as the market leaders in June, investors were left to wonder whether May had been a cruel reminder of the short-lived surge in the spring of 1996 or the start of a long-awaited revival.
Such volatility is far from unusual. An analysis by Prudential Securities of data compiled by the University of Chicago's Center for Research in Security Prices shows that micro caps have historically posted ups and downs that are 87 percent more extreme than those of large stocks and 26 percent greater than those of small caps -- stocks with a market value under $1 billion.
The swings can increase sharply when fund managers shun diversification as a risk-management tool. American Heritage, a micro-cap fund that, like a lot of such funds, is too small to be included in many newspaper and other listings, posted a 78 percent return so far this year, largely on the back of one tiny stock. It plowed more than half its $18.1 million in assets into Senetek, a British company that says it has a treatment for male impotence.
The bet-the-store gamble paid off as Senetek's stock racked up a big percentage gain this quarter, rising from $3.38 to $4.50, but investors would have little cushion if the stock turned south. And the fund has an annual total return of just 2.2 percent over the last three years, suggesting that its valleys can be just as off-the-charts as its reported peaks.
"We are what you call a high-risk fund," said Heiko Thieme, the chairman and manager of the fund, defending his tendency to make heavy bets. "The very reason why we are up is that we remained focused."
Besides being highly volatile, the fund is also one of the most expensive around, charging fees of 6.25 percent of the fund's assets to defray overhead and other expenses, versus about 1.5 percent for the typical micro-cap offering.
Even diversified micro-cap funds can sometimes be a nightmare for impatient or risk-averse investors. Those who pulled money out of the Bridgeway Ultra-Small Company fund in response to its 3.6 percent loss in February missed out on gains that have left the portfolio up 20.6 percent for the first half of the year, when the average return for all diversified domestic funds was 13.1 percent, according to Morningstar. The Bridgeway fund concentrates on companies with market capitalizations of less than $100 million.
Micro-cap funds are particularly risky because of the speculative nature of many of the small companies they invest in. Stephen Janachowski, a co-founder of the investment advisory firm Brouwer & Janachowski, based in Tiburon, Calif., said the markets they trade in tend to be illiquid, adding to the volatility.
Those factors make micro caps a poor choice for investors unable to wait at least five years for returns, Mr. Janachowski said. He recommends that individual investors cap purchases of micro caps at 5 percent to 20 percent of a portfolio.
Although their outsized volatility makes small and micro-cap stocks notoriously difficult to predict, many market analysts argue that the fundamentals -- including a strong economy and a strong dollar -- are in place for a rebound in both sectors, which tend to move in tandem.
Other analysts point out, however, that these conditions have existed for some time but have yet to fuel a sustained micro-cap rally.
BUT even if micro caps fail to ride along with the current bull market, history suggests that patient investors will be rewarded. Since 1926, according to Prudential, micro caps have outperformed the rest of the market; their compounded annual returns of 12.6 percent were higher than the 11.8 percent for small caps and the 10.2 percent for blue chips.
"This is a great time to be looking at micro-caps," Mr. Pradhuman of Merrill Lynch said. With the heady multiples at which blue chips are now trading, he said, small stocks offer an opportunity to hunt for bargains and to diversify.
Mr. Pradhuman says small-cap stocks, including the micros, are cheaper relative to blue chips than they have been since the end of a small-stock bear market in 1990. Based on ratios of stock prices to sales, he said, micro-cap stocks are trading at about 0.32 times the average for large caps. That is 16 percent cheaper than the 0.38 they hit in 1990, the previous low for the decade.
Micro-cap funds are also relative bargains. Investors must now spend an average of $25.16 to receive $1 in earnings from funds that invest in the largest stocks, compared with $27.30 for small-cap stocks and $23.43 for those specializing in micro caps, Morningstar says.
Also working in the sector's favor is a proposed cut in the capital gains tax rate, said Claudia Mott, director of small-cap research at Prudential. If history repeats, she said, after a correction in one quarter, small stocks will rally by more than their large counterparts. That, she added, is because the smallest companies typically deliver returns in the form of price appreciation, or capital gains, rather than dividends.
On balance, advisers say, another positive factor for the smallest stocks is the recent decline in initial public offerings. Although deprived of high-flying small stocks they can sell at a quick profit, micro-cap mutual funds can benefit because investors interested in small stocks then turn their attention to existing issues, pushing prices higher.
With all these promising signs for micro caps, the only missing piece of the equation is earnings growth, Ms. Mott says. If analysts polled by the First Call Corporation are correct, after two years in which earnings improved too slowly to justify the higher risk of investing in small stocks, profit growth at small companies will outstrip that of market leaders by more than 10 percent this year and next.
The strength of the dollar argues in favor of that outcome, because a strong dollar squeezes profit margins on multinationals, which tend to be more reliant than small companies on exports. But skeptics argue that hopes for the smallest stocks could again be dashed by overly optimistic earnings projections or rising interest rates, which tend to punish small- and micro-cap stocks more than their larger counterparts.
 I'M not convinced that we're ready for a big-league period of outperformance," said Peter Canelo, an investment strategist at Morgan Stanley.
Mr. Canelo also notes that although conditions have been favorable to the smallest stocks for some time now, the stocks continue to lag behind blue-chip stocks. "I admit to being kind of mystified as to how some of these traditional relationships haven't been working," he said. "The strong economy doesn't help; the strong dollar doesn't help."
The lesson, he added, may be that in an increasingly integrated global economy, bigger is better.
Whatever doubts investors may have, they seem to have put them aside: The Russell 2000, the benchmark measure for small-cap companies, reached an all-time high on June 19.
Mr. Pradhuman argues that the current environment favors both growth funds, which invest in companies with above-average profit growth, and value funds, which pick stocks selling at discounts to their assets. The economy is strong, which is a plus for value funds, but not strong enough to ignite the rising interest rates that undermine growth funds, he said. If he is correct, that should reverse the poor performance among growth funds that has been responsible for most of the recent lag in small caps, he added.
Bruce Baughman, portfolio manager of the Franklin Group's Value and Balance Sheet Investment funds, says that it is only a matter of time before the rich price-earnings ratios of blue chips persuade investors to switch to smaller stocks. These days, Franklin's two value-oriented funds, which invest where they see value regardless of the size of the company, are heavily weighted in micro-cap companies, a greater number of which meet their criteria of selling near or below a discount to book value adjusted for overstated assets and under-estimated liabilities.
Mr. Baughman's portfolios are among this year's top 10 micro-cap performers, with the Balance Sheet fund, now closed to new individual investors, up 15.3 percent and the Value fund up 16.4 percent.
John Montgomery, manager of the Bridgeway Ultra-Small Company fund, which closed to new investors last month, said computer models that dictate his hybrid growth-value strategy showed early in the year that there were good deals to be found.
"When people start writing that the small-cap phenomenon is dead, that's the time to invest," he said.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Funds That Staggered as the Market Danced

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
GOOD news is no news for mutual fund investors these days, as seven years of sizzling stock market performance have conditioned millions of Americans to expect strong gains as a matter of course.
Mutual fund returns that just a few years ago would have had investors salivating are now greeted with a shrug, or even a yawn. Indeed, a new survey by Montgomery Asset Management found mutual fund owners confident that they would make 26 percent a year from their funds over the next decade, far more than the 10 percent that most market seers have suggested is reasonable. And who can blame investors for these expectations, given that over the last 12 months, the average stock mutual fund has gained almost 22 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund trackers in Chicago? 
 So the real news, in the dog days of 1997, is not the fact that broad-based stock funds soared 14 percent in the second quarter of the year, or that almost every kind of stock fund, at home and abroad, posted double-digit gains, or even that bond funds turned in strong performances.
No, the man-bites-dog angle arises from the fact that in one of the greatest bull markets in history, a few funds have nonetheless managed to lose money in the last year or two or five. Not many funds, mind you, and it was certainly no mean feat, given that during the last five years, stock mutual funds as a group have averaged annual returns of almost 17 percent, international funds almost 12 percent and taxable bond funds roughly 7 percent.
That such funds are still around is perhaps even more astounding, given that investors usually flee seriously lagging funds. Their proprietors then generally close them, or fold them into other, better-performing funds, eliminating their poor track records.
The funds that have hung in there despite poor performance sometimes specialize in sectors -- like gold -- for which some investors still have hope. Others are one-time top dogs that suffered temporary but severe setbacks, like some high-octane funds that invest in small companies and are still trying to recoup losses they suffered last year and early this year. A handful of losers are just quirky.
And other dogs are simply, well, dogged. "I would guess that the laggards would typically be described as stubborn," said A. Michael Lipper, the longtime fund watcher who is president of Lipper Analytical Services. These funds are typically run by managers of a bearish bent who are convinced that the stock market is due for a crash -- and who have been waiting a very long time.
"We've been bearish so long I hate to admit it," said Charles L. Minter, who runs Comstock Partners and its two mutual funds, Comstock Capital Value, which is down an average of 5 percent a year for the last five years, and Comstock Strategy, which has eked out meager gains of 2.9 percent a year in that period.
Mr. Minter and his late partner, Stanley D. Salvigsen, achieved a certain renown on Wall Street for their economic and market forecasts, particularly for predicting the "rolling recession" in housing, which hit various parts of the real estate market in the late 1980's.
COMSTOCK turned negative on the American stock market in 1990, and has been betting ever since that stocks would fall. "I do believe that if the stock market continues to go up, we will wind up having to go out of business," Mr. Minter said. For him to become bullish on stocks, he said, the market would have to fall 30 percent or more.
The results of sticking to his convictions have been painful for Mr. Minter. The funds, which once had more than $2 billion in assets, have shrunk to less than $500 million. Losses have been so severe that the funds now have more than $200 million in potential tax benefits, which have become one of their main selling points. Future profits, if there ever are any, would be sheltered from taxes to some degree.
And Dreyfus, the big fund company that once sponsored one of Comstock's funds, basically jettisoned it last year after Dreyfus's longtime (and perennially bearish) chairman, Howard Stein, sold the company to Mellon Bank. The company also revamped its other bearish fund, Dreyfus Strategic Growth, in 1995; that fund is now an aggressive-growth vehicle. "We have no bearish funds at Dreyfus," a spokeswoman said.
Though few of the so-called bear funds have been around, or stayed around, as long as Comstock's, a few cubs are on the prowl, and they have all had terrible years. Lindner Bulwark dropped 18.4 percent in the last 12 months, for example, and Rydex Ursa, which is sort of an index fund for bears, fell 20.2 percent.
Then there is the Mathers Fund, which has pretty much eschewed stocks in favor of cash for the last decade; it is the worst-performing diversified stock fund for the last five years, its annual gain of just 1.4 percent barely beating cash under the mattress.
Another losing strategy, especially lately, has been trying to "time the market," as Wall Street puts it; this means trading in and out of funds to try to catch the peaks and avoid the valleys. In the last quarter, three funds in the Rightime fund family, which, as its name implies, uses a timing strategy, suffered losses of 0.9 percent to 1.9 percent.
Though the mutual fund business has become increasingly corporate over the last decade, there are still a few of the more eccentric entrepreneurs who became famous (or infamous) in the 70's and early 80's, before the big boom in funds. Charles Steadman, who is about to turn 83, continues to run four funds that have long been too small to be listed in this newspaper. They have, however, compiled one of the worst investment records on the planet. (Over the last decade, Steadman Technology and Growth has lost about 90 percent of its value.)
Then there is Fundamental's New York Muni Fund, which is the only fund investing in tax-exempt bonds to post a loss for the last five years, falling an average of three-tenths of a percent a year, according to Morningstar. (The average municipal bond fund made more than 6 percent a year.) Lance M. Brofman, the fund's founder and manager, said he was not sure whether the fund had indeed lost money during the five-year period. In 1994, the fund plunged 20 percent because of a wrong-way bet on interest rates.
AS a group, the biggest bow-wows of the 1990's have been gold funds. Over the last five years, precious-metals funds have averaged gains of 5.5 percent a year, barely beating money-market funds. Hardest hit have been funds that specialize in the shares of mining companies in South Africa, which have been beset by labor problems; U.S. Global Gold Shares has an annualized loss of 13 percent a year over the last five years.
Why, then, do investors keep what Lipper Analytical reckons is more than $4 billion in gold funds? For the investors known as gold bugs, gold investing is practically a religion; for others, who may also be stockpiling canned goods and shotgun shells in their basements, it is a hedge against apocalypse.
But for many others, it is simply a way to diversify on the off chance that inflation picks up again, said Jeffrey S. Molitor, principal and director of portfolio review at the Vanguard Group, which runs the biggest gold fund, one that returned an average of 4.2 percent annually over the last five years.
True, inflation has been falling for several years, and hovers just above 2 percent. (In the late 70's and early 80's, when gold funds were hot, inflation topped 10 percent.) But "should we see some upward movement in inflation, there is a reasonable chance of the portfolio doing better than bonds," Mr. Molitor said. And while gold may not seem like a promising bet, inflation has been known to rise, while it would take an unprecedented economic boom to produce the 26 percent annual returns that mutual fund investors said they expected in the Montgomery survey.
Just to prove that every dog has its day, the beleaguered Japanese stock market appears to be staging a small comeback, as does the country's currency. Funds that invest in Tokyo were the best-performing group last quarter, zooming 20.4 percent. Nevertheless, investors who took the plunge in 1996 have probably not fared well, given that the funds are still in negative territory for the last 12 months, down 5.6 percent.
To some extent, the recent recovery may be what Wall Street calls a "dead cat bounce," meaning that anything that falls far enough is likely to rebound a bit. But over the next three or five years, Japan may be a good investment, because "the momentum is building for Japan to come to grips with its problems," said Elizabeth Allan, who is co-manager of the publicly traded Scudder New Asia fund, as well as the Japan Fund, one of the hottest funds of the quarter.
In the short run, Ms. Allan, who has more seniority in her post than many of her competitors, is cautious, suggesting that "the market could take a breather here." She still finds "lots of good opportunities in Japan, if one is very selective," she added, "and I say selective because there are still a lot of companies that will experience a lot of challenges going forward."
With the United States stock market hitting new highs -- the Dow Jones industrial average closed on Thursday at 7,895.81, up 100.43 -- it may be tempting for investors to put their money into areas that have failed to perform well, like the stocks of basic industries, utilities, coal mines or real estate firms. But some experts warn against it.
"I think there's a bit of a trap investing in dogs," said Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief investment strategist for Lehman Brothers. "You have to ask yourself, why should basic industrial stocks suddenly outperform? What's the fundamental case?"
But Mr. Applegate thinks there is still plenty of time for investors to get into the winning areas of the stock market. Concern about the length of the bull run is overblown, he said, adding that by his calculations, which look at economic cycles, the current bull market is by no means the longest or biggest in history.
"If you're in U.S. equities, continue to enjoy the rally," he wrote recently. "If you're not, we don't think it's too late to come in. After all, records are meant to be broken."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3938 words

HEADLINE: The Greening of Gambling's Golden Boy

BYLINE: By JON CHRISTENSEN 

DATELINE: LAKE TAHOE, Nev.

 BODY:
"HE can't back down," said Steve Wynn, the chairman and chief executive of Mirage Resorts Inc. "I'll throw my body in front of the train."
Mr. Wynn had leaned close to buttonhole a board member at a meeting here in March of the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency, but his forceful stage whisper carried around the room, just as he had intended. "We sent a message to those guys," he said. "And as long as I'm around, we won't back down." 
 Mr. Wynn is used to getting his way. The strong-willed and hot-tempered head of one of the country's biggest gambling companies, he has built a string of hugely successful casinos in Las Vegas. He recently beat Donald Trump in a court battle over an access road that will pave the way for his triumphant return to the Atlantic City waterfront. And he is building the biggest casino on Mississippi's Gulf Coast.
He has also been flexing his muscles lately around Lake Tahoe, the popular gambling center and recreation area straddling the California-Nevada border, 350 miles northwest of his home base of Las Vegas.
But while Tahoe seems like a natural setting for yet another of his gargantuan gambling palaces, Mr. Wynn's tough talk at the planning board meeting had nothing to do with winning a building permit.
To the contrary, Mr. Wynn is on the board. What he was so emphatic about was water, specifically the once-pristine waters of the 250-square-mile lake that anchors the region. And the "train" he was so ready to throw his body in front of is the armada of Jet Skis and other so-called personal watercraft that he says are dumping large amounts of unburned fuel in those waters, contributing to the alarming pace at which the lake is losing its celebrated clarity. Ten days ago, he got his way, when the board voted to ban the machines from the lake starting in two years.
Steve Wynn, master developer of mega-casinos, meet Steve Wynn, hard-core environmentalist.
The man who runs a casino that sports a "live" volcano out front and another that pits pirates against the British Navy in lifesize ships every other hour says he is now worried about the excesses of development. And not just in Tahoe, where he owns a sprawling vacation home next door to Michael Milken's and serves as Nevada's at-large representative on the planning agency's 15-member governing board.
He has also spread the message to Las Vegas, a symbol to many of American overbuilding in full flower and a city that Mr. Wynn developed as much as anyone.
"It's time for us to slow down and think about where we're going," Mr. Wynn told a gathering of business executives and civic leaders there earlier this year. The breakneck pace of development that has made Las Vegas the fastest-growing city in the country for more than a decade is leading to "quality problems," he said.
Mr. Wynn the environmentalist is even about to take the national stage, when President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore visit Tahoe on July 26 and 27 for a meeting on how business and regulators can cooperate to protect the environment. Mr. Wynn, seen by some as an effective symbol of such cooperation, is expected to play a "substantial role" at the conference, said Jim Baetge, executive director of the Tahoe planning agency.
All of this has plenty of interested players -- environmentalists, casino competitors and gambling industry experts, not to mention Tahoe and Las Vegas residents -- putting down bets about what is going on.
Some question how a developer as dedicated as Mr. Wynn could suddenly reveal a deep green streak. They wonder whether his apparent commitment to the environment camouflages a more complicated agenda.
The possibilities are as varied as Mr. Wynn's interests. Did he join the board to protect his multimillion-dollar investment in a vacation paradise, and to do the same for Mr. Milken, a friend who helped finance his meteoric rise in the casino industry? Is he trying to win points with the Government at a time when a new Federal commission is starting hearings on the social and economic effects of the spread of legalized gambling? Is he simply trying to keep Tahoe at bay -- and put Las Vegas on hold -- now that his most expensive casino, the $1.4 billion Bellagio, is rising on the Vegas Strip, making him the biggest boy by far on the block?
"For him to say we should control growth is not that sincere when you consider that his business not only stems from all this growth but creates part of it," said Rick Nielsen, director of Citizen Alert, an environmental group that has fought growth in Las Vegas for years. "If he's sincere about protecting national treasures and being an environmentalist, he doesn't have to go all the way to Lake Tahoe to get involved. We've got Lake Mead, which is only 20 miles from Las Vegas."
John Smith, a columnist for The Las Vegas Review-Journal and the author of "Running Scared: The Life and Treacherous Times of Casino King Steve Wynn" (Barricade Books, 1995), is another skeptic. Mr. Wynn became involved in Tahoe "initially to protect his investment," Mr. Smith speculated. "I'm sure he has feelings about the environment. But Steve's world is about power and control. He won't do anything he can't control."
Others who know him or have followed his career disagree. This is a sincere new side to a complicated man, they say. The son of a compulsive gambler who died in debt, Mr. Wynn has spent his life fulfilling his father's dream of building a casino empire. Now that he is 55, these people say, he wants to be remembered for more than just casinos.
"A lot of people say, 'He's got his empire; why in the world would he want to be on this board?' " said Peter Neumann, a Reno lawyer who is also on the planning agency panel. "Whatever his motivation, he has really taken a personal interest. I think he thinks of Tahoe as his home. And I think he genuinely feels the lake is a treasure, as we all do."
The clock is ticking for Mr. Wynn in another way. He may go blind in not too many years, a likely outcome of the degenerative eye disease that surfaced when he was 29. The inherited, incurable disease, retinitis pigmentosa, destroys nerves in the retina.
Mr. Wynn says he is missing the lower half of his field of vision when looking at objects up close, along with some peripheral vision, but that he is otherwise fine and not getting worse. His ophthalmologist, Dr. Alan S. Crandall, is making no promises, however. "He's down to tunnel vision," Dr. Crandall said. "If he lives long enough, he probably will go blind."
And already, he sometimes seems to move as a sleepwalker does, feeling for walls with his hands and feet. On the way back to the March board meeting from lunch, Mr. Wynn walked face first into a post. He shook off the blow like a boxer and plodded on, showing no sign of pain.
Whatever is making Steve Wynn run, some environmentalists are glad to have a businessman of his power on their side. After all, he is a wily operator who knows how to make use of laws and government agencies to get what he wants in the gambling world. Bringing those skills to the defense of a lake's water quality should produce big dividends, some say.
They point to the rancorous, 12-hour meeting late last month at which the planning board backed his campaign against Jet Skis and similar machines, waterborne cousins of the motorcycle that are almost as fast and certainly just as loud as their wheeled relatives. The board voted 10 to 4 to ban all such machines, whose two-cycle engines run on a mix of gasoline and oil, from the lake beginning June 1, 1999. Mr. Wynn led the fight for the ban, arguing that the engines discharge hundreds of thousands of gallons of unburned fuel into the lake each year. The ban, which is expected to be appealed by manufacturers and rental shops, is far tougher than the position taken by the Environmental Protection Agency, which recently ordered makers of personal watercraft to begin equipping them with more efficient engines over the next decade.
Mr. Wynn also marshaled support last fall for a $20 million state bond issue for erosion-control projects on the Nevada side of the lake. Erosion, another byproduct of development, sends soil runoff into the lake, nourishing algae that further cloud the water.
"He has done a lot to focus additional attention on Tahoe," said Rochelle Nason, director of the League to Save Lake Tahoe, a nonprofit group. "He was very helpful in getting that bond issue on the ballot in the Nevada legislature. We've disagreed with him on a few issues, but on the whole our impression has been good."
 
Jumping Into a Lake's Future
For his part, Mr. Wynn says there is a simple, and innocent, explanation for his decision to serve on the board.
Whenever he went to a party, he heard people complaining about the agency, he said in a recent interview. "Environmentalists didn't like it. Developers didn't like it. Everybody talks about the environment, but very rarely do you have a chance to do anything about it. I thought it would be an interesting exercise, kind of like going to graduate school. I thought it was going to be a noncontroversial, low-keyed, rather technical activity. It was as far away from what I do for a living as you could get. And that suited me to a T."
Mr. Wynn joined the board two years ago. Established in 1968 by Congress and the states of California and Nevada, the planning agency is charged with overseeing development around the lake. The President names one nonvoting member, while California and Nevada each get seven voting members, all appointed by local and state governments except for Nevada's one at-large seat. That seat is filled by a vote of the other Nevada appointees. Mr. Wynn was one of eight or nine applicants for the unpaid position, and while he had no formal background in environmental protection or in regional planning, several members who voted for him say they were impressed by his energy and intelligence.
They were also certainly aware that Mr. Wynn is a powerful force in Nevada politics and a significant presence on the national scene. A major donor to both Republicans and Democrats, he threw a party at his private golf course in Las Vegas that raised a half-million dollars for Bob Dole's Presidential campaign. Mr. Wynn has also played golf with Bill Clinton.
Mr. Wynn came to the Tahoe area in 1992, building a getaway home in the lakeside enclave of Incline Village, or what locals call "Income Village." It is a "nice, roomy house," he said, "with three bedrooms, a gym and a media room, and a little guest house with two bedrooms, on five acres."
"It's not a mansion," he added, "but it is 11,000 square feet."
For a time, Mr. Wynn kept a fleet of five of the noisy watercraft at his dock, jumping waves in front of his estate with the likes of former President George Bush.
But Mr. Wynn soon learned that there was trouble in his newfound paradise. Lake Tahoe, set more than a mile high in the Sierra Nevada, is surrounded by granite peaks draped with dark green pine forest. But the lake's famous clarity is rapidly declining. The first scientist to measure the clarity in 1873 could see a dinner plate 108 feet down. A similar plate is visible only to 70 feet today and the clarity is deteriorating at the rate of a foot and a half a year, according to the regional planning agency.
Soil runoff is a major villain. After reading a magazine article about the banning of personal watercraft from a Swiss lake, Mr. Wynn decided that the zippy little machines were another. He sold off his fleet (though he kept a large powerboat, which uses a less-polluting four-cycle engine) and made a lakewide ban his mission.
That raised the hackles of some local residents, who quickly came to regard him as a high-profile interloper who was meddling with their way of life.
"Lake Tahoe is being taken over by fat cats like Steve Wynn," wrote Jeff Ackerman, publisher and editor of The Nevada Appeal, the daily newspaper in Carson City, the state capital. "The billionaires are running the millionaires out of Tahoe. And they're using Tahoe's clarity as a tool to rid themselves of the riffraff who can't afford a giant lake cruiser that Wynn and his buddies use to cruise what is becoming their own private paradise."
Mr. Wynn dismissed the attacks as "sound and fury signifying nothing." In an interview before the board vote, he said: "The agency is being put to the test on this issue. If it can't deal with something as black and white as that, then it's useless."
In this practical vein, he has been pushing to get the agency to cut back on red tape and become more "user friendly" to businesses and homeowners. The goal is to protect the environment, he said, not to "waste time on minutiae and irrelevant things."
"It's not a major issue whether someone adds a deck or a back porch to their house," he added. "It should not be a problem for a businessman to add a bathroom or other things to his business. You shouldn't need three consultants and an army of lawyers to increase the size of your building by 10 percent. Those things should be perfunctory."
Only then, he argues, will the agency attract the kind of popular support that it needs to succeed at its fundamental mission of protecting the lake.
Now, with the victory against Jet Skis and the like under his belt, the environmental conference is next.
What will Mr. Wynn tell the President when he comes to Lake Tahoe? "Lake Tahoe is worth saving," said Mr. Wynn, and it's going to take "a lot of capital."

'Always a Mountain Person'
Mr. Wynn gets up to Lake Tahoe on a company jet about once a month for board meetings, sometimes making additional trips to ski (which he says he can handle just fine, despite his vision problems) or to spend time on the lake.
He and his wife, Elaine, who serves on the board of Mirage Resorts, have another vacation place, a huge spread in Sun Valley, Idaho. Their daughters -- Gillian, 28, who works for Mirage as a designer of a water laser show, and Kevyn, 31, a marketer at Mirage -- are fanatically in love with Sun Valley, Mr. Wynn said.
"Tahoe is my thing," he explained. "I was brought up in the mountains in a place very much like Tahoe on a reduced scale, with a pine forest surrounding a lake. Once you're a mountain person, you're always a mountain person."
Mr. Wynn, who grew up in Utica, N.Y., spent his early summers at Old Forge in the Adirondacks. He named his Lake Tahoe home Old Forge out of "nostalgia for my childhood," he said.
It was a special childhood, marked by unusual defining moments. Mr. Wynn's father, who was born Michael Weinberg and later changed his last name, ran bingo parlors on the East Coast. While trying to open a bingo hall in Las Vegas, he showed his son, then 11, around the city. The father was often in debt but Steve had everything he wanted. He went to prep school before going to the University of Pennsylvania, where he earned a bachelor's degree in English.
When his father died in 1963, while undergoing open heart surgery at the age of 46, he left behind tens of thousands of dollars in gambling debts. Mr. Wynn and his wife, who also grew up in a family headed by a compulsive gambler, took over the bingo business. They were both 21. He called the numbers and she counted the money. It took years to pay off the I.O.U.'s.
In 1967, Steve Wynn moved his family to Las Vegas to redeem his father's dream. He bought a 3 percent stake in the Frontier Hotel casino and became the slot manager. When investigators discovered that the hotel was owned by Detroit mobsters, Mr. Wynn sold his shares, denying any previous knowledge of the underworld link.
He then became friends with E. Parry Thomas, the founder and owner of the Valley Bank, which financed much of the Las Vegas casino industry's expansion in the 1960's and 70's and later merged with the Bank of America. In 1972, Mr. Thomas helped arrange a real estate deal in which Mr. Wynn bought a lot from Howard Hughes for $1.1 million and then sold it to Caesars Palace, next door, for $2.25 million.
Mr. Wynn used the profit to acquire a 5 percent interest in the Golden Nugget, then a rundown casino in the Glitter Gulch section of downtown Las Vegas. He eventually took control, becoming at 31 the youngest person ever to run a casino in Nevada.
 
Palace After Palace
Most casinos in those days were dimly lit affairs that exuded an illicit backroom feeling. Mr. Wynn brought in the sunlight. He transformed the "gambling joint," as he called it, into a sparkling palace for high rollers, directly across from the spot on Glitter Gulch where his father had failed to open a bingo parlor.
Unlike his father, Mr. Wynn does not gamble, viewing that part of his family history as a cautionary tale. "If you want to make money in a casino, own one," he has been quoted as saying. Like other major casino operators, Mr. Wynn sponsors programs to help compulsive gamblers. At the same time, though, he says most people enjoy gambling and know how to set their own limits, and he sees nothing wrong with bringing them in by the thousands to the glitzy showcases that have made his name.
In 1980, Mr. Wynn built the Golden Nugget in Atlantic City, using the Golden Nugget in Las Vegas as collateral on a raft of junk bonds floated by Mr. Milken. It was one of the first new casinos to bring Las Vegas glitter to the Boardwalk. He sold the operation to the Bally Corporation in 1987 for $440 million. That helped Bally fight off a takeover bid from Donald Trump (so that Bally owned too many casinos for Mr. Trump to acquire under New Jersey rules) while making a profit for Mr. Wynn of $250 million. He used the proceeds, along with junk bonds from Mr. Milken, to begin building a chain of ever more fabulous casinos on the Strip in Las Vegas.
The Mirage, with its fiery volcano, opened in 1989. Treasure Island, complete with pirates, opened next door in 1993. Down the road, the Bellagio is now taking shape on the site of the old Dunes, which Mr. Wynn blew up to make way for the new palace.
The gambling business has paid off handsomely for both Mr. Wynn and Mirage Resorts. The company's gross revenues totaled $1.37 billion in 1996, with profits of $206 million. The return to investors has averaged 22 percent a year for the last decade -- one reason Fortune magazine sees Mirage as one of the most admired companies in America, though the stock lately has been lackluster. It closed on Thursday at $24.875, still depressed from the $29.625 it reached a year ago.
Mr. Wynn's annual salary and bonus total about $4 million. His 15 percent stake in Mirage Resorts is now worth more than $500 million.
 
Seeing Past a Disease
Although the sparkle in his eyes has been dimmed by retinitis pigmentosa, Mr. Wynn's smile is still as dazzling as the well-lit facades of his casinos.
In 1993, he donated $1 million to the John Moran Eye Center at the University of Utah to create the Michael M. Wynn Center for Inherited Retinal Diseases, named for his father. He hopes a cure will be found, but he does not want to be defined by his disease.
"My handicap is an inconvenience," he said. "I can't see my own hand underneath my nose. And I can't see if you stick your hand out to shake with me, but my central vision is perfect. So the minute you're 8 or 10 feet from me I see everything. Honestly, I skied 39 days last year," albeit on wide-open runs with a guide.
And although many who know him well, including his mother, have said that he became more driven and short-tempered after the disease was diagnosed, Mr. Wynn says his basic character has not changed.
"Everybody always tries to do an interpretation of my attitude in business, my drive or my ambition with the fact that my vision diminishes, as if I have a limited amount of time, the lights are going out, the sun is dimming," he said. "It is true that having R.P. affects my behavior. I don't drive. I can't go in the dark and behave freely. I need help. I wear reading glasses like any 55-year-old man. But it's O.K."
As if to put to rest any concern about his vision, Mr. Wynn paused to look out at Lake Tahoe during a break at a recent agency meeting and commented on the "gumption" of a windsurfer who was wearing a short-sleeved wet suit on the cold choppy waters.
 
What Kind of Mission?
Asked whether he had any thoughts of pursuing any other public office, Mr. Wynn said, "I have thoughts and the answer is I won't. I'm not cut out for it."
Still, Mr. Wynn seemed relaxed at the agency meeting, where he bantered easily with fellow board members.
"You've got 15 board members and Steve's one of those members, and that's a change from his business and the way he operates normally," said Mr. Baetge, the agency's staff director. "You can't just come in and say, 'I'm in charge here.' You're not. He's got a strong personality in terms of making an argument and standing by it and stressing to the public why we do something. But I've found him fairly easy to work with."
Mr. Wynn left the recent meeting early to go to Las Vegas for the opening of the Secret Garden at the Mirage, a habitat for the rare tigers used in shows by the house entertainers, Siegfried and Roy. He also had to prepare for Mirage Resorts' annual meeting.
The next day, Mr. Wynn told stockholders that the era of rapid expansion in the gambling industry was slowing. He said that Mirage Resorts might consider expanding through acquisitions, but that too many gaming companies were saddled with aging buildings in second-rate locations. In the meantime, the stockholders could look forward to the opening in September 1998 of the Bellagio and, three months later, the Beau Rivage casino in Biloxi, Miss., on the Gulf Coast. Construction has not yet begun in Atlantic City, where Mr. Wynn plans to build a casino in the Marina section.
In his remarks, he echoed his concerns expressed earlier this year that Las Vegas suffered from "quality problems," particularly traffic congestion and air pollution.
The population of the Las Vegas metropolitan area is 1 million, and it is projected to reach 1.6 million in 10 years. "Any given area can only take so many people," he said. "I'm not sure what that number is. But if the air's not clean and you can't move in the streets, it seems like you're getting there. So what do you do about it?"
His answer is to learn something from the Lake Tahoe experience. "It takes consensus," he said. "And the only hope is to educate the public."
Skeptics say Mr. Wynn has a lot of moxie even to pose the question, given his own role in the city's growth. "If he's serious about controlling growth, he could be doing a lot more than he is," said Mr. Nielsen, of Citizen Alert. "It's a lot of hot air."
But others say he may be just the right person to ring the alarm. "When someone of his stature says things, people in Las Vegas tend to listen," said Mike Sloan, vice president of Circus Circus Enterprises, a competitor that jointly owns the Monte Carlo casino in Las Vegas with Mirage. "I don't think he's worried about competition. I think it is a quality-of-life issue."
Jeff Van Ee, a longtime Las Vegas environmental activist who sits on the local clean-air advisory board, offers some qualified support. "I find myself seemingly more in concert with him than I expected," Mr. Van Ee said. "I think he's changing. People are skeptical of his motives. As an environmentalist, looking at Steve Wynn and his impact on this community, I view him as a work in progress."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATBUSH -- UPDATE;
Market Is Off the Fast Track

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from the community board and a ruling from the city's Corporation Counsel, Councilwoman Una Clarke and officials from the city's Department of Business Services last week backed away from a fast construction schedule for a prefabricated vendor's marketplace in Flatbush.
Members of Community Board 14 said that by blocking the plan they had foiled a potentially illegal and undemocratic back-room deal. But Ms. Clarke and Earl Andrews Jr., Commissioner of the Department of Business Services, said their intent had been misunderstood. 
 At the Councilwoman's urging, the business services department and the Economic Development Corporation planned to employ a rarely used procedure known as "emergency declaration" in the construction of a vendor's facility proposed for a city-owned parking lot at Flatbush and Caton Avenues. By using the "emergency declaration," the agencies would have been able to avoid a competitive bidding process and a Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, or Ulurp, which includes community board hearings.
Alvin Berk, chairman of Community Board 14, said the board had only recently learned of the $400,000 project. The board argued that the project had to go through Ulurp. After reviewing the project, the Corporation Counsel determined that because capital funds were being used, the land use review was required. Mr. Berk said the board was only trying to make the Department of Business Services follow the rules.
"This is a really solid argument for working within the system of the community boards," Mr. Berk said, "rather than trying to ram things through and bypass public debate and public discussion."
Ms. Clarke, who obtained $400,000 in city capital money for the project, denied any wrongdoing. She said she thought a Ulurp review was not required for the vendors' market because it was not a permanent structure and was being built by a city agency on a city-owned lot.
Mr. Andrews, the business services commissioner, said the emergency declaration was only an attempt to move the project along quickly.
"The word 'emergency' is not what the declaration was about," Mr. Andrews said. "It was just a mechanism to get it through."
At a June 30 meeting, the community board agreed that a pilot program that allows vendors to use 18 of the 93 spaces in the lot as an open-air market should continue until a final decision has been made.
But about 30 vendors who attended the meeting in support of the project expressed frustration at the delay.
"We're not going to have it for December," said Enid King, the president of the vendors' group. "I'm so disappointed. I don't know what we're going to do." DAVID ROHDE

HEADLINE: Juarez, Mexico: On the Border, Between Extremes

BYLINE: By TOM KUNTZ 

 BODY:
CIUDAD JUAREZ, a city of well over a million people just across the Rio Grande from El Paso, Texas, is a dynamic point along the membrane between the world of the desperately striving in Mexico and that of the relatively prosperous in the United States.
The photographs on this page capture some of the border's grit, hustle and run-of-the-mill horrors: Mongrel dogs prowl beneath freshly hung women's stockings in the midday sun. The body of an electrocuted man sizzles atop a power line he had illegally tried to tap. And a slain young woman lies partly buried in the sand -- one of those routinely savaged in a city that draws people from afar to jobs in its many maquiladoras, the foreign-owned border factories, or to its attendant professions, like prostitution. 
 These pictures are among thousands taken since 1993 by a group of Juarez photographers who set out to document the vibrant and violent life of their town. The work of the 11 photographers (several of whom are employed by the city's main paper, Diario de Juarez) is being published in a forthcoming book, "Juarez -- The Laboratory of Our Future" (Aperture).
Although the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement was supposed to bring economic prosperity to Mexico, some people see the grim Juarez photographs as evidence of the exploitive nature of Nafta. But Jaime Bailleres, one of the photographers, noted that this growing city next to the world's most powerful economy presented plenty of troubling tableaux long before the advent of free trade.
The photo project is noteworthy, he said, because it was produced locally, by people who were working with the same handicaps and under the same hazardous conditions that confront all Juarez residents. The photographers, using ancient Pentax cameras, typically earned $50 to $80 a week, and risked their lives, alienating drug traffickers, gangs and the Mexican authorities. "It's like working in Bosnia," Mr. Bailleres said. TOM KUNTZ

HEADLINE: Double Vision;
Crime Falls, but Not on TV

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
CRIME reporting is such a staple of local television news coverage that is has acquired its own cliche: "If it bleeds, it leads." Whatever else might have happened, if someone is murdered, that story will lead the day's newscast.
So the continuing plunge in the nation's crime rates -- last week, New York City reported that homicides in the first half of this year were down about 30 percent from the same period in 1996 -- raises a question for television news directors: Are they now putting fewer crime stories on screen, too? 
 The answer seems to be no.
"The fact that percentages are down doesn't affect our coverage," said Bill Carey, news director at Channel 2 in New York, CBS's flagship station. "The communities who suffered and the families who suffered the crimes still want to know about them."
The real-estate salesman who was stabbed to death and dumped in a pond in Central Park, allegedly by a teen-age girl and boy; the dedicated teacher and son of Time Warner's chief executive who was slain, the police say, by a former student; the 7-year-old girl abducted on her way to school in Chinatown -- these murders would have been news no matter what.
 
Breaking the Habit
 But it isn't the dramatic cases that dominate crime coverage on local TV, said Joseph Angotti, a former senior vice president of NBC News who is now a professor of communications at the University of Miami, and who directed a study this year of the content of local news programs in eight cities. "Since journalism began, people have been infatuated with stories of big crimes, big trials. What's driving television news today is the ordinary, continuous kind of crime stories. It's a habit they've gotten into and it's difficult to break."
Mr. Angotti and his colleagues found that crime and criminal justice stories took up 29 percent of the average early-evening newscast in eight cities studied. Other studies in the last decade have found a similar proportion -- around one-third of the average local newscast.
"Most of that crime coverage is not editorially driven, it's economically driven," Mr. Angotti added. "It's the easiest, cheapest, laziest news to cover, because all they do is listen to the police radio, react to it, send out a mobile camera unit, spend an hour or two covering it and put it on the air."
Naturally, not all news directors agree. Many believe crime news matters to viewers. And some say their coverage has shifted as crime patterns have changed. Mr. Carey at Channel 2 says the ebbing of the city's crack-cocaine problem has changed the nature of crime reporting.
"When the drug epidemic was worse, in the late '80's here in the city, the violence was much worse and the ways people killed people were worse," he said. He mentioned schoolyard shootings, drug users killing innocent people for money and, in particular, the story of a cocaine-using woman who held her crying toddler over flames on the stove, giving the child such severe burns that he later died.
But to the average citizen, random crime is scarier than the drug-related crime that occurs most often in the poorest neighborhoods. The four local news directors interviewed said that even as they continue to put crime stories on the air, their coverage has changed to reflect the general belief that the city is safer.
 
The Giuliani Factor
 Publicity helps build that belief, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his supporters have repeatedly publicized the statistics.
"Giuliani is making that his mantra, so if we're covering the Mayor of the City of New York, it's hard not to hear it," said Marie Hickey, the news director at Channel 5, the Fox Broadcasting station. "And of course people applaud the fact that crime is down. We did a piece on that in early June, and found that people do believe it's down and do feel the city is safer."
Paula Walker, the news director at Channel 4, NBC's New York station, said recently that she has been trying to change the mindset in her newsroom. "When I challenge our people on beat checks," she said, referring to the daily phone calls made to check for news, "it's to ask, 'Why are we calling the cops? Why don't we call the schools? Why don't we call the hospitals?' Because if you're going to call around and find out whether anything's going on today and the only places you call are the police stations, what diet will you present but a diet of crime?"
That has been the diet presented by most local television station newscasts, however, especially in cities. Mr. Angotti said it may change -- again because of economics. "In at least three of the cities in our study," he said, "we found that the stations that were using the least amount of crime news were getting the highest ratings. So the theory that if you give people lots of blood-and-guts, that's what they'll watch is not necessarily true."
As Channel 4's Ms. Walker pointed out, in a big city there will always be plenty of crime. It is each station's choice how much of it is worth putting on the air -- and what to keep off as a result.
"Crime is always devastating to the victims, and I don't want to minimize that," she said. "But we have only a finite amount of time to present our news agenda. And most people in our tri-state area do not walk around every day expecting to be murdered."

HEADLINE: Tax Code;
The Secret Language Of Social Engineering

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NAME a social or economic problem. Maybe the tax code can fix it.
Think families these days are hard pressed? Give them a $500-per-child credit. 
 Want more people to attend at least two years of college? Create a credit to subsidize some of the cost.
Determined to address the nation's low savings rate? Expand the Individual Retirement Account to provide more tax incentives for long-term savings.
Eager to encourage entrepreneurs? Provide special breaks for investments in small businesses.
Unlike the two most recent big tax-cutting bills, in 1981 and 1986, the tax legislation now working its way through Washington does not include reductions in income tax rates. Although both parties have been proudly proclaiming the windfall they intend to bestow on voters, the $85 billion that Congress and the Administration have allocated for tax cuts over the next five years would finance only a tiny drop in income-tax rates.
So to get maximum bang for the buck, the leaders of both parties are instead concentrating the available money on a handful of other taxes and tax breaks. All of them appeal to at least one powerful constituency -- this year's favorites range from the religious right to Wall Street -- and all seek to support certain types of behavior or social goals.
Far from the ideal of a tax code designed solely to raise the revenue needed to finance the workings of Government, this year's legislation is just the latest evidence of how changes in the code frequently come down to dispensing favors under the guise of social and economic policy. Even modest attempts to focus the code more on revenue raising and less on distinguishing between classes of activity and income -- like the 1986 tax act -- are soon overwhelmed by the political imperative to respond to powerful constituencies who want better treatment.
"I view the tax code as a very poor place to do social engineering," said Iris J. Lav, the associate director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group in Washington, echoing what most conservative economists would say. "There's very scant evidence that the tax code has ever changed people's behavior. It's certainly a question of who has the loudest voice on tax policy."
Certainly, tax policy plays only a limited role in the economic decisions that most people make. People choose to invest or buy a home or send their children to college for all kinds of reasons unrelated to a line on their form 1040. But even where the tax code provides a direct incentive, its impact is unclear.
 
Saving, More or Less
 Both the House and the Senate bills propose sweeping expansions of the Individual Retirement Account, which is popular with banks, investment firms and middle and upper-income taxpayers who have money to save. Although some economists argue otherwise, Ms. Lav cited studies concluding that I.R.A.'s have done little or nothing to increase the savings rate, in part because decisions about saving may be more complex than they appear. Since many savers set specific goals, an increase in the after-tax yield that the I.R.A. advantage creates lets them save less than they would otherwise to reach the same goal -- not exactly what proponents of savings incentives have in mind.
But Ms. Lav acknowledged her own strong support on both economic or social grounds for programs like the earned income tax credit, which reduces taxes for low-income workers to encourage them to work rather than to go on welfare. So what seems unwarranted social engineering or interest-group pandering by one ideological camp is often seen as a worthy cause -- and a justified exception -- by the other.
Steve Forbes, who ran for the Republican Presidential nomination last year on a platform of replacing the current tax system with a single flat rate, issued a memo last week characterizing the emerging tax plan, although largely the work of Republicans, as "Big Brother Clinton knows best."
 
The Pathetic Reward
 "If your family does exactly what he wants you to do, when he wants you to do it, where he wants you to do it," Mr. Forbes said, "then you might get a pathetically small little break on your Federal taxes."
But by Mr. Forbes's standard few Congressional Republicans could claim to be pure. Speaker Newt Gingrich pushed into the House tax bill detailed provisions designed to attract investment, jobs and new residents to the District of Columbia. Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee rails against the complexities and inequities of the tax code, still champions narrow provisions, including a permanent extension of a tax credit to encourage pharmaceutical companies to do research on treatments for obscure diseases. And most Republicans have wholeheartedly embraced the religious right's argument that the proposed child credit will strengthen families, even while admitting that the credit will do nothing to strengthen the economy.
There is another reason politicians choose the tax code to pursue policy objectives. In this age of fiscal austerity, new spending programs are a tough sell in Congress. But if the same initiatives are dressed up as tax cuts they look much more palatable.
"One looks like smaller government," said C. Eugene Steuerle, a tax expert at the Urban Institute in Washington. "One looks like bigger government. In fact, they both do exactly the same thing."
 
Mortarboard Credit
 Take President Clinton's effort to encourage more high school students to go on to college. He has already won additional financing for Federal tuition grants for low-income students, and although he no doubt could have designed a spending program to make college more affordable for many middle-class students as well, he would have got little support in the Republican Congress.
As a $35 billion tax cut, however, Mr. Clinton's proposal to give credits of up to $1,500 for the first two years of college is almost certain to be enacted at least partially. Never mind that analysts doubt that the credit will inspire students who would otherwise be content with a high school diploma to enroll in college. Indeed, some analysts assert that the plan's main effect would be to increase tuition inflation.
Yet for all the uncertainty about what effects on behavior the tax bill will have, there is one outcome that is beyond doubt: In its efforts to make the tax code do more things for more people, Washington is again putting aside its promises of simplification and making the system more complex.
