HEADLINE: No Great Shakes;
A Ritual Loses Its Grip

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
HANDSHAKES are part of history's greatest hits: Arafat and Rabin at the White House in 1993; Nixon thrusting out his hand to Zhou Enlai in Beijing in 1972. They are a big reason the airline industry does not feel threatened by the rise of videoconferencing: "You can't fax a handshake" is a popular saying at many companies.
And as American-style capitalism sweeps through distant countries, more people are shaking hands, according to Roger E. Axtell, editor of a series of "Do's and Taboos" books about body language around the world. In the United States, he added, even more women are joining in the ritual. 
 But think again before you reach out and glad-hand. The handshake, as natural an act as walking upright, is being shaken itself, devalued as a symbol of trustworthiness and denounced as a health threat at the same time that technology holds the promise of upgrading it for new uses.
By most accounts, handshakes started as a way to show that neither person was holding a weapon. Desmond Morris, the anthropologist, calls the handshake a "tie-sign" because of the bond it creates. Through the centuries, the growing use of the handshake reflected greater equality among individuals, and it was used to seal agreements. The handshake became a friendly greeting, a sign of respect, a bet that new faces would be remembered.
But now, if you want to show someone respect, perhaps you should consider not shaking hands. That was the lesson Alonzo Mourning, the star center for the Miami Heat, tried to draw in May from the fifth game of the Eastern Conference finals of the National Basketball Association, when Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls refused to shake his outstretched hand.
 
Respectfully Declined
 After the game, with the Heat eliminated, Mr. Mourning said Mr. Jordan's reaction flattered him. "It makes me think we got their respect," he said. (Athletic-shoe makers are no doubt fighting over rights to a new marketing slogan: "No Handshakes.")
Others interpreted Mr. Jordan's refusal more traditionally. The Bulls had criticized Mr. Mourning for dirty play throughout the playoffs.
The handshake after a game has long been a tradition in youth leagues, but it no longer moves kids to lay down grudges and hard feelings. Coaches say players often spit in their hands before congratulating opponents. In January, a fight broke out in a handshake line after a junior hockey game in Rhode Island.
At the French Open this year, Thomas Muster was so incensed by the antics of Jeff Tarango across the tennis court that he broke with tradition and refused to shake Mr. Tarango's outstretched hand after beating him.
Even the "golden handshake" appears to be suffering from deflation. In British Columbia, Canada, the provincial government is considering a rule to limit lump-sum severance payments to 24 months' pay for executives ousted from government-run companies and agencies. A former president of a government-run utility, for example, was found to be taking home $25,000 a month three years after he left.
Moreover, handshakes can be bad for your health. The Massachusetts Medical Society recently started an advertising campaign that encourages people to wash their hands more often, pointing out in one radio spot that "any friendly handshake can carry many illnesses."
Robert E. Swindle, a retired business professor in Peoria, Ariz., wants to abolish handshaking altogether. After all, now that most people don't carry concealed weapons in their hands, the ritual has lost its usefulness, he said. Mr. Swindle is also concerned about how quickly germs spread through handshakes, particularly in settings like doctor's offices and hospitals.
"I saw a cardiologist recently, and he shook hands with me three times," he said. When Mr. Swindle does not want to shake hands, he smooths out an uncomfortable moment by saying that he cannot because of a finger he fractured playing basketball.
But if Mr. Swindle got his way, something would clearly be lost in society. Allen Konopacki, who runs a sales training company in Chicago called the Incomm Center, tried an experiment last year to better understand the handshake effect. He and a group of students left a quarter in a public phone, and after strangers used the phone and took the coin, a student walked up to ask if they had seen the quarter. Of the roughly 75 people he tried this on, well over half lied, saying that they had not seen the 25 cents that they had pocketed.
Mr. Konopacki and his students then tried the experiment with 75 more strangers, but this time the student greeted the person with a quick handshake and introduction. Only 14 of the 75 lied.
"A handshake," Mr. Konopacki said, "creates a higher level of trust, a degree of intimacy, within a matter of seconds."
 
Hanging On
 Politicians who grab every hand they can on the campaign trail clearly believe this to be true. But the handshake is also a way for the masses to get some quality face time. When Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada was glad-handing in May at a campaign rally in Edmonton, Alberta, one man refused to let go as he yelled in Mr. Chretien's face about his decision to call an election at a time when flooding had caused a crisis in the West.
I.B.M. is perhaps the most ambitious of the lot in trying to find new uses for the handshake. Big Blue created a small stir at the annual consumer electronics trade show in January with a prototype of its Personal Area Network, or PAN.
Though it won't be available for a while, the company says it has the technology to transmit data -- like a digitized business card -- between two people with just a handshake. The PAN device, about the size of a thick credit card so it can be carried in a pocket, creates a low-power external electronic field using the natural salinity of the human body that can transmit data to, and receive data from, someone else with a PAN device. The stored information can be viewed later with a computer.
Some sociologists say the apparent drop in the traditional value of a handshake reflects a general decline of loyalty in American society to institutions like marriage and between employers and their workers.
But Alan Wolfe, a sociologist at Boston University, disagreed. He said that while the handshake has been devalued by those in the media spotlight, the gesture carries just as much weight as it always has among most people because so many face-to-face encounters have been replaced by phones, faxes and E-mail.
"The handshake is really reserved for special moments," he said.
And you never know when such moments might arise. In January, a small group of men were moved to shake the hands of staff members in a bank in central Italy. It was, after all, a special time for everyone involved. The men were about to leave, having just finished robbing the bank.

HEADLINE: From Dapper Don to Dirty Chin

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
IT has come to this. In a city accustomed to the very best in mob trials and to state-of-the-art gangland kingpins, the people must make do with Vincent Gigante, otherwise known as Chin.
It's a sorry spectacle for connoisseurs of crime. In a Brooklyn courtroom, the man painted by Federal prosecutors as the head of the Genovese crime family looks as though he could not find his way down the aisle of a Genovese drug store. The mob overlord who, according to prosecutors, ran an empire and ordered the killings of six gangland rivals, sits in court day after day staring vacantly, moving his lips in a silent, one-way conversation and occasionally dozing off. 
 Mr. Gigante may or may not be guilty of the multitude of crimes with which he has been charged, but he is certainly guilty of letting standards slip.
The double-breasted suits, bright ties and razor-sharp collars of a bygone age have given way to pajamas and a bathrobe, Chin's familiar strolling attire in his Greenwich Village neighborhood. When the judge ordered Mr. Gigante, wearing an open sport shirt over a dirty T-shirt, to make a better appearance in court, his lawyer countered that Mr. Gigante did not own a suit.
And the nickname is not good. It speaks volumes about the failing culture of organized crime that "Chin" is probably just short for Vincenzo. Americans like their gangsters gaudy and grand. Mr. Gigante does not seem prepared to step into the role.
John Gotti performed the role magnificently, but he's beginning to look like the flashy finale in a show that's been running too long. "John Gotti was exceptional," said Peter Maas, the author of "Underboss: Sammy the Bull Gravano's Story of Life in the Mafia." "The media loved him, and he loved the media. He looked like what America wanted a gangster to look like."
Al Capone set the standard. A snappy dresser, he held sway over Chicago at a time when criminals, like Hollywood stars, fully understood their obligations to the public. He played to a much broader audience than his own heavily muscled constituency. He dealt death to his enemies but also set up soup kitchens for the unemployed. And his nickname, Scarface, couldn't be beat.
The film industry jumped in quickly, putting a high gloss on the image of the gangster. It hit paydirt with "Little Caesar," in which Edward G. Robinson laid down the basic rules for proper mob-boss demeanor. He was cocky, cruel and vain. In one magnificent leap, Robinson's Rico distanced himself from the mongrel pack of two-time hoods, sadists and bootleg barons that had defined the criminal upper class in Hollywood films until then. "He was rough around the edges, but he had charisma, he was commanding," said Bruce Goldstein, the repertory programmer at the Film Forum. "The Paul Muni character in 'Scarface' was just a thug."
The capo di tutti capi, of course, was Marlon Brando in "The Godfather," a kind of industrial training film for would-be mob bosses. Well before Lee Iacocca, Donald Trump or Bill Gates arrived on the scene with big books about big bucks, Vito Corleone satisfied a growing American appetite for business heroes, guys who made big companies run. Among other things, "The Godfather" was an incisive case study of a well-run corporation, exactly the kind of story that would later fit right into "In Pursuit of Excellence."
It's been downhill ever since. The romantic view of organized crime in "The Godfather" has given way to more jaundiced films. The wiseguys in "Goodfellas" spend as much time chopping garlic as they do stuffing bodies in trunks. "Since 'The Godfather,' films have dealt with the subject in a more down-to-earth way," said Kent Jones, the film archivist for Martin Scorsese. "In Abel Ferrara's last film, 'The Funeral,' you have guys from Yonkers whose idea of Mecca is the Bronx."
Anticipating the headlines, film makers have gravitated toward darkly humorous stories in which small-time hoods wage inept battles for ever-smaller stakes. Mr. Gotti brought back a whiff of the old days, when the many-roomed mansion of organized crime was so capacious that there was even room for Jewish and Irish gangsters. The murder of Paul Castellano outside Sparks Steak House in 1985 stirred old memories of half-forgotten names that fall like music on the ear: Joe Valachi, Frank Costello, Lucky Luciano, Joe Bonnano, Albert Anastasia. These were giants.
And now, there is Chin.
The trial continues, but as it limps toward the end, it's hard not to believe that the glory days have long since passed. "Sammy met him three or four times," Mr. Maas said, "and he said Gigante's hands were not just dirty, they were caked, like you see on homeless people in the street." From the Dapper Don to the Disoriented Don in just a few years.
Mother of Mercy, is this the end of Rico?

HEADLINE: Essay;
Let's See if the System Still Works

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"No fund-raising calls or mail," warned White House Counsel Abner Mikva in 1995, "may emanate from the White House or any other Federal building."
That's the law. But money-hungry Bill Clinton soon replaced Mikva, a former Federal judge, with Jack (Tell 'em Nuthin') Quinn, less concerned with legal niceties. 
 "The POTUS [President of the United States] and VP," e-mailed aide Karen Hancox in that law-breaking year, "offered ON THEIR OWN to make f r [fund-raising] calls for the DNC."
A few months ago, after Al Gore dismayed his own supporters by claiming "no controlling authority" stopped him from soliciting money from his Federal desk, the President pretended he could not recall doing anything similar.
Now, on the eve of the Senate's Thompson committee hearings, the truth is seeping out: Clinton personally leaned on 15 to 20 fat cats, often from his Oval Office phone, for at least $500,000 -- including one call urged by Vernon Jordan to shake $100,000 out of a Maryland businessman.
Both Clinton and Jordan are lawyers. They know the law against soliciting on Federal property. They were reminded of that law by the unwelcome Judge Mikva. Perhaps they were confident that Janet Reno, acting as a one-woman Supreme Court, would choose not to enforce that law.
But they surely knew how repugnant the American people would find the spectacle of their President, in the Oval Office, personally wheedling money out of wealthy citizens, with all the intimidation that such a "request" carries. That's why the Clinton memory turned so fuzzy for months.
Why are White House memories of the law-breaking suddenly coming clear? Because the Thompson committee has listed Ms. Hancox on its list of witnesses this week. White House Spin Control leaked the story on the eve of a holiday weekend, amid Mars landings and Paula Jones denunciations, hoping to detract from the newsworthiness of the televised hearings.
Another unfamiliar name on the witness list for the following week is Paul Buskirk, a trade official who deals with a classified computer network. That suggests to me that senators will be looking into John Huang's access to secret government cables. Huang was Lippo's man at Commerce, later reassigned by Clinton himself to raise money from those he serviced.
Only Asia-connection buffs know of Huang's 37 sessions with his personal C.I.A. briefer, accompanied by calls from his Commerce phone to his former Indonesian bosses and an unexplained visit to the Chinese embassy. Fewer still know of Huang's use of the Washington office of Stevens Inc., the investment bank so close to the Clintons in the past, for calls and faxes to Canada and overseas.
But now a wider audience assembles. Will the hearings reveal Huang to be an agent of influence, with the Clinton White House penetrated by a Chinese-Indonesian economic espionage operation? No; but perhaps its findings will force the appointment of an independent counsel still being resisted by Clinton Justice. The Senate's primary job is not to show "everybody did it," but to expose to public view the unprecedented pattern of corrupt fund-raising that sullied the highest office in the land.
I hope Huang is required to take the Fifth in person, along with all the others delaying or obstructing this investigation. I hope senators discover why our State Department is not trying to bring Yah Lin (Charlie) Trie -- so available to Tom Brokaw and to other interviewers in Shanghai -- home for questioning under oath.
Wang Jun, the Chinese arms dealer helping Iran obtain missiles to menace our ships in the Persian Gulf, recently told an American friend that he gave $50,000 to Charlie and thereby met Clinton in the White House. No wonder State and Justice don't want Trie questioned under oath.
One witness that Democrats will try desperately to protect is Bruce Lindsey, the newly unprivileged White House lawyer who bridges the fund-raising and Whitewater scandals.
He was present at Clinton's infamous Sept. 13, 1995, "reassignment" of Huang. And when asked by the Senate last year if he was aware of Clinton Administration efforts to steer work to Webster Hubbell, Lindsey swore "No." Let's see him slip out of those. (Hubbell, steered $100,000 from Lippo alone, now faces a threat of re-indictment for "hush money.")
The Fourth of July is behind us; let the quiet fireworks begin.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 8; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 810 words

HEADLINE: Momentous Days in Madrid

 BODY:
Bill Clinton heads to Madrid this week to construct the foreign policy centerpiece of his Presidency, the eastward expansion of NATO. The United States has initiated no more fateful enterprise since the end of the cold war, yet it has done so largely without public discussion. With NATO planning to issue invitations to three new members in Madrid, a national debate can no longer wait.
Twenty senators, representing both parties, did their best to start one last week. In a thoughtful, deceptively mild letter to Mr. Clinton, the lawmakers identified many of the questions about NATO expansion that Americans ought to consider before committing their soldiers and nuclear weapons to the defense of Warsaw, Prague and Budapest. The letter attracted little public attention, but was closely read by Administration officials looking for some early indication whether a two-thirds majority in the Senate can be assembled in 1998 to approve NATO expansion. 
 It is too soon to know, but the 20 senators, led by Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas, served notice that cornerstone elements of the NATO plan look badly conceived and that the Administration has so far done a dismal job of explaining and justifying the decisions that will be taken in Madrid. A stronger letter was sent to Mr. Clinton last month by some 40 Americans with European expertise, including former Senators Sam Nunn and Bill Bradley.
Tinkering with the map of Europe is not something to be done lightly. Two world wars started on the Continent this century and it was the primary battlefield of the cold war. Europe today is largely at peace and the great threat to democracy, the Soviet Union, vanished in 1991. If the map is to be redrawn, the reasons must be overwhelming and the potential consequences beyond doubt. NATO expansion does not now meet those tests.
The Hutchison group, for instance, would like to know what military threat NATO expansion is intended to counter, now that the Russian threat has receded. The senators, including conservative Republican Jesse Helms and liberal Democrat Paul Wellstone, wonder whether potential armed border disputes among new NATO members would warrant the use of American forces, as provided under NATO security guarantees. They are also concerned that NATO growth might jeopardize Russian approval of current and future agreements to cut nuclear arsenals.
Two important issues cited by the senators flared up even before Madrid. One is that NATO enlargement may divide Europe into two classes of nations, those admitted to the alliance and those excluded. Even promises of future consideration for countries like Romania, Slovenia, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia would leave them on the sidelines politically, militarily and economically. That may well turn into one of the most damaging consequences of expansion.
The answer is not to admit every applicant now. Even proponents of expansion recognize that doing so would overwhelm and weaken NATO. That leaves Washington and its allies skirmishing over the pace of expansion. A showdown was barely avoided in Madrid when France last week withdrew its insistence that Romania be offered membership immediately. This issue will continue to be a source of corrosive friction within the alliance.
The other immediate concern is the financial cost of expansion and how it should be apportioned among NATO members. The Clinton Administration, not surprisingly, has calculated a relatively modest $35 billion price tag spread over 13 years to modernize the military forces of new member states. Washington's share would be roughly $2 billion, or 6 percent. Other estimates run much higher, up to a total cost of $125 billion, with Washington paying $19 billion, or 15 percent. Senator Hutchison and her colleagues legitimately ask how the White House can be so certain Washington will ultimately cover just a fraction of the bill.
Hanging over the whole expansion plan is the potential adverse impact on Russia as it moves painfully toward democracy and free markets. Helping Russia complete that transition should be the primary objective of American policy today. NATO expansion, though grudgingly accepted by President Boris Yeltsin, seems likely over time to embolden Russia's anti-democratic forces. The first time NATO rejects Moscow's advice at a new consultative council set up to ease the concerns of Mr. Yeltsin, his accommodation with the alliance is certain to come under withering attack at home.
Given the absence of a clear threat to Europe and the possibility of so many unpredictable consequences, NATO expansion seems a gratuitous risk. If Mr. Clinton is determined to make it happen, he has an obligation to tell the American people why he is so sure it will not undermine stability in Europe and lead to a waste of American resources. He can begin in Madrid.

HEADLINE: For Now, Few Are Going From Food Stamps to Soup Kitchens

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE

 BODY:
When word spread that hundreds of unemployed, able-bodied adults would soon lose food stamps, this city's advocates took to the streets. They taped warnings on grocery store windows. They pinned fliers on community bulletin boards. And then the soup kitchens braced for the deluge of the hungry.
It never happened. 
 More than 500 people have vanished from the food stamp rolls since March, when Syracuse became one of the first cities in New York to deny those benefits to childless, able-bodied adults who fail to find work. But only a handful responded to the offer for help.
"We were thinking, 'Oh, my God, all these people will be coming,' " said Mary Anne Ruff, director of emergency services at the Salvation Army, "but to be honest, we just have not seen them." Ms. Ruff is still waiting for her telephone lines to burn and for lines of the needy to snake outside her food pantry's door.
More than 2,000 of New York's poorest people, those without income, jobs or public assistance, have lost food stamps for failing to find work. Under the new law, recipients are cut off after three months if they do not work at least 20 hours a week or participate in a workfare program. But to the surprise of county officials and advocates for the poor, they appear to be relying far more heavily on family, friends and low-wage, irregular jobs than on soup kitchens and homeless shelters.
They are the first public aid recipients in New York to hit time limits under the Federal welfare law. And supporters of welfare changes say their experiences prove that people will survive, and perhaps even benefit, after the safety net disappears.
Advocates for the poor say these people are just getting by, finding jobs that are quickly lost and leaning on relatives who can barely fill their own refrigerators. But even they acknowledge that the stories emerging from former food stamp recipients are tales of struggle, but also of survival.
Michael Manney, 30, illiterate and long unemployed, now shares his girlfriend's groceries and scrubs dishes for minimum wage at a Red Lobster restaurant in Glens Falls, a river town near Albany.
Theodore Clark, 36 and learning disabled, dined nightly in his retired mother's kitchen before reluctantly joining the workfare program in Fulton, just north of Syracuse.
And Cyrena Vance, 32, who had already been working off the books as a home health aide, took on another elderly client after she lost her food stamps.
"I don't need to bother with food stamps anymore," said Ms. Vance, who also receives help from her fiance.
Unexpectedly, these stories are emerging from cities with job shortages. Thirty-eight counties, including those in New York City, were granted Federal waivers to continue food stamps until November to able-bodied adults, those single men and women between the ages of 18 and 50 who lack physical or mental impairments that might prevent them from working.
But 18 of those counties, most of them upstate, like Warren County, which includes Glens Falls, and Onondaga County, which includes Syracuse, quietly refused the waivers. Saying they had enough workfare slots to place people who failed to find private-sector jobs, county executives sent hundreds of letters warning that benefits would soon be cut.
Over and over, the county officials encountered the same response: silence. Most people never responded to offers of workfare placements and simply disappeared once their food stamps were cut.
"We sent letters to 200 people asking them if they wanted a work slot and 30 showed," said Ted Mohr, the Commissioner of Social Services in Oneida County, whose office has cut food stamps to about 150 people.
But advocates for the poor and academics who have studied the impact of benefit loss in other states caution that while the anticipated chaos has so far failed to emerge, so have stable, long-term solutions for many people struggling to build new lives in the post-welfare world.
State officials estimate that about 17,000 able-bodied food stamp recipients will ultimately lose benefits for failing to meet the 20-hour-a-week work requirement. The vast majority live in New York City, where higher unemployment rates may make suffering more acute.
They are mostly men without high school diplomas who have received food stamps for less than a year. But many are illiterate, abuse drugs or alcohol and struggle to find permanent work.
"They are often street people who were living on the margins anyway," said Barbara Weiner, a lawyer with the Greater Upstate Law Project, an advocacy group that tracks changes in welfare rules. "We won't necessarily see them starving in the streets, but that doesn't mean everyone is happy and working. Their lives are more desperate."
Sandra K. Danzinger, an associate professor of social work at the University of Michigan, agreed.
"People turn to whatever limited and precarious personal resources they have and hold on as long as they can," said Ms. Danzinger, who has studied the elimination of Michigan's welfare program for able-bodied adults. "But friends and family absorb that impact at a cost that is kind of hard to measure."
In Glens Falls, Laureen Colbert, 40, prays every morning that her boyfriend, Mr. Manney, will keep his job. It is her only hope, she says, of staying afloat.
When Mr. Manney lost his $120 monthly allotment of food stamps in March, the couple survived on Ms. Colbert's disability check and food stamps. But at the end of every month, they found themselves living on spaghetti and Cup-a-Soup, unable to afford even milk or cereal.
In June, after months of resisting his girlfriend's entreaties to find work, Mr. Manney finally found the job washing dishes at Red Lobster.
In Fulton, Joan Clark fed her son, Theodore, and his wife, Cheryl, for three months in her sagging wooden house. Mr. Clark, who works as a school crossing guard 10 hours a week, refused to find another job to supplement his income.
"I already got a job," insisted Mr. Clark, who is illiterate and learning disabled. "I ain't going to kill myself for no food stamps."
He is a big man, who lost a full-time job as a janitor two years ago and never bothered to find another one. He cannot read the help-wanted ads in the newspaper or fill out a job application. And his confused blue eyes wander when his mother tries to explain the new welfare law.
"I wouldn't never let them go hungry," said Joan Clark, who helped support the couple with her disability check. "But we're lucky if we can afford a sandwich at Wendy's."
Two weeks ago, after enduring relentless pressure from his wife and his mother, Mr. Clark reluctantly agreed to join the local workfare program to help out. "I have to do what I have to do," he said.
In Glens Falls, Gerald Sutton, a 39-year-old recovering crack addict teetering on the brink of homelessness, is scraping by with the help of friends and the local food pantry.
He measures time not in the hours ticking away on his wristwatch, but in the slices of bread left in his cupboard and in the dwindling number of coins in his pockets.
Despite the hardship, he says he believes that food stamp recipients should work for their benefits.
"I got interviews at Wal-Mart, the hospital and the amusement park," said Mr. Sutton, a lanky, bald man wearing good-as-new slacks he dug from a thrift-store barrel. "That's the way it should be. You don't get something for nothing in this world."

HEADLINE: Clinton Credits Law For a Steep Decline In U.S. Welfare Rolls

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5,

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that more than a million people had left public assistance rolls since last August, a figure he offered as proof that the tough new welfare measure he signed was working.
In his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton said welfare caseloads fell by 3.1 million people between January 1993 -- when he took office -- and April of this year. In April, he said, there were 11 million people on welfare, or about 4 percent of the population, the lowest share since 1970. 
"All Americans should be very happy that three million of our fellow citizens are now off welfare rolls," Mr. Clinton said. "Let us redouble our determination to give more and more of our fellow citizens their own personal independence day."
Last August, the President signed a welfare measure that imposed a lifetime limit of five years for receiving welfare and gave the states control of Federal cash assistance and food stamps. The law, which took effect in all 50 states in July, ended the 60-year-old system of unlimited, direct assistance to the poor.
A report released in May by the White House Council of Economic Advisers attributed the drop in welfare rolls to three factors: strong economic growth, waivers that allowed states to experiment with welfare reform plans and Administration policies such as an expansion of the earned income tax credit, toughened child support enforcement and increased financing for child care.

HEADLINE: Narvon Journal;
Rustic Life Of Amish Is Changing But Slowly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: NARVON, Pa.

 BODY:
The horse carriages still ply the hilly roads of Lancaster County, a black top indicating a Mennonite driver and a gray top an Amish one.
But they are not traveling to and from farms so much anymore, as they have through decades in a style of life resistant to the march of technology and urban confusion. These days, the drivers are just as likely to be headed for a bakery, a clothing store, a handicraft shop or even a cement factory -- sure testimony that a revered and resolute way of life is changing ever so slowly. 
 "And it continues to happen," said Moses B. Smucker, 46, an Amish man whose life as owner of Smucker's Harness Shop Inc. seems to symbolize the evolution. "It's pretty simple. There is not enough land needed to farm. People are making other choices.
"I don't consider it a negative. Some do. But I don't."
Amish and Mennonite families make up 36,000 of the 435,000 people in Lancaster County. For generations, the traditional among them have clung to the land for their values and livelihoods, resisting the temptations and conveniences of the outside world. Theirs has always been a rustic life of hard work, plain clothes, horse-drawn plows and no electricity.
But their style of life has made them a curiosity to outsiders, and the curiosity has grown into a tourist industry, attracting up to five million visitors a year. Lancaster County towns like Intercourse and Bird in Hand, once dots on the map where carriage drivers met to talk quietly, are now vacation destinations.
Main streets are flecked with bed-and-breakfasts and boutiques that sell Amish and Mennonite wares. Many stores are open on Sundays, a practice once unheard of here.
New industry has also found the area, drawn by a culture, fostered by the Amish and Mennonites, of hard work and dependability. As one of the faster-growing regions in Pennsylvania, with a population surge of nearly 6 percent from 1990 to 1995, Lancaster County is now home to 10,000 businesses, including giants like the Kellogg Company, Tyson Foods Inc. and the R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, which have all built factories.
The county unemployment rate, 2.6 percent, is well below the national average of 5 percent, and residential subdivisions are flourishing.
But the combination of tourism and commercial success is fundamentally changing the sociological fabric of the Amish and Mennonite communities, which share the same Christian beliefs but differ in how they practice them. The Amish are generally more conservative.
New residents have driven up property values, and Amish and Mennonite families, which tend to be large, often with six or more children, are struggling to find enough farmland for all to make a living.
Many offspring stay, working family acreage for corn, tobacco, grains and other crops, and many others are leaving to find cheaper land elsewhere. But a growing percentage of Amish and Mennonites are abandoning the farms to pursue their own entrepreneurial instincts or jobs with new businesses that their communities spurred.
Mr. Smucker grew up on his family's 40-acre farm just north of here, in Churchtown. His father began making harnesses for horses as a side business in 1962. But eight years later, he was killed when a truck in which he was a passenger was in an accident, and the farm was sold.
Like thousands of young Amish, Moses Smucker worked the fields, but once the farm passed out of the immediate family, his interest waned. "I wanted to be in business," he said, so he concentrated on harness making.
Today, Smucker's Harness Shop on Route 23, amid dozens of small farms, stands as thriving evidence to his fortitude and the increasing diversity of Amish and Mennonite people. Generating millions of dollars a year in revenue, the shop has become a world-renowned source of hand-crafted carriages, bridles and other horse-related products.
"Our whole industry buys here," said Paul McDade of Border Carriages in New York City, a company that operates horse-drawn carriages in Central Park. He and two friends had just bought new bridles.
About half of the 24 employees at Smucker's are Amish. They make many of the products, some of which cost thousands of dollars. And like other Amish and Mennonite people, they are adjusting to a life apart from the farm, once an anchor for their traditions and values.
"More and more, we're becoming business people," Mr. Smucker said. "And I'm not so sure our leaders, the ministers and bishops, know how to deal with it. They're getting the hang of it. But they're still uncomfortable with it."
It is not only financial pressures that are changing the Amish and Mennonites. With increasing commercial development around them, their communities are also being pushed closer to the technologies and leisure activities that most Americans take for granted.
Outside a small food market in Leola, an Amish boy passed by on Rollerblades, his traditional black boots in hand.
Some businesses owned by Amish and Mennonites have begun advertising. "It's unbelievable what's happening," Mr. Smucker said. "We're now using color advertising in our catalogues. When we first started, all we did was open the front door."
Mr. Smucker, who said he would like to leave his business to his children -- three daughters and two sons -- has his eye on a new pursuit. He wants to be a full-time auctioneer, something he now dabbles in.
On a recent Saturday in New Holland, hundreds of items were being offered for bids, including dozens of expensive horse carriages. As Mr. Smucker was preparing for the sale, he hurt his toe, which required an ice pack and a bandage.
To carry on, he climbed into a golf cart and drove around the grounds. Resting in the small console that would otherwise hold golf balls and tees was a cellular telephone.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the land of the Amish and Mennonites in Pennsylvania, boys still use the traditional black boots, but there are many signs of modern life. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)
 
Map showing the location of Narvon, Pa.: In Narvon, Pa., Amish and Mennonites are confronting the future.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Cardinals Rise in the N.L. Central on the Wings of Their Pitchers

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
So, what took them so long?
 The St. Louis Cardinals needed nearly a month more of this season than last to arrive in first place in the National League Central. Everyone sort of knew they were the team to beat, but that's what was happening to them the first three months of the season -- most everyone was beating them.
On July 1, the Cardinals reclaimed the position that was theirs on the last day of last season. The next day, they reached .500. for the first time. 
 "I just hope it lasts," said Walt Jocketty, the team's general manager, thankful for any sign of pennant-race stability. "I've been kind of waiting to get to .500. I think this club is capable of taking off."
But since the Cardinals finally reached the elusive .500 plateau, they have lost three successive games to the shockingly competitive Pittsburgh Pirates and have tumbled back into second place behind the Pirates. That is not what Jocketty and Manager Tony La Russa had in mind.
"We're still not scoring a lot of runs, but we're playing a little bit better," Jocketty said. "We're still waiting for the offense to take off. If we had the offense of Colorado or Cleveland, we'd have quite a club."
That the Cardinals have reached the top again is not an achievement strictly of their own doing. They have had plenty of help from the other teams in the division, particularly the Houston Astros. Before the teams had played a full month, Houston led the Cardinals by six and a half games, but the Astros were unable to maintain their strong start. The Pirates joined them at the top of the division, and both looked as if they were keeping the spot warm for the Cardinals.
If first place was the Cardinals' inevitable destination, responsibility fell on their pitchers to get them there.
"Our pitching continues to be the strongest part of our club," Jocketty said. "It starts with the pitching coach, Dave Duncan. He's done an outstanding job molding this staff to his own personality -- hard working, diligent in going about their business. They kept us in the race until the offense could come around."
The starting rotation of the Benes brothers, Andy and Alan; Todd Stottlemyre; Matt Morris, and, when healthy, Donovan Osborne, is as strong as any rotation, the general manager said. Osborne has missed two months because of a groin pull but is expected back late this month.
The pitching staff is ranked No. 2 in the N.L. Only Atlanta's 3.11 earned run average is better than the Cardinals' 3.36. The Cardinals have also allowed the second fewest home runs and are second in strikeouts. In addition, the Cardinals have an ageless closer. On Friday, Dennis Eckersley, 42, squandered only his third save in 21 chances.
The team's hitters, on the other hand, have not placed the Cardinals among the league's run-scoring leaders. But right fielder John Mabry and first baseman Dmitri Young have picked up in recent weeks, and Delino DeShields has made Jocketty's decision to sign him as a free agent look good. After three mediocre-to-poor seasons in Los Angeles, DeShields has returned to the hitting level he achieved earlier with Montreal.
"He's developing into the catalyst at the top of the order we hoped he would be when we signed him," Jocketty said.
The negatives for the Cardinals as they look to the second half of the season are catcher Tom Pagnozzi and Brian Jordan, the regular right fielder. Pagnozzi, afflicted with a groin injury, has played only four games. Jordan is on the disabled list for the second time with a bulging disk in his back and may miss the rest of the season.
"He sat out six weeks, came back and still wasn't right," Jocketty said. "At this point it doesn't require surgery, but it is something that's a constant irritant and affects his swing and the way he plays the game."
 
New York, New York: No Draw
 The Mets' three-game interleague series in Detroit drew the smallest attendance for a three-game interleague series. In fact, adding in the two-game series played by West teams, only the series between San Diego and Oakland attracted fewer fans.
While the Mets' visit to Detroit drew 46,060, the Yankees' three-game series there a week earlier attracted 45,776. Must be something about New York.
 
Disappearing Acts
 When Clyde King, then the Yankees' general manager, was able to trade Ed Whitson to San Diego in 1986, it was considered one of the greatest acts of prestidigitation of all time. The trade of Kenny Rogers and his $5 million-a-year contract to the Padres did not rank with the move that made Whitson disappear, but it was impressive even so -- while it lasted. It seems unlikely that the Yankees, now that the trade has been canceled because Greg Vaughn has a shoulder problem, can turn around and do it again, but the story behind the trade with the Padres remains intriguing.
Tony Attanasio is an agent who was desperately trying to liberate a client, Mariano Duncan, from the Yankees. The San Francisco Giants were interested in the utilityman, who had become the No. 1 resident in George Steinbrenner's doghouse.
Attanasio, given the authority to try to make a deal for Duncan, was talking with Bob Watson, the Yankees' general manager, early last week and told him that the Giants were more interested in a pitcher than Duncan, but would consider accepting a package including the two players.
Would they take Rogers? Watson asked. No, he was told, Rogers makes too much money for the Giants and, anyway, they were interested in Dwight Gooden. But, Attanasio told Watson, if you want to put Rogers and Duncan together and would be interested in Vaughn, the Padres may go for that deal. They did. As difficult a season and a half as Rogers spent with the Yankees, no player had ever been treated the way Duncan was. Steinbrenner has tried to dictate lineup changes throughout his 25-year ownership reign of error, but never has a manager so blatantly capitulated to the owner's dictates as Joe Torre did on Duncan.
Steinbrenner declared Duncan no longer the Yankee second baseman, and Torre then rendered him virtually invisible. Steinbrenner has occasionally had short-term success with his lineup declarations, but nothing that approached the Duncan affair.
 In 1986, the owner told Lou Piniella not to play Dave Winfield against certain right-handers, but Piniella said, "If I keep doing this, I'm going to lose everyone else on the team because everyone will know who's making out the lineup." He told Steinbrenner that if he wanted to write the lineup, he could get someone else to manage.
 
Show Henderson the Money
 Rickey Henderson entered June with a .164 batting average and the distinct appearance of a veteran player who would be better off beginning the rest of his life. A calf injury, the Padres' crowded outfield and his inability to hit kept Henderson's plate appearances to a minimum.
But Henderson's performance the past month showed that he is not ready to retire and that he should be the Padres' regular left fielder again. His performance also made it easier for the Padres to trade Greg Vaughn. Since languishing at .164, Henderson has 37 hits in 106 at-bats, a .349 pace that has raised his season average to .281.
"With Rickey," said a baseball executive who knows him well, "what matters is pride and economic incentive. He wanted to play every day, so he beat out Vaughn."
 
Dubious Distinction Awards
 It was not a good week for the Milwaukee Brewers. Not only did the Cincinnati Reds sweep them in a three-game interleague series, but the Brewers also had the worst showing in the All-Star voting. Their catcher, first baseman and second baseman finished last, their shortstop and designated hitter placed next to last, their third baseman was 11th out of 14 and their 3 outfielders were among the last 8 of 42 on the ballot.
Philadelphia entered last night's game with a .277 won-lost percentage. Over a full season, that percentage would give the Phillies a 44-118 record. And the Pirates were supposed to lose more than 100 games?
 
Pitchers Reclaim Dignity
 Pitchers have reclaimed some of their rightful share of the major league game. In the first three months, runs and home runs were down from the first three months of last season. In 1,118 games last year, teams scored 11,428 runs and hit 2,530 home runs; in 1,115 games this year, teams scored 10,624 runs and hit 2,201 home runs.
The National League dropped to 8.96 runs and 1.77 home runs a game from 9.43 and 2.07. The American League dipped to 10.11 and 2.18 from 11.01 and 2.46. The major league game averages fell to 9.53 runs from 10.22 and to 1.97 homers from 2.26.

LENGTH: 1954 words

HEADLINE: Computer Age Millionaires Redefine Philanthropy

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 5

 BODY:
Among the multitudes of Microsoft millionaires here, something big is brewing.
Something that, though emanating from what many consider the Evil Empire of computerdom, has the potential to do such tremendous good that it reminds philanthropy experts of the turn-of-the-century transformation of New York City by the railroad and oil barons. Or the infusion of civic-minded wealth into the Ford-and-Chrysler Midwest a generation later. 
 Slowly, scores, if not hundreds, of the several thousand millionaires created by Microsoft's high-technology hegemony, many of them so suddenly flush with rocketing stock shares that they can retire at 35, are coalescing into a network of unusually young, unusually rich people who think along these lines:
"We've been lucky -- we've been really lucky," said Trish Millines, a 39-year-old Microsoft retiree who has just created a foundation to help train minority children in computers. "And one of my first instincts as a person who grew up fairly poor is: You have it, you share it."
And sharing it they are, in ways that are beginning to transform the culture of the Seattle area and, experts say, of philanthropy itself.
The Microsoft techno-benefactors include billionaires like Paul Allen, the company co-founder who has given tens of millions of dollars to a variety of causes; Bill Gates himself, who last week announced the donation of $200 million toward connecting libraries here and around the nation with the Internet, and a constellation of mere millionaires backing projects like saving the historic Paramount theater, arming environmental groups with the latest in computer tools and creating a baby blanket company that gives all its proceeds to children's causes.
Charity specialists are watching with fascination as Microsoft disciples begin to try to remake the Puget Sound nonprofit world in their own image, introducing into the sometimes-stodgy world of philanthropy a high-energy, high-tech, hard-core business approach that seems to enter the DNA of employees on the Redmond, Wash., campus.
They are also taking note of the particular orientations of this new generation of givers: They tend to want to support education -- their own key to success -- and environmental causes, and share a certain belief in technology as salvation.
If their nascent efforts live up to their promise, said Craig Smith, a longtime philanthropy consultant here, the region will become a showcase for how high-technology patrons "help society make the transition into the information age," from spreading technology across class barriers to using its profits to improve education and help the poor.
The upstart geekocracy of high technology is not known for sharing, and grateful-but-skeptical Seattleites often point out the strings attached to gifts: Mr. Gates's library plan will help promote use of Microsoft software, and Mr. Allen, who recently paid for a statewide vote on a new $425 million stadium, which he will help build, to keep the Seattle Seahawks football team, which he just bought, in their hometown, is expected to make money off the deal. Many of the millionaires also use their donations for tax relief.
 
A New Generation Of Philanthropy
In general, techno-millionaires, who make up one of the biggest pools of new wealth in the country, have been regarded as one of the stingiest, too caught up in navigating the whitewater change in their industry to focus on helping others. And Mr. Gates, the richest individual in the world, has been seen as the group's alpha ingrate, balking at sharing his billions until he was older.
But the seedlings of a new generosity in the Seattle area, among what is thought to be the biggest crop of quick millionaires that any company has ever produced, has stirred hope that many are getting old enough or burned-out enough to start thinking about personal legacies.
And the giving seems to presage ever greater influence for the city's Microsoft elite, whose flash has already associated Seattle in the minds of most outsiders with, "Oh, Bill Gates!" despite the longstanding dominance here of the Boeing Company, a business behemoth that still dwarfs Microsoft.
What is happening among Microsoft millionaires now in Seattle, said Peter Dobkin Hall, a research scientist in the Program on Non-Profit Organizations at Yale University, is the formation of a "philanthropic community," the kind of network that is needed for large-scale investment in social needs.
And already, he said of the ever-more-sparkling city, "Largely due to the impact of these people on civic life, it's just been transformed."
The signs that the techno-millionaires are reaching a critical philanthropic mass here had begun well before Mr. Gates announced his gift last week.
Earlier in June, at a meeting of more than 130 potential contributors, five high-technology leaders, including two Microsoft retirees and a current executive, founded Social Venture Partners, a sort of donors' circle. Conceived by Paul Brainerd, a pioneer in desktop publishing who sold his Aldus Corporation in 1994 for $450 million, the partnership is set up much like a venture capital firm, with each member "investing" at least $5,000 in its initial stages.
And Microsoft Alumnet, which, among other things, helps Microsoft "graduates" figure out how to donate their money and time, has mushroomed in its two-year existence to more than 1,100 members.
 
Bill Gates Begins To Lead the Way
Mr. Gates may now begin leading the way with his personal giving, and Microsoft matches employees' charitable contributions with up to $12,000 a year.
But until now, it has been mainly the Microsoft alumni -- the hundreds who have thrown off the "golden handcuffs" of deferred stock options and concluded that where they want to go today is out -- who have set the examples.
Best known nationally for large-scale philanthropy is Mr. Allen, the bearded, bearish Microsoft co-founder, eighth-richest man in the world, whose estimated $13 billion fortune supports not only a man-in-a-toystore life of sports and jets but a broad array of contributions. They include gifts to hospitals and universities and his plan for a lavish, interactive rock music museum, the Experience Music Project, built in the shape of a smashed guitar.
Locally, a constellation of other former Microsoft employees have become associated with major good works, from Ida Cole, who used some of her millions to save the landmark Paramount theater, to Scott Oki, whose Oki Foundation gives away nearly half a million dollars a year, mainly to children's causes.
When he began the foundation, Mr. Oki said with wry candor, it was largely as a "tax dodge." But he has become so consumed with nonprofit work he is a member of 23 boards, he said, and sees his mission as blending philanthropy with entrepreneurship and persuading former Microserfs and others to do the same.
"Clearly, we're still at the tip of the iceberg," he said of his colleagues' contributions, "as more and more people leave Microsoft and really figure out what they want to do with the rest of their lives."
Not on the same scale of raw wealth, but considered the political star among Microsoft millionaire retirees is Tina Podlodowski, 37, a Seattle City Councilwoman who has championed neighborhood planning, gay rights and technological efficiency, saving the city millions in computer costs.
"Nobody ever thought Microsoft would get this big," Ms. Podlodowski said. "To get this money is a wonderful bonus. For most people it's just a matter of having a safety net -- so you start thinking, 'How can we crank that safety net for other people?' "
Then there is a passel of less prominent figures -- those beginning their own ventures, like Ms. Millines, whose Technology Access Foundation will train children and teen-agers on computers, and hundreds of others joining nonprofit boards and writing checks.
Of Alumnet's 1,100 members, staff members say, about 40 percent are mainly interested in nonprofit work, while another 40 percent have started new businesses and want networking help primarily with that.
 
New Assertiveness In Charitable Groups
And then there are those who choose to remain anonymous, like the former Microsoft backers of the Wilburforce Foundation, a new fund based in Seattle that gives away $2 million a year mainly to groups in the Pacific Northwest working on habitat conservation. Microsoft alumni say they think -- based on purely anecdotal surveys of their friends -- that only perhaps one-fifth of rich young retirees have not yet gotten around to doing much beyond lingering over their lattes.
For philanthropy-watchers and the retirees themselves, the most interesting aspect of the influx of Microsoft money is the people who come with it: their desire to throw themselves into some new passion and the habits they bring from their days and nights of cranking code, crunching numbers and quashing competitors.
"I'd expect to see a bunch of very aggressive, assertive foundations because that's the nature of Microsoft people, that they're going to be independent and really think about what they do," said Bruce Jacobsen, who left Microsoft last year. He is now president of Progressive Networks, a start-up founded by Rob Glaser, a fellow Microsoft retiree, that mainly makes RealAudio and RealVideo software but will donate a fixed percentage of its profits to charity and, as a sideline, backs political groups with free technological aid.
Even those like Mr. Glaser, swept up in a new business, demand Microsoft-style measurable results from the charities they support.
"I don't find it satisfying to just write a check when I don't know the money will be used in a positive way," he said. "There should be a hybrid of the purely commercial and purely philanthropic world. You can actually create an economic entity with metrics for measurability."
Fueling the philanthropy is a rise in Microsoft's stock -- it is up by a factor of 250 since it went public in 1986 -- and the stock option plan that spreads the wealth among thousands of employees. In January alone, employees exercised $400 million in options on $1.3 billion in stock, creating $900 million in net worth, said Tony Audino, the founder of Alumnet.
Estimates of how many millionaires the company has produced range from 5,000 to 10,000 or more; it depends in part on when people sold their stock.
Philanthropy experts say the growing altruistic bent also stems from a natural maturing, one that has gone a bit slower than in other fields simply because of the age of the new rich. Many are still busy having children and buying houses.
"It's a 10-year process of money coming back to the community, even from very wealthy people," said Gib Myers, a general partner at the Mayfield Fund in Menlo Park, Calif., which has been exploring ways to encourage philanthropy among the Silicon Valley's counterparts to the Microsoft millionaires.
Nonetheless, despite widespread criticism that the world cannot afford to wait for technology moguls to mature into giving more, even such a usually sharp-tongued philanthropy analyst as Waldemar Nielsen gets excited when he considers the good they are beginning to do.
"They're not only young and creative, but they're a different generation of newly wealthy people," said Mr. Nielsen, author of "The Dramas of Donorship" (University of Oklahoma, 1997). "I'm very optimistic that their philanthropic work will turn out as creative as their inventiveness in these new fields of electronics and communications." Normally, he said, "I'm a sour and skeptical old man, but I really feel great, great hopefulness about them."

HEADLINE: Why Does It Take a Wrestling Match to Get Tax Reductions?;
Capital vs. Labor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I am rather puzzled by the Republican proposal in the House to index capital gains to inflation (editorial, July 2; front page, July 1). 
 If I understand the proposal correctly, if the inflation increase in a given year is 3 percent and I invest $20,000 in a stock whose value increases $600 during the year, I pay no taxes on the $600. However, if I receive a wage of $20,000 a year and I get a raise of $600, I am required to pay taxes on the $600. I fail to see the equity in this.
In the one case I am investing capital, but in the other case I am investing labor.
 
DAVID EISENBERG
Paradise Valley, Ariz., July 2, 1997

HEADLINE: For Richer, for Poorer

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, the former Secretary of Labor, is University Professor and Maurice Hexter Professor of Social and Economic Policy in the Heller Graduate School at Brandeis University. His most recent book is "Locked in the Cabinet."

 BODY:

MONEY
 Who Has How Much and Why.
 By Andrew Hacker.
 254 pp. New York:
 Scribner. $25. 
 Jerry Seinfeld gets at least $22 million next year. Is he worth it? NBC thinks so. It pulls in more than $1 million a minute from advertisements during the show. The laundry worker down my street earns around $13,500 a year. Is he worth it? The laundry thinks so. Even though the economy is booming, it can get someone to replace him if he demands a penny more.
In his engaging book "Money," Andrew Hacker, a professor of political science at Queens College, examines who earns what, and why they do. He shows that most Americans are more like the person who does my laundry than like Seinfeld. If $30,000 is set as a minimum middle-class income, fewer than a third of all employed Americans can be considered middle class. Even at $20,000, only about half can.
At the very top, with yearly incomes over $1 million, sit some 68,000 of the nation's highest rollers (from whose ranks, Hacker tells us, came one-quarter of all the delegates to the most recent Republican National Convention), including 1,500 people on Wall Street, 600 chief executives, 246 professional football players, 241 baseball players and a collection of inventors, entertainers, entrepreneurs, financial wizards and heirs. Just under them come America's richest professionals -- the top 1 percent of all earners, with yearly incomes starting at $200,000 -- featuring not only star doctors and lawyers but also heads of charitable foundations (the Ford Foundation pays its president $839,139), university presidents (more than half a million dollars at Boston University) and even a football coach ($975,000 at Florida State, including endorsements).
These generous incomes are mostly explained by the special skills or education of their recipients. In Hacker's view, the substance of what they learned in college is less important than the style. "The years at college and graduate school pay off because they burnish students' personalities. The time spent on a campus imparts cues and clues on how to conduct oneself in corporate cultures and professional settings." Professors themselves, although hardly in the top ranks, are paid comfortable salaries "not so much for teaching subjects like history and philosophy as for being a professional presence that students can emulate."
The rest of Hacker's explanation for why the very rich got that way has even less to do with their expertise. He argues that when organizations or individuals want to demonstrate they are getting the "best," they hire people who are already paid the most. A similar ratcheting-up occurs with corporate boards, which always want to pay their chieftains just above the norm in order to prove that the company is ahead of the rest of the pack; or with Wall Street investment bankers, who conventionally receive a 1 percent commission on all deals and so promote the biggest ones conceivable. In any event, a payment of tens of millions of dollars just doesn't seem that extravagant when one is presiding over billions. How else to explain Michael Ovitz's $128 million severance package for about 60 weeks' work at Disney?
The bottom 80 percent of the population, meanwhile, receives a smaller share of the nation's total income than it did 20 years ago. The shift began in the early 1970's, when the median earnings of men began dropping. Middle-income households avoided downward mobility only by sending wives to work and by postponing both marriage and children. At the same time, the poor have become poorer. Some of this downdraft has been caused by technological advances and globalization, hurting those with few or outmoded skills.
Here, too, Hacker suggests additional culprits. Long-term contracts and wage-setting institutions that once shielded blue-collar workers, teachers and low-level civil servants from the labor auction block are disappearing. Meanwhile, the lowest economic rungs, on which most two-income families had once perched, are now occupied by single-parent households. In 1995, 31.3 percent of American children lived with just one parent or with someone other than a parent, up from under 15 percent in 1970. Largely as a result, a third of America's children now live in households earning less than $25,000. One in five children lives in poverty. For all its riches, the United States now has a greater percentage of its citizens in prison or on the streets, and more neglected children, than any other advanced nation.
This story isn't new, but Hacker embellishes it with rich detail. In 1970, for example, 3.1 percent of American households lived in trailers or mobile homes; by 1990, it was 7.2 percent. Sometimes the precision and profusion of his detail overwhelm his argument. (In 1995, the average sewing-machine operator earned $13,052; a hotel clerk, $15,028; and an orthopedic surgeon, $304,000. The median household income in West Virginia was $24,880, while in Connecticut it was $40,243. The poverty threshold for one person living alone was $7,763.)
From such an abundance of data, Hacker draws some provocative conclusions. He argues, for example, that certain states have intentionally low-balled welfare allowances in order to create "a ready pool of women to work at a minimum wage as household servants, motel maids and in food-processing plants." Some of his verdicts are simply bizarre, as when he states that "the farther a country is from the United States, the more likely will its immigrants be to secure higher-paying employment" because "it takes more resources, either financial or personal, to get here from India or the Philippines than, say, Mexico or the Dominican Republic." Canadians and Cambodians alike would find this statement curious.
Hacker is appropriately concerned about the corrosive consequences of growing disparities in wealth and earnings among Americans. "With the legacy we are now creating," he writes, "millions of men, women, children are prevented from being fully American, while others pride themselves on how much they can amass." But he is curiously silent about what we might do to reverse the trend. His skepticism about the substantive purposes of higher education and his awareness of the difficulties in countering any of the institutional or sociological reasons for the widening gap lead him to the brink of suggesting, perhaps by default, a far more progressive system of taxation.
Hacker notes, for example, that as recently as 1979, rich Americans paid an average of 47 percent of their income in Federal taxes. By 1994, the effective rate had declined to 32 percent.
In theory, economic winners could redistribute much of their earnings to losers and yet still come out far ahead. As an extreme example, he observes that an income ceiling of $100,000 per year, affecting approximately the top 7 percent of American families, would yield $285 billion annually -- a sum that, if transferred to the poorest 20 percent, whose incomes now average $7,764, would establish a floor of $22,219 per family.
But Hacker hastily warns us off any such fanciful thoughts. His book "should not be read as a plea for income redistribution," he protests near its end. "The reason is straightforward: if people are disinclined to share what they have, they will not be persuaded by a reproachful tone." One worries that the elevated tone he chooses instead may be too high to be heard.

PUB-DATE: July 6, 1997

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 3; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2368 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
True Grits in Nashville

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV; ERIC ASIMOV writes the $25 and Under dining column for the Weekend section of The New York Times

 BODY:
SATURDAY night is rush hour in downtown Nashville. Cars stand bumper to bumper on Broadway, as police officers on bicycles wind slowly through the crowd. A gawking couple steps out of a horse-drawn carriage in front of the Old Spaghetti Factory, a franchise restaurant down the block from Hooters and around the corner from Planet Hollywood and the Hard Rock Cafe.
This is born-again Nashville, or "Nash Vegas," as denizens call it, where the prefabricated glitz of franchise clubs and packaged country entertainment is proving an irresistible siren to tourists. 
 I was hoping to find another city, where the music was more bourbon than Perrier, where the Southern restaurants still featured the Tennessee trinity of pork, pig and ham, and where lard, salt and "I'll have another beer" weren't dirty words. After all, it was just going to be a three-day weekend. And it was going to be cheap. In Nashville, music and food, judiciously chosen, are bargains.
The problem was getting there. Because I was arranging my trip on short notice -- just three days ahead -- a reasonable air fare between New York and Nashville was hard to find. American Airlines, one of the few airlines with a direct flight, quoted a fare of $992.
I tried the airline consolidators, those companies that acquire tickets in bulk and make them available at cut-rate prices, and easily found considerably cheaper round trips, $295 plus tax, but no direct flights. Then a solution appeared before my eyes.
Recently, I had subscribed to Net Saaver, a free weekly E-mail newsletter from American Airlines available through the American Web site, www.americanair.com. Net Saaver arrives each Wednesday, announcing last-minute discount fares available only on the coming weekend. These fares require departure on a Friday after 7 P.M. or anytime Saturday, with return the following Monday or Tuesday. The list of available tickets changes every week, and, from a New Yorker's perspective, the choices were always slim, with fares between New York and anywhere scarce.
This week, though, I was in luck. The current Net Saaver offered a round trip between New York and Nashville for a mere $129 plus tax! What's more, I could also rent a Hertz economy car with unlimited mileage for $24 a day through Net Saaver (I spent an extra $2 a day for a more comfortable compact).
So there I was, leaving Nashville International Airport on a Saturday morning in a Nissan Sentra -- not the Ford Escort I had been promised, but all I really cared about was that it had a decent radio.
I discovered two things right away: It's not as easy as you might think to find country music on the radio in Nashville, and it's even harder to find your way around. A good map ($4.95 at a newsstand) was essential.
I still got lost on my way to the Pancake Pantry, a Nashville institution. Even as the rest of the country has decided it has no time to eat in the morning, the South still venerates breakfast, especially in Nashville. This airy farmhouse-style restaurant on a block of low-slung stores and offices in the West End, near Vanderbilt University, offers 20 types of pancakes. My meal, deliciously coarse, granular cornmeal pancakes and rich country ham ($7.25), was the perfect welcome to Nashville, right down to the waitresses who called me "Hon" and replenished my iced tea unbidden.
Fueled up, I tried to get my bearings. My motel, a Shoney's Inn, was in the Music Row section, a center of the recording studios and industry offices. By simply stepping out of my functional but characterless room I could hear the quavering strains of a country ballad. A man in a nearby parking lot was belting out the song for tips, backed by a taped musical accompaniment in a kind of country karaoke. A little trolley plied Demonbreun Street, shuttling tourists between the nearby Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum and the sights downtown. Across the street were gift shops and quasi-museums advertising their prize possessions: "Barbara Mandrell's gown," "Hank Williams Jr.'s Cadillac," "George Jones's gold record." Each seemed to sell more local delicacies -- Goo-Goo Clusters and Moon Pies -- than musical trinkets.
I headed in another direction, to visit the Carl Van Vechten Gallery of Fine Arts at Fisk University, which houses a collection of paintings and sculptures once owned by Alfred Stieglitz. The collection was donated by his widow, Georgia O'Keeffe, in 1949 and includes works by Cezanne, Renoir and Diego Rivera, although I was more interested in less familiar modern artists like Marsden Hartley and John Marin, whose work Stieglitz had shown in his galleries.
My hope was to avoid the big country music tourist attractions -- the Grand Ole Opry, the Ryman Auditorium and the Wildhorse Saloon -- and to figure out where Nashvillians themselves go for music.
After a quick dinner at Rotier's, a dark, clubby West End bar and grill that serves the traditional Nashville "meat and three," meat with a choice of three vegetables ($5.75), I headed for the Station Inn, a nondescript stone building with a plywood floor, where Keith Little and Friends, a bluegrass group, were to play at 9 P.M. The cover charge was only $5, and Budweisers were $2.50, but with only 20 souls in the audience, the energy level was low. I moved on to 12th and Porter, a bar and restaurant that not only seemed to attract all of pierced, tattooed Nashville, but also offered valet parking.
It was packed, and waitresses in leather skirts and studded collars were squeezing through the crowd to serve dishes with names like Low Death Factor Fettuccine, the Nashville equivalent of spa cuisine. But the nightclub adjacent to the restaurant, done entirely in pink and black, was almost empty.
The band, Pat Gallagher and the Atomic Playboys, began a set of mellow love songs, the gentle lyrics settling like dew drops over the empty seats. A few more people trickled in, and as the band wound up its set, I left, having spent $3.50 for a Bass ale and $1 as tip for parking.
Could it be that all of Nashville had been invited to a party, and I hadn't gotten my invitation?
I found the party at my next stop, Exit-In, a club near Vanderbilt that specializes, I learned later, in the sort of alternative rock that appeals to a college audience. Exit-In was packed and pulsing, with a throng of young people who had paid $7 to hear Man or Astroman?, a psycho-surf thrash band, complete with props like cheesy Van de Graaff generators and big-screen televisions that flash footage from old science fiction movies. It was entertaining, but not what I was looking for. Besides, it was late, and I was hungry again. I headed out for Prince's Hot Chicken.
A friend had told me not to miss Prince's, but only chuckled when I asked him to describe it. Four or five other groups were waiting inside the largely takeout operation in a rundown storefront in northern Nashville. As chicken fried in huge, black frying pans, I read some warnings posted on the wall: Don't eat and drive at the same time. Don't touch the chicken and then touch your eyes, you could burn yourself. I ordered my chicken mild, with lemonade ($4.25), and took it back to my motel.
As I ate, the heat began with a tingling in the lips and tongue that rose into the sinuses and traveled down the throat. The plump, juicy chicken breast was undeniably a culinary treat, but perhaps not the best bedtime snack.
Particularly because I had to get up early on Sunday for breakfast. For years I had heard praise for the Loveless Motel and Cafe, most recently in "Eat Your Way Across the U.S.A." by Jane and Michael Stern. Now I was taking the 20-minute drive from Music Row to the Loveless in southwest Nashville.
Much of central Tennessee seems to congregate at the Loveless on Sunday mornings. Those without reservations are kept waiting in a little anteroom, or they may choose a buffet breakfast in an adjoining building. Those with reservations (like me) are seated right away in the homey dining room, where dishes of preserves, chunky peach and tart blackberry, sit on red-and-white checkered tablecloths.
I ordered country ham and eggs with red-eye gravy ($8.95) and a side order of grits ($1). Red-eye is a Southern specialty invented to go with grits and eggs: The salty, musky drippings from country ham are blended with a little coffee and cooked down. The eggs came with a platter of a dozen fluffy biscuits, which I tried with the jams, dipped in gravy and as a sandwich with the country ham, which had the proper leathery texture. The waitress clucked sympathetically when I told her I couldn't finish the last two. "Would you like me to pack 'em up for you?" she asked. I declined.
Later that morning I visited the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum. I almost missed the building, which was dwarfed by the B.M.I. building next door. The fascinating little museum ($10.75 admission) traces the history of country music from the Grand Ole Opry to the present, with an emphasis on the most commercially successful, of course. Among the tidbits I learned were that the early country players had been persuaded to trade in their formal attire for hillbilly costumes by George D. Hay, the founder of the Opry, who believed it would make them more accessible to their audience; that one of the early Opry stars was DeFord Bailey, a black harmonica player (the Opry also featured musicians in blackface); that Johnny Cash's hit "A Boy Named Sue" was written by Shel Silverstein; that when it came to outlandish customizing, Elvis Presley's gold Cadillac, with record player and cocktail cabinet, had nothing on Webb Pierce's 1962 Pontiac Bonneville, with its tooled leather upholstery, six-gun trim and silver-dollar decor.
I spent more than three hours at the museum, and could easily have dawdled longer, watching historic film clips of Roy Acuff and early Opry stars like Uncle Dave Macon. But I was eager to check into my room at the Union Station Hotel, which had been built in a beautifully refurbished Romanesque Gothic train station. I justified the $109 tab on two grounds. First, I was getting a good Sunday night deal; my room usually went for $175. Second, everything else had been a bargain in Nashville, so I had earned a treat.
The room seemed unadorned but not plain, with a king-size bed, comfortable armchairs and A-shaped struts that gave an unusual archlike feel to the room. A big picture window offered a view of a rail yard and a highway, and I could see that a rainstorm had begun. Tonight, I decided, I would look for music in the heart of Nash Vegas.
Maybe because of the rain, or maybe because it was Sunday, downtown Nashville seemed barren. Like a carnival barker, a woman in front of the empty Planet Hollywood tried to coax me in. But I was heading for the dives of old Nashville, like Robert's Western World, a venerable Western-wear shop turned nightclub that achieved local fame a few years back as home base to BR5-49, a retro country band that's gone on to recording-contract glory.
Onstage, the Lonnie Waters Band was playing to a dozen or so people, energetically picking its way through Hank Williams, Hank Snow and Elvis Presley. If the music wasn't original, it was played with verve and charm. As in all the older places along Broadway, the band played for tips, the people listened for the price of a beer.
At Tootsie's Orchid Lounge, which for decades served as the backstage bar for the Grand Ole Opry, Scott Wayne and the Boys were taking requests to the delight of the small crowd in an improbably bright, rundown room. I felt satisfied, as if I had finally found the music I was looking for. As the band finished its set, I left to get something to eat.
Easier said than done. After 9 on Sunday night, Nashville closes down. I stumbled on to Red, Hot and Blue, a shiny Memphis-style barbecue restaurant in the West End. There was one other person there, sitting at the bar. I sat down alongside.
"This is the only place I could find that was still open," I said.
"Viva Nash Vegas!" he replied.
