HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Public Housing Tenants Trade Rents for Mortgages

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
IRA P. JACKSON, a 54-year-old clerk and mother of five grown children, will be writing her last rent check to the Jersey City Public Housing Authority this month. In August, Ms. Jackson will be closing on the two-family home she purchased with her daughter and son-in-law from the authority.
It is the same four-bedroom house she and her family have lived in for the last two years at the Dwight Street Homes, 50 two-family houses on scattered sites over three blocks in the city's Greenville section. Ms. Jackson will be the first resident to go from renter to owner, under a program sponsored by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development that enabled the authority to sell the homes to tenants who live there. 
 "This program gave me the opportunity to own a home," said Ms. Jackson, who has lived in public housing for 27 years. "Without it, I don't think I would have taken the chance."
Maria T. Maio, deputy executive director of the Jersey City Housing Authority, said the goal is that by 2000, all 50 of the two-family homes will be purchased by tenants. She said 15 more tenants are enrolled in the program.
The authority built the 100 apartments in the 50 town-house-style two-family houses, and has 400 more units in two- and three-family homes under way or planned. Forty of the homes will also be sold to tenants. All of the houses are part of the authority's plan to replace the apartments in six of the seven high-rise towers that it has razed or will raze at Curries Woods, a 712-unit public housing complex.
The high-rise complex, like others in New Jersey and elsewhere in the country, had become a symbol of a failed housing concept. Such projects were developed in the 1950's as an economical form of housing, but many of them -- beset by crime, neglect and mismangement -- became the dumping ground for the poorest of families. The Federal Government no longer supports the building of high-density housing towers.
Their replacements, like the Dwight Street Homes, are low-rise structures, which are considered more humane places for low-income families. High-rise buildings that can be are being renovated.
Housing officials in Washington are now accelerating efforts to encourage the sale of public housing, thinking that home ownership allows low-income tenants to take more control of their lives. It also supports the Clinton Administration's strategy to increase home ownership across the nation. Since 1993, HUD has approved the sale of 4,700 public housing units and plans to sell 25,000 more by 2000.
"This is a wise investment that strengthens families and helps more hard-working Americans enter the middle class," Andrew Cuomo, HUD Secretary, wrote in a statement. His department has several programs through which local housing authorities can help turn tenants into homeowners.
SUCH efforts are happening throughout New Jersey, which has 53,000 public housing units, said the Newark office of HUD. Newark is putting up 1,777 town houses to replace apartments in 12 of its high-rises as part of a 1989 settlement of a Federal lawsuit by a coalition of tenants and housing groups.
So far, 753 of the town houses have been built and occupied, and 196 more are in various stages of development, said Harry Robinson, a spokesman for the Newark Housing Authority. He said the authority was in the early stages of working with some tenants to buy their units.
The authority, using a $50 million grant from HUD, is also planning 630 more town houses, replacing apartments in high-rises that will be razed. As part of that effort, the New Community Corporation in Newark, among the state's largest nonprofit housing groups, will use a $25 million Federal grant to build 206 town houses that public housing tenants will be able to buy or rent with an option to buy. Work on the first 103 units is to start this fall. "This is another step in what we can do," said Msgr. William J. Linder, founder of New Community.
Paterson also received Federal money to raze two 10-story buildings with a total of 160 public housing units by the fall of 1998. Residents will receive Section 8 rent vouchers to move into private homes. Those vouchers, under pending Federal legislation, could be used to make mortgage payments, enabling tenants to buy homes, said Felix Raymond, executive director of the Paterson Housing Authority. He said the authority was also applying for Federal money to tear down another public housing complex, with 498 units. The plan, said Mr. Raymond, is to replace those apartments with an undetermined number of rental units and one- and two-family houses that will be sold to former tenants.
The idea of selling public housing to tenants has been tried before on a limited basis. In 1985, Brooks-Sloate Terrace, a 242-unit low-rise complex in Paterson, was one of 18 public housing authority projects in the country selected by HUD to take part in a demonstration to sell units to tenants. It was made a co-op, and in 1992 the Paterson Housing Authority turned over the complex to tenants. Today, 202 apartments at Brooks-Sloate have been sold.
In Jersey City, public housing residents at the Dwight Street Homes now have the chance to buy their units. The 50 vinyl-sided houses, with wrought iron fences and window shutters, look no different from other homes in the neighborhood. Each family has a separate front entrance to its three- or four-bedroom unit, with 1,100 to 1,200 square feet of space, and each unit has a small yard in front and back. Two-family homes "provide home ownership opportunities for low-income working families and retain rentals for those with lower incomes," said Ms. Maio of the housing authority.
The development was completed in 1995, and in the next two years the authority devised a plan, approved by HUD last month, to sell the units to eligible tenants. Twenty-five of the families earn no more than 80 percent of the median income in Jersey City, which translates into $35,000 for a family of four. The rest earn 50 percent or less of the median income, which is $24,000. Potential buyers must also complete a counseling program, covering such issues as money management and responsibilities of homeownership. Job training is also available. "It is a different approach that has the potential to be duplicated," said Diane Johnson, HUD's New Jersey coordinator.
The homes, priced at $140,000, will be sold first to the higher-income families "who have the financial wherewithal to buy and have a good shot at success," Ms. Maio said. Thirty-year mortgages at below market rate and zero percent down will be made available to eligible buyers through the New Jersey Housing Mortgage Finance Agency for $70,000. The Jersey City Housing Authority will provide a second no-interest loan for the remaining $70,000.
To receive the financing, buyers must agree to continue to rent the second apartment to public housing tenants, who if eligible will receive Federal Section 8 rent subsidies. That will make up the difference between what tenants now pay, which averages $225 a month, and market rents, averaging $800. Ms. Maio said the rental income is counted as part of buyers' income and will help them meet mortgage payments.
Buyers also must agree to live in the home for 10 years, and each year they do so the mortgage from the authority is reduced by 10 percent. If they leave before that time, there is a ceiling on the sale price that limits profit from appreciation.
Of buying one of the Dwight Street Homes, Ira Jackson said: "This is the begining of a new life for us. Something we can build upon for the future."

HEADLINE: Watershed Pact Brings Disputes And Lawsuits

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
THE ink had hardly dried on the landmark agreement to protect watershed areas north of New York City before the euphoria accompanying its signing began to wear thin.
When the land-use deal among diverse groups was completed earlier this year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York predicted that it would serve as a national model of cooperation. 
 But by late last month, it was clear that some differences could not be swept under the rug.
On June 24, a State Supreme Court judge ruled that landowners have a right to file damage claims for lost property values resulting from regulations embodied in the agreement.
And controversy over whether to build a filtration plant for the imperiled Croton Reservoir has gathered steam, producing some unexpected bedfellows in the process and also generating a lawsuit on that issue.
Meanwhile, the construction industry, which is still reeling from a downturn several years ago, is bracing for yet more lean times because the watershed regulations limit where and how new building can occur. But the industry is also gearing up to fight back.
There is growing resentment among elected officials and the populace that the needs of Westchester and Putnam Counties were "shamefully neglected" in the deal, according to the Croton Watershed Clean Water Coalition, which represents several chapters of the Sierra Club, Friends of the Clearwater and other groups. "I don't think all is peaceful on the home front with this agreement," said Harold E. Vogt, president and chief executive officer of the Westchester Chamber of Commerce and president of the Alliance for Watershed and Water Quality Programs. "It may be a real disaster as it moves forward."
From the perspective of aggrieved property owners, a municipality should not be able to make decisions for the people it does not represent without having to compensate them, said Frederick J. Martin, a White Plains lawyer representing more than 80 plaintiffs in Westchester and Putnam Counties.
"It's like the old Revolutionary War cry," said Mr. Martin, a senior partner with Bleakley Platt & Schmidt: "No taxation without representation!"
The agreement was signed on Jan. 21 by the city, the watershed communities, the counties involved, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, the State Health Department, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, the state's Department of State and some environmental groups. They agreed to a complex program to protect reservoirs feeding into the city.
Under the agreement, New York City said it would buy thousands of acres of land to shield its 19 upstate reservoirs from pollution, improve sewage treatment and subsidize so-called environmentally sound economic development.
The city also announced strict land-use regulations designed to protect the watershed area from further degradation.
But in a 55-page decision, Judge S. Barrett Hickman of the State Supreme Court in Carmel denied New York City's motion to dismiss the complaints of landowners affected by the regulations. The plaintiffs, many of whom are developers, are seeking financial compensation for lost property values, which they say result from the city's restrictions on new construction in the watershed.
"They have a lot to lose," Mr. Martin said of his clients. "The economic crux of the matter is that this land is extremely valuable from a development point of view."
The lawyer explained that while the city has the right to regulate use of the land, it also has the responsibility to compensate landowners.
Not everyone agrees with that line of reasoning. "If regulations preserve the quality of life, then property owners should be happy,"said David K. Gordon, a lawyer for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund. "For most of us, this is a welcome plus."
And while few environmentalists would say that developing land is necessarily bad, their guiding principle is that such development should not degrade an area's natural resources.
"In other words, it's O.K. if you want to build a shopping center, just get out of the watershed," said William C. Harding, Town Supervisor for Somers. He was on the negotiating team that forged the watershed regulations, representing a mostly rural northern Westchester area known for its rolling hills, streams and meadows. The watershed area in Westchester includes the Muscoot, the Croton, the Amawalk, the Titicus and the Cross River Reservoirs.
Development interests, while not proposing chemical storage sites, are interested in shopping centers and housing developments, and they say that that kind of building can be done without harming underground water sources.
George Frank, the executive vice president of the Building and Realty Institute in White Plains, which represents 1,600 members in the real estate, home building, development and banking industries, said the regulations were harmful to healthy economic interests.
Explaining that the construction industry is slowly emerging from a recession that took place from 1992 to 1994, he said, "There's no need for these Draconian measures."
Edward R. Heelan, a realtor in Brewster and president of the Brewster Manor Development Corporation, which is a plaintiff in the property owners' suit, said both large developers and small land investors would lose their shirts because of the strict regulations.
"The politicians and the bureaucrats think this is the greatest thing since sliced bread, but many taxpayers and property owners are economically devastated," he said.
Another focus of controversy is whether to build a filtration plant for the Croton Watershed area east of the Hudson River. While the regulations are designed to avoid the need for a filtration plant for the Catskill and Delaware watershed systems west of the river, New York City is under orders from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to build one for the Croton area.
Interests in favor of development say that New York City is one of the only cities in the world without such a filtration system. And since June 1993, the city has been in violation of the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act for failing to filter the Croton water.
In April, the Federal Government sued New York City in United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York in Brooklyn for failing to build the $600 million filtration plant for the reservoirs east of the Hudson River, which supply about 10 percent of the city's water. The project has been in planning for 20 years but has been delayed by its high cost and disputes over where it will be built.
While environmentalists have often been at odds with the New York City Department of Environmental Protection over its policies and procedures, one group wants to align itself with the city in fighting the Federal lawsuit. The Croton Watershed Clean Water Coalition -- which represents groups from New York City, the Bronx, Westchester and Putnam Counties -- is seeking to join New York City in the suit.
Paul Moskowitz, president of the Huntersville Association, a neighborhood group in Yorktown, and a member of Friends of the Croton Watershed, said the coalition was opposed to filtration and supported tougher measures to keep the water pure.
"You have to prevent the problem to begin with, not try to deal with it after the fact," Mr. Moskowitz said.
He said the filtration issue was symptomatic of what he called a larger problem: that the Croton Watershed area was slighted in the agreement. "The heart of the problem is that we got neglected," Mr. Moskowitz said, explaining that New York City allocated $250 million to buy property in the Catskills but only $17.5 million for that purpose east of the Hudson.
Mr. Moskowitz and others have complained about that part of the agreement, calling it a token land-acquisition program, because in Westchester property values are so high that $17.5 million will not go very far.
There is also the worry that New York City will drag its feet in acquiring property and that its cumbersome bureaucracy is not up to the tasks outlined in the deal.
"There's a healthy distrust out there for the City of New York,"said Jeremiah R. Dineen, chairman of the Planning Board in Yorktown. "The city has been known to drag its feet. Its history has not been great."
Charles Sturcken, a spokesman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection, said New York was aware of its poor image and would seek to set matters straight. He said the department had hired more than 200 extra workers to implement the accord.
John R. Nolon, a professor of law at Pace University specializing in property and land-use issues, said it is difficult to predict how the watershed agreement would unfold.
"The issues here are huge -- the safety of drinking water, the ability of communities to develop their land and the rights of individual property owners to use their land," he said. "I think most people are taking a wait-and-see attitude on this."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Tracking Air Fares Across the Country

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Domestic Airlines Fares Consumer Report, a new report from the Transportation Department calculates the average air fare between 1,000 pairs of cities in the continental United States and for each route identifies the average fare on both the dominant and least expensive airlines. For ticket buyers, the information is not as useful or reliable as what would result from a call to a competent travel agent, but it does provide a good overview.
For example, the survey showed that the average one-way fare from New York to Cincinnati was $244, with Delta, the biggest carrier, charging $274, and Continental, the least expensive, charging $199. But as the report notes, "airlines tend to offer a wide variety of prices in any given market and it is unlikely that the average fares from this report will be the same as any particular fare offered." 
 The report also gives the average cost of flying from various cities. Flying out of New York costs 16.7 cents a mile; it is 30.5 cents out of Charlotte, 27.0 cents out of Buffalo, 11.7 cents out of Phoenix and 9.3 cents out of Las Vegas. The difference is competition.
The department picked the city-pairs with the largest percentage price changes between the third quarter of 1996 and the same quarter in 1995. The biggest increases were Kansas City-Minneapolis (up 172.9 percent) and Boston-Philadelphia (up 90.8 percent). The biggest drops were Birmingham-Tampa and Fort Lauderdale-Tampa, both down 62 percent.
The department issued its first report on June 11, covering the third quarter of 1996, and said it would issue a report every three months. The cities covered account for about 70 percent of domestic air traffic.
The report is available on the World Wide Web at http://www.dot.gov/ost/aviation/ or from the Department of Transportation, Office of Aviation and International Economics, X-10, 400 Seventh Street, S.W., Washington, D.C. 20590. MATTHEW L. WALD

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/After a Clean-Up, a $400 Million Paper Mill;
A New Life for a Polluted Old Bronx Rail Yard

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THE 96-acre site at the southernmost tip of the Bronx, once a busy railroad yard, has sat unused for 25 years, its future clouded by the asbestos, hydrocarbons and lead left from its industrial past. Now, with an unusual alliance of developers working to revive the site, the asbestos and much of the heavily contaminated soil have been removed, and what remains will be paved over with clean material to seal up the remnants of pollution.
As a result of the clean-up, the site, which is owned by the state and leased to a private developer, is well on its way to redevelopment as a rail yard again as well as the site for a mill that will turn paper trash into clean newsprint. 
 But it has taken seven years to get to this point, most of it consumed dealing with administrative and legal issues. It is an indication of the difficulties inherent in re-using old industrial land with environmental contamination, usually called brownfields.
The Bronx rail yard is one of tens of thousands of such sites in cities across the nation that have sat idle as developers have flocked to pristine, former farmlands known as greenfields in the increasingly sprawling suburbs to build offices, warehouses and industrial parks.
Fear of the unknown is one of the great inhibitors to brownfield development. Who knew what had been dumped on the land during the 100 years the Harlem River Yard was operated by railroads? The operator, the Galesi Group, tested carefully and got lucky. The actual environmental problems were pretty straightforward and without any unexpected surprises, said Joseph Fiteni, a principal engineer with TAMS Consultants, which worked on the project. To start with, there was asbestos in the old railroad sheds, which had to be removed before the buildings could be demolished.
"There were six underground storage tanks which had held diesel fuel," he said. Surprisingly, none had leaked, but sloppy fuel-handling practices over the years had left the soil contaminated with a family of chemicals known as polyaromatic hydrocarbons, or PAH's.
Coal ash from the days when most structures were heated by coal had been used as fill on the site, and that, too, contained PAH's. And there were particles of lead from the days when leaded fuel exhaust spewed from the tailpipes of the cars on the Triborough Bridge, which bisects the site.
"This type of contamination is very common on old industrial sites," said Mr. Fiteni. "It could have been a lot worse if the railroads had done a lot of maintenance."
The solution was to remove the tanks and the contaminated nearby soil for disposal elsewhere. The remaining PAH-contaminated particles and lead will be kept from becoming airborne by being covered by parking lots and buildings or by two feet of clear fill in open areas. "This gets rid of the exposure pathway," Mr. Fiteni said.
THE proposed recycling facility, known as the NYC Paper Mill, is a $440 million project that is to take waste paper from the city's trash, remove the ink and form the cleaned fibers into rolls of newsprint.
The deal to build the mill is not complete, but the project has received political and financial support from the city and state, and dozens of engineers are currently at work specifying the details of the project. The exterior is being designed by Maya Lin, who is best known for her work on the Vietnam Memorial in Washington.
The mill is unusual because it would be in the middle of a city, rather than near forests where most paper mills are found. It is even more unusual because its principal developer is the Natural Resources Defense Council, a prominent environmental group.
Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist with the group, said the mill represented a change in environmental thinking. "We have spent years stopping projects and we are still not saving the forests," he said. "So we decided to do something more proactive to improve the way we use resources. And we also think if you can find a project that does something positive and produces a good financial return, industry will jump all over it."
"We intend to break ground before the end of the year and prove that major manufacturing is returning to New York City," said John A. Cavanagh, executive vice president of Morse Diesel International, the construction manager for the mill project.
Not only will the mill reduce the amount of trash the city must haul to a landfill, but it will also use 3 million gallons of water a day from the Wards Island sewage treatment plant, rather than scarce fresh water. The water will be cleaned, used, cleaned again and returned to Wards Island to help with the clean-up of Long Island Sound, which gets treated discharge from Wards Island.
Returning the land to productive use will provide economic benefits to the locality, people involved in the project say. "This site was vacant since 1972 and it was a blight on the poorest community in New York," said Anthony M. Riccio Jr., senior vice president of the Galesi Group, which has a 99-year lease on the site. "Now we are going to have a rail yard and a paper mill and we are going to provide jobs for the community."
The paper mill is expected to offer 600 full-time jobs, ranging from unskilled paper sorters to management engineers, as well as 2,200 construction jobs during the 24 months it will take to build the plant. Other jobs are expected to be available at the warehouses and solid-waste transfer station on the site as well as the rail yard. "I have a truck driver training program under way now," Mr. Riccio said.
T HE point was underscored by Michael C. Finnegan, counsel to Gov. George E. Pataki, who backs the paper-mill project. "One of the lessons learned is that brownfield development creates jobs where they are most needed," he said. "Another is that economic development and environmental protection are not incompatible."
Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, was more cautious. Although the project "has a lot of merit from the environmental, economic development and waste disposal perspective," he said, "there are still some hurdles to overcome." Among them is the need to negotiate a contract for the city to supply waste paper.
As with many brownfields, the progress so far at the Bronx site was more a result of determination by the developer than any exotic environmental technology. Galesi, which operates 8 million square feet of warehouse space in the Albany area, signed its lease in 1990, but is only now getting close to the point where building can commence.
Part of the delay was caused by a lawsuit brought by a local group that contended that any use of the land other than as a rail yard would illegally increase air pollution in the area. The group won in a lower court, but was unanimously overturned on appeal.
"New York is unique," said Mr. Riccio, who was the city's Commissioner of Ports, International Trade and Commerce in the late 1980's. "Name any issue, and I'll get 1,000 people to protest against it. There was so much misinformation. Because we had a certain type of permit, there was a rumor we were going to build an incinerator."
Recent improvements to the rail lines in the Bronx means that for the first time piggy-back freight cars, which carry complete truck trailers, can come directly into the city. As a result, about a third of the Harlem River site will be used as a rail yard. Trains will come into the yard, large forklift trucks will lift the trailers off and deposit them in a parking lot where they can meet up with a tractor for local delivery.
Mr. Riccio said the economics of putting 100 trailers on a single train versus 100 individual trucks being driven across the country should result in a sharp increase in rail freight arriving in the city. But that could create another problem. The city is a big importer of goods, but since it lost most of its manufacturing industry, it has little in the way of goods to export and railroads do not like to haul empty cars.
The solution is garbage. With the city committed to closing Staten Island's Fresh Kills landfill in the near future, there will be no local disposal place. So USA Waste, Inc. is building a transfer station to pack solid waste into containers for shipment by rail to distant landfills.

HEADLINE: At Hospitals, Construction Is Regaining Its Health

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
RESPONDING to sweeping changes in the country's health-care delivery systems, hospitals in New York City and the surrounding region are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on construction projects designed to make health services more efficient for accountants and more attractive for patients.
Whether transforming a seedy parking garage on West 135th Street in Manhattan into a two-story outpatient clinic with 13 doctors or moving an entire hospital away from its urban setting in Meriden, Conn., to a vast new suburban campus across from a shopping mall, the region's hospitals are building again, according to architects and hospital administrators. 
 In the midst of a spate of mergers and affiliations largely dictated by the country's move toward managed care, the hospitals are, at the same time, stepping up their efforts to attract new patients in a race to gain market share. Increasingly, they are asking architects and planners to make the old hospitals function better -- and, in rare cases, to tear them down and rebuild.
In their new push to combine attractive design and convenience, the hospital buildings are changing. In suburban locations, parking is being made more convenient -- winding one's way through needle-thin corridors to the front entrance is considered a thing of the past. In some, main entrances are being moved to the back, right off the parking area.
In many hospitals, pre-admission testing is being moved closer to the entrance lobby for easy access. Admissions offices are being dismantled, with an emphasis on in-room check-in and "concierge" services. Maternity wards are moving to separate "women's wings" or "well-patient wings." Dormitory-style, multibedded rooms are out: Tomorrow's patients will almost exclusively be given private rooms.
In the new $780 million addition to New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center, Fritz Reuter, New York Hospital's senior vice president for facilities/real estate, boasted of private rooms with the best views in the city and gestured Toward one room with floor-to-ceiling windows seemingly perched above the sun-dappled waters of the East River.
Another hospital executive makes the case for reconfiguration more bluntly.
"We didn't want our pregnant women -- who are, after all, perfectly healthy people -- bumping into some guy on a gurney looking like death warmed over," said Theodore Horwitz, president and chief executive officer of Veterans Memorial Medical Center in Meriden, Conn. Along with the rebuilding of hospitals, many of the millions of dollars will be spent by hospitals wishing, as more than one administrator explained, to cover their bets by attracting new, healthy enrollees in previously underserved neighborhoods to newly built centers that, like the one Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center is opening on West 135th Street, will be staffed by hospital doctors. The center is Columbia-Presbyterian's "first venture outside its traditional service neighborhood," an executive said.
There are many examples of buildings that are rising, among them the $107 million replacement-hospital project at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut, where the existing main building, designed by Skidmore Owings and Merrill in 1951, will be demolished and a new, three-story traditional brick structure with a mansard roof is rising. On a smaller scale, Maimonides Hospital is building a $2.5 million medical center inside a former Beefsteak Charlie's pub a few blocks from the Lundy's seafood restaurant in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.
Last year, an estimated $700 million in hospital construction was approved in New York State alone, according to Kristine A. Smith, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Health.
And there are even more projects in the planning stages.
In White Plains, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center has just begun meeting with community boards and lining up approvals for a planned redevelopment of its existing psychiatric center on an elaborate and verdant 230-acre campus. When completed, what the hospital will call a Medical Village will include assisted living apartments, a treatment center for Alzheimer's disease and special care facilities for children -- along with posh retail shops.
"We're working to develop new retail space," Mr. Reuter said. "Like more and more hospitals, we're using our real estate assets as a source for maintaining the mission. To convert to new programs we need capital; without it, the places would die."
Faced with dramatic reductions in inpatient care -- reductions both in numbers of patients and lengths of stay -- the hospitals are retooling their architecture, both inside and out, to the patient of today: the outpatient, or the new breed of occupant: the "23-hour patient," who stays less than 24 hours, and because he or she is never formally admitted is not charged the hospital's rate for bed and board.
As one hospital administrator after another explained, the objective of hospital management has flip-flopped in the age of managed care.
"In the old system, if the hospital administrator walked around and saw all the beds were full, he was happy," said Cesar A. Perales, a former deputy mayor under David N. Dinkins who was hired by Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital three and a half years ago to develop its network of community sites. "Now, if he sees those same beds empty, he's ecstatic. Under the new system, he's getting paid per person -- it's called 'capitation' -- and the goal is not to use his resources, because they cost money."
IN the world of managed care, the goal is to sign up as many "heads" or "covered lives" as possible, and to treat them as cheaply -- and, as hospital executives stress, as well -- as possible. Just how to do that is something the hospitals are still trying to discover.
"There's a lot of uncertainty now," said Richard Sprow, the manager of health-care services at HLW, a large Manhattan-based architectural and engineering company. "It's a game of musical chairs -- will there still be 10 chairs left to sit in when the music stops? So hospitals try to be smarter to survive in the marketplace."
To entice "lives" to sign up, hospital administrators and architects who specialize in hospital renovation say appearances and convenience count.
"It sounds cynical, but one of the ways people will judge the quality of care is by a hospital's appearance," said Don Blair, the general manager of the New York office of Perkins & Will, a Chicago-based architectural company with the country's fifth largest health-care practice.
Mr. Blair, whose 80-person Manhattan office is currently working on 2.5 million square feet of renovated or new medical space around the region -- $314 million of health-care projects in the tristate area alone -- sees a new wave of capital improvements now being planned and started.
"After a hiatus of five or so years, the institutions are regrouping and beginning major capital projects," he said, following a time when money grew scarce -- and when available was used to finance information systems and "buying up doctors' groups and other hospitals; capital had been diverted away from major construction."
Hospitals in New York and the Northeast, he said, had generally lagged behind the rest of the country in following the recent health-care trends -- an opinion shared by many hospital executives interviewed. Mr. Blair singled out hospitals in California and the Southeast as being "far in front."
IN Meriden, Conn., a blue-collar community sandwiched between New Haven and Hartford, Veterans Memorial Medical Center is abandoning its inner-city buildings and will move one mile to a spot across from the Route 691 off ramp.
Mr. Horwitz, the hospital's president, explained that after considerable controversy among the city's residents, the hospital decided not to try to reconfigure its aging facility, where the 1920's main building sits across from a row of boarded-up single and two-family clapboard houses awaiting the wrecker's ball.
In contrast, the new hospital, designed by Perkins & Will, will be a sleek, low-slung trio of two-story pavilions -- with patients in beds on the second floors -- connected by a jazzy main floor galleria. At one end, a women's wing will have its own entrance; at the other end will be a helipad and emergency room. Running across one side is an attached wing of doctors' and administrative offices.
The attached offices -- which cost less to build than the main hospital largely because of different building codes -- are a new concept. In the past, patients might have been reluctant to get so close to a hospital for routine matters, feeling more secure visiting a doctor on the ground floor of an apartment house or on the first floor of a Victorian house on a side street near the hospital.
But in the managed-care environment, hospitals want to share in the new emphasis toward preventive care, by employing the primary-care and specialist doctors themselves and having them work in space the hospitals own or lease, or by renting them space.
In interviews, architects and administrators stressed that the hospitals of tomorrow -- even the reconfigured ones -- will not look like the hospitals of yesterday; they will have gallerias and shopping malls and food courts and exciting artwork. And they won't even be hospitals. They will be medical centers and medical villages. They will be streamlined, and they will be economical.
The cost to reconfigure the 330,000 square feet in assorted wings and additions of the old Meriden hospital, according to its president, would have come to somewhere between $50 million and $60 million -- spread out over the six to seven years it would have taken to phase in the renovations while keeping the hospital operating. "The debt service over six years was a fortune," said Mr. Horwitz. "That really put it over the top -- plus you don't know what you're going to find when you start tearing down walls."
The new 236,900-square-foot hospital, with a landscaped "Town Green" in front, three pavilions and 92 beds, will cost $74 million; financing costs, designers' and consultants' fees and new state-of-the-art equipment makes up $27 million of the total. Construction began last fall and will take about two years to complete.
Mr. Horwitz's comments echoed those of architects who say reconfiguring an existing hospital -- the only solution for many hospitals, especially in urban areas -- presents one of the hardest design tasks of all: to move patients and partitions around while the hospital is still up and running takes years, and millions of dollars.
Yet that is what a host of regional hospitals are doing, among them Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn and St. Vincent's Medical Center in West Brighton, Staten Island. "These two hospitals have very carefully targeted relatively small capital improvements, in their ambulatory (outpatient) care, in improving access and visibility," said Mr. Sprow of HLW. "Like all hospitals in the city, they no longer need as many beds. The question is what do you do with this space and make the best use of the investment."
The hospitals decided, Mr. Sprow explained, to accent what they did best: St. Vincent's decided to emphasize obstetrics -- "They were already a strong player and they decided to get even better," he said. So St. Vincent's added more nursery space as well as more pre- and postpartum facilities.
Lutheran Medical Center already specialized in obstetrics, the architect continued, but it decided to add 26 psychiatric beds; the reshuffle necessitated relocating the hospital's dialysis and AIDS units within the building. "It's a complicated domino effect to change over," Mr. Sprow said.
Maimonides Medical Center also focused on relatively small changes in its effort to gain -- or merely to keep -- the elusive market share. "We're not capital rich or heavily endowed," said Stanley Brezenoff, the president and chief executive officer of Maimonides. "Nor have we accumulated large amounts of cash. So, in looking at our needs, one thing we can't do, nor would it be advisable to do, given the changing health care picture, is to invest large amounts of money in new towers.
"We're looking to redevelop, to rework existing interior areas of our hospital as we reduce the length of stay and free up space," he continued, adding that this year, the hospital will spend between $12 million and $18 million on renovations and rehabilitation -- and on the equipment to fill the space.
The first thing Mr. Brezenoff mentioned was Maimonides's efforts to "upgrade patient amenities," including creating lounges for patients and their families. Then, he said, the hospital was "enhancing cardiac catheterization; that's one of our premier services, as well as improving radiology services." He said the hospital had just opened a newly designed emergency room -- a project that had received state and Federal backing.
Following the trend, Maimonides has also begun to open "a large number of outpatient facilities," he said. "we've opened a half dozen in the recent past, and there are several more scheduled." The new centers, he said, range from a Brooklyn Women's Center in Bay Ridge to a program for the Chinese-American community in Sunset Park, a few blocks from the main hospital.
The look and structure for these out-patient centers varies, largely depending on location.
In one of the new satellite centers Columbia-Presbyterian is planning, expanding a medical practice inside the Fort Washington Houses -- public housing for the elderly -- the hospital is boosting the number of examination rooms from four to eight, knocking down walls, changing the entry staircase to a ramp, and using gentle yet contrasting colors as directional markers -- all for a cost of $500,000.
At Columbia-Presbyterian's new 15,000-square-foot center in the parking garage on West 135th Street near Broadway -- a $4.5 million project that has not yet been officially announced -- Mr. Perales said, the design is to be different from that of the hospital's other, smaller neighborhood clinics.
He compared the preliminary design -- with a dramatic staircase to replace the parking ramp, skylights and Caribbean colors everywhere -- with another older center uptown. "This is boring," he said, walking around the older clinic, painted in beige and gray. "This is drab."
AT New York Hospital, no one could say the $780 million, 11-story limestone and brick Maurice R. and Corinne P. Greenberg Pavilion is drab. It is the last of the mega-projects left over from the 1980's, when money was flowing and deluxe pavilions and wings were going up all over town.
"We're the last of the dinosaurs," Mr. Reuter said jokingly, referring to the glamorous new wing, which added 850,000 square feet to the 1.8 million-square-foot 1932 main hospital, designed to resemble the Palace of the Popes in Avignon. The new pavilion, designed by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, with Taylor Clark Architects, takes its design cues from the earlier building but is totally contemporary. An 11-story structure built on a platform over the F.D.R. Drive, it has, according to the hospital, "as much floor space as the Chrysler Building."
Following the horizontal trend in hospital design, the 776-bed pavilion will cluster related health problems on one floor, regardless of their levels of severity -- an approach called "disease-cluster." Thus, heart patients will all go to the same floor, whether they are there for intensive care, surgery or recuperation. Seven hundred computers will be installed in the pavilion, with voice-recognition software that will let doctors and nurses dictate reports, creating, according to the hospital, "a virtually paperless and filmless environment."
New York Hospital has also reconfigured its ambulatory care, diagnostic services and offices within the main hospital -- and branched out. "We've gone from a 1,000-bed teaching hospital to 7,000 beds in 20 facilities, one in Westchester, two in Brooklyn, two in Queens," Mr. Reuter said.
Although boutique services like plastic surgery may make up some of the revenue lost by the decrease in inpatients and length of stays, the hospitals need these offshoots and satellites. "We're not going to pay off a $600 million debt with new noses," Mr. Reuter said wryly.
In addition to the enormous debts many of the large urban hospitals amassed in the 1980's, today's medical advances -- which hospital executives stress are also responsible for bringing down the length of hospital stays -- are wildly expensive. "To get a machine that can zap a tumor costs $8 million," Mr. Reuter said. "Some hospitals are going out of business, so we have to be big and strong."
He and other hospital executives listed a spate of major and minor hospitals that are reported to be discussing mergers. The architects keep track, too, and recite the reports; when two hospitals merge, there is usually money spent on a new master plan -- and the construction that grows out of it.
Even without a merger looming, hospitals are commissioning master plans. Mr. Blair of Perkins & Will said his firm was discussing master plans and/or major construction with two large New Jersey hospitals, along with other institutions in the region.
IN Greenwich, the hospital's board of trustees pushed aside one master plan, made in 1992, which called for an addition to house outpatient services as well as a significant renovation of existing space. By the next year, the board decided it needed another master plan and commissioned Perkins & Will, which wrote that: "In examining the future market potential for the hospital under a managed-care model, it was determined that the majority of the existing facilities were unable to accommodate changing technologies and operational strategies."
The new 325,000-square-foot hospital building -- in the traditional style requested by the hospital's board, according to its architect -- will include what the architects call an innovative "universal patient room" for patients at various levels of risk; clusters of private rooms, and a Day Recovery Center, with 20 rooms devoted to short stays. Harold Mindell, the hospital's executive in charge of the project, said that they were just getting ready to finish the steel infrastructure and that the hospital project would be finished in 2000. Mr. Mindell said the new hospital would be licensed for 160 beds, 100 fewer than the old hospital.
At Maimonides, a 705-bed hospital, Mr. Brezenoff worries about the rush to compete that is at least partly the reason for so much construction -- and, he says, so much money spent on advertising. "In the end, the results might not be in the public interest," he said, pausing often to consider his words. "What if something of high quality is in the wrong part of town or for other reasons, it doesn't succeed financially? That kind of free market is not always the result of a rational health-care planning process."
Mr. Brezenoff argued that the hospitals, instead of competing for market share, should instead cooperate. "We're spending money to advertise, Methodist is spending money to advertise, Staten Island is spending money to advertise. We're all scrambling, and there's a wealth of health-care dollars being spent."
Nevertheless, he said, the money spent on reconfiguration, new equipment, new buildings and new community centers -- designed not only to save money but to make the patient's experience a shorter and more pleasant one -- is different.
"The emphasis is on primary care, the breaking out of the hospitals and moving into the community, the emphasis on serving the patient," Mr. Brezenoff said. "Now that does make health-care sense."

HEADLINE: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;
Working Out The Bugs

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: TOMS RIVER

 BODY:
YOU'RE relaxed at last. You're finally home from work; the martini is in your hand, beautiful in its chilled magnificence, and you're looking out over the lawn, your lawn, your empire -- oh, yes, it is an empire, whether it is a postage-stamp plot or an acre expanse -- and you have this sense of well being, of richness. The look and smell of the grass (not to mention the taste of the juniper berries) stir in you a primeval feeling of being one with the earth.
In a neat, manicured way, of course. 
 But what's this?
A section is browning out.
All of a sudden, you have visions of microscopic creatures eating your grass, chinch bugs or bluegrass billbugs invading the turf you have nurtured with seed, fertilizer and water, an army of army worms hiding out in the thatch during the day and sneaking out at night to chomp, chomp, chomp away at blades and stems and the very core of your feelings of harmony.
So who ya gonna call?
Deborah Smith-Fiola, for one.
Experts like Dr. Smith-Fiola, an associate professor at Rutgers University and its cooperative extension agent assigned to Ocean County, are available to every New Jerseyan. And as the county agriculture agent, she and her horticultural specialists and the volunteers she has trained to answer the horticulture hot line receive lots of calls -- 3,500 last year to the volunteers known as master gardeners.
"They range from 'Why is my lawn dying?' to 'I've got spots on the leaves of my tree; what do I do?' " said Dr. Smith-Fiola, 37, who from childhood in her native Maryland wondered why plants grew and why they died, fascinated by the mystery of ecology.
"Or 'I found this insect in my kitchen; what is it?' Or 'Do I spray?' People often ask, 'What do I spray?' and often we try to talk them out of spraying. To 'What is eating my vegetable garden?' All kinds of crazy things."
Cooperative extension agents in each of New Jersey's 21 counties offer advice on agricultural productivity, food science, nutrition and health, marine and coastal resources, the environment and natural resources, and individual and community resource development.
Some, like Dr. Smith-Fiola, are agriculture agents. Each county has at least one. Others specialize in family and consumer sciences (formerly called home economics) and 4-H youth development.
Under the Smith-Lever Act passed by Congress in 1914, land-grant universities like Rutgers have been able to extend their educational programs into the community through financing by state, county and Federal governments.
"I Fear No Weevil," says one sign on the partition of Dr. Smith-Fiola's crammed and cluttered office in the two-story agricultural center building on Whitesville Road here. "Entomologists Get the Bugs Out," asserts another.
Dr. Smith-Fiola is the state's expert on integrated pest management, which involves using non-chemical alternatives, like microscopic worms called nematodes, to attack insects. She received a bachelor's degree in horticulture in 1981 and a master's in entomology and integrated pest management in 1985, both from the University of Maryland.
Shortly after joining the staff in 1989, she began the master gardener program to handle the calls more efficiently. Each year she trains about 40 volunteers, many of whom answer phone questions, educating the public about ticks and Lyme disease and doing diagnostics, which means analyzing problem plant samples and bugs.
There is not much farming in Ocean County (the No. 1 crop is hay, she says), so much of her time is spent consulting with "the ornamental horticulture industry" or, "the green industry," which, she adds, is the state's No. 1 agricultural industry in terms of gross receipts. This includes landscapers, "turf grass professionals" (the guys who cut the grass), arborists (tree guys) and groundskeepers (for golf courses).
In recent years, as landfill space for grass clippings has dwindled, Dr. Smith-Fiola has conducted meetings, classes and field inspections to encourage professionals to practice mulching, leaving clippings in the lawn.
She also shares the latest information on horticulture from Rutgers researchers like her husband, Joseph Fiola. "My husband is now the small-fruits specialist," she says. "He does grapes, raspberries, strawberries."
A majority of questions in April, May and September deal with lawns. "When should I fertilize my lawn?" (Fall.) "What is the proper time to water my lawn?" (Midnight to 8 A.M.) "If I mulch, will it increase my thatch?" (If done properly, absolutely not.)
"Do you have a lawn?" she is asked.
"Yes."
"So how does your lawn look?"
"Well," she said, "I've got melting-out disease on my lawn. It's a common disease right now. It starts off with a little spot on the leaf blade, and it works its way down. It's a fungus. It spreads with water. It works down to the crown, and it can girdle the plant and kill it. The lawn kind of turns a bleached color, an off-white color."
"What do you do about it?"
"I take pictures of it," she says, ever the scientist. "I can use it in classes later on."

HEADLINE: GOVERMENT AND POLITICS;
New Rules On Custody: Will They Aid Children?

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH SEYMOUR

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Two months after the State Supreme Court released sweeping revisions to New Jersey's child custody guidelines, experts are at odds over what the effects will be. Some say the changes could actually harm the children they were intended to protect.
At the center of the dispute is whether the amount of time noncustodial parents spend with their children should be linked to the financial support paid to the primary, or custodial, parent. 
 Under the court's "shared-parenting" philosophy, which takes effect on Sept. 1, noncustodial parents, who are overwhelmingly fathers, will be eligible for a reduction in their child support payments if they can prove that their children spend the equivalent of two nights a week with them throughout the year. They must also prove that they are feeding their children, paying for their transportation and providing them a room to sleep in.
Some lawyers said they applauded the adjustment for recognizing that child-rearing is increasingly shared by two parents. Others said it would taint the process by using money to encourage parents to spend time with their children.
"Visitation has to be decided without regard to money," said Nancy Goldhill, a senior attorney at Legal Services of New Jersey. "New Jersey's really making a big policy change to so directly interweave them and there can be negative consequences from that."
Child support guidelines were first drafted in 1986 so Family Court judges throughout the state would have a uniform method of deciding financial issues in custody disputes. The guidelines have been updated three times since then. The current revisions were drafted by the Supreme Court's family practice subcommittee in March 1996 and were announced this May.
"In terms of overall fairness, they're the best we've ever had," said Richard A. Russell, a former chairman of the family law section of the State Bar Association.
Too often, advocates of the change said, the court awards seven days of child support a week to be paid by noncustodial parents, who also incur expenses whenever the children are in their care.
"It is an attempt to mirror reality," said Mark H. Sobel, the current chairman of the bar association's family law section.
In many cases, the reduction would seem to be marginal. For example, a father of two children would pay $172 in child support a week if his weekly gross income is $630 and his ex-wife's is $500. If he were eligible for a shared parenting adjustment, his support payments would drop $28, or about $1,450 a year, court officials said. Any adjustment would be revoked if the custodial parent's net income, including child support payments, did not exceed 200 percent of the Federal poverty guidelines.
At least 20 states have adopted shared-parenting credits as part of their child support guidelines, court officials said, and a recent New Jersey custody case may have sparked particular interest here.
In 1995, the State Supreme Court rejected James Pascale's request to have his child-support payments lowered because his three children spent a significant amount of time with him. Mr. Pascale's lawyers argued that he did not want to pay less child support; he wanted to spend some of the money when the children were in his care.
Despite the ruling, the court's opinion did acknowledge that a custody arrangement could be so nontraditional that a judge might need to deviate from the guidelines.
John P. Paone Jr., who represented Mr. Pascale in the trial court, said that the case was the genesis for the court's new approach to the issue. But like many lawyers interviewed, Mr. Paone said he is concerned that in the attempt to be fair to both parents, money will now take precedence over children's interests in visitation arrangements.
"It's a problem, putting a price on visitation," he said. "Even though that's not the intent, that's what could happen."
Mary E. Coogan, a lawyer with the Association for Children of New Jersey, one of the state's leading advocacy groups, says a child's standard of living could be jeopardized under some shared parenting arrangements. The custodial parent could receive less money to care for the children, she said, while the noncustodial parent is granted a credit insufficient to provide a significantly higher standard of living for the child.
"At some point, the kid is losing in both households," Ms. Coogan said.
Judges and lawyers are undergoing training sessions to learn the new guidelines before they go into effect. Payments to some children will increase, mostly because the economic formula used to calculate awards has been updated. The court also is expanding the reach of its guidelines. In the past, basic child support awards were not drafted for families with combined annual incomes of more than $52,000. In those cases, child support payments were made at the judge's discretion. The new guidelines will apply to families with combined incomes of up to $150,000.
The 276,000 existing child support orders will not be subject to the new guidelines. But parents who already pay child support could seek to modify their agreements if other factors, such as income, have changed.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Tax Negotiators to Seek a Win-Win-Win Deal

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER promising for months to deliver substantial tax cuts to Americans for the first time in 16 years, the House, the Senate and the White House now have all completed detailed plans to reduce Federal taxes on families, investors and others.
Unfortunately for taxpayers trying to determine what breaks are coming their way, or to prepare for the coming changes in the tax code, the plans vary in many ways. And you cannot just take one from Column A, another from Column B and a third item from Column C. In the process of drafting a final version that President Clinton will be willing to sign, a number of difficult and unpredictable trade-offs will be necessary. 
 The proposals can be viewed only as a rough guide to what will be enacted. Even specific provisions that are common to all three versions may be changed.
Still, it is clear that the final legislation will include certain elements. All sides have agreed on a credit to families for each child. Capital gains tax rates will be reduced. Some students will get credits for some college costs. The use of individual retirement accounts will be expanded.
Negotiators from the House, the Senate and the Administration are scheduled to start meeting late this week to fashion out of their differing plans a compromise package that they hope will give all sides enough to enable everyone to claim victory.
In general terms, the Administration will be pressing Republicans to shift the tax cuts away from higher-income taxpayers. Republicans will keep up their argument that tax relief should go to those who pay the most in taxes, and that the legislation should not be used to redistribute income.
One of the big fights will be over capital gains. Mr. Clinton particularly wants to strip out the provision in the House bill that would allow investors to index their capital gains for inflation starting in 2001. Indexing would become extremely expensive to the Treasury in later years, and could be difficult for both taxpayers and the Internal Revenue Service to administer. The odds are that Mr. Clinton will prevail.
Mr. Clinton seems less likely to win his fight to limit the capital gains rate reduction for upper-income taxpayers. His proposal to exclude 30 percent of capital gains from taxation would reduce the effective top rate just fractionally -- to 27.7 percent from 28 percent -- for taxpayers in the top 39.6 percent income-tax bracket. Both the House and the Senate bills would bring the maximum capital gains rate down to 20 percent and create a 10 percent rate for people in the 15 percent income-tax bracket.
Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, strongly supports a broad expansion of the I.R.A. program. But Administration officials argue that savings incentives primarily benefit the affluent, since they have the most money to save. But while the White House wants to limit the expansion of tax breaks for savings, it has signed on to the concept of educational savings accounts for college-bound children.
Even where there is broad agreement, there are differences in detail that could prove difficult to bridge. The Administration would phase out its proposed $500-a-child credit for families with incomes above $60,000, while the Republican bill would start the phaseout at $110,000. Mr. Clinton wants a more generous credit for the first two years of college, while Republicans question whether the credit would do anything more than fuel tuition inflation.
Scores of narrow provisions could be of immense interest to particular groups. Most of those might be dropped, but several could sneak in when the final deals are struck, probably in the wee hours of an early morning in late July just before Congress adjourns for its August recess.

HEADLINE: Tax Spending, Not Savings

BYLINE: By Bruce Bartlett; Bruce Bartlett, a senior fellow with the National Center for Policy Analysis, was a Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary in the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
Frank Rich is on leave. His column will resume in November

DATELINE: GREAT FALLS, Va.

 BODY:
One can hardly pick up a personal finance publication these days without reading another story about how baby boomers are not saving enough for retirement. Yet our Federal tax code encourages consumption rather than saving.
Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has long advocated a national consumption tax, and has long been ignored. Now a growing number of economists and legislators are showing interest in the idea. Once the current tax legislation is out of the way, Mr. Archer says, his No. 1 goal will be to push such a plan. 
 To a large extent, the tax code's bias against saving is deliberate. When the existing code began to take shape in the 1940's, the memory of the Great Depression was still fresh. Keynesian theories, which view spending as the driving force in the economy and saving as a drag on growth, were triumphant. Federal officials rejected a national consumption tax for fear that it would stifle spending.
As a result, the United States has long had one of the most pro-consumption, anti-saving tax codes among the big industrialized countries. Our tax code looks kindly on debt, but we discourage people from putting money away by taxing returns on savings and investment. According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, only Canada has a higher average tax rate on capital -- savings and investment -- than the United States.
Not surprisingly, the United States and Canada also have the lowest rates of saving among industrialized countries. In 1996, Americans saved just 5 percent of their after-tax income; Canadians saved 4.6 percent. By contrast, Italians saved 13.4 percent of their income, the French 12.8 percent, the Japanese 11.9 percent, and the Germans and British 11.6 percent.
In the long run, countries that save more tend to have higher standards of living. More domestic saving is associated with higher rates of investment, which in turn is associated with higher rates of productivity.
Growing concern that Americans are not saving enough has led to new interest in consumption taxes. There are only two things people can do with income: save it or spend it. The idea behind a consumption tax is to tax what people spend, rather than what they save. This can be done directly, through some form of a tax on goods and services, or indirectly, by not taxing investment income.
Countries can directly tax consumption in two ways. One, widely used in Europe, is to impose what is known as a value-added tax on goods and services -- a tax levied on producers that is incorporated into the price they charge consumers. The other way, which Mr. Archer favors, is a national sales tax, much like the sales taxes most states have.
Indirect approaches to taxing consumption can also take different forms. Bipartisan legislation was introduced in the last Congress that took this approach. Under that plan, taxpayers would have received a deduction for all savings. And a flat tax proposal supported by the House majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, would eliminate taxes on savings and investment returns.
All of these approaches have their advantages and disadvantages, and once lawmakers get serious about the goal of taxing consumption rather than saving, they will have to consider such issues as the simplicity and fairness of a new tax system.
The time is right for a consumption tax. Rather than merely bemoan the difficulty Americans seem to have in saving for the future, why not make it easier for them to do so?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Gauging the Bulls in Latin America

BYLINE: By DAN COLARUSSO

 BODY:
IN the first half of 1997, Latin American stock funds produced some of the world's best returns. But whether that run will continue depends upon budget questions in Brazil, the aftermath of Mexico's elections today and investors' willingness to continue to see the stocks in the rallying region as attractively priced.
Stock markets in Brazil, Argentina, Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia, Chile and Peru have been powered so far this year by a wave of privatizations, other economic and fiscal changes and increased flows of foreign capital. Those forces helped the Morgan Stanley Institutional Latin American A fund to post a 44 percent return in the first half of 1997, while Morgan Stanley Latin American A jumped 43 percent and the T. Rowe Price Latin America fund gained 41 percent. 
 Indeed, excluding specialty funds, Latin American stock funds accounted for 8 of the 10 top-performing funds during that period, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund trackers. Even the worst performer among the 28 Latin American funds that Morningstar follows, Wright Equifund -- Mexico, was up 24 percent through June 30.
The play in the first half was clearly Brazil, where the markets benefited from the Government's decision to privatize several key companies, including Telebras, Electrobras and Petrobras, respectively the telephone, electric and oil and gas companies.
Such privatizations, which are also taking place in Peru and Venezuela, can free enterprises to become markedly more profitable. Five years ago, state-owned Telebras, a staple holding in many Latin American funds, charged just 70 cents for monthly telephone line rentals; in 1997 Telebras was charging $10.
In addition, some fund managers say the region's rally is on firmer ground than in past upswings. For one, Latin America's economic growth this time is fueled in large part by exports and foreign investment, which are steadier sources of growth than domestic consumption.
The managers say the good times are also a product of long-needed changes by dedicated governments that have finally mastered their fiscal policies, from privatization to currency management.
Patti Satterthwaite, manager of the Fidelity Latin America fund, visited Brasilia in April and "was amazed at how consistent the reform story was" among all levels of government. "There's a strong commitment," she said.
Moreover, the poor performance of Asia's emerging markets may mean that Latin America will compete mostly with Central and Eastern Europe for investor dollars earmarked for developing lands. That may keep capital inflows high.
But there is wariness as the region heads into the second half of 1997. "Latin America looks good -- fairly good -- but not as good as early in the year," said Arjun Divecha, the manager of the GMO Emerging Markets Equity fund.
Mark Haet, a Latin American portfolio manager for Bankers Trust, agreed. "We should get 10 percent to 15 percent" from the region for the balance of the year, he estimated.
Many managers of Latin American funds worry that Brazil may be bedeviled by its budget deficit -- the provinces are a big financial drain on the national government -- and worries that its currency is somewhat overvalued.
MOREOVER, while Ms. Satterthwaite said that the Brazilian market might continue its upswing, buoyed in part by a state auction of cellular licenses and continuing privatizations, the fact is that Bovespa, the Brazilian stock index, has already risen 75 percent since January. And while the index was trading at 12 or 13 times earnings early this year, it now carries a multiple of 16. That is not quite the 23 of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, but Brazil is, after all, an emerging market.
The run-up may lead some investors to see Brazil as no bargain, and it has made Mr. Divecha ambivalent. He is wary of overplaying Brazil, but acknowledges being "chastened by what's happened in the U.S. market in the past couple of years -- the momentum can just keep pushing it up."
In the search for greener pastures that is typical of long-rallying regions, Mr. Haet's firm began to lighten up on Brazilian stocks in late April and to add some more Mexican positions. Similarly, Mr. Divecha has grown neutral on Brazil and bullish on Mexico.
Mexico's market has yet to return to the levels it reached before the 1995 peso crisis; indeed, with the index carrying a multiple of 14, many fund managers say Mexican stocks are undervalued.
Mr. Divecha added that Mexico's gross domestic product was growing and inflation falling. Some consumer stocks have gained sharply in this strengthening economy, Mr. Haet said, with Grupo Femsa, a beverage bottler, up more than 70 percent since January, for example. Experts also expect construction companies, like Cemex and Tribasa, to benefit from a recovery.
But Mexicans are voting in nationwide elections today, and the long-reigning Institutional Revolutionary Party is expected to sustain big losses. Managers expect a period of "uncertainty as the PRI learns to share power," said Robert Meyer, who along with Andy Skov, manages the Morgan Stanley Latin America fund. And some managers, like Ms. Satterthwaite, appreciate the private sector's efforts in Mexico but are disappointed by the Government's slow pace toward economic change.
"As a nation, Mexico has been left behind by the rest of the region," she said. "The reform hasn't been as robust."
Behind these fears, of course, managers are doubtless thinking about all those big, risky shifts, because of politics or economics, for which emerging markets are famous.
"When economies restructure," Mr. Meyer said, "it's often two steps forward and one step back."

HEADLINE: Condemning Nike Plants Won't Prod Change

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Regarding Bob Herbert's June 27 column on my report on Nike's overseas labor practices: 
 I was reluctant to get involved with Nike in its Asian shoe conflicts because it would inevitably put me back into the "reasonable moderate" role I agonized over throughout my civil rights career. I plead guilty to idealism and optimism, but I have been through too many human rights battles to be called naive.
Condemning people in the South or South Africa, however guilty, never produced much change. Helping them create a new relationship with a "no fault" analysis set them free to be part of the process of change.
I found Nike's staff in Asia idealistic, sports-centered, socially isolated Westerners struggling with the demands of production. Their focus was quality control, without which there would be no jobs for anybody. They tried to avoid micro-management, and this was possible because there were no "systematic abuses."
Young women in their late teens and early 20's are supervised largely by women in their late 20's or early 30's. This isn't "management by terror," as critics say. It's management without adequate training or language skills. Nike has agreed to get involved and try to change the process.
Nike's critics deserve credit for raising these issues, but continued condemnation of the same few incidents among a work force of several hundred thousand will cause people to stop listening or close factories.
The salary issue is seen by many as the primary structural abuse. I do not feel qualified to determine a living wage in Vietnam or Indonesia, but workers spoke, on and off factory grounds, of saving money and sending it home. Western clothing, motor scooters and the roadside merchants at factories, even where food was provided, did not give the impression of "starvation wages."
I believe that the United States and the world need a globally integrated economy. I am determined to facilitate that because it generates jobs at home and opportunity abroad.
 
ANDREW YOUNG
Atlanta, July 1, 1997
