HEADLINE: Bootleg Videos: Piracy With a Camcorder

BYLINE: By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
"Men in Black" opened across the country last Wednesday -- about six weeks after bootleg videos of the film went on sale on the streets of New York.
"Batman and Robin" opened June 20; it was available the same day at a Harlem market for $5. And a week before Disney's animated film "Hercules" opened, a bootleg version was on sale. (Adding insult to injury, it was camcorded from the balcony of Walt Disney & Company's own New Amsterdam Theater in New York.) 
 Video piracy is thriving in America, and nowhere more so than in New York. The growing sophistication of technology and the cachet of seeing something first are combining to intensify a persistent problem, despite raids on copying labs and occasional personal intervention by film figures like the director Spike Lee.
In effect, bootlegged films are like a nagging cold for the movie industry, a pesky problem that could undermine studios' financial health and in some places, like New York, threatens to turn into pneumonia.
It is almost impossible to know how much such bootleg competition costs Hollywood studios -- though studio spokesmen quote guesstimates of lost revenues running to hundreds of millions of dollars annually. But whatever the financial losses, the studios fear they will escalate some day with the introduction of DVD, digital video disks, which will enable pirates to make perfect copies of films.
Many bootleg videos are surreptitiously copied with camcorders smuggled into advance screenings. But some come from inside the industry: work copies of films from editing houses, special effects houses and early test screenings.
"Work prints get stolen all the time," said Tom Sherak, the chairman of the 20th Century Fox Domestic Film Group, part of the News Corporation. "Now that we edit on Avid, you can pull it right off. We try to watch it as closely as we can, but you can't watch everything." Avid is a computer editing technology widely used in film and television.
Using a $500 videocamera and a tripod and occasionally making use of the theaters' audio jacks for the hearing impaired, a bootlegger "can go to the movies once a week and make $1,000 or more," said Bill Shannon, the head of the Motion Picture Association of America's New York anti-piracy office. "If he makes 30 copies, and sells them for $100 apiece, that's $3,000. And that's tax free."
The association, which investigates and prosecutes piracy cases for the studios, estimates that the bootlegging of films costs the industry more than $250 million in potential domestic revenues. But the organization's figures for the economic impact of bootlegging presume that a person buying bootleg films would have spent $4 to $8 to see the movie in a theater; a risky assumption in neighborhoods where there are no first-run theaters.
Still, no one quarrels with the association's assertion that New York is the capital of American bootlegging. "New York is the center for this problem, and particularly for illegal labs and distribution networks," said Edmund J. Pistey, the director of United States anti-piracy operations for the association. "That's why we're focusing with the highest amount of intensity there."
One problem is that blase New Yorkers tend to see bootlegging, like counterfeiting Rolex watches, as a victimless crime.
"I don't know what's wrong with the African-American consumer in some urban areas," Spike Lee said. "They want to buy an inferior product and get something for a bargain."
When Mr. Lee's film "Malcolm X" came out in 1992, he took some of his friends, "muscle," he calls them, to 125th Street with baseball bats to clean the bootleg copies off the street.
Few vendors of bootleg tapes set up shop in highly visible areas of Manhattan, instead selling them along Hudson, Canal and Duane streets in lower Manhattan and out of vans parked on the Upper West Side. They are also found in busy shopping areas around Fordham Road, at the Grand Concourse Plaza in the Bronx, and on Fulton Street in Brooklyn.
The sale of bootlegs used to be widespread on 125th Street in Harlem. Now it is endemic at the Malcolm Shabazz Harlem Market, at 116th and Lenox, where the videos mentioned in this article were purchased over the last four months.
In New York, as in other cities, the structure of bootlegging operations is simple: scores of individuals obtain prints of the film. This network feeds into a highly organized group of duplication labs, which make copies in bulk -- and most of the profits. Shrink-wrapped copies are then distributed through groups of street vendors -- often recent immigrants. Some legitimate video stores also sell bootleg tapes. Two weeks ago, police raided 10 video stores in Suffolk County.
"In the final analysis, it's out-and-out theft, and can't be tolerated," said Mr. Pistey of the association. "You're stealing the works of people. That's what intellectual property rights are all about."
The motion picture association has recently focused its attention on duplication labs in New York. Last week, the organization, working with the Queens District Attorney's Office, cooperated in a raid on a bootleg video lab in Queens that had 100 machines copying movies; more than 10,000 counterfeit videotapes were seized, the District Attorney's Office said.
In May, the group helped the Bronx District Attorney's Office put five labs in the Bronx out of business. Eleven people were arrested on felony charges at the operation, which was churning out bootleg copies of "The Fifth Element," "Anaconda," "Jerry Maguire," "Beverly Hills Ninja," "Selena" and "Liar Liar." A year ago, the largest operation of its kind, a group of labs in Manhattan and Brooklyn that was turning out 100,000 high-quality bootleg videotapes a week on 800 machines, was shut down.
The movie studios, said Daniel J. Castleman, chief of the investigation division of the Manhattan District Attorney's Office, "would like the police department to do nothing but pick up people for bootleg films."
"But there are murders and rapes," he said. "We're aware of the economic impact of bootlegging. We have a terrific relationship with the M.P.A.A. But they want us to solve their problem."
Alassane Diop is the manager of the Harlem Market, which is on an empty lot owned by the Malcolm Shabazz mosque, named for the slain leader of the Nation of Islam. He said the vendors who rent space there sell "African masks, art, costume jewelry, dolls, eyeglasses, hats, beads, designer jeans, handmade sweaters, cassette tapes."
"They have some videotapes," he added.
But on visits in March, April and May, the main business of the Harlem Market seemed to be videotapes. Booths, which vendors, many of them recent immigrants from West Africa, rent for $42 a week, are stocked with the latest films, from "Hercules," and "Men in Black," to "Face/Off," "The Lost World" and "Batman and Robin." Several of the booths even had video players so that customers could check the quality of the tapes before buying.
The site has become so popular that it is now a tourist attraction. Buses from New York Apple Tours pull up to the Harlem Market and discharge passengers to shop. "We stop at Canal Street, Delancey Street -- and I'm sure bootleg items are sold at those locations," said Hayim Grant, the president of New York Apple Tours. "It's not our concern what the vendors sell."
Even the businessmen who seem most threatened by the piracy occasionally buy bootleg copies. Ed Arentz, who manages Cinemavillage, an art house theater in Manhattan, found Jim Jarmusch's "Dead Man" at Harlem Market. "The price was right," he said, "and I hadn't seen the film."
Allen McCollum, the manager of the Blockbuster video store that opened last year on 125th Street, said: "It doesn't affect us much. A lot of people don't like bootlegs. People say it's a waste of money, too foggy."
Even a policeman, approached at the 116th Street subway station across from the market, shown a bag full of bootleg tapes and asked if they were legal, said, with a shrug, "If you bought them, they must be legal."
Mr. Arentz said lax enforcement of domestic bootlegging would hurt the industry abroad, where piracy has been an even bigger problem. "To give up the ghost here would mean that the Chinese and the Egyptians would say, 'Why pick on us? You can't even enforce your own laws,' " he said.
"We go after vendors, the labs; we're trying to hit at every level," Mr. Shannon of the motion picture group's New York office said. But arresting vendors and charging them with the misdemeanor offense of selling pirated tapes will not halt the practice, the organization argues.
Peter English of the same office said of arrested vendors, "Basically, they'll be let out the next day." And, he added, buying or owning a bootleg film is not a crime in New York. "It has to be for commercial advantage or private financial gain," he said.
A year ago, the group announced the largest raid in its history, at Amarson Video, on West 26th Street in Manhattan, and at three labs in Brooklyn. The operators of the business were arrested and charged with criminal possession of a forged instrument and other felonies involving the sale and manufacture of unauthorized recordings.
But a year later, Barbara Thompson, a public information officer for the Manhattan District Attorney's Office, said the accused counterfeiters, out on bail, had fled the country.
Threat though it may be to the industry, bootlegging is still a joke to many. This past season, an episode of NBC's hit comedy "Seinfeld" featured a subplot in which the show's characters dabbled in bootlegging. "Seinfeld made light of it," Mr. English said. "But to the M.P.A.A., it's something that's putting people out of business."
 
BOOTLEG VIDEO REVIEW
The Good, the Bad and the Soundless
The quality of 30 tapes bought this spring in New York ranged from execrable to excellent, from those with neither audio nor color to those that had a clear picture and almost cinema-quality sound. Half of the tapes were obviously shot with camcorders in theaters, and often had a hollow sound and audible audience reactions. Three of the pirated casettes were copied from advance tapes, of the kind sent to video-store owners. The rest were excellent copies that appeared to be based on 35-millimeter films.
 None of the camcorded tapes showed a shaky hand, though some revealed an intermittent focus problem. Camcorded tapes never showed the extreme left or right side of the movie screen and always contained the top or bottom edge of the screen, sometimes, in the latter case, including other viewers' heads. Most had crowd noises. All of the tapes were bought for $5 and all except one were of movies still playing in theaters. Here are one viewer's reactions:
 
"Jerry Maguire" (Columbia-Tristar)
Released in December, bought in April, a month before release of the video version.
A very good copy of the video version. The words "Property of CTHV. Duplication, sale or rental of this video is strictly prohibited" are displayed every 20 minutes. The tape ends abruptly 15 minutes before the end of the film.
 
"Liar Liar" (Universal)
Released on March 20, bought on March 21.
Clearly camcorded, from a seat in front on the left. The angle makes Jim Carrey seem like a pinhead in long shots. Audible laughter and comments give the viewer the feeling of watching "Mystery Science Theater 2000" with a laugh track.
 
"Men in Black" (Columbia-Tristar)
Bought on May 24, opened in theaters on July 2.
An M, for master print, appears in the upper-right corner throughout the film. The sound quality varies. Some special effects are missing: A talking dog doesn't move his mouth; a movie star being eaten by a giant bug briefly appears in white wire-frame. Lacks any audio track for the last 20 minutes.
 
"The Lost World" (Universal)
Released on May 23, bought on May 24. (Tape is labeled Jurassic Park.)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Computer Makers vs. the Television Industry
The recent challenge Microsoft, Intel and Compaq issued to the television industry seems to be fading. The computer makers said they would set the standards for the new digital era. But even others in the personal computer business have failed to lend support, and the three-company front appears to be crumbling. [Page D2.]
 
Growth on Long Island
In the 1990's, Long Island is undergoing a nontraditional economic recovery. As military contracting has all but disappeared, the area has engineered a revival heavily reliant on smaller companies, computer technology, retailing and business services. [A1.] 

Here Comes Cellularvision
Shant Hovnanian has been a tireless advocate for a wireless technology he says can be used to beam phone conersations, Internet access and television pictures to small dishes mounted on windowsills. A dispute with other companies has limited Cellularvision's access. But recent breakthroughs may spread the technology throughout New York City. [D3.]
 
Farm Workers Win Right to Unionize
Employees at the DeCoster Egg Farm, the Maine farm that is the nation's largest producer of brown eggs, recently won Gov. Angus King's approval of legislation allowing them to unionize and requiring the farm to pay overtime. The measures are only the latest setback for DeCoster, which has also been under fire from state and Federal officials for unsanitary and unsafe working and living conditions. [A12.]
 
News Bureau Blues
Knight-Ridder is taking the control of its foreign bureaus away from its four big papers and placing the reporters under the direction of a single foreign desk in Washington. The shift has irritated some editors. [D7.]
 
Internet Address Inquiry
The Justice Department is investigating the current practice of assigning Internet addresses, to determine if the control exercised by Network Solutions Inc. amounts to a violation of antitrust laws. [D5.]
 
Of Britain and Libel
Britain's libel laws are considered some of the toughest in the world. They come from a deep-seated tradition that often seems archaic to outsiders. Defendants are required to prove the truth of their statements, an extremely hard standard to meet. Recently, Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian, presided over his paper's defense of a lawsuit brought by the former Minister for Defense Procurement. The paper prevailed, just barely. Publishing. [D5.]
 
Newsletters and the Web
Many newsletter publishers are embracing the Internet. The Newsletter Publishers Association estimates that 40 percent of all newsletter companies have Web sites. The different approaches newsletters take may suggest what works in new media. [D7.]
 
And the Answers Are. . .
Once again, it's time to ask 20 questions on advertising, marketing and the media. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]
 
Credit Card Searches
Several Web sites allow consumers to find the credit card they want most. While these sites don't charge fees for the services offered, some require users to divulge personal information, especially when filling out on-line applications. Taking In the Sites. [D4.]
 
Airline Strike Near
Talks between British Airways and union leaders aimed at stopping a flight attendants strike broke down, clearing the way for a planned three-day strike. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Can Russia Be a NATO Insider and Outsider?;
Defense Opportunists

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "U.S. Arms Makers Lobby for NATO Expansion" (news article, June 30): Defense manufacturers and their allies in the Pentagon are scurrying to cash in on NATO expansion by dangling expensive weapons systems in front of Central European nations. Meanwhile, the Departments of State and Treasury are expressing concern about the economic consequences of increases in the military budgets of Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. 
 Why this disparity between responsible fiscal concern by State and Treasury and an opportunistic hawking of wares by the Defense Department and its industry pals? Such a disconnect arises every time there is an important arms trade policy decision to be made.
NATO is not an American jobs program. Defense industry lobbying -- by company executives or Pentagon officials -- has no place in the debate.
 
JORDANA D. FRIEDMAN
London, July 2, 1997
 
The writer is director of the international security program at the Council on Economic Priorities.

HEADLINE: Fort Lee Mayor Girds for a Showdown Over Bridge Traffic

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: FORT LEE, N.J., July 3

 BODY:
For years, this little town of high rises and heavy traffic has been a most unhappy host to the George Washington Bridge.
City Hall has long grumbled that the bridge brings bumper-to-bumper traffic most mornings and ill-tempered drivers zipping around side streets, particularly on holiday weekends like this one. The traffic forces the community to hire additional police officers, and guarantees potholes, motor vehicle violations and high taxes, all without a cent of reimbursement from the bridge's owner, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. 
 After quietly enduring the indignities, Fort Lee has decided to fight back. That means, roughly, that the gnat -- a 2.5-square-mile town of 32,000 people -- is publicly bullying the elephant -- a sprawling bistate agency with $2.1 billion in gross revenues.
"The bridge is a nuisance," Mayor Jack Alter said. "They're collecting the gross receipts and someone else is paying the expenses, and that's our suffering taxpayers. We'd like to get reimbursed for our costs for the bridge's presence. We're tired of their inertia and stonewalling."
The Mayor said the City Council had set aside $10,000 for summer billboards encouraging travelers to cross the Hudson River on the Tappan Zee Bridge in Tarrytown, N.Y., about 20 miles up the Hudson River. And he said, Fort Lee might file a lawsuit over congestion and air pollution generated by the 97 million vehicles that used the bridge, and streets and highways in Fort Lee, last year.
The Mayor also noted that the local police have standing orders to set up roadblocks at Fort Lee's borders when traffic back-ups on the bridge create absolute gridlock on local streets and hinder Fort Lee's firetrucks, ambulances and other emergency vehicles.
This tactic is a holdover from Fort Lee's last public plea for reimbursement, in 1994. Since then, the roadblocks have gone up twice, each time for only a few minutes. But that was just long enough to leave thousands of motorists fuming on the clogged streets of the neighboring towns of Leonia, Edgewater and Englewood Cliffs.
After Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, Mayor Alter is the Port Authority's noisiest public critic. But for all the saber-rattling, he said he was ready to negotiate with Port Authority officials. "I called them the other day and asked if a discussion would be useful," he said. "I'm waiting for an answer."
The Port Authority suggested that it would be willing to discuss a specific proposal, but none has been mentioned by Fort Lee officials. "There's nothing on the table they've proposed to us," Allen Morrison, an agency spokesman, said. "They have not come up with an appropriate project for us to contribute to."
Mr. Morrison said the Port Authority is developing a $25 million electronic system to manage bridge traffic, with road sensors that detect tie-ups and big message signs that suggest alternate routes. And, he pointed out, Fort Lee rejected a Port Authority offer in 1993 to build the town a $7 million police station near the bridge and finance it with 30-year bonds.
Mayor Alter, a Democrat, negotiated that deal. But he said local Republicans, now out of power, scuttled it. "It fell apart in a political pile of mush," he said.
He noted that the George Washington Bridge was the Port Authority's most lucrative facility last year, with $134 million in income, more than Newark, Kennedy and La Guardia airports, which the agency runs.
A 1990 study commissioned by the town found that the bridge's presence forced Fort Lee to spend about $5 million a year for extra police to deal with traffic, crashes, and arrests and summonses for motor vehicle violations, the Mayor said.
Fort Lee's chief financial officer, Joseph Iannaconi, estimated that the town could cut its 92-member police force and its $10.5 million police budget by one-third to one-half if the bridge were somewhere else. Bridge-related road maintenance, like repairing potholes on the town's streets caused by the high volume of traffic, costs $100,000 more a year, he said.
But the Port Authority said there was no spare money from the bridge's 1996 net income of $134 million. That money helped cover deficits in other parts of its bistate transportation network, including the $192.8 million the PATH train system lost last year and the $60.2 million deficit of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan, according to the agency's annual report. Mayor Alter also spoke of a $10 million property tax bill Fort Lee sends the Port Authority each year for the bridge. "They ignore it," he said.
Disingenuous, the Port Authority countered. As a bistate agency, its mission, agency officials noted, is to serve the public good by improving regional transportation and the regional economy. And like all government agencies, its property and operations are tax exempt. "Governments don't pay taxes to other governments," Mr. Morrison said.
Mayor Alter also contends that the agency gives money in lieu of taxes to other communities that house its operations. Bayonne, for instance, gets $104,000 a year for an auto import-export terminal the agency owns, and Jersey City receives $645,000 a year for a shipping terminal the agency owns in old rail yards. But in Fort Lee, "We get nothing -- zero," Mayor Alter said.
Mr. Morrison said Fort Lee was not eligible for such payments because the bridge's toll booths, its entrance and exit plazas, and the bridge itself were part of highways that were tax exempt.
Most important, he said, the bridge has made Fort Lee, which has one of the area's strongest local economies, a boom town.
Town officials conceded that. But, they added, there is a down side. All the new high-rise apartments in the last quarter century have brought in more children and forced the town to raise school taxes.

HEADLINE: Save Tax Cut for When Cupboard Is Bare

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Representative Tom Campbell's excellent article on the folly of ignoring the deficit to pay for a tax cut (Op-Ed, July 1) missed a crucial argument against cutting taxes now: timing. 
 At the top of the business cycle, with low unemployment and economists worried about inflation, now is not the time for a supply-side view that would pour $85 billion into the money supply over five years. Now is the time to finish off our budget deficit and save money for tax cuts when we need them, in future recessions.
Some argue that structural changes in the global economy have brought the end of the business cycle, but their evidence is far from conclusive. Until it is, our Government would be foolish to spread money around in a time of economic growth, bringing the inflation that could lead to an economic slowdown.
Mr. Campbell says a balanced budget in two years would be possible if not for the tax cuts, and would have been "an immense psychological and political achievement." It also would have been a case of politicians investing in the future beyond the next election cycle, a phenomenon almost unheard of in the permanent campaign atmosphere of today's Washington.
 
AVI GREEN
Bala Cynwyd, Pa., July 1, 1997

HEADLINE: Integrated Wireless Service May Be Coming Soon to a Windowsill Near You

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Shant S. Hovnanian is nothing if not patient. For more than a decade, Mr. Hovnanian has been the lonely advocate for a wireless technology that he says can be used to beam television pictures, phone conversations and Internet access to small dishes mounted on windowsills.
Mr. Hovnanian's company, Cellularvision, has persuaded 14,000 customers in Brooklyn and Queens to install its squat, boxy receivers, which enable them to receive 49 channels of television. But the company has been unable to spread its wings farther because of a dispute with other companies that laid claim to its slice of the airwaves. 
 Now, after five years of relentless lobbying in Washington, Mr. Hovnanian has at last prevailed. And he is determined to create the nation's first integrated wireless provider of voice, video and data services. If you live in the five boroughs of New York City, Cellularvision is coming to a microwave tower near you.
"One goal is to turn wireless into a broadband pipe capable of delivering all kinds of services," said Mr. Hovnanian, a burly, genial 38-year-old, whose family built houses in New Jersey and got into telecommunications by stringing cable systems to those homes.
His technology goes by a forbidding name: local multipoint distribution, or LMDS. Basically, it works like cellular telephone service, in which a signal is transmitted from a central tower to a small antenna. But unlike cellular, it is beamed to many receivers. It is also remarkably pliant: the signal can bounce off buildings and still be received with clarity, which makes it well suited to the canyons of Manhattan.
Cellularvision began its first big assault on Manhattan last month, when it introduced unlimited high-speed Internet access at a price of $49.95 a month, plus a one-time installation fee of $199.
Mr. Hovnanian recently recruited Bruce Judson, former general manager of Time Inc.'s new media division, to market Cellularvision's service to people who are used to navigating the Internet via phone lines.
The wireless technology would allow subscribers to download material from the Internet at speeds of 500 kilobits a second -- roughly four times as fast as the service offered by phone companies like Nynex. The company's installation fee covers the cost of the receiver dish, a modem and a set-top converter box.
Time Warner, the dominant cable provider in New York City, has introduced a high-speed Internet service, called Roadrunner, in Elmira, N.Y. and several other cities. But a spokesman said the company would not bring Roadrunner to New York before next year.
"We believe there is a huge demand for Internet access," Mr. Judson said. "By early next year, we'll introduce an even faster service."
Cellularvision will focus its Internet marketing on Manhattan, where it sees an affluent population starved for high-speed access. In Brooklyn and Queens, the company is pushing its package of television channels, including Home Box Office and the Cable News Network, as a low-cost alternative to cable television.
Such segmentation is easy to do because, unlike phone or cable companies, Cellularvision does not need to upgrade its entire physical plant -- wires or switches -- to offer two-way data services.
Mr. Hovnanian eventually hopes to provide telephone service on his network as well. Last month, the company signed an agreement with Nynex, under which Cellularvision will lease lines from Nynex and resell the service under its brand name. When it signs up enough customers, Cellularvision plans to shift them over to its wireless network.
"This market is ours to lose because we feel we have an inherent economic advantage in our delivery system," said Patrick J. Greaney, a former senior vice president of Philips Electronics North America, who joined Cellularvision last week as its chief operating officer.
Mr. Greaney is a true believer. At Philips, he oversaw a $5 million investment in Cellularvision. The company has also attracted small investments from Bell Atlantic and J. P. Morgan. In February 1996, Cellularvision made an initial public offering of its stock, raising $39.8 million.
Still, it has not yet won over Wall Street. The stock has slumped with the rest of the wireless industry because of fears of ruinous competition. On Thursday, it closed at $8.25, up 12.5 cents on Nasdaq -- well below its high of $16.75 in July 1996.
And Cellularvision needs to raise capital because it is investing $25 million to build its network of transmitters.
While specialists said that local multipoint technology does work, it is prone to the weaknesses that afflict other types of wireless service. For one, the signal can fade in heavy rain if the network is not properly designed. And while it does not have the crippling line-of-sight limitations of technologies like wireless cable, it may not work too well in hilly areas.
Some of Mr. Hovnanian's competitors say that his wireless technology will ultimately hobble Cellularvision.
"What do they have?" said David C. McCourt, chief executive of the RCN Corporation. "They have an inferior video product, no phone product and no way of migrating their traffic to a fiber network." RCN, a unit of the cable operator C-Tec, is building a fiber optic network to provide alternative cable and local phone service in Manhattan.
But other experts said it was not fair to lump Cellularvision with other, garden-variety wireless companies. The company's technology was invented by Bernard B. Bossard, who helped develop the guidance system for the Patriot missile. Mr. Bossard is still chief technical officer and a major shareholder.
Moreover, Cellularvision has an indisputable advantage over other wireless competitors. Because it pioneered local multipoint technology under a special Federal program, it did not have to pay for its license, which covers 8.3 million people in New York City, Westchester, Rockland and Putnam counties.
Mr. Hovnanian thinks he will be vindicated this fall, when the Federal Communications Commission auctions licenses nationwide. Phone and cable companies are expected to bid millions of dollars for licenses in markets far smaller than New York.
Given all these virtues, he cannot understand why investors are not lining up outside his door. He noted somewhat ruefully that Microsoft recently invested $1 billion in Comcast, a cable company run by Brian L. Roberts, a fraternity brother of his at the University of Pennsylvania in the late 1970's.
"I'm glad that Bill Gates found my fraternity brother," Mr. Hovnanian said, "but I think there's someone else in my fraternity he ought to be talking to."

HEADLINE: Knight-Ridder Revises Its Foreign Reporting

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
Like other big news organizations, the Knight-Ridder newspaper chain spends millions of dollars to maintain reporters and news bureaus overseas. Yet much of this expensive coverage never makes its way into most of its papers.
Knight-Ridder's solution: It is taking the control of its foreign bureaus away from its four big newspapers and placing their reporters under the direction of a single foreign desk in Washington. 
 The move has upset senior editors at the papers that will lose bureaus they had operated as their own, but management said the move was needed both to coordinate overseas coverage and to try to resolve a problem facing many big newspapers: how to make overseas reporting meaningful to American readers.
Still, some editors believe this shift in control of the bureaus will mean that Knight-Ridder foreign correspondents will spend more time covering breaking news with short, quick articles and less time developing more in-depth articles about trends overseas. Reporters are also likely to feel that they have less say about how their articles are edited than when they reported to a particular newspaper.
Clark Hoyt, a vice president for news at Knight-Ridder's Miami headquarters, said that the move was not aimed at cutting the $2 million a year the company spends to support eight overseas bureaus and that there were no plans to close any of them. Foreign bureaus operated independently by Knight-Ridder papers would also not be affected, Mr. Hoyt said, although the bureaus would be expected to coordinate coverage more closely with the chain.
"When the bureaus were set up around 1980, there was a lot of discussion about whether they should be centralized or distributed among the newspapers," Mr. Hoyt said. "The final decision was that they would be operated by what were then our four largest papers, but that they would operate as a trust for all the papers and be responsive to the needs of all Knight-Ridder papers."
Knight-Ridder then opened eight overseas bureaus and awarded two each to The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Detroit Free Press, The Miami Herald and The San Jose Mercury News in California. But the bureaus -- in Moscow, Rio de Janeiro, Jerusalem, Beijing, Tokyo, Mexico City, Warsaw and Harare, Zimbabwe -- soon became largely associated with their parent newspapers. In addition to its Knight-Ridder bureaus, The Inquirer also has its own reporters in London, Rome, South Africa and the Middle East.
"When I was in Detroit we ran the coverage and we promoted people to our bureaus, and we were satisfied with that, but I would say the other Knight-Ridder papers were not satisfied," said David Lawrence, who had been the editor of The Free Press, and who is now publisher of The Miami Herald.
As Mr. Hoyt pointed out in a June 13 memo outlining the change, while The Miami Herald used all 65 articles filed by its Jerusalem correspondent, John Donnelly, in the first four months of this year, no other Knight-Ridder paper used more than 4, and most used none.
"I think it ought to work to our benefit," said Glenn Guzzo, managing editor of The Akron Beacon Journal, which has no foreign bureaus, but is one of the founding papers of the Knight-Ridder chain. "We are not prepared to run the foreign stories that are generated by Knight-Ridder correspondents at the length they are now being written, and we have difficulty finding out, in fact, what is being written and when it is coming."
Case in point: Last week, when Hong Kong reverted to Chinese rule, The Beacon Journal covered the event with articles only from the news services of The Washington Post and The New York Times. The only Knight-Ridder coverage of one of the biggest stories of the year in The Beacon Journal was a Sunday piece, filed well enough ahead to let Mr. Guzzo know it was available. "If you don't tell us what's coming, how can we use it?" he asked.
Maxwell E. P. King, editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, said, "I have my differences about the direction that this is going, but I do not argue with the assessment that this is a problem." Mr. King said he tried to persuade Mr. Hoyt to allow the host newspapers to retain control of the bureaus and to focus on improving coordination. But as Mr. Hoyt pointed out in an interview, that had been the original intent, and it had not worked. The Inquirer operates Knight-Ridder bureaus in Beijing and Moscow, as well as having reporters in four other areas overseas.
In his memo, Mr. Hoyt also spoke of changing the nature of foreign coverage, a move that is likely to raise concerns among Knight-Ridder's foreign reporters. A questionnaire being prepared for the senior management at all Knight-Ridder papers will include questions about whether bureaus should focus on news or on longer, in-depth pieces; should concentrate on certain subjects, like world trade and economics, or be general, and on how foreign pieces should be made more "local" for American readers.
"Our coverage has been very enterprise-driven as opposed to breaking-news driven," Mr. King said. "I think from the note that they will want to do more news-driven and shorter pieces, and it's a particular source of my worry, that the jobs will still be satisfying and sustaining for career journalists if that happens."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
After The Handover

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
For many Americans, the handover of Hong Kong is just the latest installment in the long-running China-U.S. morality play -- "The Butchers of Beijing vs. the People." But Hong Kongers look at events here with much more mixed emotion. For them, it's not Communism versus democracy, but nationalism versus the rule of law. That is, there is real ethnic pride here in the return of Chinese sovereignty, after 156 years of British colonialism. But there is also real fear that what Hong Kongers appreciated most about Britain's colonialism -- the rule of law -- will vanish along with it. As one Hong Kong businessman remarked to me on handover day: "I feel torn -- like I just watched my mother-in-law drive out of town in my new Mercedes. I'm glad she's gone, but what about my car?"
Well, what about that car? Since the reversion, there have been some intriguing straws in the wind here. The first is how relaxed this place is. The democracy activists wasted no time defying a police ban on unlicensed demonstrations and the police responded that they were not going to waste taxpayer money prosecuting them. End of story. My favorite democracy demonstrators were those selling miniature plaster replicas of the "Goddess of Democracy" the students of Tiananmen Square had erected. They went for $100 a copy, and they were "Made in China." Where else? 
 The Chinese Army troops that the U.S. networks focused on so relentlessly planted China's sovereignty here and then disappeared into their barracks. China's Communist Party is still banned in Hong Kong, and Beijing is hesitating to make it legal, because if it becomes a legal party in Hong Kong it will have to run in Hong Kong's next legislative elections, and if it runs it will get creamed by the democratic parties. Tung Chee-hwa, China's hand-picked chief here, last week promised that elections for a new legislature would be held by mid-1998. The hottest-selling T-shirt at Hong Kong's Shanghai Tang department store is emblazoned: "Most Flavoured Nation."
What might this be telling us? The relationship between China and Britain over Hong Kong was like a bad marriage: everything one did the other disparaged. Any democratization by Britain, China treated as a stick in the eye. Any assertion of sovereignty by China, Britain treated as potentially the next Tiananmen. But now that China has Hong Kong back, China, and Mr. Tung, can afford to be more relaxed, because leniency no longer constitutes kowtowing to Britain. Rather, it's something they do in the interest of stability in Hong Kong, which is now also their interest.
The second straw in the wind is the speech China's President, Jiang Zemin, gave on handover day. Christine Loh, one of the leading pro-democracy activists in the recently disbanded Hong Kong legislature, insisted on reading aloud to me passages from that speech when I visited her last week: "Hong Kong residents will enjoy their rights and freedoms in accordance with law and will all be equal before the law. . . . A gradually improved democratic system suited to Hong Kong's reality is an important guarantee for its social and political stability. Hong Kong will develop democracy gradually with the ultimate aim of electing the chief executive and the Legislative Council by universal suffrage. Hong Kong's success is attributable to . . . its well-developed legal system and highly efficient civil service."
What's new is that the Chinese President wasn't speaking about some British colony. He was speaking about the importance of rights, legality and democracy for what is now part of China. How long before elites in Shanghai or Tianjin come to Mr. Jiang and say that they can't compete economically with Hong Kong unless they have what he has vowed to preserve in Hong Kong -- civil society, rule of law and a market economy free of corruption?
The point is that -- post-handover -- there are still real politics in Hong Kong. And it will add to the real politics already going on inside China. How much and for how long remains to be seen. But if you only look at China through the simplistic lens of "Butchers of Beijing," you'll miss those politics and their possibilities. The people who understand that best are the democrats here. Until China proves otherwise, argued Ms. Loh, "The best thing America can do is not to look at Hong Kong as a problem, but as an opportunity -- something that might actually add value to the U.S.-China relationship."

SECTION: Section D; Page 3; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1049 words

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;
Gates's largesse stirs a discomfiting question: Is there indeed a computer literacy?

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
WHO could possibly object to $400 million of free computer equipment and software? Last month, when William H. Gates and his wife, Melinda French Gates, announced that gift to financially troubled North American libraries, it was hailed as a major act of philanthropic wisdom, a worthy successor to the donations by Andrew Carnegie that built 1,679 libraries in 1,412 cities and towns, helping to establish the nation's public library system.
Just think of all those hard drives, loaded with Microsoft software, ready to download files from the Internet, available in even the poorest communities. (The donation, by the Gates Library Foundation, is described at the organization's site, http://www.glf.org/pr.html). Isn't this the sort of idea President Clinton had in mind when he posed a "technology literacy challenge" in 1996? 
 "We know, purely and simply," the President then declared, "that every single child must have access to a computer, must understand it, must have access to good software and good teachers and to the Internet, so that every person will have the opportunity to make the most of his or her own life"
It is also a goal the National Education Association has supported. A 1996 report (summarized at http:// www.nea.org/cet/BRIEFS/brief9.html) argued that one educational necessity "transcends institutions, resources and goals." That transcendent need is for "the use and implementation of technology" in the classroom and library. A poll of teachers last year ranked computer skills and media technology as more important than the study of biology, chemistry, physics, classical literature or European history.
The drums have been beating at the local level, as well. There are schools in which the study of music or art has been sacrificed for cyberspace exploration. Few parents seem to think that a school is doing its job unless computers are widely available. At a New York City school recently, a computer company's representative held a computer literacy night for parents, describing the Internet as a library containing everything that has been thought or known in the world, a kind of universal repository of knowledge.
What child should be denied access to something like that? And if it costs at least $10 billion a year for at least five years to guarantee such access, the lowest of the national estimates, shouldn't it still be a top priority?
But it has become increasingly clear that there is something a bit peculiar about these ambitions. Reacting to the President's original declaration, Edward Miller, editor of the Harvard Education Letter, said, "Of all the things one could wish for American education, I would place this very far down the list." Even as ardent an advocate of computer skills as Sherry Turkle, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology social scientist, has asked, "Are we using computer technology not because it teaches best but because we have lost the political will to fund education adequately?" (http://epn.org/prospect/31/31turkf.html).
In a series of articles, The San Jose Mercury News said that despite surveys that have reported vast improvement in student performance from the use of technology, their own analysis "showed no strong link between the presence of technology -- or the use of technology in teaching -- and superior achievement." Only in low-income areas did technology make a noticeable difference, partly perhaps because its presence may have been accompanied by an attentiveness to students that was lacking before. (The debate about computer literacy is summarized at http:// www.sjmercury.com/news/local/ schools/main115.htm). This month, the Atlantic Monthly has also published a cover story, "The Computer Delusion" by Todd Oppenheimer, associate editor of Newsweek Interactive. It recapitulates much of the controversy (and can be found at http://www.theatlantic.com/issues/97jul/computer.htm), but is unabashed in its conclusion, "Cutting other school subjects to make room for computers may be educational malpractice."
That is beginning to seem like an understatement. What, after all, does computer literacy consist of? Unlike ordinary literacy, it is not even required to obtain other forms of knowledge. One can be mathematically literate, literarily literate, musically literate and historically literate without knowing a single command in a computer language.
Of course, real computer literacy requires training in logic, in clear thinking, in the values of planning, in economy and efficiency, in the abilities to manage information and correct errors. But right now, the term computer-literate usually just refers to the ability to use a few commercial products and perhaps being able to smoothly touch-type.
Are there any curricula that require eighth-graders to know the programming language C++ and analyze the structure of a processing chip -- a computer literacy that might actually involve something substantial? Joseph Weizenbaum, professor emeritus of computer science at M.I.T., has pointed out that computer languages are unlike natural languages; there is no advantage to acquiring them when young. And, one might add, they are far less useful when older.
As for universal access to the Internet, it would be quite helpful for some student research -- but it, too, is hardly the kind of prerequisite for success that the President outlined. The Internet will not come close to replacing even the most ordinary library until every book of importance is published in digital form, financial arrangements are worked out with publishers, and search engines become as powerful as the index in back of a reference book. Right now, even the most limited local library has much the Internet cannot touch.
Only a Luddite could dismiss the potential value of computers. But imagine if instead of donating millions of dollars to purchase soon-to-be-obsolete equipment -- with its built-in hunger for profitable upgrades to the donated software -- technological philanthropy involved real training in mathematics and science for students or teachers. And imagine that computer education was seen as supplementary, rather than as a cure-all for widespread problems. It seems almost an impossibly utopian dream -- one worthy of a major philanthropist.

SECTION: Section C; Page 14; Column 3; Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
How Endless Information Restricts Your View

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

DATA SMOG
Surviving the Information Glut
By David Shenk
250 pages. Harper Edge/HarperCollins. $24.
 Sometime around the middle of this century, David Shenk tells us in his new book, something happened to alter human history: "We began to produce information much faster than we could process it." 
 With the introduction of computers, microwave transmissions, television and satellites, we were pushed from "a state of information scarcity to one of information surplus, from drought to flood in the geological blink of an eye." Today we are drowning in data, pelted by newspaper and magazine stories, 24-hour television news, E-mail, junk mail and faxes. Cellular phones, car phones and beepers insure that we are always on call, while ubiquitous television sets -- in bars, sports arenas, airports and airplanes -- insure that we never lack visual distraction. Advertisements have proliferated along highways, in schoolrooms and on the World Wide Web, and they adorn everything from our hats to our luggage to our shoes.
In "Data Smog," Mr. Shenk, a journalist and radio commentator, tells us that the average American spends 60 percent of the office day processing documents. In the 1980's, per capita paper consumption tripled (to 1,800 pounds a year), and third-class mail grew 13 times faster than the population.
Such statistics aren't new, but Mr. Shenk has done a good job of pulling together a lot of observations about the downside of information technology and presenting them in a coherent and highly readable fashion. Though one may not agree with all of Mr. Shenk's theories, his book nonetheless forces one to re-evaluate the effects that data smog has on daily life and its long-term social and political consequences.
As Mr. Shenk sees it, data smog is bad for your health, promoting stress, memory overload, compulsive behavior and attention-deficit disorder. It's also bad, he suggests, for the health of the community, producing what could be called the Dennis Rodman or Madonna effect. By overstimulating us to the point of distraction, he argues, data smog forces people to resort to hyperbole and histrionics to get attention. "The degree to which today's television programmers, movie producers, performers, spokespersons and publishers apparently feel compelled to turn up the heat is a serious threat to moderation and intelligence in society," he writes. "It reduces our attention span. It makes us numb to anything that doesn't lurch out and grab us by the throat."
Although much has been written about mass communications' turning the world into a global village, Mr. Shenk astutely points out that that village is, at the same time, growing increasingly fragmented and factionalized as people, despairing of being able to master a grand overview, retreat into their own special interests. These days there are more and more niche magazines and more and more niche advertising targeted at specific audiences and neighborhoods. As a result, community begins to give way to tribes, shared values to irreconcilable differences.
The Internet accelerates this trend. "Like niche radio and cable TV," Mr. Shenk writes, "the Net encourages a cultural splintering that can render physical communities much less relevant and free people from having to climb outside their own biases, assumptions, inherited ways of thought. This is perhaps best evidenced by the ominous emergence of so-called smart agents, which automatically filter out information deemed irrelevant to the customer."
With smart agents, there is no stumbling across unexpected subject matter, and there are fewer exchanges with people with different interests and opinions. As a result, both the idea and practice of pluralism suffer.
Throughout this book, Mr. Shenk admonishes readers to refrain from "info-pollution" by being economical in what they "say, write, publish, broadcast and post on line." This is advice that Mr. Shenk tries to follow himself, with largely admirable results. Toward the end of the book, however, when he turns from sociological assessment to more subjective political analysis, his penchant for concision can lead to oversimplification.
He argues, for instance, that cyberspace promotes "a highly decentralized, deregulated society with little common discourse and minimal public infrastructure," and then goes on to make the gross generalization that "the digerati are helping conservative Republicans create the world they have been after for a long time." In another chapter, he asserts that "the emergence of niche culture has also turned the tables on political alienation," suggesting that "poor minority groups" have ceased to be "invisible to the world and to each other" because they now have the ability to put out "their own 'zines, listservs, Web sites and cable TV shows."
Such reductive assertions unfortunately distract the reader from the other, more substantial arguments in this book, which despite its lapses stands as a useful overview of the unintended consequences of information technology.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls vs. Yen on Surge In the Japanese Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday to a nearly four-week low against the yen after Japan reported a surge in its June trade surplus, reviving concern that the dollar's strength is hurting American exporters.
But the dollar recovered from an early selloff against the mark and ended higher against the pound, helped by British data showing unexpected manufacturing weakness. 
 The data at least temporarily dampened market expectations that the Bank of England would raise interest rates at its policy-making meeting Thursday. Expectations of higher rates have been been driving sterling higher in recent weeks.
Traders said the foreign-exchange volume was thin because of summer vacations, exaggerating currency movements. But the rise in Japan's surplus surprised the market.
The data showed Japan's surplus rose to 453.20 billion yen in the first 20 days of June, far more than expected and more than double the 197.65-billion-yen surplus a year earlier.
The dollar traded as low as 112.16 yen in intraday dealings before settling in New York at 112.77 yen, down from 113.89 Thursday and the lowest closing level since June 11. United States financial markets were closed Friday.
The dollar also fell to an intraday low of 1.7421 marks before recovering to settle at 1.7521 marks in New York, down from 1.7535 marks on Thursday. The pound cost $1.6886, down from $1.6906.
The early weakness of the dollar against the mark partly reflected its decline compared with the yen, as well as mark strength on fears of a delay in Europe's single currency plan past its January 1999 starting date. Most participants in the plan for the single currency, known as the euro, are having trouble meeting its strict fiscal criteria.
The fears were based on a Financial Times interview with Edmund Stoiber, Governor of Bavaria and a political ally of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who called for a delay in the introduction of the euro rather than proceeding with a weak currency.
But the impact of the Stoiber remarks diminished as the day progressed, partly because the predominant view in the market is that the single currency plan will proceed as scheduled.

INDUSTRY: NAICS521110 MONETARY AUTHORITIES - CENTRAL BANK (57%); SIC6011 FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS (57%);

HEADLINE: Observer;
After The Magic Dies

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER; A. M. Rosenthal is on vacation.

 BODY:
In the old days husbands and wives murdered each other. Now they hire hit men to do it for them. This is surely the final disgrace of a society corrupted by its own riches.
Before the big money rolled in few couples could afford to hire somebody to clean house, much less a hit man. 
 We are talking of an age before anybody ever heard of mutual funds. Back then, husbands killed their own wives and wives killed their own husbands. They did it extensively, too.
Two years of news reporting on the police beat filled me with wonder at the connubial murder rate. The first warm corpse I ever saw was the late husband of a young wife with a gun.
The best trial I ever covered dealt with a husband who had planned to subject his wife to the perfect murder. He succeeded in killing her, but not in getting away with it, and was subsequently hanged.
Most marital murders were routine. Prime time for them was Saturday night. Usually one or both parties to the marriage had taken too much whisky, gin, beer or Sneaky Pete.
Argument ensued. The family gun appeared. The job was almost always done with bullets. I recall no case in which she used the carving knife or he his old trophy Japanese bayonet brought back from the Pacific.
I suppose there was an occasional murder produced by rat-poison overdose, but I never covered one. If you occupied the murkier levels of society and dropped dead suddenly, the medical examiner did not invariably favor you with an autopsy, so a poisoning spouse might just possibly get away with it.
Three recent hit-man events in the Baltimore-Washington area illustrate the new style. A Maryland woman, a minor political figure, has just been charged with trying to hire a hit man to dispose of her husband.
Outside Baltimore the cops have booked one Mark Cordero, alleging that he offered $10,000 for his wife's murder. Cordero is said to have made the offer to an undercover policeman after the usual anonymous tipster disclosed that he was up to no good.
Another undercover cop figures in the case of a man in Capitol Heights, Md., charged with trying to hire a hit man to dispose of his wife. Again, Anonymous Tipster talked to the cops, who had one of their own pose as a hit man for hire. The police say the price offered in this case was $1,500.
Several questions arise. How often does a spouse in search of a hit man make a deal with the real article instead of an undercover cop? If hit men are available, how do they set the price for their work?
And finally, are there really that many hit men out there willing to work for disgruntled husbands and wives? Murderers have traditionally preferred to work only for powerful institutions -- kings and queens, crime families, national intelligence agencies -- which could guarantee them protection from the law.
Are there really any willing to work for psychologically unstable malcontents who cannot be relied upon to tell a professional killer from an undercover cop? That consumers should think so may mark them as foolish. Nevertheless, that ordinary Americans now feel sufficiently well off to afford professional murders enhances the glory of our market economy.
I think we ought to be outraged about having the hit man turned into a romantic American figure. Romanticizing murder suggests that we are far gone in decadence.
Murder has never been a career to boast about. In "Macbeth" and "Richard III," Shakespeare painted his professional murderers as loathsome. Four knights murdered Thomas a Becket in Canterbury Cathedral to please King Henry II, and infamy has been their reward for the past 800 years.
Now, though, we have movies like "Grosse Pointe Blank," in which charming John Cusack is a professional killer; "Goodfellas," in which funny Joe Pesci is a professional killer, and "Prizzi's Honor" -- admittedly a satire on romantic Mafia movies -- in which hit-man Jack Nicholson marries hit-woman Kathleen Turner.
When hit men are such rich and famous stars, how can we fail to think them glamorous? How romantic their work must be. Surely the woods must be full of these fascinating rogues. Surely they are itching to represent you for $10,000, or maybe only $1,500.

HEADLINE: Dorothy Chandler, 96, Dies; Arts Patron in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

 BODY:
Dorothy Buffum Chandler, whose vision and fund-raising fervor helped transform modern Los Angeles and who as the wife and mother of successive publishers helped turn The Los Angeles Times into one of the nation's great newspapers, died on Sunday at a rest home in Hollywood. She was 96.
Mrs. Chandler's greatest single achievement was probably her nine-year drive in the late 1950's and early 60's to finance and build the Music Center of Los Angeles County, which revitalized the city's downtown district and fused old-line society with the newer wealth of Hollywood. 
 The opening of the center in 1964 earned her a spot on the cover of Time magazine and an accompanying article that declared her effort to get it built as "the most impressive display of virtuoso money-raising and civic citizenship in the history of U.S. womanhood."
The next year, the center's largest auditorium, which has become a frequent home to the Academy Awards ceremonies, was named the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion.
Gov. Pete Wilson of California called Mrs. Chandler "the heart and soul of Southern California's cultural life." Mayor Richard Riordan of Los Angeles told The Los Angeles Times that "her imprint will be part of Los Angeles for many centuries to come," particularly its cultural life.
Dorothy Buffum was born in Lafayette, Ill., and moved with her family to Long Beach, Calif., when she was a toddler. Her father and uncle opened a dry-goods store in Long Beach that eventually grew into the chain of Buffum's department stores, a fixture of Southern California until the 1980's.
She met Norman Chandler, the son of Harry Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, at a dance at Stanford University, and they married in 1922.
During the years that Norman Chandler trained to be publisher and worked his way through the newspaper's executive echelons, Mrs. Chandler raised their daughter, Camilla, and son, Otis, and did volunteer work for the Children's Hospital of Los Angeles and other institutions.
When Harry Chandler died in 1944, Norman Chandler took over as publisher, and four years later his wife was named his administrative assistant. Her presence was quickly felt within the newspaper, particularly in the coverage of women and the arts. She was instrumental in inaugurating the paper's Women of the Year awards, which were given to more than 200 women between 1950 and 1976.
"She was just really a ball of fire with whatever she set her mind to, whatever she wanted to get done," said James Bellows, a former editor of The New York Herald-Tribune and The Washington Star who was associate editor of The Los Angeles Times in the late 1960's and early 70's. "She really worked at the role of women in the city, and was very involved in setting up the Women of the Year. She was very concerned that it reflect the diversity of the city and that it be given to women for their achievements and not just for social activities."
Mr. Bellows said he found Mrs. Chandler to be "tough, but not intractable," someone who knew her mind, was willing to debate and listen to argument and who eventually "usually got her way."
Mrs. Chandler's role as a civic fund-raiser began in earnest in 1950, when she undertook a successful drive to save the Hollywood Bowl. A few years later she began her effort to build the Music Center, eventually raising $19 million and forming a committee to float an additional $13.7 million in bonds that were guaranteed by the county.
"She was a critical figure in the modernization of Los Angeles," said David Halberstam, whose book, "The Powers That Be," chronicled the newspaper's rise under Mrs. Chandler's husband and son. "If you're charting the coming of a big, sleepy, conservative community into the modern, affluent, increasingly sophisticated metropolis that exists today, she may be the single most important player."
At the time, Mr. Halberstam said, Los Angeles was split between an older establishment centered in the downtown area and a newer establishment in Hollywood and farther to the west.
"Culturally, she helped connect West Los Angeles with downtown Los Angeles, two communities that 40 years ago had almost nothing in common and barely spoke the same language," he said. "It was her drive, energy, ambition and even hubris that connected them."
Otis Chandler succeeded his father as the paper's publisher in 1960 and held that post for 20 years, though Norman Chandler remained an executive with the company until his death in 1974. Mrs. Chandler strongly supported her son's efforts to improve the quality of the newspaper and to raise it to the ranks of the nation's finest. Otis Chandler is now a board member of the Times Mirror Corporation, which owns the newspaper.
In later years, Mrs. Chandler served on numerous boards and Presidential commissions, devoting special attention to the University of California. She was among three women chosen by President Lyndon B. Johnson to visit South Vietnam in 1967 to assess the status of the American war effort. In 1985, President Ronald Reagan included her in the first group of winners of the National Medal of Arts.
She is survived by her son; her daughter, Camilla Chandler Frost, eight grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren.
Anecdotes about Mrs. Chandler's fund-raising prowess are numerous.
One friend recalled how she tore up a $20,000 check from a wealthy businessman and handed it back to him, telling him that it was unacceptably paltry. At a private dinner where she was a guest, just weeks before the Music Center was to open, Mrs. Chandler is said to have stood up after coffee was served and gone from person to person collecting money in a large, blue bag.
"I think of myself as a catalyst," she said in an interview shortly after the Music Center opened. "There are so many people with good ideas and good intentions. They doubtless know more about the arts than I do. But I pull them together. That's my job."

HEADLINE: Rivals Say Giuliani Belittled Stapler Factory's Closing and Job Losses

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The planned closing of a Queens stapler factory led to a mini-debate yesterday over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's economic policies, after his Democratic opponents questioned a series of remarks he made that appeared to belittle the loss of the plant's 450 manufacturing jobs.
On Sunday, asked at a news conference about the recent announcement that the Swingline Stapler factory in Long Island City would close over the next two years, and the loss of its jobs to Nogales, Mexico, Mr. Giuliani said, "the city comes out of that quite well." The loss might have meant something when the city's economy was declining, he said, but nowadays the city can do without employers who do not want to pay their workers a decent wage. 
 For months, the Mayor's Democratic rivals have signaled that they will focus on the city's sluggish job growth, and yesterday two of them seized on the remarks to demonstrate what they said was Mr. Giuliani's insensitivity to the harsh realities of life at the lower end of the city's economic spectrum, where every manufacturing job counts.
Ruth W. Messinger, leading in the polls for the Democratic nomination, noted that the city's unemployment rate had risen over the last year, and said Mr. Giuliani was "fiddling" while Swingline burned.
"This city needs an economic development policy that pays attention to small businesses," she said. "The one thing I will never do as mayor is: when human beings lose their jobs, I will never say the city comes out well, or that it doesn't mean anything. When 450 additional people lose their jobs, that is not O.K. It means something."
At a news conference yesterday, the Mayor went even further than he had the day before. He said it was a loss of perspective to concentrate on Swingline when on the same day, the new Mercantile Exchange opened in the World Financial Center. That, he said, preserved 8,100 jobs that might have gone to New Jersey had he not offered the exchange $184 million in tax incentives to stay. (The Mayor rang the bell for the opening day of the exchange yesterday.)
Asked whether those jobs affected people in a far different economic class than those in the stapler factory, he called the question "ignorant." The exchange "employs people at all levels, including entry levels," Mr. Giuliani said.
"They have a kitchen, they have food they serve all day, they have custodial services," he said. "So a large employer can produce a large number of entry-level jobs." He added: "And then just think of the 8,100 people who work there; think of how much money they spend in the restaurants surrounding that area, new restaurants going up."
Demonstrating an increasing willingness to attack Ms. Messinger by name, Mr. Giuliani said her political philosophy had "devastated this city economically." Specifically, he said, she had voted to increase the city's hotel occupancy tax when she was on the City Council years ago, while he cut the tax shortly after taking office.
The Mayor cites the tax cut several times a week to bolster his contention that such cuts can stimulate economic growth, although tourism officials have said the city's reduced crime rate and increasing number of attractions may be more responsible for the rise in visitors to the city.
Sal F. Albanese, a Brooklyn City Council member who is also running for mayor, said Mr. Giuliani's remarks about the Mercantile Exchange showed that he was willing to "bend over backwards" for the city's booming financial industry but did not seem interested when lower-paying manufacturing jobs left town.
"He should have shown more empathy for those workers," Mr. Albanese said.
Officials in the Giuliani administration said they had tried unsuccessfully to retain the Swingline jobs. Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine said the city had told the company it would do "whatever it takes" to keep the stapler factory in New York, but he said the company showed no interest in any of the city's incentives.
Wendi Kopsick, a spokeswoman for Acco USA, Swingline's parent company, said it would save $12 million a year by moving the factory to Mexico over the next two years, adding that none of the city's incentives would change Acco's "cost position."
Although the city's economy is improving because of gains in financial services, its unemployment rate rose to 9.4 percent in May from 8.5 percent in May 1996, an increase of 33,556 unemployed people, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The Mayor said the increase was because more people are now looking for work, having been moved off welfare by his policies.

HEADLINE: Phone Wars Heat Up Over Sponsorship of Ad

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
As the war over telephone deregulation grows ever more rancorous, newspaper advertisements have become a favored battleground where local and long-distance phone companies trade accusations.
But an ad published yesterday in The New York Times and other area publications seemed to be different. The half-page ad, which contended Nynex had the highest local rates in the country, was sponsored by a consumer group, New York Consumers for Economic Competition. 
 The trouble is, the group -- and the ad -- were financed entirely by the AT&T Corporation, which is lobbying against Nynex in a rate proceeding before the New York State Public Service Commission.
AT&T's name does not appear anywhere in the ad -- an omission that has prompted protests from consumer groups and has drawn the scrutiny of New York State's Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco.
"Dennis Vacco is obviously concerned if there is any misleading of consumers," said Jennifer Farina, a spokeswoman for Mr. Vacco. "So we are looking into it."
The ad, which also appeared in The Albany Times-Union and Crain's New York Business, urged the Public Service Commission to reject a proposal by Nynex to impose a variety of surcharges on local phone calls carried by new competitors in the New York market. Nynex, the ad said, was trying "to preserve its monopoly over local phone service."
The ad's readers are encouraged to fill out an attached coupon and mail it to the group's headquarters in Albany. They can also dial a toll-free number for more information. The group has scheduled radio and television commercials to run later this week in the Albany area.
A spokesman for AT&T, John Heath, acknowledged that the company had financed New York Consumers for Economic Competition. But he said AT&T did not believe the ad was misleading because the coalition included several other companies and organizations.
"We support the group, but there are several other non-telecom companies that also support it," Mr. Heath said.
Among the other members of New York Consumers for Economic Competition are the MCI Communications Corporation and the Small Business Survival Committee, a lobbying group that represents entrepreneurs and small companies. An MCI official said the company did not pay for membership.
Ray Keating, a spokesman for New York Consumers for Economic Competition, said AT&T had provided the seed money for the campaign, but that he hoped to raise money from other donors. A spokeswoman for The New York Times, Nancy Nielsen, said a half-page ad in the newspaper costs about $36,000.
Susan Kraus, a spokeswoman for Nynex, said yesterday that the ad's central accusation -- that it has the highest rates in the country -- was unfair. And she said the surcharges would be a reasonable compensation for the cost of opening up Nynex's local network to new rivals like AT&T and MCI.
Some consumer lobbyists complained that the ad undermined their credibility. "If the powers that be see that this is a front group for the long-distance industry, it doesn't make our job any easier," said Robert Ceisler, executive director of the Citizens Utility Board, a consumer group that he said was supported by donations from individual members.

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1148 words

HEADLINE: What's in a Name? At Wyoming Butte, a Culture and a History

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DEVILS TOWER, Wyo.

 BODY:
For millions of years, the gray volcanic plug has towered majestically over the surrounding plains, rising a quarter-mile into the sky.
But now the two races of humans that regularly congregate around the tower's base are warring over its name: Devils Tower or Bear Lodge. 
 "To name it Devils Tower is a slap in the face because of what the whites used to call Indians back then: they were devils, dirty devils," said Diana Mitchell, an Eastern Shoshone Indian.
The English name Devils Tower first worked its way into official status through the 1875 writings of an Army colonel. But many Plains Indians argue that a traditional name, Bear Lodge, should be restored to the tower, which is in northeast Wyoming about 275 miles north of Cheyenne. They cite ancient stories that say a massive bear raked its claws down the sides of a magically rising tree stump that later petrified into the tower. In addition, some maps from the early 1800's identify the tower as Bear Lodge.
Noting that Indians increasingly go to the tower to pray, to leave prayer bundles and to participate in sweat lodges and vision quests, Mrs. Mitchell asked, "Who wants to pray at something called Devils Tower?"
White residents of the area strongly resist any name change, retorting that what was good enough for Theodore Roosevelt is good enough for them.
In 1907, Roosevelt, who was then President, created Devils Tower National Monument, which seemed to settle a name disparity that had existed since the first French trappers explored the region a century earlier.
"My dad came here in 1913 in a covered wagon," said Winifred Bush, Mayor of Hulett, the town nearest the tower. "I've been here ever since I was a little girl, and I never saw any Indians around here until two years ago. If the tower's sacred to them, it's sacred to us, too."
Mrs. Bush has won statewide applause from Wyoming's overwhelmingly white population for taking verbal whacks at the idea of changing the name of the nation's oldest national monument.
"That name change idea is like a rattlesnake," she said. "You can't just let it sit there."
The three members of Wyoming's Congressional delegation, all Republicans, have introduced bills in both chambers this year to block any move to erase "Devils Tower" from American maps.
Devils Tower is not the only place in the West where Indians and whites are jousting for cultural supremacy.
Earlier this year, for example, in Lake Tahoe, Nev., the United States Forest Service ordered rock climbers to stay off Cave Rock, a volcanic core revered by Washoe Indians as charged with spiritual energy. And last November, in New Mexico, the Forest Service barred a ski area outside Santa Fe from expanding its lifts and trails to a mountain held sacred by Tesuque Pueblo Indians.
But here in Wyoming's remote northeastern corner, the conflict, which involves more than just the name of the tower, is perhaps the sharpest.
In April, lawyers argued in Federal court over a ban imposed by the National Park Service last year on commercial rock climbing on Devils Tower for June, a month when Sioux and other Plains Indians congregate here for summer solstice dances. The Federal judge hearing the case has yet to rule.
To spiritual Indians, said Deborah O. Liggett, the park superintendent, the sight and sound of climbers hammering pitons into Devils Tower is akin to people rappelling down the walls of the Vatican while Roman Catholics try to pray.
To whites, the issue is part commercial, part sentimental.
Wyoming is heavily dependent on its tourism industry, which brings in $1 billion and three million people a year, six times the state's population.
For the souvenir shops, motels, campgrounds and gas stations that give economic life to the villages surrounding the monument, Devils Tower is a nationally recognized name that must be guarded as zealously as a trademark. Located between Mount Rushmore and Yellowstone National Park, Devils Tower now receives almost half a million visitors a year.
Tourism started to surge here in 1977, the year that Richard Dreyfuss met the aliens at Devils Tower in the movie "Close Encounters of the Third Kind."
White residents fear that the recent resurgence of American Indian religious activity devalues their own pioneer history and traditions. Older residents warmly recall the Fourth of July picnics that the settler families had at the tower's base. On July 4, 1893, two local ranchers made the first known ascent of the tower, planting the American flag on top of the summit.
"Who did the major part of the roads, setting up the trails?" said Rodney Hackett, a member of the Hulett town council, recalling the work done by local men enrolled in the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930's.
Andy Petefish, a rock climbing guide who is suing over the climbing ban, added: "It really irritates me that the Indians are calling our ancestors liars and manipulators. The Indians are using the excuse that they didn't have a written language. Well, the Euro-Americans were the great record keepers, the great cartographers."
The locals say the Park Service is bending over backward to accommodate Indian visitors.
"If you are Native American and show an I.D., you don't pay at the door," said Gisele M. Robinson, whose husband, Peter, was superintendent at Devils Tower in the 1970's. "They get away with things the rest of us never would."
To some locals, Ms. Liggett, the superintendent, is pushing diversity policies to curry favor with the bureaucracy in Washington.
The view is different to Ms. Liggett, who regularly meets with a core group of the 23 American and Canadian tribes who ascribe cultural and religious significance to the tower.
"Every time I consult with the tribes, it is the No. 1 issue," the superintendent said, referring to the tower's name.
One solution, she said, would be to rename the butte Bear Lodge and retain the park name, Devils Tower National Monument.
To Elaine Quiver, a Lakota Sioux who works with a society of traditional elders, the name dispute is simply a matter of mistranslation.
"Mato Tipila, the Bear Lodge, has been in our oral history as long as I can remember -- and we would like to restore that name," Mrs. Quiver said from her home in Pine Ridge, S.D. "For us, in our culture, there was no word for devil, no description of the devil. That name is offensive, demeaning."
To reach an intertribal consensus on a suitable name, Mrs. Quiver has met with four tribes over the last year, and both sides plan meetings for the summer. Bear Lodge is the leading name candidate.
Last fall, The Gillette News-Record, a local newspaper, conducted a reader contest: "Name that Rock!" Though most respondents said the name should not be changed, Lyndon Hunt won the prize, a free night in a Black Hills motel, with a culturally neutral offering: "The Tower."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
